Beautifully Intricate. A little further out of town, this stunning temple, also know as The Lady Temple, is a great example of the skillful work-man that the Angkor Empire boasted. Incredibly intricate designs adorn this smaller, but no less impressive temple.I would recommend heading up to the Kulen Hills to check out the river carvings, to make the extra miles worth the trip out there. Though make sure you go in the right season, as in the dry season, there is minimal river and no waterfalls.

Worth the drive. Not the largest temple, but certainly unique with it's pink hue and intricate carvings. It is also interesting to see how all the doorways line up on the walkway leading to the temple. The ceilings are all gone and everything is exposed to the elements, but the carvings are well-preserved. The pond at the entrance was completely dried up in early May and I hope that they receive rain soon--I know that the country needs rain desperately.

It was worth the drive. . It's not as crowded as the other Temples and its smaller them the all the other Temples. It was probably my favorite one. Mainly because it looked the oldest and the uniqueness of the pink colors throughout. If it's a hot day, I would strongly suggest hiring a car to drive you there. Taking a tuk tuk up the there didn't look fun. From Siem Reap, it was an hour drive (in a car). This Temple is part of the Temple Pass you buy to get in to most, but not all of the Temples.

Small but beautifully detailed temple. This is by no means a big temple, if you want big go to Angkor Wat. This temple has the most beautiful stone carved images and is unique to the other temples because of this. The carvings are excellent and one which I would highly recommend. We arrived at around 10am and it was very busy, I would recommend arriving sooner to miss the crowds. It is around a 45 min drive from the centre of Siem reap but the drive is a lovely one through beautiful Cambodian landscape. Would I visit again? yes without a doubt! Don't miss this temple!

Far off but worth the trip. It is easy to get temple fatigue in Siem Reap. The 1.5 hour trip to this temple gives you the opportunity to take in the refreshing countryside scenery. Banteay Seri is certainly one of the more unique temples, the carvings are intricate and vivid, depicting tales from Hindu folklore. The sandstone catches light beautifully and you can get a lot of nice photos here. The visitors pavilion is a great bonus. It really allows you to understand and appreciate the site better.
Pink stone . All the temple in Siem reap on banteay Srey temple that have stone pick color. And one this temple made by queen , other temple are by King .

Different style of temple. Usually this place will be planned after the small circle tour and big circle tour. It is quite far away from the City Center and I don't recommend to take Tuk Tuk. (I did and I regretted) It take 1.5 hours to go there.The place is lovely and the style is quite different from what you can see in Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. However, it is not a big template and a lot of Chinese tours will visit there. It is difficult to take good pictures as people are everywhere. Be prepared about this.

Talking to monks made the trip for us. monks from the nearly monastery stopped and talked to us here and even wanted photos taken with us which was a talking point with us after that as we were so surprised with their friendliness as we had been told that woman should not touch a monk so we did not know what to expect.

Mesmerizing temple. This temple is a little far out, but completely worth the journey and time. It's intricate carvings sets it apart from the rest of the temples.Can be clubbed along with Kbal Spean which on the same route .
It nice caving. it was far way from siem reap city but it was very nice temple had a lot caving had lady photo and pink stone ,it amazing
A Gem. Isolated, away from the crowds, beautiful pink-stone temple with extraordinary carvings that surpass any of the other major temples.

Best temple to visit first. Went there at around 12 noon after we arrived, its one of the further away temples but for sure one of the best due to its details in the carvings and the color of the stones. Combined it with another temple nearby

A small temple with different stone carvings.. To go here, I recommend to combine the trip to also visit the waterfall which is located nearby. But bring water because it is a nice but long jungle path to the falls with stone carvings.
small but interesting temple. Banteay srei was far from siem reap city ,It amazing temple with very nice caving and different style and Send stone ,i high recommend to temple ,

A small gem. Banteay Srei is only a small temple compared to the others near by but don't let this from stopping you. The carving work in this temple has to be seen to believe that's what makes it different to the others. If you love the others you will like this one even more plus the different colors in the rock work really make your photos pop.

I would like to go back. So many tourist when we went there, and it rained! I wasn't able to appreciate most of the carvings since there are ropes enclosing the temples, and its hard to see the carvings details.It is best to visit first the exhibit hall where the history and architecture of the temple is explained. So one will know where the carvings are exactly and what to expect. It also shows in the pictures the different architecture of the other temples, not just Banteay Srei. And of course, appreciate the temples more.I would love to go back and see the temple again and hopefully get to see the carvings closer.

Beautiful sandstone temple . This temple is a little far from Siem Reap but worth the visit. The carvings and architecture here is intricate and better preserved as it is harder stone. This temple is the oldest as per the guides. Unfortunately the roof has collapsed.

Enchanting.. but a bit of a drive to get there... Getting to the Lady Temple will take you about 40 minutes on a tuk-tuk... its a drive but worth the time and very easy to see why its worthy of its Unesco World heritage site monument.. (right before the entrance of the Banteay Srei Temple. With thanks to a small musician's band at the far end of the temple the air is filled with birdsong and melodies from a more gentle time - there are several eateries and shops around.. be prepared to haggle, prices are super inflated ( 70USD for a small silk table cloth..and normally when you walk away the price drops to 10USD.. amazing..) Back to the Temple.. have a camera handy.. and patience.. tourists are everywhere..making unique pictures hard to come by.. the site is blessed with an abundance of picturesque moments.. and and some rice paddies and such in the area if you have the time to explore.

More beautiful than Angkor Wat?. We were blown away by this small temple. The intricacy of the carvings, the story behind and the mind-manageable size made it our favorite. A bit of a trip from Siam Reap but if you can it's well worth the effort.

Unusual temple well worth the trip to get there. Banteay Srei (also known as the Temple of Women) is about a half hour drive from the main group of temples. It is well worth the trip.The temple is very different from the others in that it is constructed of pink sandstone. The colors are beautiful and very unusual. My guide told me that if you are there at sunset, the temple walls "shine". I had hoped to visit the temple during the time of day when the sun would be at the right angle but unfortunately our schedule put us there in the middle of the day. Still, the temple was beautiful and it was one of my favorites. If you have the time, don't miss seeing this very different temple.

God is in the details. I have heard so many wonderful things about this temple before visiting and when I finally saw it, it didn't disappoint. The carvings are to die for!!! Just make sure to go here early as the throngs of tourists build up also early.

Elegant temple that is very different in style to the rest of the Angkor temples. This is undoubtedly my favourite temple. It has a very different style to most of the others in the area, in that it is almost Balinese in feel and very elegant. We discovered this trip (having explored further afield) that this style is found more in the northern regions

Delicate architecture yet small. This place is a must do in Siem Reap. About 30 minutes drive out of the city. Has some of the finest architectures of Khmer dynasty. The stones are red and so is the soil. Look for the delicate inscriptions on the gopuras.
The 'Women's Temple'. A very beautiful pink sandstone temple with wonderfully rich and intricate carvings. It is worth going the extra distance to visit Banteay Srei

Not so good . I feel there are better places to be on Cambodia than spending time in bantaey srei. I can say there is nothing special about it. If someone is interested in intricate stone carvings, India has much amazing places to visit - belur and mount abu being few good ones.

Red stone temple. This temple was so distinctive from the rest of the temples in the Angkor complex. The temple is built of red stones which makes it beautiful. It's quite far away from Angkor wat but I would still suggest to visit it. Even the way to this temple is very interesting, u actually see a lot of Cambodian houses n their life style.

Long drive but worth it. We took a tuktuk for the 20+km, hour-long drive to Banteay Srei. We went first thing in the morning to get a headstart from the rest of the tourists. The temple also known as the Temple for Women is newly renovated, so the surrounding gardens and walkways are well maintained. It is distinctive for the red sandstone temple in the middle of the complex, embellished with beautiful carvings and sculptures. Beautiful place, not to be missed.
My Favourite Temple. While i was in Cambodia i visited about 16 temples and out of em all i think that banteay srei was the best.P.s: Try to visit it during sunset the view is exhilarating :)

Off track but worth the visit. This place is 30 km from the Angkor complex, but worth the visit for its rose-colored stones and carvings in good condition. If you are in a rush, taking a car may be better. But if you want to see the country side and stop to take photos, try local rice noodles and delicacies sold in along the road, taking the Tuk Tuk is also good if you have time.

Pink Beauty. As temples in the Angkor region go this is one of the best both in beauty and in it's detailed and intricate carvings especially of women. Build of a pink sandstone which gives the complex a pinkish hue all of its own. One of the oldest temples, even if somewhat smaller than others, in the Angkor region you will need time to study all the carvings. Easy to find if you are exploring the area without a guide. If you have engaged a guide or Tuk Tuk driver make sure you agree price first and look to incorporate other sites into the day's outing. This has plenty of amenities associated with the site with good descriptions and photos of the complexes restoration. Trails and boat rides can be found around the complex.

Worth visiting. This place is a bit further from Siem Reap, approx an hours drive, but definately worth the effort. Allow at least an hour to wander around the ruins which still appear to be in the hands of the jungle in place.

Worth the travel!. One of the things I enjoyed is the travel in the city while going here. It's more than 1 hour but worth it.This temple is gives you a certain shrill, but you can't take too many pictures beside. There are lots of closed areas.

One of our favorite temples. Hard to believe you can still see all the details on this very old site. If you are visiting Angkor Wat you need to see this local favorite. Get there on an off time (like lunch time) to avoid crowds

The most amazing temple of the Angkor Wat Complex. Dedicated to Women, this temple on it unique floor is a pure beauty. The pink sandstone sued is amazingly carved and mostly preserved. Very peaceful, a bit far but with an easy access, it is definitely amongst all the temples, a retreat.

Timing is everything with Banteay Srei. Banteay Srei is a beautiful little temple that features extraordinary carvings. This is one of the older temples, yet it's in great shape. The sandstone here has more of a pinkish hue to it than the more gray sandstone found at Angkor Wat and company.Because Banteay Srei is so small, it can easily get inundated by tour groups. These groups typically arrive at Banteay Srei in the late morning or early afternoon, so I would try to arrive there earlier in the morning or later in the afternoon.It takes about 45 minutes to drive from Banteay Srei from Siem Reap. It's a pretty drive, however, as you pass through many rice fields, and countless homes on stilts. I think the drive alone is worth the excursion, as it will give you a feel for rural Cambodia.-- John Shors, bestselling author of Temple of a Thousand Faces: A Novel of Angkor Wat
Ruins in their natural state. Such an interesting contrast to Angkor way and some of the other repaired ruins. We really enjoyed exploring here

Beautiful little gem. A rather small member of the family of temples at Angkor, Banteay Srei makes up for lack of size with it's outstanding intricate carvings and rose-colored stone. Also one of the better-preserved temples

Don't Missed this!. Banteay Srei is known as the Women's temple for its delicate sculptures and the lovely red color of its stone. Just when you think you couldn't see another temple that will take your breath away! Went with group and a guide which was helpful and informative.

Worth the trip out of town. This impressive temple is outside of town and so it takes about 30-45 minutes to get here from Siem Reap. Totally worth the journey though as this temple is absolutely stunning especially if you see it in the morning light like we did. The color of the sandstone is vibrant and the detailed stone carvings are something really special.

Citadel of Women. At least that's what the words mean. It's miniature compared to the other temples of Angkor. Beautiful red sandstone and extremely intricate carvings. It's away from the rest of the Angkor temples but definitely worth the extra time and distance. Too far to go in a tuk tuk so plan on hiring a car & driver which is added expense.

A walk into the History of Cambodia. Early morning of 12th May 2016, my tourist tour guide drove my and my hubby to Banteay Srei. It was quiet with very few visitors. As we walked along slowly, we appreciated and admired the finest carvings on the walls that built from red sandstones on this miniature temple. Unbelievable that during that era of times, with very limited tools, cravings were so artistic and fine, each has stories to tell. So, don't miss this opportunity to visit this red lady temple if you come to Siem Reap.
#Templemadebywomen. Its also my 5th time in this amazing temple ruins. The difference of this temple from any other temple in Siem Reap is the color. Its like a red/orange hues.

Well worth the visit. This is about 25km from Angkor Wat but is worth taking the time and expense to visit, as the carvings are the most elaborate and beautiful I've ever seen. It wasn't as crowded as the other temples and a 45 minute visit can do it justice, which is welcome in the oppressive heat of Cambodia.

Amazing carvings. A bit apart from the other key temple sites and less of the buildings are left standing but this is more than compensated for by the amazing carvings on the parts that do remain. Well worth the effort

Stunning...not to be missed. Spend a whole morning to appreciate the details of the intricate carving. Well worth the trip out there, but do it with a guide. I have to admit the heat and humidity is staggering, so bring a lot of water.
Golden light. Good to view it in the early morning when the sun is low and the light is golden. Many interesting carvings. Best to get there before the tourist buses arrive.

BEAUTIFUL. As I have mentioned in my other reviews we were getting 'templed out' due to the extreme heat - but glad we 'soldiered on' all the sites visited were brilliant and well worth a little effort!

A temple not to miss. You are spoils for choice in Siem Reap . Make sure this ruin is on your itinerary as it is the middle of nowhere and you could close your eyes and imagine it totally overgrown by nature until it's discovery

Small best craving temple!. Small best craving temple!
A lovely temple dedicated to the ladies "Srey"meant, the Banteay Srey is worth to visit. You need to ride pass the village called "Preah Dakk"which is a location of Khmer traditional noodle called "Noom Banh Chok" but no one feed you as per its name, you need to feed yourselves with a par of chopsticks!

This was awesome. Amazing historical site. The stone is beautiful rose color, there are wonderful statues that are different from Angkor. It's a unique feeling you will get during strolling through the temple.
go early. look up the professional photographer kimleng sang; he will guide you to the best angles for photos. and go EARLY!!!. skip angkor wat & come here
Impressively preserved. Carvings in hard limestone have remained largely preserved since 975 AD making this an amazing temple to visit.....a must!!
Home of the Butterfly Center and close to the Land Mine Museum. A must see when you are at Angkor. It is close to the Butterfly Center and the Land Mine Museum. Tell your driver to take you there.
Small but very fine. This is one of the smaller temples but is well worth a visit. The stone work has some great detailed carvings.

An interesting little place. This temple is quite ruined but the main section is on very good condition. The carvings here are beautiful and seem a little different to the others. I really like walking around the small complex as it had a different feel to other temples - like it was built by another group of people. Worth a visit.
Carvings . The finest, and most well preserved carvings in the entire region. Stunning stuff. Popular, but not overcrowded.

A little beauty. Banteay srei is small but stunning. Quite a drive from town (1 hour) but worth it. Clearly funded well and so unlike the others which look extremely authentic but not obviously under restoration, this one is. Incredibly beautiful temple built by Hindu priests under a minsters production budget. If I recall right it is more than a thousand years old. Go with a guide who can explain the Lakshmi-Vishnu-shiva-Rama vali sugreeva and Ravana stories to you. Absolutely Magical if you know the stories behind the carvings, stunning even if you don't.

Temple for the ladies. Banteay Srei is a small temple that is dedicated for the goddess. What really differentiates it from other temples:- The temple is made from "pink colored" stones. That's why it is very often to be associated with goddess or ladies. - This temple depicts the story of Ramayana (Rama and Sita). So you will see Hanuman statue as the guard of this temple. - You can't get inside the temples - you can only walk around and see from the distant. To walk 1 round is only like 15-20 mins - so not really much to see, but again, this is the pink temple. - Since you can only walk around - when there are group of tourists walking around - it is a bit chaotic, noisy and you can't enjoy the tranquility of this temple. So best time is to get to this temple in early morning. - To get this temple is like 1 to 1.5 hour from Charles De Gaulle Boulevard (using Tuk-tuk). The other nearby objects/things-to-do are Landmine museum (1-2 hours visit) and Butterfly Center (I didn't go to here). So think carefully if you have plenty time to get to this temple or no, as the travelling time from and to Banteay Srei can take like 2-3 hours.

Amazing carvings!!. Banteay Srei is a little far off from the other temples that I visited but it was definitely worth it! It is also not very huge but I was very amazed with how intricate the carvings were on the stones and how well it was preserved until today. Tourists are also not allowed to go very close to the walls, as the carvings are so well done so I understand why. There are also boat rides available but during the time that I went it was the super dry season so it was not very attractive.
Petite but detailed and beautiful. Most detailed carvings in my opinion across all the temples of Angkor. 30 minutes ride on tuk-tuk made the trip a lot easier in the extreme heat.

Breathtakingly beautiful. I had two favourite temples, Ta Pruhm where they filmed Tomb Raider, and this one - the Ladies Temple. Absolutely magnificent, this temple HAS to be visited. The pink sandstone is a very strong stone and the carvings are so intricate and in such amazing condition that you won't believe what you see. Do not miss this one - it's about a 45 minute drive out of Siem Reap but absolutely worth it! Mind blowing!

Worth a visit. A small temple in red stone with detailed stone carvings. Best visited in the mid/late afternoon when the light is perfect. It is 20km from Angkor Wat. The trip through the countryside in the afternoon sun is very relaxing.

Beautiful and peaceful. After visiting the crowded temples of Angkor Wat this temple is a welcome relief away from the crowds. Even though you can walk around in 10 mins it's this place that holds you in a charming embrace and gives you the opportunity to reflect on the past and the amazing people who built the temple.

Jewel in the crown. We spent three days visiting the temples at Angkor and this was the last one and the best one.
The carvings are incredibly detailed and well preserved

My favourite temple!. We weren't in Siem Reap very long, so I was a little nervous going to this temple (it is quite a ways away from the city). However the reviews were so good, we decided to chance it, and I'm so glad I did. Even though it's small (we were only there for 20 minutes), this was probably the best temple we saw. The carvings are beyond description. The detail that had been preserved is astounding! It's one of those places that's so beautiful, you just can't capture it in a photo. The tuk tuk ride was about 40 minutes each way, but it was definitely worth it. In fact, we found the ride very pleasant (there are villages along the road, and lots of kids were waving at us as we drove past). And the breeze from the ride was very welcome after a hot day!Can't recommend this gem of a temple enough! And bonus: it's not that crowded! We went near closing, and we were one of three couples there!

the best carve stone in ankor thom. Banteay srei is the perfect carve stone ,and very complete structure,the temple is far from city 37 km,but it is necessary to see it.If you are backpack tourist ,I suggest to rent car (30-40 mins) or tuk tuk,but tuk tuk is slow about more 1 hour.I suggest the car rent with driver,he is very good service mind,toyota camry with air conditioner. contact with facebook MSN: vin sing dmk

Wonderful shades of color. Banteay Srei stands out for its color. With shades of yellow and somewhat-pinkish sandstone this temple predates Angkor Wat by 200 years. It is close quarters here so you can easily turn around and enjoy the design. This "Citadel of Women" also presents a rarity among the many temples of Siem Reap as one should look for the mitering of the "window" openings. Banteay Srei truly complements the many temples you can visit and should be on your list.
Pretty little temple. This was worth the extra drive away from Siem Reap to see the remarkably well preserved carvings on a temple that has otherwise crumbled away.

A great experience. This temple is a real gem and not to be.missed. You walk through and it help you imagine a long lost time, where people lived a very simple life. The heat and the humidity makes it feel extra special, but take It's of water as you will need it.
Amazing. We loved it! The colours, the atmosphere...it is the best one! Don't miss it!! And bring with you a lot of water if you go in March/April...

Really Cool- Watch the Stairs. This temple was, as the whole Angkor complex is, really awesome. When I was there, it was incredibly hot so make sure that you have plenty of water with you and be cautious when you are going up and down the stairs at these places- they aren't all even and some of them are really high. Good shoes are a necessity here.

Long way to go but still great . This is a long Tuk Tuk ride to get here and it is arguably worth doing more for the ride itself than for the temple. You pass through lovely little villages and get to see authentic Cambodian life. The temple itself is really nice especially if you are into the beautifully preserved carvings but apart from the carvings it doesn't have that wow factor and it is just so incredibly hot there due to it being so exposed to the sun. There is very little shading to escape the sun so we rushed through it and didn't really appreciate how beautiful it is. The trip should be combined with the hidden gem of the Angkor temples - Banteay Samre which is just stunning and is on the way to Banteay Srei.

Definitely a precious gem. We loved our visit to this temple. Although smaller than some of the other temples, there are some lovely intricate carvings gracing this 10th century Hindu temple. We took a tuk tuk there which took about 45 minutes. The drive itself was part of the experience for us, we enjoyed the cool breeze while we were driving through the scenic countryside.When we arrived there were not very many people there and that combined with its location made it feel serene and tranquil. We were able to take our time walking around and easily spent an hour looking at all of the detailed carvings.We’d been told the best time to visit this site was before 10:00am or early afternoon around 2:00pm to take advantage of the light hitting the sandstone to get the full benefit of the red colouring of the stone. We arrived at around 9:00am and did see the beautiful colouring of the stone. It was also a good time to visit to avoid the full heat of the sun. I think it has been my favourite temple so far and can easily see why it is considered a “precious gem”.Entrance to this temple was included in the Angkor Pass. To visit any of the Angkor Wat temples you need to have an Angkor Pass, available in 1, 3 or 7 day passes. This gives you access to the temples for any of those number of days in a given week, or month if you have a 7 day pass, they don’t have to be used on consecutive days. We went with a 3 day pass for $40. When you go to the main entrance to get your pass your photo is taken and printed on the pass, which you must present on each visit to a temple.Would recommend a visit even though it is a little way out. The drive out there is part of its charm.

Smaller, but most intricate structures and beautiful coloring. This is much further away than any of the main Angkor temples, but definitely worth a little travel. The temple has a beautiful hue that other temples do not (called pink stones althogh they are not really "pink"). It is also much smaller, and petite, but beautifully carved all over...supposedly created by the ladies with ladies' touch.

Definitely worth the trip !. In comparison to many of the other temples this is pretty small but the workmanship of the carvings is truly beautiful. I was first here neatly 14 years ago and I was a bit disappointed as to how touristy it has now become but it poured with rain as soon as I arrived and so I was thankful for the cover !!! It didn't take much for the temple to become quite flooded but despite the water it is still a fascinating place to visit.

An extraordinary little gem of a temple. This small temple emerged from the jungle and has been repaired, but not restored in the sense of reconstruction. What sets it apart are the beautiful carvings around the many doorways. A 30-45 minute drive but definitely worthwhile. We also enjoyed learning about the palm sugar process at the roadside stands along the way. While "touristy" it is low-key and interesting nonetheless.

Early visit recommended . This is my pick of the temples in Angkor Wat. Smaller and a different red sandstone makes it special. The carvings are incredible and the colours spectacular in the early morning sunshine. A must for the trip
Beautiful . Worth the slightly longer drive to get to. Beautifully detailed and intricate carvings everywhere you look. This one is not to be missed.

Another beautiful temple ruin.. Banteay Srei is one of the many temple ruins in the Angkor Wat area though a lot further out from Siem Reap than the others. Well worth the trip. The site is well organised with the entry point away from the temple with information and a shop. On one side there is a museum and a market and restroom. On the other the start of the walk up. An easy walk until you get to the step (not many compared to some of the others).Inside you can tell it was not for devotion but for practical purposes. The iconic religious symbolism is less prominent but the protective icons are there. Apsara are the images most seen but the highlight are the monkey guardians around the main structure most intact and very detailed (see image).The tour round goes round the gardens or the lake both of which were dust bowls when we were there. It has been so hot and dry but a nice walk. Be wary, the market is more expensive than the central markets with no uniqueness or additional quality and not the friendliest if you look but find it too expensive.

A little different from most of the other temples. It's the Wandering Yank here. Mrs. Yank and I spent 3 wonderful days touring the Angkor area. This is the temple with the finer carvings in sandstone, far more delicate than what you'll find in most of the other temples. They're quite beautiful and unique. It is a popular temple, so expect some crowds, but it wasn't as overwhelming a crowd for us as was Baphuon and Ta Prohm.2 thumbs up!
Absolutely Essential. Should definitely be on your list of temples to see while in Siem Reap. This one is beautiful from all angles.

Lovely place. Banteay Srei is really worth the 45 minute ride on a remork from Angkor Wat area. You can visit it with the same pass that you bought for Angkor archeological park. It offers unique pictures of freskos, carvings and doors. The colour of the stones is so beautiful.All in all another must see in this beautiful area.
A must see. Definitely in the top 3 temples to see. It's small, so it's a quick one, but what is amazing is the quality of the carvings on the walls. Don't miss it!

Impressive carvings. It is a long tuk-tuk ride from Seim Reap and will cost you $60 so take a couple of friends to share the cost. The carvings are excellent and the most detailed we saw of any of the many temples we visited.
big tour package. the big tour consists of smaller temples more spread out. still worth checking out if you have time but try and avoid the sun- its hot!

Definitely Have To See. It's a place you definitely have to see in Siem Reap. But if you have limited time, I'd probably forgo this place in lieu of seeing Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, and Beng Mealea. The carving is the most decorative at any of the temples in Siem Reap, and that is the draw. The scale of the property can't match the three I mentioned above though, as I feel you can walk through this place in ten or fifteen minutes. Try doing that at Angkor Thom.

Different pink sandstone temple. Well preserved temple. Loads of intricate and well preserved carvings, each set telling a different chapter of a story that our local tour guide related to us. The pink sandstone made this temple unique in the Siem Reap area.
Holiday. Beautiful place not to miss while in Siem Reap. The architecture of the building depicts the history.Though many ruins but the remains left history to be written.

Different. It is nice at the smaller temples. Less crowds and better opportunity to take pictures without other people. You can quietly contemplate the magnitude of the whole archeological park and imagine what it must have been like for this ancient civilization.

citadel of women. carved exquisitely in pink sandstone,, this temple is dedicated to shiva. the lintels depict scenes from the ramayana as well as shiva, parvati, hanuman and krishna. far away from the main city of seam reap, this can eb visited if one has 3+ days in seam reap.

Small and nice. It is located far from the other temples. You have to take a Tuktuk or car. But you can enjoy a nice scenery along the road, rice field, local houses, people, stop to enjoy some local foods. At the site, there are also many stalls of souvenir and foods.

Intricate carvings. We were hot and exhausted but have to admit the carvings were really intricate and amazing. Nice to sit afterward and listen to the blind musicians. Then stroll the back way to the entrance and you will find water buffalo. Really cool.
Very nice Temple. It is very beautiful temple and very nice and small carving on the wall with the red and pink color.

Out of the way but worth the visit. This temple is on the edge of the whole park, about 35kms from Siem reap, but is worth visiting. The statues are in better condition than some others, almost perfect.
If you get the 3 day pass then spend a day visiting the lesser temples - they are definitely worth visiting

Different style and older than Angkor Wat. This temple is further away from Siem Reap than Angkor Wat but stiil worth seeing a tuk tuk will cost about $20 for 2 people but is around 30 km out.The tuk tuk drivers will also stop at the landmines museum and palm sugar producers at no extra cost . A very good half day trip and very interesting

Interesting Drive/ Short Visit. This temple requires a 45min drive from Siem Reap, however it was a good chance to see the countryside and the more rural towns and activities. The temple itself is very small compared to the Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom sites, however the carvings and reliefs are very unique, interesting and well worth the trip to see. As with most of the temples sites there were some vendor booths and opportunities for refreshment. This was the most organized of the sites I visited in terms of facilities.
Excellent temple. All the Angkor Park temples are similar. But each one has its own distinguishing features. Battery Srei is definitely worth a visit.

A little more off the beaten path, making it a more relaxing experience!. As Angkor and the majority of the complex has a pretty common path most people take, it's nice to get to a temple which has a much more chilled out flow. You may get a few tour buses showing up while there, but if you either walk a little faster ahead, or stop for a few minutes until they passed, you'll be able to enjoy the temple at your own pace without the hassle of hundreds of photo-bombers or tranquility-killers passing by.

The Ladies Temple. This temple is about 37 km from Siem Reap and totally different to the other temples due to the colour of the stone (pinkish). I really enjoyed this temple and the drive through the countryside to get to it.

Beautiful pink sandstone. The carving is exquisite! Here, or somewhere nearby, you are sure to be approached by a child selling a guidebook. Buy one! There is much info that the guides don't share (or know) and the book is a bargain.

Beautiful Temple. This was the last temple we saw on our vacation, and we loved it just as much as the others. The beautiful stone was fascinating, and we even got to see workers clearing rice fields around the area. The whole experience was wonderful.

Beautiful smaller temple, more than worth the trip. This temple is a little out of the way, but a real beauty with excellent and beautiful decorations. Very peaceful and far less people than the Angkor Wat area temples

Reminded Me of Roman Ruins. This temple is all pink so it's unique from other area temples and we were told it is a dedication to women. It has walkways of ruined columns, which reminded me of Roman ruins. It's a bit of a drive to get here, but you see some of rural Cambodia, which I found interesting.

Away from the main complex. Away from teh main complex, about 45 minutes tuk-tuk ride, but very unique and worth seeing. not large, but the most intricately carved of all the temple. While here, dont miss continuing into the mountains for the waterfall as its only another 30 minutes or so.

Another temple but worth a visit. My suggestion is to hire a tuk tuk on a daily rate as this temple is approx 35KM from the city center, it is worth a visit but try and add some other non temple attractions to make it an interesting full day. Also try to avoid the tour buses re timing to visit.

Small but full of details. This temple is not so full. Is a little bit far from the rest but I really recommend to visit the place. The engravings are so full of details. And also is completely different from the rest because of the stone color.

Another different style temple. A very beautiful temple with a totally different design dedicated to Shiva. It's quite a bit out of the area but worth a visit and it is included the overall Angkor temple ticket.

beautiful red stone. this set of temples has a distinct red coloring that makes it really pretty to see. even the carvings are a tad more intricate than some of the other temples. a perfect way to round off the day.

Lady's temple. About 40kms from the main temple sites. You can go by tuk tuk but be prepared to covered in dust. Try to go early as the tourist buses arrive and every single passenger wants to take an individual photo with each and every arch in the temple complex. A couple of walks in the area and free roaming oxen. A very naturistic temple

Most beautiful in term of crafting . Took tuk tuk to be here. It takes approximately 30 min from East melon temple. They call it the city of women. The size of this temple is not big. But the uniqueness is he temple crafting. Love the craft of the this temple. Along the way, there are many villages. We stop to buy the palm sugar. The price is 2, 3 and 5 US dollar I would said worth travel here.

Most beautiful of the sites around Siem Reap.. This place was exceptional even among the host of other truly wonderful and beautiful sites in Siem Reap. Had me thinking days and weeks after visiting, and I would return to walk around, take more pictures and listen to the live music.
Very colourful temple.. This is a very different temple, with beautiful colours in the stone, the detail and scripts are well worth spending a little extra time.

My least favourite among all the Angkor temples. My least favourite among all the Angkor temples. 10 minutes seems more than enough for this one. I guess after experiencing all other amazing temples across this amazing medieval Khmer empire, this one (mainly due to its size) feels rather disappointing.

The lady temple. This temple is also known as the lady temple. It is quite a drive from Angkor Wat and center city Siem Reap. Most don't visit it because it is a 45 minute car ride or even longer tuk tuk ride. It is beautiful though and unlike any other temple in Siem Reap. Highly recommend a visit to this beautiful and unique temple.

Beautiful 😍. Very beautiful! We were lucky, when we went there there were not too many tourists! Leave your hotel early to beat the large crowds.. Very small temple, you would only about an hour there.

The Ladies Temple. This temple is much smaller than most of the other ones in the Angkor Wat complex but it was worth it. The reliefs are beautiful and it's in fairly good condition given it's age. If I were short on time I might skip this one but I had the time and I'm glad I made the visit.

Banteay Srei. I was a bit hesitant to go out to Banteay Srei, as the temple is located outside the original temple area. It took me aprox 45 minutes one way in a tuktuk. However, I really enjoyed the trip there. It was a great opportunity to see more from the country side of Cambodia. The temple itself is smaller then many others, which I appreciated after walking around the huge temples, such as Angkor Wat and Bayon. As the temple is smaller, you can see the details much better. And also, as its located abit of, there was not nearly as many tourists there. It is also surrounded by lovely nature, so you can go for walk in the greenery afterwards.

not as pink as advertised, scarily overcrowded, but the details.... It's more brown than pink; completely no roof so immensely hot; quite a small and compact temple, especially when the inner part is closed (can see from outside); unluckily went at the same time as 2 big bus tours so it was..hmm...full of women trying to pose and look good under the blazing sun in front of every stone. However, you find amazingly preserved carvings and structures, which are usually lost in the other temples. Must wear clothing that cover shoulder and knees~ (i just wrapped a shirt around my waist and was let pass~)I do not regret spending the money (had to travel by car due to the long distance, not by tuk tuk) and time on travel to get here. Note that according to the driver, when it rains it's impossible to drive to these far away temples, so beware if you are traveling during the rain season (starting from May I think)our day plan for your reference:Board car 5am at hotel, see sunrise at Angkor Wat, look at the galleries we missed in our first visit; jump back on the car by 8am, go to landmine museum en route to Banteay Srei; spent a little bit longer than we should in the museum as it was so informative and important, ended up having less time to see Banteay Srei; drove to Beng Melea, turned our head around to a restaurant as it was already noon, way too hot to be walking around; saw Being Melea after lunch (unfortunately it's a big ruin, without a guide we couldn't really make sense of it; and we only had less than an hour as we wanted to see sunset in Rolous Group; 5 minutes stop at Lolei temple as it was under renovation; longer stop at Preah Ko, as it was almost empty (our 3 days temple visit conclusion: any crowded temple is unattractive temple; any empty temple is amazing temple. TRUE! As there's always so much to see so much to explore if you have the space); and at last to Bakong Temple for sunset. The car for the day: UDS75

Highly intricate and intact!. While this is a much smaller temple than some of the other greats, it was incredible to see the amount of detail in the carvings and the fact the this place is pretty much entirely intact really blew me away.

Worth the travel. Highly recommend the extra travel to get to this temple. The detail is everything you read about. We had a guide for the more popular temples but not this one - only a driver and it worked fine. It was great to spend time exploring every angle of this temple at our own pace. We took a thousand photos and I'm sure they will not capture how amazing this place is.
Visit Angkor Wat first. It is difficult to pick and choose. But if time is at a premium you can skip this temple. Visit Angkor Wat first.
Beautiful History. A small place but a 'must see' place. Go early to avoid crowds and take a goo Tour Guide to explain the history.

This is the Temple of Womem. This is totally worth the time to visit. The colors in the late afternoon are stunning, and it is so small compared to others. Beautiful temple with fantastic carved stone reliefs.

Lady Temple. This one is different from the others around Angkor Wat. it's situated an hour drive outside Siem Reap city center. What makes it different is that, its a bit smaller in size and the color as well. one of my favorite temple in Cambodia.

Another stunning - unique - temple. Banteay Srei was a little different that other temples within Angkor, still extremely beautiful, powerful, breathtaking. This was more open, religious-feeling. The carvings were incredibly intricate and fascinating. If you can bear the heat and sun to take the time and look at them intently, you will be surprised and almost enthralled. I don't know how they did it. I would love to hold a wedding here. Really, try this temple. It's one of the older ones, more on his own. I'd love to see it again.
Beautiful. A beautiful place. Peaceful and serene. The carvings are incredible. Amazing to think how old they are and how well they have survived the passage of time.

A must when seeing the Angkor complexes. This is also known as the 'lady temple' due to its smaller scale. They believe it many have been built by women due to the dainty size rocks used for the construction!Whatever the story it makes for a very pleasant visit when you're on the verge of getting 'templed' out.

Quite different from the rest. One of the older temples, quite different in architecture design from the other temples. Very intricate wall cravings, with great details of Hindu mythologies (this was before the change to Buddism).

THE MOST BEAUTIFUL OF THE ANGKOR TEMPLES. For all the sombre majesty of the imposing structures at Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom this little red sandstone temple sits in isolation as a tiny miniature. Banteay Srei is a 10th century Hindu jewel that packs a different kind of atmosphere. More peaceful, delicate, gentle, feminine. Its name means 'citadel of the women' or 'citadel of beauty' and the intricate bas relief carvings on walls and above doorways are amazingly well preserved. Apsara dancers. Elephants. Kings. Gods. Demons. Battles. Chariots. And the statues around one building feature a guardian group of human figures with animal heads that conjure one of the major fight scenes in the 2001 'Tomb Raider' film.The Angkor temples deserve so many adjectives but Banteay Srei is the one for "beautiful".Unmissable ...!

the best bas relief. This temple is quiet unique in its stone and its quality and fine level of bas relief. Well worth the trip out, not only for the temple but for the ride out there through the country side and villages. Great facilities there.

Interesting, but a bit far to go just for the temple. This one is different from the others around Angkor Wat. That said, it is fairly small and only takes 30 minutes at most to see. Adding a top at the Butterly Refuge or Landmine museum makes it more worthwhile. As it is almost an hour from town (30 min from Angkor Wat), I recommend spending a little bit more and taking a car, unless you just love long Tuk-tuk rides.
Better than Angkor Wat. We know we shouldn't say this, but the guys at HI in Siem said this is amazing. Less tourists, better temple. Just go. Can't explain why. You wil know when you go
Great temple. Our trip was took 5day. It was very amazing when we arrived at this temple. Ur guide was unexpected to described Banteay Srey. Great temple.

Best temple in the area!. This temple is a bit further away and they will charge you extra for the ride but it is the most beautiful temple from my point of view. The park around it is also nice and it is a nice opportunity to go through the local villages on the way there . Definitely would not miss it !

A delicate gem. This was an hour drive from Siem Reap and was strongly recommended by the hotel staff. Sometimes I'm wary of strong rec's like that (upsells) but they're simply very proud of this temple. The grounds include botanical gardens and a fishing lake but really, it's the temple itself that has to be seen. Because of its great condition and delicate sandstone, you can't get as close to it as some of the other temples closer to the city but just to see it is good enough. just like the Koh Ker temple system, it's a drive but if you flew all the way from the US like I did, it'd be a shame not to drive just a little more and see this wonder. (ps, don't take a tuktuk if you like comfort - hire a car.)

Better preserved smaller wat. This wat is better preserved than some of the smaller wats in the Angkor Archaeological park. It is approximately 35 km away from the park, but well worth the drive, all the Tuk Tuks will take you there, and there is food etc available at the site.
Loved this temple. This was a beautiful temple with elegant, delicate carvings. It seemed different than some of the other temples we saw - if you have the time you should visit.

Watch out for pigs on the loose. We traveled for 40km from Siem Reap to see this site. Unfortunately, many large coaches arrived around the same time as we did. We were surrounded by Chinese people on group tours who seemed to be more interested in getting "selfies" than respecting the site as many site monitors repeatedly requested them not to touch pillars and other areas of conservation. It is a pretty site, carved out of pink sandstone, devoted to the 'queen' or to females...a nice spot to visit if if wasn't so crowded with tourists who didn't appreciate the history.

Intricate Carvings of Banteay Srei... Banteay Srei is a must visit places ..I took tuk tuk for a day for 28$ from my hotel , there ride was superb you can gaze at the county and villages of the authentic traditional Cambodian lifestyle, house and huts farm lands and villagers ..I saw the process of palm sugar extractions and palm jaggery products on the road sides, also bamboo handicrafts and wood furniture's..On reaching Bantea Srei temple which is a protected monument ..encompasses splendour intricate carvings lintels and the temple us well decorated with the carvings if pedestals pillars and I was wondering struck with the Architectural beauty of the sanctum with Indian Hindu mythology and women deities carvings. The temple is well maintained and its being restored to its state if art Banteay Srei Citadel of women city ...the sure has a photo gallery and soviners gift handworks paintings shops and food courts. 3 day pass include Bantea Srei temple too...I visited Land Mine museum on my return trip and combined Banteay Samre and Rolus Group Temples in my day trip for 28$USD.In this trip I got to feel the nature of Cambodian village scenic views and the feilds...gave an memorable experience of the real Cambodian side....

Mr Chaan's favourite . This is a small but beautiful temple dedicated to women and Mr Chaan's favourite. It is only small but beautifully persevered and pink in colouring. It won't take you long to view, but I throughly recommend a visit.Whilst we were there we took a boat trip which was only 7dollars for both of us, which took us past the water buffalo, beautiful birds and peaceful scenery.
Farther but worth it.. This was the farthest temple we went to and I'm happy we did. The carving on this temple are absolutely stunning. Don't miss it!
Wonderful )). Unique "Pink Sandstone" Lady's Temple!Very cute and beautiful, incredible and impressive detailed architecture!Worth to see it your own eyes !))

An hour from Seim Reap but combine with other attractions. This is a long drive but just about worth it. A large complex that is in reasonable condition and has great carvings in red stone. There are some good walks around the complex and a good information center and a place to get some food. It is much more some of the other ruins in the area.
a different style of temple. a 40 min drive out of town. It interesting to view the countryside.A beautiful temple. We visited about 1pm and it was very hot
Best Carving temple.. Everyone said it is ping color temple. Truely the temple was very nuce color and specially had very nice carving whole temple we realy love it lots.
Recommend. We.visited many (but not all) temples. This one was particularly pretty. Many of the carving are preserved.

Beautiful. This small temple was so beautiful. The colour of the rock and all the carvings make it really special. We took so many photos! This is worth the drive out to see it. Plus, the country side outside the city was interesting to see. Combined with a visit to the Landmine Museum.

The Pink Temple. Much further away from the city, The Pink Temple or Lady's Temple Banteay Srei was recommended to us by our tour guide saying that it was a beautiful sight in the sun. Rare pink sandstone was used to build the entire temple devoted to Shiva, god of destruction. The carvings are beautiful. However this temple is much hotter to trek (in direct sun) unlike Angkor Wat (which had cool halls) for the lack of trees and breeze in the area. Not as big as Angkor Wat either so a quick stroll through and picture taking was enough. Better to visit in the early morning or later afternoon to avoid having to rush through because of the heat and sun.
LOts of Stairs. Great site to wonder around with a lot of elephant statues not common in other temples. Lots of rough steps but must do, not that large to see.
Fine carvings. This is not a spectacular temple in size or grandeur but has the most refined and beautiful carvings. The trip out to it (37 km from Siem Reap) is very pleasant also.

Smaller but equally impressive to Angkor. It was well worth the extra distance to go out to Banteay Srei. The detail of carvings on the sandstone walls is extraordinary, and it didn't seem as crowded as the other main sites of Angkor.

Fantastic experience. We took the tuktuk from the hotel to this temple, which took about 1 hour. It's an amazing experience, driving through the country side and then arriving at this temple complex. The temple is smaller than most temples within the Angkor Wat complex, but absolutely worth a visit. I would definitely recommend adding it to your itinerary.

Intricately carved temple. This temple is out of the way a bit, but it is worth the trip! The temple is a pink sandstone and has beautiful carvings. You would definitely want to be in a car for the trip. We saw plenty of people in tuktuks and they looked so hot!

Small But Very Well Preserved! . The temple was small however did not appear to have experienced the pillage and plunder plus impact of war that the others had. It was under repair as most temples are with many bricks replaced in the ancient manner to ensure the structure is preserved. It used to be accessed by boat however is now situated next to the rice fields dependent on the rainy season for water and adjoining farming areas. This was a very authentic and well preserved temple and with such detail is worth a visit. Avoid the April heat as it is exhausting reducing the ability to take the time to simply wander.
Great Temple. Amazing temple. Nice view, especially during the morning. This is a must-visit place in Cambodia. Highly recommended.

Worth the drive!. Banteay Srei is located about 35 km from Siem Reap town. it is a beautiful, small temple with intricately carved walls and amazing pink and green colours in the stone. It is well worth the drive. Go in the afternoon as it is very busy in the morning with full buses of tourists inundating the area. As it is quite small, it doesn't accommodate the large crowds as well as some of the other bigger temples.

A wonderful spot outside the big crowds. Our guide asked if we wanted to see this pink temple. He said it was extra as it was much further away from the other sites. First, the drive out was awesome. We got to see a different part of the country. The temple site was very small but spectacular! The color of the stones and the intricate details was amazing. This also shows how these sites are getting over run. It use to be open for people to wander around in. Now you can only walk around the outside.
Small and not crowded.. We had this complex to ourselves (except for a couple of guards). Really nicely preserved reliefs are found here. There is renovation going on which is fascinating to observe.

Beautiful temple off the main routes. This temple is well worth a visit beautiful detailed carvings and serene feel, not as busy as the others in a rural setting. Be aware it is about an hour and a half from town plan your time it closes at 5pm.

Small but exquisite temple. We visited the "Lady temple" after the sunrise at Angkor Wat, and arrived at about 8am. We had the temple to ourselves. The size is quite diminutive in comparison to other temples, but the carvings and decorations are stunning. A little further out than some temples, this is worth the drive.

Pink Temple. Designed by a woman and is more delicate and pretty. Made of pink stone and has some very interesting detail. Further away from Siem Reap but travel by Tuk tuk and enjoy going through villages seeing how the locals live,
A little further out but worth the trip. A beautifully engraved temple make the journey if possible. The pink stone is lovely, adding to the feeling of grace and elegance.

Hindu Temple. After Angkor Wat, I would say this is my next favourite temple. The carvings are intricate and some of the finest in the world. The stone has a pinkish hue and it is no wonder that this is considered to be the 'jewel in the crown' of Angkorian Art. Do not miss this, it is very different to the others.

Small complex quite far away. The carving and preservation is amazing. But the complex is quite small probably take 30min to see everything at the complex. Its a good 45-1hr drive from the Siam Reap city.
Conclusion is if you have the budget and time maybe worth going, but if you are on a tight budget or limited time give it a miss.

Beautiful and different from the rest of Angor complex. This is the most detailed temple in Angkor complex, it is known as the Lady Temple, because it is so lavishly decorated. But it is a little bit far from Angor Wat, we took about 45 minutes in a tuc tuc. But no doubt it is worthed. I strongly recommend it.

Visually Stunning. This temple is very different from the others - not only is it (very) far from the rest, it is made of red sandstone. The affect is gorgeous - it is very well preserved, the carvings are incredible, and I'm glad we made the trek out there. That being said - it really is a trek, and the temple is quite small, so it may not be "worth it" for some people to travel out that far. But, as I mentioned, we just loved it.

Banteay Srei, beautiful, Khmer, 10th century temple in red sandstone.. Banteay Srei, is built largely of a hard red sandstone that lends itself to the detailed and elaborate carvings. Brick and laterite were used only for the enclosure walls and some structural elements. The temple is known for the beauty of its sandstone lintels and pediments. A pediment is the triangular structure above the doorway and a lintel is the horizontal beam that serves as a support, and is used for decorative carvings. At Banteay Srei, both these are extextensively used for for both purposes.Bantei Srei is so called today because of the lovely devatas carved on its walls. Actually it is dedicated partly to Shiva and partly to Vishnu. Don't miss visiting this Temple.
Unique. One of the more interesting temples in the area. Very different from others. apparently is was also the setting for Tomb Raiders. That aside, put it on your list.

My Favorite. Six days in Siem Reap - six temples; this was my favorite. It is small and understandable, but so detailed and well restored. It just makes you marvel at how this was created and what it all meant to the makers.The band at the exit is pretty incredible too - and deserves your donation.Take your time and stop along the drive out to the temple because the people are "just living" but are so warm and willing to share their lives with visitors. It will make your time in Cambodia so much more meaningful.
Well Preserved. Although much small than Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom it is stilll highly regarded for its elaborate wall carvings. The red sandstone gives it a totally different feeling.

Lovely but very busy. Dedicated to Shiva and built in a red sandstone this temple is well worth the 25km trip from Siam Reap. The journey itself is interesting as you pass through a number of local villages. The temple has many intricate carvings. It is smaller than the other temples so it is really busy. There were a local group of musicians at the end of the temple who all had injuries from the Khmer Rouge era or whilst farming and treading on mines. Inspirational !

Incredible detail, so worth the distance. I chose the three day pass to see the temples, and to be honest by the third day I was losing steam. I almost opted out of this one, I was hot and tired. So happy I saw it though. Beautiful detail, and different than the other temples. You must see it!
A wonderful experience. This is one of my favorite temples. Each one are magnificent and magical. Don't miss this and check it out.

Beautiful. This is a small archeological site but well worth the visit. Make sure to visit the interpretive centre where you can read about the dig and it's surrounds. The story of Andre Malraux is bizarre and a must to check out.
Not to be missed : intricate carvings. It's small, intricate carvings are a must-see. Keep hands to yourself. No touching or leaning, hat for sun.
Long drive, highly commercialised. Beautiful, but in the grand scheme, nothing special compared to other sites in the main complex. It's a long drive to the site as well.

The Citadel of Women. I saw the female influences of the Hindu deity inscribed in stone in all the temple surfaces. This ancient culture had a special devotion to women and the importance of their gift of life to the whole nation.

Small but wonderffk. This temple is around 20 kilometers away from Angkor Wat, but is considered as part of the complex. The ticket fee to Angkor includes this small temple, which is exquisitely carved. If you are a lover of details, you'll enjoy this small temple in which even the door frames contain writings in Sanskrit. Don't forget your water, and hat, since this place is not covered by trees or any kind of shade.
Beautiful intricate carvings. Amazing 10th century hindu temple built of red sandstone with elaborate carvings that have survived to this day! Definitely worth a visit!

Not in good condition even though it is supposedly being restored.. Not impressed and would not return as very little information there while outside there are numerous locals trying to sell different items at very discounted prices..
Fascinating. A small, very old Hindu temple with very detailed carvings. It is a bit of a drive away and there are lots of steps but we thought it was worth it.

Beautiful temple. Like all other temples in Siem Reap, this temple is a beauty of its own. We found this temple to be a little hotter than the others and were told by our tour guide that it's due to the types of stones used to build the temple. Great visit.
Do not miss this!. Banteay Srei is a magical place. A miniature compared to Angkor Wat but so incredibly beautiful. Get up early and take your time to take in the details.

BEAUTIFUL. This temple is further out of main Angkor Wat temple complex.It is about an hours drive from Siam Reap town but it is worth visiting. This temple was dedicated to Hindu Lord Siva and was build on red sandstone. The temple is widely known for the beauty.The admission fee is $5.If you have spare half day then take a taxi or Tuk Tuk to visit this temple.

Exquisite carvings, beautifully presented. This complex is about an hour out of Siem Reap by tuk tuk, but well worth the trip. There’s a beautiful welcome hall with museum on the grounds. The archaeological complex is fairly small, but the bas-relief carvings are among the finest you’ll see in the Angkor area. Unfortunately part of the center of the temple has been roped off, probably to protect the carvings, so you can no longer get up close to take photos. The drive itself is interesting as it takes you past villages where you can see the locals engaging in various cottage industries, throwing elaborate weddings, etc. We stopped alongside the road to buy cheap, juicy watermelon which the seller cut up for us.
One of my favouites!. Loved this temple, but it is a fair way from the other temples, but quite different in that it is Hindu, hence different carvings. Good markets in the entrance grounds.

Small but beautiful. The entrance of the temple is very nice, both sides you have several blocks and bricks with beautiful images. It is one of the smallest Angkor temples to be found there but Banteay Srei compensates for its small size with greatest beauty. The temple was built in the year 967 and as many temples in Cambodia is the Banteay Srei built to Hinduism
The most detailed carvings in any Siem Reap Temple. The carvings are over a 1,000 years old and absolutely gorgeous. It's amazing how something can still remain so detailed and beautiful.

Predating Angkor Wat itself, but not nearly on the same scale nor as intricate.. Well worth the time to visit. Built by Jayavarman V it predates Angkor Wat by 100 years and without the ornate bas-reliefs of the larger temple.

Worth the visit!. Pair it with another site as it is a bit out of the way, but worth it. Small compared to everything else, but made up for by the intricacy of the carvings! Also it is included on the Angkor pass in terms of admission.

Exquisite and intricate. One of my favorite temples. The level of detail on the carvings blew my mind. Small and compact, this temple is carved to perfection. The longer you look at the lintels, the more you saw. Fascinating. Farther out than the other main sights. I would recommend combining with beng mealea and the landmine museum.
Pink Sandstone. A temple complex that is older than Angkor Wat itself.Visit this temple dedicated to the Lady, and see the exquisite carvings on something unique, pink sandstone!

Unbelievable history. we walked around with our guide absolutely fascinated at what he was explaining. It is amazing to think how old these places are. It was very hot when we were there but it is worth the effort to explore the history of what you are seeing. There are many steps encountered so you must be able to walk around but it was easy. Well worth a look

The artwork. One of the best temple in angkor wat! The carvings are well kept so you can see all the details. For a temple that is built in 9th century, I'd say they have great taste of art and detail. A must see! Sometimes I wonder which is greater the churches of italy or the temples of cambodia (when it comes to art).
Brilliant reliefs. The reliefs at Banteay Srei are apart from the one's at Angkor Wat the most beautiful and well preserved.

Absolutely top!. One need a car with driver to get there in a comfortable way; it's quite far by tuktuk. Certainly the most beautifull decorated temple of all. The carvings are sometimes 10 cmm deep and the arms and legs of some figures are even completely carved out, even at the backside. Also the model of the different small buildings is very elegant. TIP: vsit the temple late afternoon between 16:00 - 18:00; the light is super and almost NO other people aound. It's a disaster in the morning because all the big busses arrive at the same time; sometimes 30-40!

Simply the best. It may not be impressive at first site but the cravings are from far the best quality made and also in very good state for these very very old Hindu temple (more than 1000 years old) and we appreciate the little rope fences enabling everybody to take pictures without tourists everywhere!

Small temple...but worth it. It's a small temple, around 20-30 kms away from Siem Reap. Your tuktuk driver or car will charge extra money (our tuktuk driver charged 25 $) for going there. Its a small (comparatively with Angkor wat) temple . The redish dust makes the majestic carvings more beauiful... But, I feel, if you are satisfied to see Angkor wat,Angkor thom and Ta Prohm, you can miss this temple easily. It's not at all worth to go extra miles for this smallll temple.
Beautiful. It is a bit further away from the other temple attractions, but it is worth the trip. Our guide related the stories found on the murals and lintels, and it was fascinating.

Out of the way, but worth it!. This temple is quite a ways away from the main temples, but it was definitely worth the tuk-tuk trip! It's said to be one of the most intricate temples and it didn't disappoint!

the temples are amazing. Best visited early in the day ro take advantage of the cool. We used both an accredited tour guide and Tuk Tuk for places that were close. Found the Tuk Tuk drivers very good. Loved Pub St and the market
nice colours. incredible like all angkor temples. whats more, this one has amazing colours, not crowded, not very big

Small but definitely top three!. So it was worth the drive and I'd do it all over again. The carvings on this place are special and in really hard stone. Honestly for something 1000 odd years old you can still see the fine teeth that were carved into the tiny snakes up on the roof corners. The detail is quite exquisite and given it is so remote it feels a little bit special. What's interesting and sad all at the same time was our guide let us know they are yet to know where the stone came from... be it that given the land mines they are still yet to explore the local area. But if you've not watched the LiDar documentary on Angkor then do so and hopefully eventually they will be able to do similar surveying in this area to learn more. Worth the drive!

Rustic pink temple of ancient charm. I visited banteay srei as part of my whole day tour. The most unique part of the temple is the pinkish hue of the stone due to iron content. It's one of those Temples which have more detailed and exquisite carvings which Angkor wat doesn't have much of. Our tour guide told us srei means lady hence the name lady temple. It's a small compound but it's worth it to just see it as part of your trip to Cambodia.

Our favorite?. Asking about ones favorite temple is not easy to answer. We enjoyed this probably more than the big boys and was a toss up with Ta Prohm (Tomb Raider). Obviously, if you're going to Siem Reap, you'll visit Angkor Wat. Banteay Srei and Ta Prohm should be the next 2 on the list, especially if you're time limited. The detail and colors in this one are amazing.

Another amazing place. We went and visited this place with a guide. I found it more beautiful then some of the other temples we visited and according to our guide this temple complex is being often overlooked

Amazing but very far away!. We visited here as we read it was a must do whilst in the area. Very impressive extremely intricate design, absolutely beautiful but it is very far out of the way in my opinion. It took about 1 hour each way in a tuk tuk and I was almost templed out by that point. As it is quite small it gets extremely busy and people tend to crowd around and stand in the way so it's quite hard to see properly and take pictures. With hindsight I probably would give it a miss but I'm glad I saw it.

a gem in the forest . this is my favorite temple. its simply uniqu. yes it is far from the others but its worth it. we enjoyed our tuk tuk ride all the time. fresh air and perfect view. Same as what everyone in here is saying. this is a must see if your in Siem Reap.
A bit distance but must visit . Love how was built and it architecture at that time. The scripture on each place seems like someone is communicating with you.
a must!. After Angkor Wat and Bayong , Banteay Srey for for me must be seen.unforgettable for me.You will never forget that.

Beautiful carvings in pink. Also know as the Citadel of Women, the Banteay Srei is situated the farthest away among the temples of Angkor. The journey by car is roughly 45 minutes.This temple is the only temple made of pink sandstone. It also has the most intricate of carvings compared to the other temples. The buildings/ shrines have low doorways and small windows, another feature not seen at the other temples.Despite the long journey, it was worth my time to visit the beautiful pink temple.

Beautiful Temple. We hired a private guide and spent the day visiting Phnom Kulen National Park and Banteay Srie. This was the perfect combination for a day out of Siem Reap. The intricately carved "Lady Temple" was enhanced by the late day sun. Take the time to visit this gem.
Women Temple beautiful carvings!. Also known as the women temple, this is a must. Is really small compared to Angkor Wat or Angkor Thom, but the carvings are very detailed and beautiful.

Gorgeous gorgeous . I am a Hindu, have been raised in India and a very firm shiva believer. Architecture wise this is the most beautiful temple I have ever visited. This cannot be missed.
Beautiful carvings..
so cute. Even it looks a bit small but this temple appear by the pink color with in small style and the history was meaningful....

An Absolute Must!!!!!. The condition of this temple is the best in all of Angkor area. We were able to get in prior to the opening of the temple and escorted behind ropes to see the carvings up close. Absolute amazing panels and carvings.

Very beautiful, but only worth it if you've REALLY seen everything else.. Really enjoyed the TukTuk ride out there. It's far.You can't climb around on the ruins like you can on all the other ruins, so that was unexpected first us since that's what kept our kids' attention at all the other temples. It is gorgeous, but again, I'd only recommend it is you've done everything else or you're REALLY into Khmer art and history. Landmine museum on the way is worth a 15 minute stop.

Worth the Short Drive from Siem Reap. I had read about the Banteay Srie temple on Trip Advisor. It was on my "must see' list along with Angkor Wat because I wanted to see the intricate and detailed carvings that everyone was talking about. My first impression was that it was so small compared to all the other temples we had seen that day. Besides its diminutive size, it was remarkable because of its red color that our guide explained was due to the use of laterite stones used to build the temple. He further explained that laterite is often mistaken as basalt, or some type of volcanic rock, there are no volcanoes in Cambodia, so this isn't possible. Banter Srei is also called the "lady temple" because it is presumed that the carvings were done by women, not men, hence the level of detail in each of the carvings. The other plus to this temple is that the carvings have not been defaced or ruined as they have been in many of the other temples as the kingdom went through alternating periods of Hindu and Buddhist leaning leaders.

Uncrowded and well preserved. A 1 hour tuk tuk ride thru the Cambodian country side. Uncrowded and picturesque with intact intricate relief carvings. Worth the trip. As with ALL the temples...see this one BEFORE you see Angkor Wat. (All the other temples pale in comparison)...but if there was no Angkor Wat, each and every temple would be VERY impressive . Each temple is unique and distinct. Bring fluids, dress appropriately, follow the dress code and you will be awe struck!
Stunning pink temple!. By far the most intricately carved temple in all of the Angkor Wat complex, said to be carved by women. The stone is a subtle pink color, and very unique.

Intricate littel temple. Like most places in the area, Banteay Srei was annoyingly crowded with tourists. We had hoped that due to being a bit further out it wouldn't be, but I guess it's a fairly easy addition to the grand circuit, particularly if going by car rather than Tuk Tuk. It is definitely a worthwhile addition to your itinerary though, with beautiful and intricate carvings on the pink stone.

Abit far from Siem Reap but intricate design . Now writting this review after seeing all the temples in Siem Reap I feel it's fair to say this has the most intricate design and is well worth a visit but took nearly an hour to get there by tuktuk would recommend going to the land mine museum and butterfly sanctuary to break up the trip abit.
Fantastic Carving. Everything the guidebooks say and more. The carvings are so detailed you would think the stone was wood.
Lady Temple, Very Pretty in Pink. Another beautiful temple but this time in pink sandstone which makes it rather stunning. Also has sheltered areas with cafe, clean toilets and some souvenir shopping
Small but beautiful details. This sandstone temple, c. 25 kms from the main Angkor complex, is small but has amazing detail in its bas relief carvings. It's set in a tranquil location.

Tied for second best with Bayon. This is a small temple area but worth the 1 hour drive out of town. You see many interesting villages and people along the way. The temples seem to have less wear on the details of the sandstone. It is also a pink sandstone not found anywhere else and they do not know where it was quarried. I went in the afternoon and there were only a handful of tourists.

STUNNING! Details over Details. This is I think the most detailed and beautiful temple of all the archeological site at Siem Reap. It is far away, about 37km from Siem Reap. I did with a TukTuk and I would never do it again with a TukTuk. Spend some more money but take a car, it's too far away with a TukTuk and it's very uncomfortable ride. But the temple is well worth it, it's very small but totallly worth to be visited. So many details.
A must see . The temples are really unbelievable. I really enjoyed this temple as the flora around it is fascinating. While the crowds deter a little bit, it is worth seeing.
Ancient Hindu site. We arranged a special trip to Banteay Srei temple. It is an extraordinary site and has a very special religious significance to those of us who follow Hindu religion.

Banteay Srei visit. Everyone recommends Ta Prohm as the best smaller temple site after Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom but my view is that this site is hard to beat. So much extant archaeology and reliefs. You can still see how the environment has encroached and is currently managed and the beautiful pink stone. Definitely worth an hour or two out of your day to visit.

Often forgotten. This temple is about 30+ kilometres from the main part of Angkor wat. Because of this, there were no crowds and it was a great part of our day. We rode all the way out, going through many villages. The trip alone was an experience. This temple has a lot of intricate detail in the stonework which is a lot different to the others. The pink colour was also quite unique. Where it is very small, I still found it a beautiful and interesting place to visit. The survivors or land mines musicians who were performing were also a wonderful treat. Please buy their cd.
Small but beautiful. This temple it not big as other temple but carving was very very beautiful and color of stone was very nice than other we love it lots.

Detailed carvings, preserved for centuries!. The pink (more towards red) stone used in this Citadel of the Women is harder than in Angkor Wat and Bayon temples. Thus the carving is more detailed, even intricate. Not such big crowds, as this one is about 45K from the town. We traveled by tuk tuk, so saw lots of the countryside en route. Well set up for tourism, too. Clean bathrooms and nice gift shop. Even a Cambodian band selling CDs to complete the ambiance.
Anither. Great stop...different colour makes it a bit different....loved all the temples we visited...no disappointment!
Awesome. The most detailed carvings i have ever seen just an amazing piece of Cambodian history. Bring your water bottles, it's hot!

lady temple...beautiful in the morning. though it's quite far but this lady temple was worth a visit. It's so beautiful in the morning ;-) we visited this temple on our 2nd day (we got 3-days pass) early morning, before we visited smaller temples in Angkor.
