Banta Srei was pretty cool!. A must see! I loved this temple and it is a top 5 for me. You get to see architecture that is from the 12/13th Century, and that is very very cool. Most of these are in good condition, but work still needs to be done.

Small but noteworthy. We started our day of temple touring here. We hired a tuk tuk and an hour later arrived. It was a pleasant enough ride, seeing and smelling the local countryside was much more relaxing then a bus or car for us.The walk to the temple is shrouded with the usual hawkers. Including the local police who quietly came alongside offering to sell their insignia and police identification badge and being quite convincing in why I should buy them . We resisted but several others we saw succumbed to the pressure salesman in the local police . The visit to the temple is humbling to say the least . The intricacy of the carvings in what is a fairly small temple is unbelievable, especially noting it was made by females and so many centuries ago.It began raining as we started our tour of this temple which made it very frustrating trying to progress through with visitors huddling in the limited door ways and passageways sheltering from the rain. This temple is advertised as being especially pretty as the sun rises on it to capture the colours; we weren't that committed so didn't arrive at sunrise however pleased that we took the long journey out to see it and begin our Angkor Wat Temple visit. A word of caution, in addition to the pressure to buy everything and anything from the locals, I personally found this very confronting as it was my first contact with landmine victims who were performing as an orchestra as you leave the temple and Just up the road, a severely disfigured young lady approached me begging for money, obviously the victim of a fire or land mine blast and facially unrecognisable, but I'll live with the image and sound of her wailing for years to come.I mention this as several people I spoke to during the tour spoke of similarly graphic encounters that will haunt them because like me, they were not prepared to see this, nowhere is there warnings or guidance.

Bit far from town BUT worth for a visit!. It really is beautiful little temple in the middle of jungle located around 40 minutes by tuk tuk from Town. But I would recommend this if you're a temple lover, just go check this out!

One for temple junkies. The artwork, statues and engravings are exquisite. I was glad we took an air conditioned car because it was a 45 minute drive from Siem Reap, and it was quite hot in July. Go early in the morning to dodge the crowds. There is a restaurant and knick knack shop on site.

Excellent temple. Lots of temples in this part of the world, but this one is a standout. The different colors and the details in the stone are very impressive. Probably one of the most well preserved of the ancient Cambodian temples. Very impressive.

Pink Illusion?. Also known as the women's temple, it was said to have a pinkish appearance, but it didn't. :( I think it faded theough time...although its shade is a little bit diffrent fom the other temples' just. It was just small compared and you can wear anything unlike in Angkor Wat.

Do not miss this one!. Definitly worth the drive out. If you started early on the day this is a nice break and a nice drive out to Banteay Srei. It's small and way different than all of the other temples. The carvings are amazing. Do not skip this one!
Quite different than the rest of the temples. This "City of Women" temple is quite unique in its own way, very much different from the Angkor temples.
Not to be missed. This is not to be missed if you have the time. The detail still in the carvings is amazing and it gives you a look at a temple older than Angkor Wat.
Interesting. You will probably be tired by going to so many temples. Try not be beacuse they are all worth the effort.
far. a bit far but worth the distance... lots of butterflies and monkeys crossing the street going here..

A Visit to Angkor Wat Must Include Banteay Srei. Banteay Srei is the north, 10-15 km, smaller of the temple groups but has the most artistic and preserved carvings in sandstone that I have ever seen. Be sure to visit as soon as the grounds are open. They are heavily guarded. If you are alone the guards may allow you to go just beyond the roped areas. It was the last of a four day photographic guide tour and the very best and most memorable. Take time to look closely. My guide said that as many times he has visited each time he makes a new discovery.

Our Favorite of the trip!. By far our favorite temple we saw! The drive alone to get to the temple is worth it - beautfiul driving through villages and rice fields truly seeing how the locals live. Since the temple is off the beaten path, it was not crowded at all. It is a Hindu temple and one of the earliest ones built - it is truly unique in it's carvings and color. So glad that we decided to make the trek out there, again by far our favorite temple of the trip. In my opinion, it is a must see!!!

One of the Most Beautiful Temples I Have Seen!. This temple was one of the highlights of our trip - and my favorite temple in the Siem Reap area. It is slightly farther afield, but well worth the visit. It is the only pink sandstone temple and was awe inspiring to visit. I must say that this is my favorite of the many temples we saw during this trip - even considering the massive Angkor Wat itself! Carvings cover every inch of this temple and are done to perfection. The pink color of the stone, and the multi colored aging create highlights and depth that are incredible to see. The figures seem to come to life. This temple is very serene. I could have spent an entire day just soaking up the history and the calming atmosphere. The king who built this temple dedicated it to his mother, so this temple is one of the few honoring women. The detailed architecture is superb and worth seeing all on its own. I personally loved the monkey-like seated statues in the inner courtyard. Actually, I loved everything about this temple and recommend that everyone visiting Siem Reap be sure that this is on their list. Don't miss this beautiful treasure.
A must see!. The whole place is made from the sandstone obtained from Koulen mountain. Very beutiful scrupture which are very well defined.
Best temple!. This is the most beautiful temple I have ever been. The sandstone carvings are superbly detailed. One of the best temples!

Tiny Pink temple. This temple is situated around 30 km away from the main Angkor monument group. This is relatively a tiny temple. The construction of this temple, with pink sandstone, was completed in 967 AD and dedicated to Lord Shiva. Carvings are the main attraction of this temple and hailed as the "Jewel of Khmer Art".
One of the most interesting temples in terms of architecture. The entry area to this temple is very serene and beautiful. One of the most interesting temples in terms of its architecture.

Beautiful carvings. Banteay Srei is an utterly magical place and not to be missed if you are visiting Siem Reap. The quality of the intricate carvings which decorate this temple make a visit here a humbling experience. The carvings were crafted in situ and into very hard rock. They are extremely well preserved and full of beautiful detail.
Wrong time to visit. I heard there has been a bit of a drought here. The good news is that it is trivially easy to get to - the bad news is that without the water there is really nothing here to see.

DO NOT MISS!. Everyone goes to Siem Reap for Angkor Wat. However, we actually liked the other temples better! Banteay Srei is one of those that blew Angkor Wat away. Make sure you have a good guide to give you all of the insider details!

Exquisite Carvings. Don't miss this beautiful pink sandstone complex. Much smaller than the more famous Khmer temples, but perhaps more beautiful. The detailed carvings are just exquisite. This was my favorite of the Khmer temples.

Beautiful small temple, worth the trip from Siem Reap. Banteay Srei was my absolute favorite temple of all the temples we saw. It's further from Siem Reap than Angkor Wat and some of the other temples, but it's worth getting a car and driver for the day and combining it with other sights in the area (we paid $63 for a driver for the full day). You can go by tuk tuk ($20 for a full day), but a friend who chose that option ended up with a sore throat from all the dust.

Pretty, pink sandstone. This temple is known for the pink sandstone that it was made of and the intricate carvings and amazing spires. It is fairly small and very easy to walk around. The red dirt road leading up to it was neat too. Yes, it is a little farther than some of the other temples, but well worth the trip because it is so unique, quiet and serene. Just beautiful in the afternoon sunlight and makes for fantastic photos.

Out of the way, but well worth visiting. If you're staying in Siem Reap this rather small temple is definitely out of the way (around 50km outside of town), it is notable though for its use of pink sandstone and the incredibly well preserved and intricate carvings. It is the most well preserved in my opinion of the Khmer temples and is extremely stunning in person.
A must!. A little out of the way, but this is a temple that you cannot miss because of its elaborate details and intricate architecture.
Office outing in Seim reap. Pink sand stoned castle so amazing. The ruin castle and the surround pond are still preserved. Anyway a lot of tour group sometime noisy but the area still clean

Our Favorite!. One can easily become "templed" out when touring Angkor Wat and the surrounding sites but save time and energy for Banteay Srei. It is of a different colour, design, and height, compared to the other temples in the vicinity. It's the prettiest by far and makes for some great photos. Note: there are not stairs to climb at Banteay Srei - its relatively flat.

Unbelievable temple!. This temple is a bit far from the city. it took us for about 30 minutes from the hotel but we were not tired when we saw it. The sculture of the temple is amazing and absolutely unique. We cant imagine how hard works they made it. Strongly recommend the guests to visit and take photos of its sculture.
One of the finest examples of Khymer Classical temples. Temple with very detailed carvings and reliefs. Was very quiet when we were there given us a chance to appreciate beauty and the craftsmanship.

Far but worth it. Banteay Srei was not close to the other temples but its well worth the trip. For those on bikes I wouldn't recommend it because of distance and if you are fine with the distance you do use up a lot of time getting there. Grab a tuk-tuk instead.Renowned for its delicate carvings, it being said that woman must have done them because of how delicate they are. Because to this delicacy it is very different then the heavier looking and feeling temples. Its smaller on scale as well.The trip out there was well is a good way to see the Cambodian countryside and well worth the trip.

What an amazing Temple. So Pretty. Definately worth a visit.. This was such a beautiful temple to visit. It was only small, but stunning. The rose sandstone was beautiful. A real jewel. The details in the carvings were fascinating. We loved this place. Different to the other temples in so many ways. Well worth the visit.

Slightly More Unusual. This is quite a long way out. It took us about an hour to get there. Although a little more unusual than the other temples, it was smaller than I thought it would be. For the length of time to go there and back, if you only have a short time in Siem Reap, probably give it a miss as it would take a good 2-3 hours to get there and back.
Temple contrast. This temple is vastly different from any other I have visited due to the use of pink sandstone - this looks really amazing.

Well preserved. After visiting numerous temples around Siem Reap, the carvings and statues here in Banteay Srei can be considered as in the best condition. It is unique because of the reddish hue on the stones. This temple site is a bit far off Angkor Wat, but be sure to visit Kbal Spean as well.

Breathtaking!. This site is ~40 Kms away from Seam Reap (depending on where you are situated in Seam Reap). We took a Tuk-Tuk from the hotel to Bantaey Srei. It lasted approximately an hour. Very pleasant. The site is breathtaking and is a "must see" for anyone visiting Angkor Wat. It is much smaller is size. Each lintel-piece has a story to tell, and is exquisitely carved. It helps if you read-up about them before you get there. To see the whole site thoroughly you will need ~2 hours or so. We did not visit any of the neighboring fishing/boating sites. The Landmine Museum is on the way, but we decided not to stop by.

Beautiful Carvings. I guess everyone says the carvings at Banteay Srei are amazing, but they are. I really enjoyed walking around the different parts of the temple and just looking at the carvings. It is amazing artwork, and fun to explore.
Detailed intricate carvings. Visited this site as part of my 2x full day private tour with my highly recommended guide Pin Vannack & driver. It's not big but it's beautiful.
Very nice and interesting place. I really liked all the temples around Angkor Wat, and this was really the nicest one. Pay attention to the details, this place is really worth a visit.

Women Temple. known as women temple, said bcoz of the sculptures shapes that are nicely done, mini size, different from the other temples that have a big cut of stones and sculptures.
I very much enjoy the visit, this is also a must to go temple, although it's located quite far but it's totally worth the visit.

Serious Photographers Not Welcome, Police Solicitors. First, be prepared to be bombarded with child beggars. Yes, the urchins are at other temple sites, but seemingly more so here. But, it is not just the children. Once past the checkpoint I walked down the road towards the temple and 2 uniformed policemen started to approach me. I stopped and one took out a badge and 2 patches identical to the ones on his uniform. He said, "$10 for all three." I said no thank you, and started to walk away and he said, "OK...$8." Again, I politely said "no thank you" and continued to walk on. Another policeman also accosted me on the way out with the same scam.Now the bad news for serious photographers. This is the only temple in Siem Reap that I have been to that forbids "professional photography" without a permit. Professional photography means...no filters and no tripods, and possibly anything else that does not look like a point and shoot camera. It all started when I was outside the main temple area on a "grassy knoll." There were a total of 3 people; myself, another tourist, and a staff member. I set up my tripod positioned the camera for a wide exposure of the complex, then put on a "Big Stopper" for a long exposure to "hide people." When the filter went on the staff member came up to me and said I couldn't use it. I asked why and he said something about changing the color. I explained the purpose, took a picture and showed him that it didn't change the color. I took a few more shots and another staff member came up to me and said I couldn't use a tripod. I asked why and he told me there were too many people. I politely informed him that there were now only 4 people in a 10 meter perimeter of the tripod. But, he was adamant so I packed up and went to the info booth. Sure enough...there is a sign there that states "No professional camera equipment without a permit." But, nobody on site knows anything about the permit.I spent less than 1 hour at the site. The site is small, the buildings remind me a lot of My Son in Vietnam. Morning sun brings out the pink coloration in the buildings so get there early. Perhaps my experience jaded my rating. I would go here if I had time, but I wouldn't put it on a must see list.Actually, the trip to and from Banteay Srei was probably the best part. Lots of "local" photo ops along the way. I stopped the tuk tuk driver as we passed a field with a man plowing his field with oxen. I walked through the field and got several shots, then he even allowed me to give it a go and I plowed 2 rows for him...although not quite as straight. He and the driver had a good laugh.

10th Century Shiva temple possibly built by Tamil scupturists from Chola Empire. This is one that remains in my mind - with its intricate sculptures ... said to be build with sandstones - during Chola Era! The sculptures are really amazing!

Delicate and feminine temple. These carvings were amazing! The carvings at all the temples in Siem Reap are amazing, but these were super delicate and different from any other temple. Plus, the reddish tones of the buildings were also very different. Must-see!

Only recommended if you are really into temples.... Another group of ancient temples in Siem Reap, famous for their reddish pink walls. It is not as crowded as Angkor Wat and Ta Prom temples because it is located further away. Beautiful as they are, they are still not as iconic as the other 2. Only recommended if you are really into temples.
Lingas. this is were the lingasa are carved into rocks that are in the water...its an easy walk through the forest to get there
near by temple of Angkor Wat. take this temple to your 3 days temple ruin tour, not covered with the roots of the trees but yet nice to see

In the top 3 temples. This was definitely one of my favourite temples. The red sandstone was quite breathtaking. The carvings were absolutely exquisit! I could visit this temple again and again! It was disapoointing that the main part was barricaded off, but I would rather look from afar than damage these amazing monuments!

Great Khmer temple in the greater Siem Reap are. While most of the attention goes to the Angkor Wat temple itself, there are many other temples in the Siem Reap region which also deserve 'must see' status. Banter Srei is one of those.Although smaller in scale than many of the other temples, it is of a more refined nature and a nice complement to a visit to the region. It is also known for its colours which are nice indeed.Next to the small visitor center for the temple there is an open air restaurant which serves delicious Cambodian food at very reasonable prices. The Cambodian sweat curry dish was very good.This temple is a bit further away from Siem Reap than many of the other ones, but worth the trip. Have your guide add it to your itinerary, or for the more adventurous, just take the took-took for the trip.

mini sculptures. miniature sculptures were off this world, most of the temple is damaged and dissappeared, but what has remained is worth the trip, mind u think about taking a taxi, tuk-tuk takes ages and taxi takes u there from SR in 30 minutes, gives you time to stay longer and visit more during the day
A must se attraction. Stunning Temple and a very worthwhile visit. It's mind-blowing that Temples like this exist anywhere in the world.

Worth the visit. This temple is a bit out of the way but has the best carvings we saw. We combined the trip with a few other things out that way including a hike up a mountain to waterfalls at Kbal Spean. Worth the extra dollars!

Banteay Srei — "citadel of the women" or "citadel of beauty". Although Banteay Srei is out of the way it's definetly must visit 10th-century temple complex. The well-preserved relief carvings on the central buildings depict scenes from ancient Hindu tales. It is built of red sandstone and coloration is unique.

Quaint, intricate, and pink. While John Mellencamp's Little Pink Houses paints a lesser-seen view of the real people's America, Banteay Srei, with its unusual three tones of sandstone, delicate carvings, and smaller size, paints a colorful portrait of another, lesser-known side of the Khmer Empire. Being the only major temple at Angkor NOT built by a monarch, Banteay Srei stands in a unique position as the "jewel of Khmer art." If you'd like to know more about Banteay Srei's intricacies (and maybe even have your picture taken with some visiting monks), then don't forget to get a guide. I know a great one--perhaps the best: narinviptours@gmail.com; www.angkorbesttourguide.com.
You must go!. Amazing! Everyone needs to travel to Cambodia, to the jungle, to meet hess people and walk around these sacred and holy temples.
Best View in the evening. It is best to visits banteay srei in the evening (4pm local time). The sun rays will hit the temples and make it look amazingly beautiful.

Less crowed- read up before you go.. A Hindu god temple.About over 20 km from Seam Reap.Built from red sandstone, thus the temple is of orange in colour. The wall is elaborately decorated with fine carvings of figurines. Less crowed and a good place for photography. Easy to walk around as it is a small temple.Do not have to climb high stairs like other temples in the small circle.No tour guides around so it is good to read up about the place before you go.

I can't recommend this area highly enough. All the temples in this area are unique and wonderful. You can feel the history the second you walk in and there is such beauty at every turn. Highly recommend spending more than 3 days to really see the temples

Red palace. Small scale, but unlike many of the majority Angkor temples, it was built with red sandstone. The walls, columns, lintels and surfaces of buildings were almost completely carved, full of the Angkor period superb carving. This is quite a different experience to see a most splendid architectural sculpture, a colourful and charming hindu temple. Make sure you would not miss Banteay Srei.

The gem of a temp,e. Away from the temples within / close to seam Reap - this temple is nestled way from the town . Would advise a tuk tuk for this trip -instead of a taxi . The open til tul will allow you to breath the air rural Cambodia - the route from Seam reap to this temple covers several villages , shos of handicrafts. You can stop at any of the craft shops . Do not venture out too much - there is till a danger of the line mines which may still be active . See warning about it and take it seriously . Being at a distance from the town The temp,e is not too big or crowded unlike other temples. Beautiful temple brings devotion and admiration in heart of most who visit here .

Rough ride through the countryside. Approximately an hour by tuk-tuk from Siem Reap, and parts of the journey would be best described as bone-jarring. However, it is well-worth the hassle for those who seek a different kind of temple structure to the more famous Angkor complex.

Great detail without the crowds. It's quite a way away from Siem Reap, but if you're heading out to see the Landmine Museum (definitely worth it), it's only another few minutes out to Banteay Srei. It's a smaller temple, but the detail on the walls and arches is amazing. The red color of the brick is beautiful.The best thing about the temple is the lack of crowds, the distance is your friend as you have the chance to explore without being pushed around.

Pink Temple. Not to be missed, this small and relatively intact temple, in the original pink sandstone is quite something. Some original sanskrit script carving on the walls remain, as well as the many pictures and images. Worth getting there early before the crowds, as it is small. Great approach to it, along a small causeway.

'Women's Temple'. Well worth the drive out to this temple. Despite the cloudy day causing it's pink colour was more muted it's another lovely temple to visit. We combined it with Kbal Spean. Bring you swimmers as you can and need to cool off after a hot but relatively easy walk up hill to the lingas.
Worth the visit. An hr drive from Siem Reap, but worth the visit. Scenic beauty and feels so different from rest of the temples.
A charming small temple. This one is farther away than the most crowded ones (Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom/Bayon), but it's really a nice place to visit.
Far but worth it ... This place is another amazing temple in Siem Reap. It is located north of all the other temples and quite a trip to get there. BUT, if you love temples it is definitely worth it.

Longish drive but worth it. This is a petite temple but very beautiful. The carvings are exquisite and different to other temples. The grounds are surrounded by lakes (largely empty when we were there as th rains had not yet come). There's an excellent display describing the history of the site, including how it was rediscovered and restored and the architectural elements. We visited the temple first, then the display and then back to the temple again as we understood better what we were seeing. It's 37 kms from Siem Reap and included in the Angkor Wat pass, so don't forget your pass or you won't get in. The tourist police here were vey pushy trying to sell you bsdges (this happens at other tempkes as well). They also were quite aggressive about my hat. I had bouht a Vietnamese traditional hat at the start of tour and wore it everywhere without problems. Here, one of the tour guides from the site tried to snatch it from with me with no explanation except to say I couldn'twear a hat in the temple. As other tourists had hats on I thought this was another scam, so I continued on. Suddenly I had 2 policemen telling me to take off my hat. I tried to ask why but they just kept sayimg no hat. Eventually one said it was Vietnamese so I couldn't wear it. The penny then dropped about the significance of this hat. I felt mortified as I try hard to be respectful of other cultures. This was the first time the hat had been mentioned as an issue (by this time I had been through Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom without issues). Once they bothered to explain the issue, I stopped wearing the hat. So just beware around sensitivities on this.

Far but worth the trip. Also know as the lady temple. The art of this temple is very different fro the rest in Angkor. The detailing is amazing and is pretty well-preserved compare to others. Is a must-visit !

Lady in Pink. The temple made out of pink limestone. Ruins are in poor maintenance but the carvings are magnificent. Every carving tells a story of good over evil. Lots of stall owner trying to sell you things. Even the Police on site try to sell us his badge. A must see because of its special construction material

Serene Temple in Rice Fields. Banteay Srey Temple is unlike the other temples of Angkor. Nestled amidst rice fields 30 mins from Angkor Wat, it's a bit of a trek to get to, but well worth the effort.While driving to the temple, you'll get a glimpse of rural Cambodian life- something that is often overlooked in the Siem Reap-Angkor Wat bubble. Getting to the temple requires some walking, which is a nice change from the other temples where you can literally pull up in your tuk-tuk.The overall experience and orientation of Banteay Srey is totally different. I highly recommend it.

Banteay srie tour by tuktuk. Banteay Srie is famouse temples and remote area about 37 kms from Siem reap city and we went there by tuk-tuk about one hour by tuk-tuk.Funny, exciting and comfirtable trip.Www.angkortuktukdriver.net

Citadel of women. With many carvings of the ruins still in tact, this temple area was small but very pleasing to visit. Our guide told us this was his favourite, I guess that was because most of the carvings were of topless women!

One of the Best Temples. The temple has a redish hue to the stonework making it quite different to most of the temples. The amount of detail in the carvings is some of the best you will see. There has been quite a lost of restoration but there is still a lot of original detail. A definite must see. We combined this with a visit to Beng Mealeam another must see temple.

Further away temple, should be seen if on the way to Kbal Spean. A beautiful red coloured temple dedicated to Shiva, its a smaller temple on a larger ground area where you can walk around the trees and surrounding area, the temple wont take too long to exploreThey also have a market at the front of the temple which you can pass through and buy some souviners, be aware that the shop owners can be pushy and loud and sometimes rude here due to the amount of tourists that come through hereThis temple is on the way to Kbal Spean so what we did was go here first in the morning to try to miss any crowds and it worked really well, it never felt crowded at either attraction so I would suggest leaving and driving out here first and then Kbal Speal

Stunning… pity about the tour groups. An absolutely beautiful temple that was ruined for us by a busload of (nationality noted) tourists who were loud, pushy and disrespectful. Still definitely worth the trip out of Siem Reap to see this temple… so get there early, before the crowds.Visit the landmine museum and butterfly farm on the way back to Siem Reap for a truly great day.

Pink Delight. I would highly recommend this temple. Intricate designs in beautiful pinkish stone. Well worth a good 45 min to an hour with a competent tour guide. My family put this in our top 5 along side Ta Prohm, Bayon, Angkor Wat, and Beng Mealea.

Will flood of rain!. My last temple of the day after visiting Kbal Spean. Build in mid of 10th century by Rajendravarman is one of the oldest temple of Angkor. I met a huge rain during Kbal Spean and stop after my 1 hour. When I reach here there are slight flooding

Small but pretty temple. Temple is about 40 kms away from the main temples (Angkor Wat, Bayon, etc.) but it would be interesting to visit if you have the time. It is unique because of the very intricate sculpted pieces on red sandstone. The temples are smaller compared to others in the complex. It takes less than an hour to move around and casually examine the whole complex. The place isn't large at all. A tour here would cost a little more because of the distance.
Ancient Ruins -- a photographers paradise!. Beautiful beautiful full of history. Please be respectful and don't touch everything! Also, be respectful of other visitors around you...some are so pushy!

Well Preserved, Intricate, Worth the trip out.. The temple itself was significantly smaller compared to the rest of Angkor Temples but the carvings in the temple were small, intricate and one of a kind. It can combined with a trip to Kbal Spean (River of a Thousand Lingas) and the Landmine Museum. There are plenty of tours which come to visit the temple, to consider visiting at 4p.m. onwards to avoid the crowds.You will need the Angkor pass to enter the vicinity. The temple grounds are well organised with side attractions and there are proper toilets and stalls at the entrance to the grounds.
a completed route in Siem Reap. the sun shines reflection makes this historical sites looks marvelous too .get ready for photo shooting too. a satisfactory visit .

Long trip. It took me about 2 hours tuk tuk to and fro journey, start point from Angkor Wat. Try not to go on Tuk Tuk, as difficult to get any rest during the long journey. Worth to go thou, the Wat is different from the few others I visited, and its in a better condition.

Banteay Srei - a must see location in Siem Reap. This is a must see temple in Siem Reap, it's different to the others and awe inspiring the different colours and construction materials are beautiful.Stand at the top and look down into what would have been a busy place and try and imagine what it was like. You stand amongst the ruins of a wonderful time.
Beautiful pinkish color, elegant,. A jewel a bit far from the central Temples.The colour and the stone are a bit different from the rest. Worth the trip.

Just amazing!. Banteay Srei has been the most enjoyable of all temples I have been to in Cambodia. Perhaps because I just did not expect its beauty, perhaps because I have been so so so lucky not to have to share it with hordes of disrespectful, boisterous tourists and its peace got to my soul. Its carvings, its surrounding majestic nature made it just magical.

The Pink Palace. Well temple really. This place feels unique and different compared to the other Angkor temples. The pink sand stone gives it an otherworldly feel. It's a little removed from the rest but worth seeking out as it's truly a highlight and gem.
Lady temple. Far from town. From our hotel it was one hour by tuk Tuk. We passed some nice villages. Banteay Srei itself is small but adorable.

You definitely need a tour guide!. This place has lots of beautiful sculptures and you need to have a guide to understand the significance of each of the side. This place is not that big and most probably, you will spend less than 30 minutes.

Beautiful temple - well worth the drive . Beautiful smaller temple about 1 hour out from Angkor Wat. The temple has the most incredibly detailed carvings and decorations. We took an early morning tok tok to get to the temple by 9 (having seen another temple on the way). Could also take a taxi but thoroughly enjoyed the country side on the way out!

The journey is as good as the destination. We really loved the journey out to Banteay Srei. We hired a tuktuk for the day (30usd) for Banteay Srei/Bayon/Angkor Thom. It takes approx 1hour to get out there and its a great view. Worth it!!!Banteay Srei itself was lovely but wasn't a stand out for us. We did appreciate the information centre they had and the little shops around the place.All in all, great experience and would defff recommend.

A small temple an Hour from Angkor Wat. To be honest this was the least impressive temple I visited , only recently rescued from the jungle , some nice carvings and reliefs but small .The hour tuck tuck ride have plenty of chance to watch the Khmer way of life , though I did not do it think it would make sense to tag this trip with the butterfly farm

Incredibly beautiful. This temple is a little off the main route but it is well worth the drive. This was my favorite temple due to its incredible detail and pink colour. Highly recommend going to see it

beautiful pink temples. Visited this temple in the morning, on the way to kbal spean.Though, it was only around 8-9am, it was very hot and humid.Temples are beautiful, though one can’t visit right inside part of temple. Beautiful pink colour.Better to visit this around 7am, if you can wake up early.If you buy 3 days ticket at Angkor wat, the ticket to this temple is included. So the cost of ticket is worth it.It is worthwhile later proceeding to kbal spean.

An Awesome beauty of Hindi culture.. This one of the amazing temple in siem reap. We went to this temple in the evening after returning from Kulen mountain. Not much crowded at that time.A very nice place to take pics and explore the history. It's a lord shiva temple but the lord idol is not in the temple. A ruined beauty of hindu culture.
Beautifully made. Very intricate temple made by women's hands. A little out of the way but worth the extra few miles. The color of the stones used is pinkish. An amazing site!
The Pink Monument. Banteay Srei is located at one corner of Archaelogical Park and is a must see. Inform your tour guide in advance if you have just one day to explore.

Great Temple. Not my favorite temple, but still worth seeing! A hindu temple built representing 3 of the hindu gods. I think if you come here it is better to come with a guide so you understand more about the temple history. You can tell my it's structure that it is different from buddhist temples.
worth the trip!!. Please please go see this! It's the most detailed temple of all of the ones. You can't go to the temples and skip this one. You'll always remember it.
Worth the trip. Our driver on his remork did a great job and this smaller tranquil place was great to visit. The carvings were very ornate and there was an informative centre.

My personal favorite. There is no comparing one temple to another, but Banteay Srei will definitely have to be my personal favorite.
The red stone, the intricate stone carvings all add to give a feeling of extreme elegance. While it is a bit far out, the drive is worth it.
Plus, you can stop at the Landmine museum en route.

Far but worth it. Bantaey Srei is one temple a bit far from the main temples. But the carvings of the small temple were really intricate and the color of the rocks were beautiful. So sad that we were not able to fully look around because of the heavy rains.

the lady temple away from angkor wat. you will be awed and surprised how a temple away from angkor is built. the structures and art carvings of banteay srei were more detailed as compared to the other larger angkor temples.

Trust Maurice and make the effort. You might not think the slog out to Banteay Srei is worth it, especially if you haven't got time to spare. It is. We used the afternoon of our second day to go here and to Banteay Samre.Quite a lot of the temples are similar to each other but this is set apart from those by the intricacies of the carvings and the smaller scale of a temple that dates from 968.Our minds were settled by this little extract from a guide written in 1944 by Maurice Glaize, a member of the École française d'Extrême-Orient and conservator of Angkor from 1937 to 1945:"Given the very particular charm of Banteay Srei - its remarkable state of preservation and the excellence of a near perfect ornamental technique one should not hesitate, of all the monuments of the Angkor group, to give it the highest priority. Although, in our opinion, there is no gain in trying to classify the quite different monuments of Angkor Wat, Banteay Srei or the Bayon in order of merit - nevertheless, Banteay Srei is by popular consensus a “precious gem”, the “jewel of Khmer art”. This commendation, however, also carries with it the only justifiable criticism - which is that the work relates more closely to the art of the goldsmith or to carving in wood than to sculpture in stone."

hot..hot...hot. you will visit this area under hot sun. dun just simply ask any thing that you dun want to buy when you enter this area, the boy/girl who selling the souvenirs will follow you from beginning until the end....my bad experient
almost didnt go, glad we did. we almost didnt go here as a little out the way, but it was lovely to see the differnt colours of the reds and some really intricate carvings were really nice to see

The most intricate of all the Angkor temples. The level of detail in the Banteay Srei carvings is unbelievable. It's a little out of the way, being almost 2 hours from SR town by tuktuk but definitely worth a visit. There is a bit of a tourist welcome centre at the entrance of the site but it's manned by uninterested staff so it would be better to get your own guide from Siem Reap or at least have a guide book to tell you more about the temple's history and the carvings.Try coming here as early in the day as possible, there isn't much shade in the temple area and you'd want to spend time observing the carvings - which becomes sort of torturous in the midday heat.

Combine this tour a waterfall swim. An hour out of town this trip must be done in a car or 4x4. This temple is on one level only. Overgrown until recently. The pink colour of sandstone is a distinction.

A true and exceptional Jewel. This temple has the most refined, delicate carvings in the area. At times it looks like lace and embroidery on stone. The peculiar pink tones of the stone is an additional plus.Not as big or imposing as the other temples, it is nevertheless the most beautiful.
Beautiful. A stunning temple which like all of Cambodias temples take your breath away, a MUST visit on any bucket list.

A must do. Spent 3 days trying to see as much as possible around Angkor, this was one of my favourites.
Very well organised and laid out with informative displays on the original construction techniques, restoration etc. Felt much more like a European museum, whilst at the other temples you really need a book or guide to put things in context.
Quiet & Cool Spot. Very intricate carvings, cool site and off the beaten path a bit. A nice break from the rest of the tourists.

Mind blowing carving . My opinion, Banteay Srei has its stone deeply carved and it's beautiful too. This red stone temple was built in 8th century to 9th century. As known as Lady Temple. If you visit this place, don't forget to bring your fully charged camera. Ha ha.

Small and intimate site. After the huge scale of Angkor Wat, Banteay Srei is on a different scale. The carvings are magnificent and in very good condition generally and the temple is small with almost a family feeling about it

Wonderful Jungle Temple. I booked a Guided Bike Tour on February for a day in Angkor. It was really funny, enjoying Angkor temples in a small group of 5 guests from all over the world. We could rest during our visits to the amazing Jungle temples. Fantastic! Next day I came back to visit the area again with a motorbike!
Another Must See. Early or late. Avoid it between 11 AM and 4 PM. Too many people and too hot to really take time to appreciate it.
Currently very popular. Banteay Srey, 'Citadel of women'. Currently very popular. Well worth the extra effort to visit, maybe a stop off on the way to Phnom Kulen.
Apsaras. This temple has the finest example of apsara carvings. Definitely one of the best temples to visit but a little remote. Combine it with a visit to Kbal Spean.
Small Gem indeed. Good carvings and well preserved architecture. Although the restoration process is still ongoing, more work need to be done to bring out the best from this 'beautiful lady'...

2nd Most Beautiful Temple!. I really loved the Banteay Srei, almost my favourite temple in Siem Reap, asides Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat. Banteay Srei is also known as the ladies temple. The structures have engraved many delicate carvings that are minute and meticulous in detail. It's a beautiful one-storey temple worth exploring. There is also an interesting history behind this temple! Do find out from the tour guide!
as, solna. Well-worth visiting, fantastic buildings especially taking into consideration the building technique.
Worth a visit!. The temple was much less busy than the others probably because of the much longer drive from the city.

Beautiful Small temple. We visited this temple in the morning.It is a cute and very beautiful temple.The carvings are very fine depicting various mythological stories,and we feel as if we are looking to n Apsara,an attractive lady.Compared to other gigantic temples,this one easier to see ,walk around,and,you feel pleasant.One must watch this site.
Far nice temple. I can say this is the best carving temple among all temple in Siem Reap even Angkor Wat but this one is just small temple only.

I really love this temple for its structure and nature view. While this is a smaller temple it was built years before Angkor Wat and contains the best rock carvings we have seen. It is so entirely displayed how great and beautiful archtechture it is to be a combination of both Brahminism and Buddhism.

Nice drive. We took a tuk-tuk out to visit Banteay Srei temple. It was a nice long ride where you can see coconut and palm trees, fruit and Palm sugar selling along the road by locals. Lot of trees and nice scenery.
Wonderful temple. So beautiful and interesting. Well preserved and ancient. Lovely carvings and segments. worth a visit.

Ii love this temple. Endure/enjoy an hour rough tuktuk and keep the video rolling thru the village traffic. Stop at the Cambodian Landmine museum & donate generously! arrive at 5:03 pm sharp! have $2 handy for pink gargoyle monkey closeups

The Rose Temple and very beautiful.. A Hindu temple dedicated to Shiva, considered to be the jewel in the crown of Angkorian artisanship. It is cut from stone with a pinkish hue and includes some of the finest stone carving seen anywhere across the world. Therefore it is a very popular tourist attraction and you will be extremely lucky if you get to see it by yourself or with just a handful of other visitors. But regardless it is worth visiting and it lives up to everything a guide book throws at it. It takes about 45 minutes to get there from Siem Reap. Because of the distance your driver may require a bit of cash to cover costs. No more than $10. Depending upon your stamina my advice would be to visit Cambodia Landmine Museum, Banteay Srei and possible end with Bang Mealea or Banteay Samre. Get the furthest ones done in one sitting
So beautiful temple in Cambodia. It is a lady temple with beautiful carving. A unique temple which made of pink sand stone. Even though It is a bit far away from town, do not miss out. Great!!!
First temple. It was the first temple of our visit and was the begiining of an awesome experience, this temple is somewhat resored and is small but an amzing comples with beautiful vistas.
Amazing Pediments!. Take your time in looking at the temple's pediments. They are so well-carved. It might be better to hire a guide if you do not know a lot about Buddhism and/or Hinduism.
Gotgeous. Seeing the sandstone temple after the others, one can appreciate the colorful stones and the carvings. The detas were amazing

A gem in the country side!. Our hotel recommended to us to head out here. It was well worth it. Yes, it's smaller in size to the other temples but the detail in the pink sandstone is incredible. We got out there at 6.30am and were the first people there. We took a Tuk Tuk from our hotel and it took about an hour to get there but the country side is beautiful and it's nice to take it all in. It costs extra for a Tuk Tuk to go out there, prepare to pay 20-30$. The grounds are well kept, it's nice to walk around. They have boat rides available too - which we didn't do on our trip but the option is there. The only thing I would mention is that one of the police officers approached us and said we had to have a guide (this is not the case), he insisted that he be that guide and we pay him $5 US. We did not want to argue so just did it, he actually had a lot of great information but it was dodgy and forced. Don't let that deter you though, it's a beautiful place and worth the trip. We stopped in at the butterfly centre on the way back to town and it was lush and lovely. $4 entry and they show you the life cycle of the butterfly.

Worth the 37km ride out of town. Take a tuk-tuk and enjoy the bumpy, dusty ride here. There is a nice market that covers your souvenier needs as well as cold water, etc. The temple itself has the most intricate carvings and should be admired up close for this value. I enjoyed the local band at the back of the temple (purchased a CD to support them as well). The music certainly added to my visit experience.

Exquisite Banteay citadel. Bantay Srei is a smaller temple, exquisite detailed carvings. It was very crowded and the inner temple area is cordoned off so you cant walk among the buildings.Its a shame, you walk around the outer perimeter but you can view the temples adequately.

Worth going the distance. This is a beautiful temple. It is relatively small, but in a good state of preservation. It is situated a way out from Siem Reap, but I implore travellers to visit . An absolute gem.

Beautiful femenine carvings.. The carvings here are quite different to some of the other temples. Much more flowery and feminine especially over the doors.. Very beautiful. The sandstone is very red and this temple was built by the same people that build the Banteay Samre, a Hindu temple also of the same red sandstone.

relatively small temple site. This is tiny compared to the main Angkor site, Plus it is a a bit of a haul to go to it. I had set aside most of afternoon anticipating much more. Unless you have a couple of hours to simply burn, I would give this a skip.

Detailed carvings. Not as impressive as the Angkors but this is charming in so many little ways. The level of detail is really incredible. Absolutely worth going if you have a second day at Angkor Wat.

One of my favorite. Banteay Srey is one of my favorite temples of Siem Reap. Fantastically detailed carvings, and stones that are a lovely colour in the afternoon sunshine. Because of the stone used in it, the color and the carvings remains almost as they used to be.

A must visit!. Laying about 20km outside Siem Reap, your TukTuk driver will charge an extra fee to visit the "Lady Temple", do yourself a favour and pay the extra. In comparison to the grandeur of Angkor Wat, Banteay Srei is tiny. However the carvings are the most intricate of any to be found around Siem Reap, and many are in near pristine condition. That combined with the pink sandstone make this quite a sight. I've visit Siem Reap yearly, and my guide Navuth helps plan alternative itineraries to keep things interesting, and avoid temple burnout...yes it does happen:-) If you want an experienced TukTuk driver/guide who can arrange pretty much anything try Navuth. His website is angkordriverprivatetour.com

A hidden Wonder. By rights the carvings take ones breath away. Some 30 KM away from Siem Reap, this place is a must visit if you are in that area. Built in 967 by Yagnavaraha, a minister of Rajendraverman II. The Bass Relief carvings gave the name Banteay Srei - Castle of Women or better still Castle of Beauty. That it is beautiful is fact!

Beautiful temple but with restricted area!. Absolutly love this temple. It's well preserved and so many small beautiful details. It's a temple you have to visit. BUT!!!! They have closed off the inner section. You can't see the statues properly, you can see the wall decors and you can't see the inner shrine. I went here because it's famous for it details in its wall decor and that it's made really small. Now they've restricted almost the whole area. I know there are tourist wanting to touch the wall carvings and such but instead of destroying everybody's experience use the 5 guards doing nothing but relaxing in the shade outside and put them inside and open up the temples so we can see what we came for.

A gorgeous location and something a bit different. I took a day trip out to Banteay Srei via Tuk Tuk and was actually pleasantly surprised by the grounds and the visitor centre. I wish I went here first as it has quite a lot of info about all the temples in Siem Reap and some of their history and restoration info. The temple itself is quite run down but beautifully detailed. There is no shade so be aware of the hot May sun. Would recommend combining this visit with the Landmine Museum which is not far away

Early morning visit to Banteay Srei highly recommended.. We left Siem Reap at 6am on June 1 to visit Banteay Srei before the bus loads of other tourists arrived. We're still patting ourselves on the back because we arrived at 7.30am and there were only 3 other visitors there. The silence was very different from the buzz of noise from other temples we visited at other times. It was lovely to stroll in the cool of the morning and dawdle at the carvings and generally take time out to enjoy the atmosphere and antiquity of this magnificent temple. We also really enjoyed the Interpretation Centre with its informative photos and text about the history and restoration of the temple. A suggestion that may make the walk in the general surroundings more pleasant would be to make more regular rubbish pick-ups.

The most intricate handiwork. Banteay Srei seems small and unassuming when you approach it, but you soon realize that its one of the prettiest of the Cambodian temples. The stone decals and detailed artwork gives you a glimpse into Cambodia of yore. Beautiful.

Not really worth the drive out. After thinking about having seen the main attractions - Angkor Wat and friends, this temple is a bit of a letdown because the drive out by tuktuk which already takes about 45 minutes is not really worth it. People have raved about the intricacies but (I'm sorry) to me the other temples were similarly intricate. Perhaps what's so drawing about this place is that historians guess women built the temple, therefore the carvings are more detailed. I can't remember for sure but 45 minutes by tuktuk and eating dust didn't seem too good.
A lovely little temple in the complex. Lovely pink sandstone temple, but the continual stream of people makes it hard to stand back and appreciate the building. Worth some time and some camera space.

A work of art!. Probably my favourite of all the temples visited in Angkor. You probably may not be able to make it if you are having just a day or two to spare in Siem Reap, but it is well worth making the effort to get here. This is a temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, and the nuances are discernible even in the 1000 year old structure. The surrounding area has also been very well developed.

The pink temple!. This temple was about 30 minute drive from Siem Reap. We went there straight after having watched the sunset in Angkor Wat, and arrived there before the hordes, and were almost alone there. It has beautiful carvings, some very small and delicate. It has a pink hue, which has given it the nick name the pink temple.There are some souvenirs stalls by the entrance selling some nice pieces of handicrafts.

Something Special Though Not One of My Favourite Sites in Angkor. It is a bit far from the main attraction sites in Angkor. To be exact, it is 25 km north-east from the main group of Angkor temples. It is built with the red sandstone and the distinguished architecture that you will see will make you question and curious to know its history. If you wish to know more about the visit to Angkor Temples, please kindly check out @ http://www.heypt.com/#!Visiting-Siem-Reap-Angkor-Wat-Other-Temples-in-Angkor-Region/c1kiu/55688e3d0cf2adc1ad677703
Small Pink temple. Exquisite work of art. Looks like wood art than stone art. Worth visiting as different from the usual temples.

Unique temple. This one is different from the other. Eventhough it is far from the other temple. I'm having a back-ache riding motorbike from angkor. It took 30 min to get there. But its worth it. Its beautiful in the morning. With pink sandstone.

Colours. After the grey stones of the other temples of this region you get here and you find the warm colours of this finely carves temple. apsaras and monkeys.... a different emotion. A beautyfull experience even if less famous. Go there!!

More delicate than the rest. Hindi stone carvings with strikingly fine details, unlike the other temples which are charming for different reasons. Interesting red / pink sandstone used, perhaps more photogenic too.

Exquisite Art. The art work here is the very finest, the temple is small but can get very crowded with tour bus tourists. So go early and be sure to take lots of photos. We liked this temple the best of those we visited.

Smaller and on a more human scale. This is a little gem about thirty-five kilometers outside Siem Reap. A pleasant drive through the countryside brings you here in about three quarters of an hour. The result is to come upon a small temple filled with beautiful and ornate carvings. Not to be missed if you have the time.

Pink stone temple. Distance far from town and group of Angkor temple. Banteay Srei temple very beautiful palace of Khmer Cambodia. Just two hundred meter walk from parking lounge , there is many selection of local shop and restaurants. One in the world should visit when visit Siem Reap.

Another temple. After our first day of temple watching, I didn't expect that our second day would still be the same routine. I expected to see a different side of Cambodia. But don't worry, the temple was so beautiful. Smaller but the carvings were some what more ornate and detailed!

Locally known as the "women's temple". Because of the miniature sizes of the structures and carvings. Little bit away from Siem Reap proper; but worth the trip. Nice ride through the country side where you can see local cambodian lifestyle.

An hour away from the main temples of Angkor. If you have 3 days or more in Angkor then I'd recommend visiting this place. If not, then you'd better visit some of the temples on the main site... The greatest thing about going to visit Banteay Srei is the fact that you get out of the main touristy places, and get to see other lesser known temples on the way there (like Prea Kahn which is the best one) as well as get to see the Landmine museum if you have time.Banteay Srei is small, and is a hindu temple unlike some of the buddhist temples in Angkor. It features beautiful red stone carvings. It is still a very touristy attraction once you get there, so just beware there will be many visitors. Make sure to hire a good chauffeur to get there (it can be a dangerous ride otherwise).Overall, it's a different type of temple and well worth the ride if you get to see other attractions on the way there & back.

Elle Woods would have loved it.. Not going to lie - I was expecting more pink. For some reason I had fluro pink or at least baby pink expectations. I'm odd like that. This was a lovely temple though - intricate designs and architecture that has been well maintained (especially when compared to some of the abandoned temples). Just a lovely interlude on the trip.

A long way to go to see not much. First, consider the 37km ride out there; a trip by car costs about $45.00 (or so the hotel says). By tuk tuk is way cheaper but takes a lot longer on a road full of potholes and drivers who don't know their Highway Code. Not for the faint hearted. Because you'd have seen Baphon and Angkor Wat, you'd have looked at pictures of Banteay Srei and think it was the same scale. No, the buildings stand cheek by jowl with each other. You could see it all in half and hour and there's nothing much else around, just come rice fields, a garden, which during the dry season isn't up to much. It's probably still worth a visit if you're here many days. Oh,beware of the stores near the entrance. The first store on the left sold us a bad coconut and then refused to change it. Make sure you choose your own or go to another.

Breathtaking!!!!. What a Magnificent temple... Built of red sandstone this temple glistens in the sun like gems it is stunning all the detailed carving truly a work of art!!!! Don't miss this one!!! enjoy my friends :-)

The most artistic temple in the Angkor cluster. It is beautiful and very unique, not falling into the 'Indiana Jones' feel that some other temples have. Full of intricate carvings and almost like a doll-house temple, with very tiny doorways and miniature dimensions. Lovely red stone. Feels as if it was made to be kid friendly!A bit far off, so you travel 90 mins, but spend only 30 mins there since the complex is quite small.

The amazing temple with detail carving. Though it is smaller than other temples but it is unique as it is constructed with pink sand stone. It is harder and stronger.The premise is very green and nice. Love this place.

Excellent. Great group of ruins. Banteya Srei was one of the bigger places and about a 45 minute drive from the Angkor Wat area. They have restroom facilities on site and lots of vendors as well (similar to other temple areas). Overall, this one was impressive and worth a visit.

My favourite. Banteay Srei is my favourite of all. Although its a very ling tuk tuk drive away (around 1 hour) and it is petitie in comparison to the others, it is well worth it. I have been before. On this visit because it was after Chinese new year there bus loads of tourist and it was very busy. They had roped off sections where you could previously walk but I was happy about that as the amount of people going through would have caused damage climbing all over this intricate temple. Tip don't go to SR around Chinese NY. The start of the wet season is a great time to go. Cheaper hotels and less people.

worth it when combined with the landmine museum. We hit up banteay srei on our last day so we were a little 'templed out' by that stage but it was still very beautiful and something a bit different to the other temples we had seen over the previous days. It took about 50 mins by tuk tuk from siem reap to get there with a good glimse of rural cambodian life on the way. We arrived at about 10am and there werent too many people there at all, not too many big tour buses. We had an early lunch there and the food was very good but the menu price was inflated when we looked at it and when we got up to leave to go elsewhere they gave us a $2 discount off each item we ordered so i suggest employing this tactic.This temple is also the only one we found with reasonably good information boardswith info on the datesand people associated with the temple which was nice. This temple is included in the 3 day Angkor Pass.

A Small Gem. Much older and smaller than Angkor Wat, this was my favourite of all the ancient buildings we visited in the area. The exquisitely fine carvings, smaller scale and pink colouring gave this place a special charm. It also shows you how temples were built in earlier centuries, and has an excellent display with information explaining the history and the restoration.
Different from the others. Banteay Srei is worth the far ride. It's a 'temple' different from the rest because of the red stone/clay and the fine incravings.

Amazing tour. This was our 2nd day of all day touring of temples in Siem Reap. We saw Pre Rup, East Mebon, Ta Som, Preah Khan, Pra Dak Village and Banteay Srie, Banteay Srie (the pink temple) was our favorite. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable, but a little hard to understand. Our tour included 4 people total, so it was small which was nice. If we had more time, would recommend not doing back to back full day tours. We were a little "templed out" by the time it was over. We bought a book from a young vendor at one of the temple sites which was handy to read later to try to understand all that we had been told the last few days touring. So glad to have seen these unbelievable UNESCO sites!
One on the list. This is also one of the must do whilst at the Angkor complex. because of its distance it is recommended to keep aside a day and pick other places close bye to explore.

Intricately Beautiful. We travelled for about an hour with our tuk tuk driver to see this one, we stopped at Pre-Rup on the way here and the Cambodian Land Mine Museum on the way out - which I highly recommend to make the most of the trip. The carving are intricate, so well preserved and so beautiful in red sandstone. Definitely a must-see temple in Siem Reap

My favourite temple in the whole world. This temple is a bit out of the way, but it is so worth it to go there. It is small and mostly just ruins, but its beauty made me speechless. It was so beautiful, I thought I was going to cry when I looked at the detailed carving. It is really incredible.

Beautiful at sunset. This is one of the most well-preserved temples in the entire complex. We went late in the day and the light was beautiful. It was not nearly as crowded as the others closer in, but we definitely weren't alone.It is far (~30km). May be worth it to get a car hire. We went by tuk-tuk though and it's certainly doable.I'd recommend either early or late for this temple as so much of what makes it neat are the colors.

Better go there early!. Totally worth the 30km tuktuk drive! I've been there early (around 6h30-7h00am) and it was completely empty! no one to harass you for vending purpose, no other tourists...only the guard who's telling not to touch the carvings. With the sun in a proper angle, it reflect quite beautifully on the impressive carvings!

One of the oldest temple. A great trip over an amazing landscape and small villages to Banteay Srei. The "Lady Temple" is smaller but one of the oldest building in Angkor area. Beautifull fragile reliefs and statues. The place to visit!!!

A beautiful temple with incredible colours.. This temple is 50 kilometers from Siem Reap but so worthwhile. It also has a fascinating history. Again, make sure you have a guide to inform you of its incredible story.

Stunning sculptures in beautiful settting. Visitors to Siem Reap who want to see the most beautiful and magnificent temple sculptures need to travel to Banteay Srei. It is a small temple complex about 40 minute drive from the main Angkor Wat temple complex. The sculptures here are very detailed, intricate carvings in a beautiful reddish hue sandstone. The scale of this site is much more human than the massive Angkor complex. Photographers will have a wonderful time taking pictures of this sculptures. There is walking, but nothing like Angkor Wat.

Only if you have time. It was a beautiful complex, and a bit different than the others. It wasn't built by the royals, rather buy a wealthy landowner. The stone is pinker than the rest of the temples and is quite lovely. It does take quite a while to get there, though, and your driver will likely charge extra.
Beautiful carvings. This small temple has some of the most delicate carvings. Although inner circuit is closed to visitors its worth looking and seeing the guardian statues. Beautiful small place.

Don't bother unless you're mad on temples!. We included a visit to Banteay Srei in our day tour, but I hadn’t realised how far away it was. It took about 45 minutes by tuk tuk from Angkor Wat. I expected it to be empty when we arrived but it was a very commercial site with toilets, a visitors’ centre, etc. and a few coachloads of people had just arrived so it wasn’t a very pleasant experience. If I’d known I wouldn’t have bothered going there and would have finished the tour earlier (before the heat).

Georgeous Temple. Located outside of Ankor Wat, around 28 km, 60-75 minutes rides with tuk-tuk.Its free if you already buy the Ankor Pass.This is a very beautiful temple, orange-pink coloured and filled with georgeous and compilcated carving and bas-relief in all around the temple walls and most of it are still in gud shape.Definetely impresive.. Must visit.

Beautiful and special place filled with,. lightness and a temple dedicated to the Hindu God Shiva, well worth a visit. This temple is well preserved and includes carvings of male and female relief work. This temple is dated back to around AD 967.

Best small temple you must visit. Banteay Srei is a bit out of the way from Angkor Wat & Thom temples (about 25min by car) but its a must.My advice is please get a Tour guide or organise a tour as it is essential to understand the history to this amazing place. We used an excellent & best english (American accent) guide- Vannak (vannakguide@gmail.com), extremely knowledged.This tour was organised thru (the best) Odyssey Indochina Tours with a air conditioned car driver and guide- knowledge of history, language, customs and area including food. I would say this moated temple has the best carvings of patterns in stone than other temples. The colour of the rock is also different.This temple is a popular visit for many and has really good facilities and many stalls.

Small, quick and easy to see, great details!. By far the smallest temple that we visited, Banteay Srei or "Citadel of Women" was dedicated to the Hindu god, Shiva, and was the only temple in the Siem Reap area not built by a king (built 967 AD). It's intricate carvings in red sandstone are beautiful...amidst the enormity of most of the temples in the Angkor area, this is probably my favorite!

beautifully crafted. This is a bit far from city but worth a visit. its a complex of temples surrounded with a pond in front add its charm. u can take a boat ride which is situated on the back of temple.one can listen the traditiona khmer music there. nice place to buy souvenirs.

All Templed Out. This was a rather different temple. We had spent 2 days exploring many temples in oppressive heat and humidity so the third day we had our guide take us into the mountains. On the way back we stopped here but I was not that impressed.

Stunning!. The temple is around 45 minutes from Siem Reap but it is one of the most stunning. Even though it is one of the oldest, the carvings are genuinely stunning and some of the most detailed of all the temples you will see in Cambodia. I was blown away by the beauty of this temple.There are also very good facilities here; toilets, gift shop and a good restaurant.
Banteay Beauty. The intricate stone carvings and pink-ish color of the rocks are stunning. It's only a small temple but you'll get mesmerized taking photos.
Nice and very beautiful temple. The temple is nice and very beautiful, really worth the 37km travel from Siem Riep. Good time to visit is late afternoon to avoid crowds.

James Bun. Absolutely the jewel of the Khmer arts , very intricatedly carvings on the best quality of pink sandstones... highest craftsmanship of the Khmer people and their country. It is only 37 km north east of Angkor temple complex .. Very well worth to visit !
Worth the trip. It took us around 30-40mins to travel from Siem Reap to this place. Beautiful temple. It is not as crowded at those temples in the city.

Another great experiece. Each temple, although somehow similar, is so different from the other. Their meaning teaches you so much of the history of Cambodia and it people. I encourage evarybody to see as many as they can. Additionatlly, they are a work of art.
defintely a sight to see. even though i am asian the culture and the richness of the traditional cambodians is so different from mine. i definitely appreciated it

Stunning-Don't miss it!. Too many tourists vist Angkor Wat and perhaps a couple of other in town wats. You need to make an effort to get to Banteay Srei as it's just a little further out. If is absolutely worth the time and effort and you should plan your time in Siem Reap accordingly This is unquestionably the most beautiful of the sites with its delicate and intricate carvings, presumed to have been done by women because of the painstakingly delicate work. The color of the stone also makes this rosy complex unique and especially beautiful in varying lights. This place is magical for any one who takes their photography seriously or fully appreciates the labor involved in such fine carvings.
Nice. Went there during lunchtime, so not many people there, but not as impressive as the others. BUt still worth a visit!

My Favorite temple. This place is stunningly beautiful and not very crowded. It would be a must see on my list. It's called the pink temple for the color of the stones. There is no fee to get in. Be respectful. There are no guards. You can walk up and touch all the stones.

Small but of the most impressive temples in Siem Reap. it is a tiny, but really impressive temple, very well preserved, with amazingly carved and ornamented elements. The owner of our B&B told us that it was one of those rare temples that Pol Pot didn't find.
Our advise - watch for space monkeys inside the temple! (the ancient guardians to be precise!)

Must see. This temple belong to the bigger circuit, but it is worth visiting as is older than Angkor wat, so it gives you an idea on how it all started and eventually some style changes that will happen on the other temples

My favourite temple!. Simply loved the intricate carvings on the stone and the general layout of the temple.
Make sure you don't skip this temple!
So beautiful. Hard to pick a favourite out of all the amazing temples in Siem Reap but you have to put this one on the list. Just be prepared for the usual, children trying to sell souvenirs.

Little pink temple .. 1 hour trip from the group temple in Angkor area , this temple very interesting build and design .
Do not miss this place when you are in Siem Reap .

Just stunning. Banteay Srei was a pleasantly long drive from my guesthouse in Siem Reap. I enjoyed driving through the little villages and seeing the country side of Cambodia. And while the temple was much smaller than most at Angkor Wat, it was stunning. The carving were so beautiful and very feminine. This temple is a must for both itself and the drive.

A smaller, but still impressive, temple. We were told that it's know as the Women's Temple, not because it only allowed women but because the carvings were done by women. They're exquisitely detailed and of a different style than what you see at Angkor Wat.The scale of the temple is quite a bit smaller than the other temples nearby but it's still quite impressive.
easily one of my favorite temples. This temple is a bit further away from the main park, but it's definitely worth it. The colors are really vibrant and the carvings are the most intricate.

Gorgeous little gem. Banteay Srei is small - the smallest of the major temples in the Archeological Park - and one of the prettiest. The detail work is amazing and some of the carvings in the more protected areas look like they were done yesterday instead of more than 1,000 years ago. Try to get there early (around 7 AM) to beat the crowds and you will be rewarded with an almost private visit.

Wow!. The carvings are exquisitely preserved and a wonder to see up close. The colours of the stone are truly unique too. We visited when it was exceptionally hot so make sure you've got water as the shade is off to the sides of the temple site.

bit far out - but lovely detail. If you have done Angkor close to Siem Reap, Banteay Srei is next on the list. Take a car (about $35) it is too far for a moto-remork! The size is limited, but the finishing of the sandstone impressive. Do yourself a favour - STOP AT THE LANDMINE MUSEUM ON THE WAY! It is well worth it!

Picturesque!. Banteay Srei temple is also called the Citadel of Women or Beauty. The temple was built just before 1000 CE and is the only temple not built by a king. It’s dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva but later rededicated to Siva. It is believed to have been abandoned in the 14th Century and was rediscoverd in 1914. This led to a case of looting though some of the relics were returned. The site has been restored with the aid of the Swiss. It is surrounded by a moat which makes for some nice photo opportunities.
A little bit different to other Angkor temples. Built of red sandstone...very romantic somehow with miniature buildings (compared to other temples). Very nice decorative wall carvings.
Lovely temple. This was my favourite, a wonderful place to see and marvel at the building and surroundings. Lots of tourists but that is to be expected - enjoy the time there

The Reddest of Temples maybe?. Banteay Srei temple was founded in 967 AD and dedicated to Hindu god Shiva. I felt like it was not one of the most visited temples, but it has beautiful detail and the rock is of a reddish hue, which makes it interesting specially at sunset. It was different because it feels more homely, I guess.

The Red Femme's Temple - Banteay Srei. Don't make the mistake to expect a big stone complex like Bayon! This place is deliciously carved and the red stone made it very interesting experience! A lot of Buddhist / Indian allegories adorn this place, take all pictures you can!

The "red" temple. This is quite a distance out of Siem Reap but different in that the stone has a red hue. If you have time, we think it is worth seeing just as a comparison with the other larger places.

Untouched. Good to see temples that are less touched up for the tourists and still in its historical state. Must do it with a guide who explains the history. Went with Happy Angkor Tour - Private car with tour guide "Mr Em". Fantastic person!

Beautiful, but busy. This is a very popular, quite small temple about 30km from the main area. It's abou a 40 minute drive by car, over an hour by tuk tuk. It's extremely popular because of its fine details and pretty colour - a sort of pinkish hue. Unfortunately, there were busload after busload of tourists being pushed through (their guides made them go quite fast!) but if you just stand your ground there'll be periods of quiet between the buses when you can just enjoy the beauty. It's a 'one-way' temple due to the volume of tourists so if you want to walk around the outside of the moat (but still within the walls), do that before you enter the central part of the temple.

Amazing Temple. Our family & I visited Banteay Srei as part of our guided tour itinerary in Siem Reap. It is a 10th-century Cambodian temple in honour of the Hindu god Shiva. Banteay Srei is built largely of red sandstone whereby giving it the reddish colour. The temple have beautiful decorative wall carvings which are still observable today. This is one of the smaller temple in the Angkor. Another must-see attraction in Siem Reap.

Absolutely amazing. This is probably the most beautiful temple in the Angkor area. Although this is not big and a bit far away from the main attractions of Angkor Wat and Angkor Thome, it is well worth a visit. The stone carvings are extremely detailed and delicate. The best time to visit is in late afternoon when the red sandstone temple is glowing red with the setting sun. if you are visiting Siem Reap, you should see Angkor Wat and Angkor Thome first. But after that, you should find time to visit this breathtaking little temple.
Don't miss it!. Very different from the temples at Angkor Wat. Unique carvings, very well preserved. It is worth the extra drive.

Gorgeous pink Indian temple - a must see. This was so beautiful....go early to beat the heat and be prepared to use your elbows on the Chinese tourists who monopolize the views. I think I liked this the best of all the temples we saw in Cambodia...as it was smaller and more charming.
Amazing. All the temples you visit are amazing and to be able to walk around and see the detailed carvings and the sheer size will leave you speechless
My Favourite!. The amazing detail and uniqueness of this little, pink-hued gem make the longer ride worthwhile. I visited twice and could easily have enjoyed it still again.

Beautiful. This is a small temple which is only just being restored. The carvings are beautifully detailed. I went at 1530 so it was very hot but no crowds at all and got great photos with no other people in them
Worth a visit. Cannot get enough of temples. Fascinated with the history of each. Make sure you have a good guide to appreciate all that the temples offer.

Nice temple, little far out. I liked Banteay Srei. It's a nice temple and here especially the carvings are excellent compared the other temples. It is also known for the pinkish sandstone which is different from most of the other temples. If you are pressed for time I would consider skipping it. It is quite far out from the main sites and I found it not that special compared to the others (Bayon, Angkor Wat, etc.)

Beauty. Situated in the jungle, about 45 min. by car from Angkor Wat, this small pink sandstone temple is definitely worth seeing. It is one of the older temples. Amazing carvings. Very photogenic. It took us 40-50 min. to see it entirely. There were few people there at 1.00 p.m.

Made Angkor Wat look ordinary. I loved this temple. Although it is a bit out of town, it's worth seeing. Extraordinarily beautiful carvings. These women knew what they were doing and were true artists. The area is small, but can be easily combined on an outing with other temples.

Small, exquisite temple - worth the drive.. Loved this place. It's not as massively imposing as Angkor Wat, no doubt, but it's delicate and ethereal where Angkor Wat is majestic and impressive. It's sandstone sculptures are petite but exquisitely carved and of very pleasing proportions.As it is not as popular with the tourists as Angkor Wat, it is also refreshingly less crowded.It is much better organised and set out than at Angkor Wat.
