There is a visitor's center at the landscaped entrance as well as an area to buy cold drinks and snacks. Western toilets are available.Vendors of souvenirs have a dedicated open air plaza that you can visit. It is next to a paved car park.This site should be no problem for the elderly or for kids. There is not much walking and no steep stairs to climb.Highly recommended to visit. Especially in the early morning - the light makes the sandstone glow.

Small but worth the trip. Banteay Srei is a little further from Siem Reap than some of the other temples, but it is worth the trip; via car, too far for tuk tuk! The level of detail and preservation at this site is exquisite. Additionally, the entire facility had a more Western attraction feel with well designed placards explaining the history and meaning of the temple, clean bathrooms, food, and vendor areas.

Pink sandstone temple. This temple is situated around 30 km away from the main Angkor monument group. This is relatively a tiny temple. This temple's construction was got done by Yajnavaraha, who served as a counselor of King Jayavarman V and King Rajendravarman. It was completed in 967 AD and dedicated to Lord Shiva. The temple is constructed of pink sandstone. It consists of three primary towers. Detailed carvings are its most attraction. It is hailed as the "Jewel of Khmer Art".

A beautiful contrast. If you are looking for the soaring towers like Angkor Wat etc. don't go here however, if you want to see wonderful carving in great condition, different to anything you have seen elsewhere, go to the Pink Lady. Yes it is commercialised but all of that is away from the temple and does not intrude.Clean, calm and serene

Most beautiful carvings!. Though this temple is not as grandeur as Angkor Wat, it definitely has the most intricate carvings of all the Siem Ream temples. It is about a 45 minute drive out of the city and is covered by the 3 day pass. The best time to visit this temple is in the morning when the crowds are low. If you have 2-3 days in Siem Reap, this temple is a must-visit (along with Bayon and Angkor Wat).
Loved it. This is such a beautiful temple. It is only small in comparison to some of the others and gets very busy but it is well worth visiting. It is totally enchanting.

Temple with more intricate carvings. This temple is a bit special because its carvings a more intricate than most of those you will see at Angkor Wat or in the Angkor Thom area. On the other hand its scale is much smaller than either Angkor Wat or even Bayon. It is covered by the same ticket as Angkor Wat etc. but is some distance away - about 40 minutes from Siem Reap by car and much longer by Tuk Tuk. We visited on the way back from Phnom Kulen.

Our favourite!. Of the 14 temples we staggered around in the extreme humidity that is Cambodia.....this was our favourite. The intricate stonework was just stunning and quite different to all the others.

Stunning!. The carvings here are just mind blowing, the pink sandstaime has held the detail well over time, the intricate work looks as good as the day it was completed. It might be out of town but this was the highlight of our temple tours.

You should take binoculars.. This tourist spot is in a far place so that you have to go from the center of the town by car but I think it's better to go. When you see Oriental Mona Lisa, you should take binoculars.

The beautiful temples in pink sand stone.. We had to see Banteay Srei or our visit to Siem Reap would not be complete. Though it was not on our itinarary our tour organisers accepted our request.These temples reminded us of the Raja Rani temples in Bubhaneshwar, India. The architecture is much different then the one one saw at the Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and other temples in the complex.Shiva riding Nandi with Parvati, Gajantlaxmi, Garuda, and other deities took one back in the Puranas.The intricacy of the carvings, the finerty, detailing is worth looking at. These temples are relatively well preserved though sand stone wears much faster than granite.

Get there early to avoid the crowds. If you had a tuk tuk bring you to the sunrise and you want to go see Banteay Srei, once the sunrise is over, get them to take you straight there. Or try and get there for when it opens. It's great for pictures until the tour buses start rolling in. Since it's 30+km away from the main Angkor Wat grounds, it's a much smaller area here. Get there early to avoid the rush.

Small structures and beautiful carvings. This temple is constructed of red sandstone which gives it a different look from some of the other temples. Each small "house" is decorated with beautiful carvings. The site is not too large so it's easy to see all of it.
the Citadel of Women. A wonderful pink sandstone temple with spectacular carvings of men. This carvings are the oldest and most intricate of all the temples in Cambodia

Very well preserved carvings . Of all the historical places I went to in Siem Reap, this place has the most well preserved carvings. The carvings are still intricate after so many years.This is due to the red sandstone used which is harder than stones used in other places.

Captivated with this city women of temple!. its picturesque!the pictures we have is not enough to describe its beauty, it's beyond better to see it in person. very far from other temple but its worth it!
oldest temple. the oldest temple intricate carvings well preserved also having work done it dates back to 10th century worth the drive about 40mins away from Angkor Wat again included in entrance fee

One of my fave temples. It's a trek from Angor Wat and Angor Thom but definitely well worth the schlep. It's not too big of a temple but the detailed that went into building it - the engravings and inscriptions are amazing. It's amazing to see up close. It's also a good excuse to venture out to the country side and get away from hustle and bustle of Angor Thom.
Excellent. One of the best temple sites that you can visit while in Cambodia. Make sure to include this temple in your tour. Very peaceful, beautiful architecture!

Worth the short drive. It takes about a half hour drive to get here but you'll be glad you came. The temple is beautiful with intricate carving, much more detailed than the other temples (different type of stone used). Also saw some water buffalo close up and lots of Cambodian countryside and rural houses along the way.

Good for wandering on your own. You don't need a guide here- there are beautifully intricate carvings on the walls but if you have had a guide at any of the other temples you can interpret these for yourself. Its just a beautiful cute temple to explore. Now it also has a great natural area around back so you can walk around a really beautiful wetland. Good to stop at the landmine museum on the way as they are in the same direction.

Less-known gem. The Banteay Srey temple is several kilometres from Siem Reap, and is consequently less visited, though it is exquisite. It is one of the older temples , and is one of the only ones not constructed by the king. Because it is old the sandstone used in its construction is of better quality, and so it has kept the fantastically intricate carvings phenomenally well-preserved. The level of workmanship is truly astounding, and most of the carvings looks like they are only 100 years old not 1000! If your plans don't include a vista here while you're in Siem Reap, change them immediately

Out of the way but different . A female temple dedicated to Shiva, it had a totally different feel than any other temple I visited. The stone was different and the set up and decorations. You can tell it was a Hindu temple originally. Doesn't take long to go through but beware - no shade!

Small but very beautiful temple. This is one of the most beautiful temples in Siem Reap. Far from Siem Reap / Angkor area but still worth the visit. We hired a tuktuk outside our hostel and took almost an hour ride to this temple. The area is only small but man, the carvings were beautiful and very detailed. I think it's best to go there during the afternoon or earlier than usual before tourists flock the area. We were there during the Chinese new year weekend and there were a lot of people. :/ Still enjoyed the place tho.

Pretty in Pink... The Most Beautiful of All the Temples. Banteay Srei is a smaller temple but a true masterpiece inits own right. This was definitely the most beautiful temple amongst the ones we vistied. It is the oldest temple in the area, built around 960. The beauty of this 10th century temple is stunning with the red/pink sandstone so well preserved. The sunlight casts different hues against the pink stone giving it a youthful glow. This must be the most durable stone of all because the intricate artwork on the walls of this 1000 year old temple are so beautifully preserved. The entry way to the temple and the intricate carvings above all the doorways tell many stories about the different Gods. The carvings are so detailed that I wish I had days instead of hours to study them. The soft tones of the temple and the reflection from the pond in front definitely made this one of the most beautiful architectural ruins that we have ever seen.  The temple is dedicated to the Hindu God Shiva, also known as the "Great God" or "Supreme God". But the temple is also known as the citadel for women. The true greatness lies in the architectural femininity of the temple. It truly is pretty in pink and masterfully preserved.  We got to the temple at around 10:30. This was a great time before the afternoon sun and while most of the large tourist buses were still hanging around Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat temples. It would be a beautiful place for a picnic lunch because the setting is just so stunning. Mid day was lovely but I could imagine the color hues on the temple at sunrise of sunset would be magical. It doesn't matter what time of day you go to this place... just make sure you GO!

Beautiful Masterpiece. Banteay Srei was one of the temples we visited during our trip last April. It is a smaller complex versus the other temple complexes but it is one of the must see temples in Siem Reap. I love the beautiful color and the sculptures. If you are a photographer, this is a must as its pretty maintained. I was able to get some good shots. Since this is a popular temple, expect many tourists. It was hard to take some pictures as there were so many people. I would recommend going early or later. We went in the afternoon and the sun illuminates the beautiful color.
Such nice carvings!. Amongst the favorite temple on our tour in Siem Reap. I absolutely loved this place, so intricate and exceptional design.Must see!

Get there before 6.30 a.m.. Some of the best, smaller, more delicate carvings on lintels and walls. Red sandstone. Awash with buses with Koreans, Chinese (very loud in groups), and Vietnamese by 8 a.m. Earliest there best experience. Travel by local tuk-tuk and buy one of the two great guidebooks.

A beautiful temple. I love the red color of Banteay Srei. Though smaller in size, the red color makes it striking and fascinating. A good tour guide is necessary to better understand the history and architectural details of the temple.

fantastic place. it such a stunning temple with beautiful carving on each gallery wall along the walk way
i would recommend other traveler to explore this beautiful temple

Colours of Banteay Srei. Banteay Srei is a little further out of town than the local Temples of Angkor. The red colours intricate patterns make it worth the visit. Little market area at entrance good shopping and Cambodian souvenirs

Worth bearing the heat. In order to avoid the crowds, the guide again took us to the best sites at around lunch time today. Man, the sun was so strong! Needed to hide in the shade where available. The sculptures were so well preserved (in a relative term).Btw, I had a 4 years old DSLR camera and an Android phone. I ended up taking most of the photos with the phone for the HDR capability. If you don't know what HDR is, you need to know it before going to Angkor Wat. You need it, trust me!

Women Temple. This temple is dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva, so it is dedicated to women. All made in red sandStone, there are many sculptures carves in the sandstone. Very beautiful, a bit far from the others temples,

Loved it! So Awesome!. Worth a visit! Like the other temples in Siem Reap, Banteay Srei is stunning and awe inspiring! I couldn't stop taking photos, and you really feel like you are transported back in time. A trip that I will never forget!
woman power. If you have the time, visit it, it´s a longer drive, combinew with Kbal Spean and you will have an unforgettable day.

Serene, small scale temple with stunning carvings. A must see along with Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm and Angkor Thom, Banteay Srei was our personal favourite of the four. It is a smaller site but is much better preserved with exceptional and exquisite carvings. For their protection, access to the central structure is restricted. The site might be small but allow at least an hour. The temple is located over 30kms from the centre so you are best hiring a guide/driver or renting a car. The site understandably attracts tour buses so is best visited at dawn (or sunset) when you might be lucky enough to have the place to yourself – a really calming, serene almost spiritual experience; plus the rising/setting sun transforms the colours of the temple. Included in the price of the Angkor park ticket. Little walking needed/few steps and there are good facilities at site entrance.
Pink sandstone. this temple complex is small but very well,preserved and known as the 'ladies temple' as it was built for one and is made of pink sandstone , truely beautiful and well,worth seeing.

Worth the drive. not nearly as many groups here which is a relief. You have to run the gauntlet of really irritating hawkers and beggars, but once past them its a nice small temple in good condition to explore .

Pinkish delight. One of my fav 3 temples in Angkor archaeological park. The colour of the temple is kinda pinkish and the carvings here are one of the most impressive. Lots of tiny details... the locals say it must have been carved by women because of the fine details. Definitely worth to see, even if it is 25 km away from Siam reap. Maybe in combination with Banteay Samre and Kbal Spean (river of 1000 lingas) - which is on a mountain, a 45 min walk, we couldn't visit cause the tuk tuk broke down.There's no additional fee, you just need to have the Angkor park ticket.
The highlight. One travels to this corner of the world to see the old temples. They do not dissapoint, especially Banteay Srei.

Worth the drive. This area is a bit of artel, outside the main Siem Reap city. It is definitely worth the effort. There are several temple groups in the area and hopefully your tuk tuk driver will take you to them all. I was fortunate that there weren't too many groups so we had the temples to ourselves. I loved all the friezes, whether restored or not. It is hot climbing in the sun, but come on. It's an amazing place.

Fantastically restored 10th century temple. Banteay Srei (Citadel of Women) has buildings of the old Khmer style, but on a smaller scale, that does not leave you gasping at the enormity of it. This temple is a bit far off the beaten track, but has some of the finest carvings that we have seen in Cambodia.

Lovely temple. Also known as the Women's temple for its delicate sculptures and the lovely red color of its stone. This temple is located about 37 kms from the city so you need to rent a car or if going by tuk tuk its an hour away

Perfect at sunset. We visited at sunset when there were few other visitors. The effect of the setting sun transformed the colours of the temple and highlighted the fantastic carving on the walls.A bit further away than the rest of the temples but well worth the journey. Highly recommended.

this temples is interesting. got here around 9.30 am no one insight walk in and found 2 other peoples inside so yeah we have the whole temples to ourself its not as i expected but still worth the visit.
Should see if you have more time here. In Comparesion with Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, It is smaller, but it is different style - Highly recommend to visit if you have more time

Outside of Siem Reap and Worth the Trip. Strongly suggest you escape the crush of tourists at Angkor Wat and visit this jewel. The relief carving is much deeper than at Angkor, the stone is beautiful rose color, there are wonderful statues that are different from Angkor. Just outside the confines of the temple you can find walks that lead to boats for a float in the marsh. Quiet and different from inside Angkor.

One of the most beautiful and intricate small temples - A MUST SEE.. Most people visit the large temples when they visit Seim Reap, but the real treat is to go off the beaten path and visit the smaller and less crowded temples. Banteay Srei is about 20 minutes away from Angkor Wat and is a 10th centuryHindu temple dedicated to Shiva. It is built off red sandstone and has beautifulornate carvings. It is believed that because of the intricate and delicate elaborate carvings that it was built by women. Also because the temple is small it is called the "citadel of women". In addition to being beautiful and out of the way it is not very crowded. If you wait a few minutes the groups will get out of your way and you will be able to take great photo's. The sculptures of many female images also adds to the common belief that the temple was built by women. The temple had two libraries and was built of brick, laterite and sandstone. Above the ornate doorways were beautiful ornate carvings. Banteay Srei is a MUST SEE when visiting the Angkor Wat archaeological park.

Must Do.... Dedicated to the Hindu God Shiva this is the only temple not built by a Monarch.Adding to Khmer architecture - mythological subjects are pictorially depicted/carved in stone on all the walls of the enclosures.

Intricate details. This temple is a bit outside of Siem Reap - a good 35-45 minutes drive away. The drive was an experience in itself; going through the small villages seeing the local everyday life was very interesting compared to merely staying in the city center.The temple was perhaps the most beautifully preserve site we visited during our time in SR. Apparently the temple was discovered at a later stage and much covered by earth so a lot of the carvings have been amazingly preserved. Also the pink colored stone makes different from the other places we went to - It's not a very big temple, but worth the trip!

Small but lovely. The emphasis in this small temple is the finely detailed delicate carvings, supposedly done by women as men, with their bigger hands, would have lacked the sensitivity. Whether this is true, who knows, but the temple is certainly an interesting contrast to the other temples in the area. Very impressive.

Pink delight!. i loved this temple, it is delicate and serene and aptly deserves being dubbed the "lady temple." The pink sandstone is simply stunning and the carvings are well preserved. Lots of wonderful detail. Go at first light so you can have the place to yourself.

A must see temple. This temple is significantly smaller then the other major temples. It has alot less foot traffic then the other temples. Visiting this temple you get a more of a personal experience because it's less traveled.
Favorite of all the temples. Incedible carvings, not as many steps, further away but worth the trip. Pink sandstone temples really different. Exquisite, delicate carvings, I loved this one.
nice. This temple is a bit further out but in a great location , we went by car , well worth the visit , saw some country side as we went .

worth the extra miles. Known as the Lady Temple in modern times this temple was 'discovered' in 1914 by the French but our local guide said that the Cambodians had never lost it! The site is nearly 40km from Siem Reap but a very interesting drive through roadside villages. It is worth the extra effort but is quite small and will not take much more than an hour to explore. The carvings are amazing and the colour of the stone is different from the main Angkor sites being coloured pink through to red. Not so much walking required and there are good facilities and a shop at the entrance. If you have time don't miss it

Don't miss Banteay Srei. Angkor Wot has the overwhelming size, Banteay Srei has detail like no other. Definitely worth visiting. Welcome area is lovely, cleanish toilets, food & drinks available. The fresh pineapple and mango is cheap that locals are selling, don't bypass them. The guys selling guide books - go away!

Beautiful Sandstone Carvings. About a 30 minute drive from SR but well worth it in my opinion. The carvings are made on a unique blend of red sandstone, volcano rock and soapstone. Ancient Sanskrit writings and the structure of the temple tell a story of the 5 world - Hell, Earth, Water, God, and Heaven and the temple is built to reflect that . Beautiful for photography nuts and history buffs. And the lok lak (national specialty) at the temple restaurant outside the grounds is delicious so that's a plus!

Beautiful temple complex; unique colors and photos there. I loved this temple because of the unique color of the stones used to build it. It is a smaller temple complex than some of the others but the photos were absolutely beautiful and it was less crowded. Highly recommended because of the size and unique views across the moat.

Best carvings.. Maybe the best temple for seeing intricate carvings in my opinion and the stones are different in that they are a red colour. Something to be aware of at most of these temple sites is the children trying to sell you postcards / fridge magnets / bananas and other goods mostly for $1.

Bantey Srei - something different. CBantey Srei is bit far from SR, but worth visiting. The sand stone used , is red 'ish. It must be also bit harder, since the reliefs and carvings are so well remained.

Intricate carvings. One of the best, small though it is. Loved the tuktuk ride out to this temple as well because it went through numerous villages and we could see how the people were living their lives.

Jewl of Angkor.. Many people think that Angkor Wat and Bayon are the only bigges attraction in Siam Reap. No doubt they are, but missing Banteay Srei would be a HUGE loss. It is AS GOOD AS any other architecture in that place. Constructed at the same time with detailed and intricate carving is just unbelievable. Its is a MUST see place when visiting Siem Reap.

Excellent carvings. Built in the 9th century with red sandstone. This is a temple dedicated to Vishnu, Bhrama and Shiva - the hindu gods forming the holy trinity. The temple is smaller than the others in the Angkor Wat complex and farther from Siem Reap - takes about 30 mins one way. It is worth the visit because the carvings are very intricate and beautiful.

Carvings make this Temple special. Banteay Srei is a little further out but well worth the trip. Only a small site in comparison to some of the others but the carvings and details make this site. Many of the carvings above doors and on the walls are in perfect condition and the quality and details can not fail to impress. Easy to walk around the site and get some great photos, the buildings are in good condition for a ruin, and the site is well organized.
Beauty epitomised. This temple is a short drive away but do not miss it. It is small but absolutely stunning. Red sandstone, intricate carvings and a refined style.

A long trip in a tuk tuk!. took about an hour each way... Take a car or tour if you can... We really liked the simplicity of this temple...easy to get around....fabulous detail in the carving...well worth the long trip!

Bad experience. We were looking forward to visiting this beautiful historic site with its intricate carvings . we did the early morning tour as you get less crowds, However, after paying so much for a guided tour we were not allowed into the main shrine because of construction. We were told that if we paid the on duty police $5 a person we could enter the main temple. I was disgusted and took some photos of the so called cops. I wish the tour operators had told us the place was closed for restorations.

Beautiful temple carvings. Much more intricate carvings compared to the other temples in the archaeological park. Further out from the other temples, but well worth making the effort for a visit, especially if you have already got the 2-3 day pass. The visitor complex is more organised than the others. Could also stop by the land mine museum and butterfly complex on the way, as well as stop by to visit the local artisan stalls along the road.

lovely temple. All though it is 37 km from the Siem Reap, this temple definitely worths to go. And I would recommend you to go in the morning, as even though there are less tourists in the afternoon, the sun can destroy your photos.

Tranquil temple. This is a wonderful place to visit for heritage lovers. The shrine has detailed rock cut iconography which depicts Cambodia's Hindu past. A short drive out of Siem Reap, this place gets fewer visitors than the Angkor complex. It is best photographed in the morning when sunlight falls on the temple front, making the rock cuts virtually glow in the fresh light.

Beautiful Place. Banteay Srei is a beautiful setting and surrounding. But crowded too much sometime and its spoil the beauty. The temple show the best beauty around 2pm but if you want to feel more of temple and nature, morning time is less visitors.

Worth the drive. We went out first thing in the morning and were happy we had done so. It was getting very crowded by the time we were ready to leave. It is a small temple area, but with excellent interpretation panels at the entrance.I would recommend going to the end near the parking lot first as there is an excellent interpretation area there as well which describes some of the lintel carvings you will see. It would be been better to go through this area before going to the temple area. Just to clarify, there is an small interpretive area at the front entrance and a second at the end of the visit near the parking lot and shops. Go to this second interpretive area BEFORE you tour, especially if you are touring without a guide.

Bit of a drive, but well worth it. This temple was a bit of a drive, but if you read up on history, it is an important one to visit and see. The grounds are well maintained, with shops at the parking lot which is about 150m away from the temple. Try to visit earlier in the morning to avoid the crowds and the sun and also to do some boating and fishing.Don't forget though that this also requires the temple pass - so don't throw that away before visiting this temple.

Delicate. I had seen this Tempe on a previous trip but was probably too overwhelmed to distinguish it from the others. It is a overly delicate place with the best and most intricate carving across the whole Angkor site. Compared to the carving on more recent temples in Siem Reap it was brilliant.

A dash of red in the Khmer jungle. One of the few Angkor temples that doesn't involve many steps, Banteay Srei makes up for the lack of the height with an amazing colour palette of reddish orange stone that looks a bit like basic brick, but with much more detail and scale. It's nowhere the size of some of the other temples, but Banteay Srei offers a deluge of intricate details, featuring reliefs of gods and demons, with plenty of murals, all nestle in the middle of a tropical meadow.It is definitely worth a visit, but prepare to make an effort. It is one of the farthest sites from the main city of Siem Reap - about 45 minutes even inside a car. Also, because of its relatively low scale, there isn't much shade, so come prepare with covering.

The best of all!!. I really loved to visit this Hindu Temple in particular because it has more detail and elaborated carvings in the red sand stone. It is believed that because the reliefs are so delicate that only the hand of women cut do it. Probably is the reason for its name "City of Women" It is also in an amazing state of preservation considering that was built in the 10th century.

Out of the way but worth a visit. Combine this temple with other activities such as kbal spean because it is quite a distance from the main temple site however it is worth the trip. Very small temple but contains the most intricate carvings that we saw. Nice colourings too.

Sivan Temple. This temple was built for the Hindu God Sivan surrounded by forest and located on the outskirts of Siem Reap.The major material used for the building is red brick sandstone.This temple was built on a smaller scale but has one of the most intricate designs and sculpures. Most part of the walls are sculptured with statues of deities.The inner temple is guarded by statues of Hindu god Hanuman.This temple is a wonderful place to visit and never to miss from your itenaries.There are lots of places to take memorable shots by movie cameras.

My favourite. Our driver Phalit had suggested this temple, we had it on our reserve list and it's probably my favourite, it's small compared to Angkor Wat, but beautiful, at Phalit's suggestion we got there early and beat the crowds.

More personal than Angkor Wat. Built with warm caramel-colored stone, this temple is lovely and accessible. The carvings are intricate and easy to view as the temple is less crowded than Angkor Wat and others. Our guide Meung Chongsan from Odyssey Tours was knowledgeable, kind, and flexible in arranging the tour to fit our needs. He also spoke very clear English. I found this site to be a authentic place of worship or contemplation.

different than the others - more beautiful than most: do not miss. the red color combined with the different architecture compared to the other temples of ankor ist really beautiful. so even if you think you have seen enough temples: you have not until you saw this one.although it is a longer way from siem reap it it certainly worth the trip! you should not miss it!there are also lot's of clothing stalls nearby if you want to bring a gift.
Impressive. The citadel of women. 10th century temple that dedicated to Hindu god. The carvings are very detailed and impressive!

Smaller, but Lovely. Smaller, but the carvings are intricate and beautiful. Well worth the visit. Our guide was excellent giving us the history here. So many temples to see, and this one is just as beautiful as any. Hat, sunglasses, and water are a must!
Far away Temple. This one is far away from the Angkor Wat - its like an hour away! This is like a big park park with restos and museums.

small yet special and impressive. This small temple with the well preserved women figures, decorations, and the ievitable pond, serving today as a wonderful reflection point is something you should not miss. We enjoyed it a lot.

More detail than the others.. This is a smaller temple complex that we were told was built by someone wealthy, rather than one of the Kings.Red sandstone was used , which was more expensive , but the stone is much harder than the grey used in the other temples. Therefore, it has maintained more of its details. A truly beautiful place.

Incredible stone carvings. The carving on this temple is the best of the 12 temples we visited whilst in Siem Reap. They call it the women's temple because it is said only women could have done such delicate stone carving... who knows.

Called the "woman temple" because it is diminutive and exuisitely carved.. This small temple has exquisite carvings in pink sandstone. It is about an hour away from Siem Reap and we enjoyed the glimpses of the countryside, palm trees, and cows. The pink sandstone is hard and has not weathered as much and that makes the carving details stand out. I think pictures would be best here early to mid morning and late afternoon. This temple is worth a good look!

Banteay Srei- Exquisite site. This temple is worth a visit. The detail and colours of the stones are absolutely amazing. It is a smaller area and can be easily accessed without as many higher level buildings. The carvings are really beautiful...

A real "gem"!. Banteay Srei temple was the greatest surprise of our 3 days visit in Siem Reap. Surrouned by light green rice fields, with its delicate and very well preserved towers fully covered by astonishing carvings, each telling a different legend, this temple is simply gorgeous and should not been missed.

Simply spectacular. You must get there around 07:30 latest if you want to capture the beauty of the site.
After 08:00 the hoards of buses arrive and you cannot experience the magnificence of the site.
It is 30 minutes from Siem Reap but really worth it.

Definitely worth visiting. This is not close to the main temples, is on a smaller scale but is certainly worth a visit. It was much quieter so allowed you explore in relative peace!
About an hour away by tuk tuk, but this gives you a chance to see the country away from the main tourist area.

Exquisite Carving. The temple was clothed with dark pink color under sunshine and the carvings were so unique and exquisite. It's a mystery while this temple was done so differently than all the other ones. But anyway, a very different one and worth stopping by.
Beautiful!. It needs an hour tuc-tuc drive each way to reach this beautiful temple, but it worths all the effort. A small but fine temple.

Great carvings and lovely colours. Went for sunrise and only had to share the site with one other couple. Beautiful carvings and rock colours. Small temple but still worth visiting. Included in usual temple pass.

Exquisite carvings-too many people. If it had been empty this would likely have been the favorite temple in Angkor, but the crowds made it more like the metro nearing rush hour. this temple is relatively small and over attended. That makes it difficult to actually enjoy the magnificent carvings. While it is organized well and the flow is controlled to go in one direction, that only marginally mitigates the chaos. If I were doing it again, I would try to arrive at the time it opens to try to avoid the crowd. Regardless on a trip to Angkor it should not be missed. Admission is included with Angkor pass.

Top 3 Temples. We spent 4 days in Siem Reap and saw just about every temple (well at least the ones on the map). Rather than reviewing all of them, I decided to just review my top 3, and Banteay Srei was one of them. The colors of this temple were really pretty and contrasted perfectly! This one is being renovated so it gives you a bit of a more "complete" view of what it once looked like. Check this one out for sure (but see as many as you can!)

I was not particularly impressed by the Temple. Firstly, our guide told us that most of the temple has been restored however there are huge parts of it that are still broken down. The carvings are intricate and the pink stone is different however for the price to drive out with a car to see this I did not think that it was worth it. There were bus loads of tourists trying to take pictures and making a noise so the whole effect of the temple was lost on us.

A little jewel. The best little temple we have visited. It is better to go early in the morning - maybe after a sunrise trip- to avoid the crowd and fully appreciate the intricate details of the place.

What a gem. After visiting the large monumental architecture of Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, going to this "ladies" temple miniature scale, is by no means a let down. Indeed, the intricate carving of the temples, arches, monkeys etc is more than just worth a visit, it should be a destination unto itself. Don't miss this charming place, get there early so you can appreciate it without the crowds.

Most intricate carving works. This so called 'ladies temple' stands out for the very intricate stone carving works. The door frames are magnificent. There are a bunch of lady statues, one allegedly the 'Mona Lisa' of the east (could not find it). You can't get to close to the center, as it is cordoned off.

Smaller temple with the best carvings. This small temple is older than Anngkor Wat with probably the best relief carvings, which are mostly intact and in good condition. Further away from the main temples on the one day tour, this is a lot less crowded and you can hang back a little if a tour party arrives without another tour following right behind and so get a quite visit. This together with the carvings and location make this temple my favourite small temple.
Good Khmer Food. It is good khmer food restaurant that I had in air conditioning room,I would recommend to every body if you like to try khmer food.

Beautiful cravings but too many tourists. The craving on the stones are amazingly dedicated and well preserved . Worth to spend around sometime on travelling to visit this temple . My experience there was not perfect thou since I was surrounded by hundreds of tourists during my visit ..... @@

Visit at end of day. We had visited Angkor Wat and the temple in the jungle before visiting this spectacular jewel of a temple. I'm glad our tour guide insisted because it was late in the day and I was worn out.Visiting it in late afternoon is a must! The light highlights the exquisite carvings. Don't miss it during your visit to Siem Reap!

A beautiful site, best seen in late afternoon sun. A wonderful temple site, we arrived late afternoon when the crowds had dissolved a bit, so it was quiet. The sun was quite low so the light on the sandstone was lovely to show off the carvings. It's quite a way out from Siem Reap, but worth the visit, especially if you haven't seen any surrounding countryside. Need about one hour here.

The Best Temple!. Do this with a tour guide! The carvings at Banteay Srie have fascinating stories to tell. This was definitely one of my top three temples, the carvings are better preserved and far more detailed than most of the temples and whilst they aren't as grand as the Angkor Wat carvings I found them much more interesting. Worth the trip out of the main temple area.

Unique Temple within the Angkor area. We are a family of 3 (2 adults and a 10 year old kid). We got an overall of 5 days in the Angkor Archeological Part.First of all, be ready for a very warm and humid weather and second be ready for many steps up and down.This is a “little” temple with much less people than the “must do”. The temple itself is unique in Angkor and completely different than all the others. The pink stone makes it special and the quality of the carvings is exceptional.It is the same ticket from Angkor that costs USD 20 for a single day or USD 40 for 3 days, so you don't need to buy anything else.it is a little further from Siem Reap, nevertheless it worth the time to visit.

Banteay Srei or Banteay Srey. This beautiful red sandstone temple was dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva. Located in the area of Angkor in Cambodia. It has elaborate decorative wall carvings and not as large as the other Temples, but very beautiful. It is a must see and the "precious gem", or "jewel of Khmer art".

The most beautiful of all the temples. This stunning teme situTed over 20kms from Angkor Wat is an absolute gem just waiting to be "discovered".....easy to navigate due to its small size it is nevertheless a very worthwhile temple to visit. We went fairly late in the afternoon - in between the crowds leaving & closing time for the temple & we had the place almost to ourselves. Almost every part is accessible & the whole structure is extremely photogenic. The carvings on the stones are still virtually intact after over 1,000 years & are marvelous

Literally in the middle of the forest.. Literally in the middle of the forest. If you look past the stalls that set up camp before you see the temple, it will make you wonder how they created this temple. It was in the middle of nowhere and the impressive carvings on the red rocks add to the awe.

40mins from centre by tuktuk. On the advice of our hotel, this was a great temple to visit early in the morning, and so we arranged to leave by tuktuk at 6am.The journey there was pleasant, and we loved watching all the school kids cycling to school - which must've been miles away!We were the first people to arrive at the temple that day, with another couple not far behind us, and, whilst we enjoyed how quiet it was, it wasn't exactly enthralling.Don't get me wrong, it was impressive, we just weren't sure it was worth sacrificing getting to another temple super early, and felt our time could've been spent better elsewhere.We spent about an hour here, and kids (not the ones going to school) started to arrive trying to sell us postcards; and upon leaving about 20 or so tourists arrived in a mini-van - the first of many!

Beautiful Color!. This temple is famously known as the 'pink temple' and I was not sure what to expect - certainly not the bright orange hue that we encountered!! The color is really vibrant. The carvings are amazing. Look for the frames where you can photograph yourself. You can click the entire day away, and still wish for more.

A gem among the wats. This is an often overlooked war, but in my estimation, it is the best. The sandstone carvings are sensational, the colours on the walls are pink and blue, the monkeys guarding the temple are extraordinary, and the trees growing out of the rock, exceptional. Don't miss this one!

One of the best temples. Angkor is impressive no doubt but this temple although small has some of the most beautiful carvings and was our favourite of the tour. It's worth spending gate time to go and see.
The most beautiful temple. I never been visited the beautiful temple as Banteay Srei. This temple has the best view to visit and is the best place for photography.
My favourite. This place a bit far fro Siem Reap but it's definitely worth to be visited. Different style and size compared to Angkor Vat but very beautiful though.

Most Charming of all. My favorite temple of all. It is not as grand of a scale as Angkor Wat but a very romantic site. Its beauty and natural pink stone aged gracefully and in most colorful way. All the intricate carvings can be seen at Banteay Srei as they are still mostly in tact and well preserved.

Overwhelmed by Tourists. For me, the beauty of this Khmer temple was ruined by busloads of Chinese tourists. The temple complex is small, and could not accommodate the hordes of people visiting. Without the crowds, I am sure I would have enjoyed seeing the delicacy and intricacy of these ancient Hindu temples. Try an afternoon visit would be my suggestion.

Just love the intricate carvings at the "lady temple". Third time to this little temple and it doesn't get old! Lovely intricate carvings on this little red stoned temple that is older than Angkor wat. There is now an interpretive centre, a little gift store and food vendors as well as a restaurant. It is a bit out of the way but it is easy to get to and the road is good now.

The most detailed and intricate temple!. The womens temple was my favourite temple of all of the others visited in and around Ankor Wat over a period of 5 days in the area. The details on all of the walls was truly amazing and also less busy than the other ones. A bit further away but well worth the effort to get here and spend some time!

Lady Temple. Also known as the Lady Temple, Banteay Srei is a perfect jewel. It's not like the main Angkor sites, it's much more small-scale and detailed. The carvings are the most beautiful in Angkor. You can't get right into the centre as it's roped off but you can still see everything. But, even more than with most temples, get there EARLY! It's an hour from Siem Reap, which is a bit boneshaking in a tuk tuk, so don't leave your hotel later than 7:00; 6:00 is better. It's so small that once the tour groups get there you can't move.
Intricate. Enjoyed the long ride out to visit this temple. The temple itself is small, intricate and well preserved. Was worth a visit, but not one of our favourites.

Underrated. This Hindu temple dates back to AD 967 and is an absolutely charming piece of art--or a "gallery of art" one might say. It is located some 20 miles (32 km) outside of Siem Reap, but well worth the effort.We engaged a competent English-speaking guide which was tremendously helpful in interpreting the stories that are captured in the walls of this wonderful temple that many visitors to the area pass by.

Breath taking. Smaller than Angkor Wat. But lot more detailed. Intricate work. Of course like most places in SR, this place is also in shambles. But not as bad as Ta Prohm. Not a lot to climb. Flat surface. So, senior friendly! It was a hot day. Fortunately we were well hydrated. I advise folks to be prepared with a lot of water bottles. We had an excellent guide, Kampoul tour services. ( see my review elsewhere).Don't forget to take a picture of the light shining through the top. Almost like a candle over the Linga! I guess it depends on the time of the day for this effect to take place.Loved the story of karaikaal ammaiyar.Lovely little children outside trying to sell stuff. How much to give them. You come out feeling helpless. These kids deserve better. We enjoyed the experience.DON'T FORGET YOUR ANGKOR WAT PASS!!

Nice carvings. Very intricate carvings that make this temple worth seeing. Drive is about 30 min so I recommend a car a not a tuk-tuk. Not crowded. Be sure to stop and read the history at the entrance. Very interesting.Plenty of food vendors and nice restrooms

Lady Temple. This is called Banteay Srei meaning in English Lady Temple. Very beautiful with red stone style. The temple a bit far from Siem Reap (35 km) but very nice temple. Along the way to Banteay Srei you can visit Butterfly center, land mind museum ...

A fair trip out but worth it.. Left this temple until the last day. Hired tuk tuk for about 25$ for the ³ of us. Quite a long ride but really lovely to have the wind in your hair and see a bit more of rural Cambodia. The temple itself is small but beautiful, different in scale which makes it stand out from the other temples. It has exquisite carvings. If you arrive as lone travellers when a tour is going through just walk around the most and slip back in behind them. This gives you more space to appreciate the different aspects.
The best details. Smaller than its giant kin, it is a must see for beauty. Not as crowded, pleasant stop with food nearby,

A gem. Further afield from the main temple sites but the trip to this temple is worth the effort. Beautiful carvings of a subtlety and finesse that for me surpassed the grander more exotic friezes of the Angkor.

Exquisite. My favourite temple. The intricate stone carving is mind -blowing in its detail and perfection. Less tourists too, as most are noisily making their way around Angkor Wat, etc.
A bit out of town, but hire a tuk tuk driver for the day and enjoy.

The jewel. The temple is small but its carving is unbelievable. It is so fine carving qnd still in aperfect state of preservation.
We like this temple all thing about it except a lot of people.

Amazing stone carving. One of the absolute gems of the Angkor complex . Legend has it this temple was carved by women as men's hands would be too large . The sandstone carving is awesome and the setting of the temple is beautiful . Some critics describe this as the finest stone carving in the world. A must see !

A small, incredible gem among temples. Hire a local guide if you can and visit by Tuk Tuk. Should cost around $75 for the whole thing - but an absolutely priceless experience! This temple has the most magnificent detailed carvings which stand it apart from everything else in the Angkor area. Try to visit late-morning, when the coach loads of Chinese tourists have departed and the complex is quiet and infinitely more enjoyable. Your Angkor Pass will cover entry, so be sure to include this in your (minimum) 3-day stay.

Red stone. The red stone of Banteay Srei has some of the best preserved sculptures of all the Angkor temples. The carvings are amazing- so intricate.it's amazing they have survived over 500 years and this is testament to the skill of the Khmer artisans.Go there early to avoid the crowds and plan your routes over the three days (longer if you are lucky) to maximise your time at Siem Reap.

What! Another Temple no way!. Comon' your having a laugh, another Temple, how many it to many?Well in this case never enough!Stunning is the only word I can say for this, it quite simple stunning. To me this one stands out head and shoulder about the rest, it's small but perfectly formed, real if you miss this one you have done yourself's no favours.Not only is the Temple brilliant but this one has what none of the other ones has, or that I saw, it's got a information centre and I found this to be what made this the most interesting one. Read the stories about who discovered it in the 1880's and who ended up in jail for trying to steal artefacts from the site and take them back to France I think it was.Loved this one, really really like the whole experience.
Worth the trip. Very much enjoyed the journey through all the small villages and the countryside, as well as the temple itself.
banteay srei. banteay srei also called women s temple is one of the beautifullest temple in siem reap a must see for everyone

Fine stone carvings - The Pink Temple. This temple was inaccessible until the 1990s as it was one of the last territories of the Khymer Rouge. The carvings on the fine sandstone are possibly the most detailed and exquisite in the area. This is only a small temple ( called the Pink Temple) but worth seeking out. Commonly also regarded as "the Jewel in the Crown"

So Many Temples, Not Enough Time. There are a staggering amount of things to do in Siem Reap so before your visit its definately worth check where things are on googlemaps so you can plan days that are logical, you can easily fit the Landmine Museum, the Butterfuly Center, Banteay Srei and Kbal Spean in a day and you wont regret it, as I have said in other reviews for the temples, each one has its own charm and this one is no exception.

beautiful. Its a beautiful small temple. Its a distance from the other temples but worthwhile. I used a tuk tuk to get there. Enjoyed the drive but was passed by so many cars and buses. Recommend getting there in the morning before everyone else gets there. A lot of people for a small temple. Would be 5 stars if they would limit the amount of tourist. Plus it would help preserve them.
Tina. About 37 km out but well worth the effort to go and see , better to go by car . The temple , a woman's temple in a lovely area , nice restaurants around .

Get There Early. If you come to Banteay Srei, be sure to do first thing in the morning. The temple is stunning in the morning light and the intricate carvings of Hindu mythology seem to come to life in the right light.It's barely still in the Angkor area, but is worth the drive. Be sure you get there as soon as it opens so that you can enjoy the temple and the carvings without the throngs of tour busses that will eventually arrive.
Awesome temple. This is one of the more awesome of the temples. There is much to see and explore. Plan to come earlier in the day to avoid the hordes of tourists. Ugh!!
Great carvings. It is a small temple but with great carvings. Takes over an hour to get to but it is worthwhile. It is different from other temples.
Citadel of Women. This temple has the finest carvings. It was built in the 10th century to honor the then king's mother. Here the carvings are of mythic stories and characters.

Smaller temple but well worth the trip. Take the time to see this temple - we saw it as part of a day trip to Kulen Falls and the Landmine Museum. It was quiet serene and not a busy as the other temples closer in to Angkor Wat.

Amazing. This temple was amazing. It is a small temple and a little bit of a distance from the others but it is well worth the trip. The intricate detail in the carvings are absolutely incredible and was by far the best in the way of carving. The temple is also set in a beautiful backdrop with amazing garden and lake.
Wonderful temple !!!. This is one of the best temple we had visited in Siem Reap. The area has many many big temples and full of culture carried on. People here are very friendly.

Muted pink in the late afternoon. This was one of my favourite temple stops because of its beautiful, muted pink colour, especially in the light of the late afternoon.
I liked it because it was smaller, there were a lot less people and it was just so beautiful, pink and golden and dramatic.

Temples. Although a lot further from Siem Reap than other Temples, we enjoyed our ride in the tuk tuk to get there and going through local villages and see life outside the Town. Beautiful Temple, well preserved

Another temple to visit. This was a smaller temple in the area and an important one historically. If memory serves (the number of temples we visited gave some confusion) this is one of a pair 1.5 km apart built by father and son kings.

The best of them all in Angkor. Spend a whole morning or whole afternoon visiting this charming little temple. Appreciate the details of the intricate carving. Watch the colours of the stone buildings change with the time of day. Walk around the temple precinct and view if from different angles. Catch its reflection in the water.

MUST SEE. Make the effort to include Banteay Srei. It is about 24 km. outside of the Angkor Archeological Park but it is so special that it is worth it. Banteay Srei Wat is beautiful, intricate and delicate. It is on a human scale rather than a monumental scale. There is nothing else like it. This is a precious gem that is not to be missed.

Worth the long drive. This temple is about a 45 minute tuktuk ride from the Siem Reap city center. Go out there and see this temple. The carvings are so delicate and different from the other temples. They say the carvings must have been created by the hands of a woman because they are so small and intricate. On the ride to or from, you can stop for some palm sweet.

My favorite Khmer temple. We visited a lot of the Khmer temples on our trip and this one really stood out for me. It really is enchanting. Built of red sandstone, the temple has some amazing bas-relief friezes.

Smaller gem.... Not on the scale of Angkor Wat, but definitely worth the visit. Most people come to Siem Reap to see Angkor Wat. However, after seeing it, it is definitely worth the effort to see this smaller temple complex. Its size makes it a more manageable complex to view in its totality. Also, there area many carvings and statues which make the temple a terrific site to see. This is someplace that I would tell people not to miss.
Lovely ruins. Very beautiful ruins , still being excavated. Huge trees that almost look "Arty " hugging the pillars & stones.visited with the early morning sun , was less crowded. Worth a visit.

A pink small Wat with beautiful shady gardens a quiet oasis. Banteay Srei which is a small wat seemingly built for women with pink stones and and very relaxing natural environment of trees and water and shade made enjoying the delicate carvings rather than the other very hot wanderings

Worth the trek (in a car, not a tuk-tuk). This is definitely worth the 40 km trek to the temple. The 'Women's Temple' is absolutely beautiful, with intricate carvings in red sandstone. Try to get there a little earlier during the day, as it gets pretty packed (and HOT!) in the afternoon. There are a little too many vendors for my liking, but you just have to smile and move along.

Simply Amazing!. These ancient ruins & temples are simply amazing. When you stand & view the stone carvings & architecture that people all those years ago put into these places it is mind blowing. They never had the technology of today yet the structures, positioning & detail is astounding. absolute must see.
Pink beauty. It's about 40km outside Siem Riep but worth the drive through pretty villages and rice paddies.This small pink sandstone temple has exquisite carvings dating back to around AD 967.
WOW. Wonder. Cant describe in words .All places in siem reap are worth visit if u love history and able to relate to Indian mythologies
Stunning colours. The temple has so much detail, it will take you an age to walk round and admire it all, while enjoying the sounds of the birds.

Worth The Journey.. It is a good distance from Siem Reap and if you are traveling by Tuk Tuk (how I did it) it will take about an hour to get there. It is in a state of disrepair but it still a great place to visit. It is included in the Angkor Ticket as are most of the attractions in this area.

Favourite site. The three temples at this site are easy to approach, manageable without too much difficult walking, and with beautiful small sculptures. Less crowded, perhaps because of the distance from Siem Reap and very enjoyable.
Such a stunning temple. One of the older ones, built of pink sandstone with intricate carvings. Built on a smaller scale than many others but the detail I the carving is worth the trip.

Beautiful Sandstone carvings. Smaller temple away from the main attractions but worth the trip, Great for Photos. Not so crowded but can get busy at times, like all the Angkor temples try to plan to avoid the tour coaches.
pink stones. A MUST SEE!!! while you visit angkor watt. my favorite out of all the ruins. Chan Sinarith is a knowledgeable & wonderful tour guide. you will learn more from a tour guide.
Visit on day 1. Visit on day 1 with a guide, save Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom for day 2. You'll be more impressed with this one, it's less busy and the colors and details are beautiful!

Beautiful Bas Relief. This temple is a little further away from the main cluster and is much smaller. Nevertheless it is definitely worth a visit to view the intricate bas reliefs. The day we visited it was very crowded so you need to be patient to be able to view the carvings. Again, taking a guide is worthwhile in order to get the most from your visit.
Worth diverting for.. Smaller temple but with great feeling about it. Many of the carvings are better preserved/intact. The trees growing on the structure are well worth the time taken to visit.

A lovely little temple in the complex. Worth some time and some camera space. Sadly the temple area is one of the few spots that still has some of what must have been some amazing jungle area with majestic trees at some time.
long way Banteay Srei. We insisted on including this on our one-day itinerary. it's a little temple, out-of-the-way but so worth the trip. Beautiful.

Well worth the effort. Commonly referred to as the Women's Temple, this is another must see. It doesn't have the grandeur of the other temples closer to Siem Reap, but it more than makes up for it with the amazing colours and intricate carvings. We asked a tuk driver for his recommendation, and for about $20USD, he took us out here. This was one of our best Cambodia experiences, going past lots of villages and seeing the locals do what locals do. Kids playing in ponds, laughing, cattle on the side of the road, what passes for a petrol station, in a wonderfully scenic afternoon.

Must see, worth the longer ride to get there. This temple is further than most temples. I put it on the must-see list, with temples like Ankgor Wat. Don't skip this one. It is worth the trip.The carvings in this temple are some of the most impressive and intricate, second only to Ankgor Wat itself, maybe. The carvings are different than what you will see in Ankgor Wat. The carvings are amazing. It's smaller and very easy to walk through. (I also had a relentless girl and her friend trying to sell me a book on the way out. I enjoyed the exchange and bought the book from her.)Check out the pictures. It's am amazing place. Please don't skip it. Better to see it later in your trip.There is a well-paved road out to the temple, so the trip goes quickly once you are outside the city.

Extremely beautiful temple.. We called in here on our way back from a trip to phnom kulen national park. I had heard that it was worth a trip and our guide agreed that is was worth a very small diversion to visit. It really is very beautiful with a totally different ambiance to some of the much larger temples. It is much smaller and delicate with intricate carvings and a lovely pink stone. We were told that it was built for a woman hence it is much more delicate. It was also a lot quieter and more peaceful so if you want a slightly less frenetic trip than the main temples it is worth a visit.

Beautiful carvings. This is surely the most spectacular of the temples in the Angkor complex--the carvings are much more intact, and the trees growing from the temple structures show what Angkor must have been like when it was first rediscovered. This is well worth the visit--take the time to really look around!

Worth going the extra mile. I think this is the most beautiful of all the temples. The detail in the carving is amazing and the setting is also lovely. The colour of the stone is also eye-catching. If you have time not one to be missed out!

one of most beautiful temple. The details of the carvings are so amazing.. and the selected pink stones made it even more special.. I love the pretty size of it with nice trees around.. just beautiful.. if go to siem reap. do not miss this one.. hire a local driver bring you to there..

Reowned for Intricate decoration. Away from the town of seam reap,,its famous for exquisite decorative carving in pink sand stone, miniature proportions in a peaceful,isolated semi wooded settings.Built in the second half of 10th c by Rajendra Varman,it has intricate carvings depicting beautiful themes from HINDU mythology,such as DURGA,A fight between Siva and Arjuna, Ravana shaking Mt Kailash,Devatha, Kama( God of Love) firing an arrow at Siva to mention.There are few shops for buying souvenirs at a bargain pric.MUST VISIT.
Beautiful. There's no words to describe how beautiful this temple was. It's one of the most beautiful temples around there. Just... go there
looks nice. Its really an amazing fantastic that you cant believe it,you can just wonder how this place looked for about 800 years ago,, my second time here but still amazing to see the sculptures
Go to this temple.. This temple is really amazing. It is one of the best, so well worth renting a taxi and drive the kilometers to go to this temple.
Beautiful Banteay. Beautiful grounds and a beautiful temple. The detailed carving is incredible and well worth a visit.

not to be missed. Drive out about 20kms through pleasant contryside and you will reach this little gem of a temple which is from the 9th century. With equisute carvings and roots of trees holding portions of the walls this is a place that should not be missed.

A favourite!. We bounced out here in a tuktuk and it was well worth it. The temple is unusual as it's made from pink sandstone and the carvings are the best we saw in any of the temples. There were very few people so we loved the peaceful atmosphere.
The gem of Angkhor complex.. Far out in the countryside but not to be missed. The best carving and design on lintels anywhere at Angkhor . Pink limestone adds beauty as do pools.

.....nice...but all the world was here. This temple is one of the most famous outside angkor city.It is smaller than the others temples but ver y nice forma its carved stones.ThE temple was madre by women...the day i was here many people of big tourist group was also.You can combine the trip with Kbal Apean waterfall.

My favorite. Little further out (about an hour out of Siem reap), so wasn't as busy as Angkor. I think this was my favorite as it wasn't quite so busy, so you actually had time to marvel without hordes crowding you from behind.

Elaborate wall carvings on this "Citadel of Women". Beautiful Khmer carvings on the wall of this "small" temple build on red sandstone. Row of "Linga" line the left and right of the entrance pathway. I still wonder why it was given the name.

Well worth the effort. Whilst an hours tuk tuk drive out of town, this is a must see. Well recommended as the best of remaining art and bas-reliefs in the Angkor area. Whilst smaller than some of the others you it is one of the best preserved sites and so you could get a real impression of what it must have been like. The drive through the villages to get there was a wonderful introduction to the lives of locals and there was plenty to keep us interested at every turn.The recently developed visitor centre, cafes and shopping market meant we could spend a very pleasant few hours satisfying every need. Marvellous

Banteay Srei. We visited this smaller temple on a trip combining a visit to the landmine museum and a few stops a long the way to watch villagers fishing. The temple is different in colour and in the detail still evident in the carving. A wonderful way to spend a day.

Must visit :). It's a small temple, we spent half a day visiting here. The tuk tuk charged 17$ for a day trip. The style of architecture is different the carvings etc are very different from those in the Bentey Kdei and Angkor Wat. The drive to and fro is a delight. the temple tour doesn't take much time but yes the distance to it claims the time. Must visit

Beautiful with intricate carvings. A little away from the Angkor complex, this sandstone temple is full of intricate carvings from Hindu mythology. We were lucky to have Mr. Rachna as our guide...quite knowledgeable. There were carvings of sita's abduction, vali vadham, ravana lifting kailas, kama helping us, durga killing mahisha, bhima killing jarasandha, khandava prastha. Probably even temples in India do not have such carvings. Their knowledge and intricate carving is mind-blowing. Better to brush up your knowledge of Hindu mythology before visiting the temple

Fantastic place. We visited Banteay Srei on our last day in the Angkor area and really enjoyed it.Especially the Wall carvings are magnificient and just great art.Absolutely worth the longer way from Siem Reap!!!

Beautiful temple. This small, reddish temple is something you can't miss: there are beautiful sculptures and bas-reliefs, it's an ancient temple and it's not crowded like the Angkor Wat, thus you can spend much more time admiring the area.

Very Beautiful. This site has some of the best stone carving in the region. Its about an hour tuk0tuk ride away from Siem Reap, but worth the trip their and back. It's a smaller site, but still has plenty to see and study.

Love the carvings. Although a little out of the way, it is worth the drive. The pinkish stone, the beautiful carvings, some of the best preserved. Even loved the u inquest villages and the sweet treats you could buy along the way!
Worth the long drive. Loved the drive to bantey srei on a tuk tuk. The temple itself is less crowded than angkor wat and ta phrom etc. I recommend it if you have time.

Deteriorating, from red to black. I visited the temple five years ago and it was gorgeous. The red sandstone laced with intricate cavings were so lovely. I just went back for a second visit. The condition nearly broke my heart. Lack of maintenance. The red sandstone are now turning black. Moss-grown and wild grass could be seen on the doors, pillars, walls. What has happened? If you have not seen its glorious days, you may think that this is its peak condition. It is heart ache to see the temple runs into disrepair. Given another ten years in the same situation, Banteay Srei may return to a pile of ruins again.

Very interesting and popular. For some reason I didn't like this one quite as much as my husband did, but it was beautiful with so many intricate carvings. Many tourists visit here and that would explain the many local vendors selling their wares.
Peaceful. This is a Hindu temple, so a little bit different to the other ones. It is also much, much quieter. It is worth the extra ride out there as it is very serene with interesting carvings.
Ornate and Feminine. A jewel like temple with amazingly ornate carvings covering every surface. The pink colored sandstone really stands out against the green foliage and lichen.

Beautiful. Amazing sculptures from the Mahabharata and Ramayana, still intact after so many years, absolutely worth the travel of 50kms from Siem Reap. Another jewel of the Angkor kingdom ofbthe Khmers

Not worth the extra trip - smal and no better than the central temples. Drivers may pressure you to make the journey out here to make extra money but if you are short of time or even if you have time it isn't worth the bumpy trip out to this small temple with it's murky looking carvings. The carvings and statues aren't much better than other temples within the Angkor Wat area and there are so few of them. The quality statues have been removed to the museum anyway. You are better visiting the central temples carefully. Even the Roluos group which is closer is better.

It's Worth the Drive because the Engravings are More Intricate. Even though the Banteay Srei Temple was at least a thirty minute drive from the other temples we had explored (all of the other temples were exceedingly close together), but it was worth the drive, especially when we had a driver and were able to nap and get a break from the intense and morbidly uncomfortable outside heat. While the Banteay Srei Temple is seemingly miniature in comparison to all the other temples we had visited, it is considered by many to be the jewel of Khmer Art as the intricate carvings have remained well intact and preserved. It was built in pink sandstone and the intricate surviving detail was astounding. The pink sandstone stood up over the years far better than the gray stone so the carvings were more pronounced at the Banteay Srei temple. Due to the well-defined and ornate engravings at the Banteay Srei Temple, the Banteay Srei provided a flavor of how the other temples may have appeared before they were caught in a battle with mother nature over time.Just remember that while it is hottttt, proper temple attire is required. Ladies shoulders, as well as, at least their knees must be covered. I wore lightweight pants to be safe. Hats or umbrellas to protect you from the sun might provide some comfort.Each temple is beautiful and has a fascinating history. We recommend getting a private guide as we felt having a private maximized our experience at each temple visited, including the Banteay Srei. Also, having a private guide allowed us to tour the temples at our own pace, as if you go with a large group, you are stuck by the whims and pace of others. Our guide was Dy with ICS Travel and he phenomenal. He was extremely knowledgeable, personable, and had a passion for history. We loved every minute.
Worth the extra time to get there. Its a bit farther than the main temples but the carvings are amazing. As usual get there early for good photos and less crowds.
excellent but small. Wonderful carvings and a nice start before you set out to see the larger temples unfortunately there were too many visitors when we were there

This is a different temple. It is a smaller but different temple that can show another face of the angkor complex cultural, religious and archeological history. Nice to include and see all the details different from the other.
Smaller temple with superb carving. A lovely red stone temple complex with plenty of great carved stone. A moat surrounds the temple complex and provides some great photo opportunities.

Further from the city but worth the journey. this smaller temple seems to be a miniature version of Angkor Wat in many ways, although distinctly redder in colour. It has some well preserved wall carvings and statues, and is well worth the trip through the countryside. It makes a great place to visit in the morning, and then stop off for lunch in a nearby village on the way back.

Small but detailed. Come here for the carvings. Older than the other temples by 200 years, but the carvings are better preserved because they used more durable stones (reddish / pinkish). We stopped by the temple on the way back from the mountains (Phnom Khulen), so it was not a big deal that it was a bit out of the way (outside of the Angkor Wat area by 30km or so).

Nice one but small. I was a bit disappointed as there was not much to see as this temple is completely away from Angkor area and very nice. It's just unlike the other temple, its carving and size is just really for woman. My only problem is just there should have been more to see.
The best carvings. Not a huge temple but the one with the highest quality, most exquisite carvings in the whole area. Well worth the travelling time.

A bit underwhelming, considering the distance. Hired a motorcycle driver who recommended the "Lady temple" (Banteay Srei) as part of a 'big tour' (the outer ring of Angkor) and said it's very beautiful. Honestly, I was a bit underwhelmed (and possibly suffering from temple fatigue; went here on the third day after already seeing many). It's very small compared to say Bayon but takes about 30 minutes each way to get there (though I did appreciate seeing the countryside / more of rural Cambodia along the way) and does not exactly stand out (at least for me) among some of the others I've seen and favourites (e.g. Baphuon).

Small can be beautiful. Visiting Siem Reap encompasses a wide range of experiences when it come to Temples. from the amplitude of Angkor Wat to the other features presented by each Temple, you should be opened to appreciate variety. This is a small Temple - much smaller then Angkor Wat. The distinctiveness of that Temple is the very refined carving, unbelievable details carved in stone. So you won't find big towers or extensive panels - but the columns seem to be embroidered. The Apsaras are beautiful, and the refined work in the inner walls is very impressive. The external walls are not ornate - but it will only enhance the beauty of the work Inside.It's a little bit far to Siem Reap's distance rate (everything here is very close one to another), but to my point of view, it's worthy. It bring you also an unexpected bonus - due to the distance, big tour groups won't go there - so it will be less crowded.Some remarks that might be useful - there is no shade at all in the site, so be protected against the sun. The pavement is very, very irregular, and that night be a problem to one who has any kind of moving limitation.

Beautiful!. One of My favourite Temples. It is a small temple compared to the others. Very beautiful and made out of different rock to other temples. Looks more orange and sandy. Easy to walk through with not many steps. Behind the temple is a group of locals playing music, they are all survivors of the mines. Photos are lovely at this temple.

A must see temple. This temple appears well preserved compared to others. There are not as many tourists there because it is so far away from the main tourist attractions. They don't know what they are missing. You get in on the same ticket as all the other temples. The pink sandstone is beautiful and the carvings are well defined. Put this temple on your agenda!
The art on the wall really interesting. every art on the wall is really nice............ if you not pick up this temple really regret........... also tapom temple also make me feel wonderful.........

The precious gem or the jewel of Khmer art. The scale of this temple is much smaller but the ornamentation is much more intricate and delicate in scope. It is a pleasure to see intricate carvings in such close proximity because the temple is really 'human sized'. It was built by a counselor to the king. Some of the best pictures that I took was at this temple, the red sandstone glows in the afternoon sun and the pictures looks divine.

A must attraction to appreciate temples of Siem Reap. We were hot and tired and did not want a long drive from city: a guide pushed us to go. It is not a long trip and through beautiful countryside with better showing of typical Cambodian daily life. Interesting homes along road. Nice walk from parking area among trees. Spoiled a bit by children selling souvenirs too aggressively. If you buy anything, be prepared for a swarm of more kids.The temple is small but a treasure. It has been restored/preserved well. It is older than the larger temples nearer town but intricate beautiful ornamental carvings more beautiful. We visited in later afternoon and light of setting sun made temple even more beautiful. It is an excellent to seeing the larger temples. Very memorable. Somehow try to see when hoarders of bus tourists overwhelm you and the temple.
Easily accessible. This off the beaten path temple was worth the drive. Banteay Srei or "Citadel of Women" is a 10th century Hindu temple with magnificent relief carvings.
Another one. A much smaller temple under renovation but nonetheless well worth seeing. A very interesting part of a much larger complex.

Really Beautiful. Bantey Srei Temple is really beautiful. One should not miss it at all if you visit Siem Reap. I really don't have words to describe the beauty of the Temples. What an Architecture? Such a beautiful carving. I have never seen such a beautiful thing in my life. Truly wonder of the world. All I can say in few words that if you compare beauty of Angkor Wat with much talked beauty of Taj Mahal, Taj Mahal will look like Garbage in front of Angkor Wat. No comparison at all :)
Intricate designs. I really liked this temple. Although small and very crowded with tourists. I really liked the intricate designs. It is embellished with more carvings then the other temples.

Exquisite small well-restored temple with great information centre.. The Banteay Srei temple is located approximately 30 minutes drive from Siem Reap. The drive there through the countryside is beautiful. The temple is made out of red sandstone, small, really well restored and with the best carvings in the whole Angkor region. This is really the jewel of Khmer art and with a size that you can fathom.The temple is quite often crowded. There are fewer tourists in the early morning or immediately after lunch, when it is really hot. It is advisable to have a guide explaining the temple and the carvings to you.You need to wear long pants and have your shoulders covered to visit the temple.The temple site is really well organized with excellent parking, restrooms, cafeteria with drinks and food, souvenir shop but most impressively a great Information Centre with a really good, modern and informative exhibition about Khmer building techniques, different styles and then in detail about the Banteay Srei. This is the only temple in the Angkor region with an Information Centre.

Pahantastic. Banteay Srei was (on purpose) the last temple we visited. And it is the most charming one. We combined it with a trip to the National Park (in the morning). Not too many tourists in the afternoon.
Go super early - or take ear plugs. Get here before 7:30am. By 8am you'll be swarmed by tour buses and any chance of serenity will be lost. Morning light is great for this temple.

Very well managed. A very interesting temple. Relatively small compared to others, but beautiful. The way the park was managed is much better than others. There is a nice information centre, and very well kept toilet.
