Tiny Temple overrun with Tourists. This temple is obviously best visited early or out of tourist season. It is small with beautiful and delicate carvings unlike any other temple at Angkor, but when full of tourists the experience can be challenging.
Best for sandstone carvings. This is the best temple to check out intricate sandstone carvings. My top three were Banteay Srei, Ta Prohm and Bayon

Unmissable!. Possibly the most evocative of all the sites on the Angkor Wat complex. A huge number of absolutely stunning stone carvings in the walls, including one that can only be a stegosaurus - how did they know about them? A truly beautiful setting, surrounded by forest and lakes.DO NOT MISS.
Small but exquisite. Mind-boggling detail -- well worth the extra distance you need to travel to get there. From a purely artistic point of view, undeniably gorgeous.

No pants no entry. No short skirts, no sleeves apparel & wear good hikable shoes or sandals for this one.
Oh & kids below 12 not allowed so be prepared to stand watch while your partner probably finishes their turn.

Worth the drive. This is a bit out of they, but so worth the drive. We arrived first thing in the morning and what an experience it was to be in this intricate and gorgeous temple with only a couple other people.
Beautiful carvings. It is a small temple so easy to manage. You can walk around in short time. Do take time to observe the detailed carving. Most intricate of all temples I visited in Siem Reap

A wonderful temple. A wonderful temple, beautiful and well preserved. We arrived there in noon----it's really hot at that time, but just few visitors there. We took our time to appreciate the beautiful sculptures.I think it's a good idea to hire a tour guide if it's your first time in Siem Reap. Our guide tailored a wonderful trip for us. He knew the stories behind the stones, and also told us the best time to visit temples, and the best location to take a good photo.
Angkor's rococo jewel. The sculpting here (on frontons, lintels, etc.) is the most intricate of all the Angkor temples. Since it's small and popular, it's very crowded! Come early.
A small temple by size. This temple is further out but well worth the drive. Seeing the countryside and villages adds to the trip. You can also visit some very early brick temples on the way.

'Citadel of the women'.. This is another beautiful temple, built from pink sand stone, with some of the best carvings we have seen at any of the temples.
Also, an interesting drive out from the city,to see how people live & work in the Cambodian countryside.

Fantastic stone carvings. Banteay Srei is also known as the Ladies temple. It is a small temple constructed of red sandstone. Even though it is quite small, the carvings are fantastic and are easily the best around Siem Reap. You can see great details on all the buildings. It is located about 30 minutes from Siem Reap along the South Korea Cambodia friendship road. They have developed a whole tourist centre around the site. You have access to toilets, food and drink. There is even a tourist shopping area.
Another stunning temple. Its possible to get a bit nonchalant regarding these temples as there are so many, but each one has its own magic and story to tell, just brilliant.....

Picturesque temple with stunning carvings. Well worth the extra time to visit here. Take a tuk tuk as there's some interesting scenery & village life to see on the way & the breeze as you travel is refreshing.
Stunning. You just wish the crowds away. It's most intricately carved of all the Wats. It's too beautiful for words.

Intricate carvings. This is one of the best preserved temples in the region. Called the 'temple of the woman' for its beauty, it is truly captivating. The fine carvings depicting scenes from hindu myths and epics keep you engaged for long.

Angkor in miniature. This temple wasn't on our original agenda, but so pleased we saw it.The cravings are so intricate & detailed on the pink stone miniature temples, I think making Banteay Srei one of the best preserved?!This is definitely worth a visit, but beware of the souvenir shop ... Nothing is priced & when asking the price of something be prepared & advisable too have someone ready to catch you ... More than 100$ for a small Buddha!!! Also the coffee shop\cafe has priceless menus.

Long way but worth visiting. This temple isn't really big and it takes a little bit long way. But worth visiting! The details in each entrance were amazing. There is a exhibition room where you can see the reservation during the past

Early morning light is best. This temple glows a beautiful orange in the really morning light. It is peaceful and really pretty, and best enjoyed in the morning before the crowds arrive (head there straight after watching sunrise at Angkor at).

Beautiful Pink Sandstone Temple. The scenery is lovely on this long drive, passing many single temples on the way. About 40 mins from Siem Reap. The carvings and script were just beautiful and i think the pink sandstone made this one, for me, the prettiest. It was very well preserved. There was also shops attached for food, gifts and souvenirs.

Worth the Trip. Small temple and a drive to get there, but well worth it. One of our favorites. The different colored stone used and the deep relief of the carvings combine to a unique temple in the area. Recommend you make the trip!

Lovely temple. Visited this one after our 3 day pass had expired so had to get a new single day pass. It is a long way out so try and do it as part of one of your days here so you don't have to buy an additional pass.The temple itself is very pretty and the colour is lovely, as it is the ladies temple it is quite small, especially in height. The drive to the temple is also very pleasant.

My Favorite site. A bit farther out, beautiful drive with great scenery. Different enough from the other Wat's with pink-ish color rock and much more intricate carvings that anything else we saw. Get there early before the tour buses arrive for some gorgeous photo ops.
beautiful pink temple. we were there late noon, and the lighting was great. the setting sun on the pink walls made it quite nice for pictures.

If u like cycling, hire a mountain bike and cycle to this one. Ok, it is about a 65-75km round trip depending on where you're staying but we hired mountain bikes (recommend green bikes) the night before which allowed us to art off early (6am) when it was cool and there was no traffic. We found it easily as it was well sign posted and we followed one of the tourist maps (from town head up right side if river past wat bo area) towarss angkor wat and then takenthe roads to the right of it and follow the signs. hard to get lost and by 7:30am there are a few tuk tuks with tourists coming by so u know you are on the right track.This temple was worth a visit- much smaller than the others so doesn't take that long but the beautiful intricate red sandstone carvings surrounded by the most are lovely. It was pretty busy by 10am.There's food and water sold as well as the usual touristy stuff.
Beautiful !. Is the only one temple made with pink and yellow sandstone, with very detailed and beautiful craving!!! A hour drive from Siem Reap. Worth to visit.

Packed with Detailed Carvings. I enjoyed this place a lot. It's small comparing to Angkor Wat or Angkor Thom. However, it was built with red sandstone and it's packed with detailed carvings. I couldn't stop taking a lot of pictures, closed-up or far away.

Best Wat. small and beautiful. Best decorated Wat. Close to center for conservation of Biodiversity. About an hour away North from Siem Reap by car but worth the journey. Not many people were there so very peaceful.

worth the drive, keep for day three. We visited this temple on day three of our three day visit to Angkor Wat. To be most effective, you need to take a car and it take 45 minutes. By Tuk, it would be 1.5 hours. You are driving through the towns and its pretty dusty. It cost us $40 for a car and we had a guide which I would recommend.I liked this temple. Not my favorite but if you want to make sure your see the full picture of the Angkor Wat area, Banteay Srei should be part of your visit. The key difference in this temple is that it is made from a completely different material, a pink sand stone. Whether the pink sand stone is dirty or not, it is completely different looking than the rest. The best part of visiting each temples is each one is in a different state of preservation. The Cambodian government is now trying some renovation but these are the temples in their true form.Like others have mentioned, driving through the countryside was an added bonus. Good for photos. We tagged this visit on with Pre Rup.

Worth a quick stop . Not my favourite of the temples in Angkor but it does have some very intricate carvings and is worth a visit if you're in the area visiting the land mine museum (which is really worth seeing).

An average experience. Well, to be honest, didn't find it as amazing as the other temples, probably because it is not as massive. We went there after having read good reviews about it but found the temple sort of insignificant. Nothing much to admire except the (now dirty) pink carved walls of the temple and the few remaining statues.

The Search for Enlightenment Part 7. Banteay Srei. Day 2 of our Siem Reap temple run starts off with a 1 hour trip ouside Siem Reap city. A bonus to this trip is seeing the Cambodian country side. The Cambodian design for their houses is that it stands on 4 posts, probably because of floods during their rainy season.Banteay srei was built earlier than the more famous Angkor wat. Less crowds and a smaller area makes it an easier attraction to visit. One will immediately notice the intricate carvings on the reddish stone. One hour inside is enough. Then, take a few minutes to shop for souveneirs at the market outside the temple. We got a nice mask of Buddha. As in all Cambodia, bargain for 1/3 of the price.

Temple carved with history. Great place to visit in the early morning before the sun gets too hot. Wall carvings are full of fine details which may need more time to appreciate. Splendid images for the memory!

One of the most detailed. This is a small temple, about 40kms from the others in the park. Worth the trip out there. The details in the stone are intricate. And the pink sandstone sets it apart. There is info on how it was built and what the monuments mean in the 'interpretation centre'.
The pink Lady. It's a quite far away and not really big temple, but absolutly worth to visit, because of the fine and detailed reliefs made of (I would say) sandstone in beautiful colors.

Beautiful relics carved in red sandstone. This was the first temple I visited at 7:30 A.M. This is a good time to visit the temple in my opinion. Its a small temple area and after +/- 8:30 A.M. it will be heavily crowded with lots of tourists who will arrive with a tour company. Also the weather is more pleasant early in the morning. The temple is quite small but has a special charm. The color (red sandstone) and the carved relics in the stone are extraordinary. The temple is surrounded by high trees and beautiful nature. Must see when you visit the Angkor temple complex!

Beautifully carved temple. Worth a stop on your way to Beng Melea. Doesn't require more than 1-2 hours to visit this site. Avoid using an umbrella to escape the sun - if you look along the doorways you can see the writing from 1,000 years ago is almost destroyed due to chafing from the ends of open umbrellas.
A must visit!. We visited this temple last. It is very well done, the level of detail is trully impressive. Very nice place overall worth the visit!
A gem of pink sandstone. A small temple with a special charm. It's the only temple with very well preserved original relief in pink sandstone. Definitely worth a visit.

Exquisite. Even if you're all temple-out, don't miss this little gem. It's just over an hour by tuktuk from the centre of Siem Reap. The rose pink stone is stunningly carved and absolutely charming. Combine with a trip to Kbal Spean for the walk to the waterfall (allow 3-4 hours to do this and wear stout shoes) and the Angkor Centre for Conservation and Biodiversity, (tours at 9.00am and 1.00pm) for a great day out.

Let Down. It is definitely very far away compared to the other temples but the drive is very enjoyable especially if your in a tuc-tuc. I thought the temple itself was very beautiful and the carvings are breath taking, you can't really see them as well as you'd hope since they're closed of and in my opinion i don't think it was worth it and felt a little let down.

Well worth the hour or so side trip. A very beautiful pink sandstone temple. You don't need an entry ticket here, despite what you might be told. It's a small place but it's also on the way to Bang Malea, so it's worth the trip.
Detailed carvings and statues. This was my favourite. Although small the detail in the walls was amazing. Don't forget to go out a little further on your visit and see the river carvings.

Beautiful and different little temple - drive was highlight!. The temple itself was really different from the others. Absolutely beautiful and very different carvings. Temple is more Hindu in style than others without heavy Buddhist changes and is very beautiful stone in a lovely forest setting - without the crowds as well.However highlight was the journey!After a few days of Siem reap city and Angkor park it was lovely to take our tuk tuk ( or more properly Remort) out into the countryside to the rice paddies and rural life for a 30 minute blast. Great, smooth roads with lots to see and places to stop and look at palm sugar candies being made and see an explanation of how it is all done. Palm wood plates etc are cheaper here than central market and feels nice buying close to where it is harvested (in theory).Highly recommend but DO NOT do it in a car you will miss half of what is going on so much fun in the open air. It was 28 degrees and we were a little cold in the open at speed - pack a scarf or long sleeves.

Rain!. I was really looking forward to this one even though it wasn't the biggest. It was a wonderful drive out of the city to the country side. Unfortunately, my driver, didnt want to do this place first. I had wanted to see a couple of sites and this wound up being last on the route. It started pouring rain the moment I got in. There are children running around selling rain covers. The covers are $1 and tear very easily. I was asked repeatedly to buy another one. When I was able to look at the pics on my computer, I was surprised how beautiful the rain made them look. I was very pleased. On the way back, I went to the butterfly museum. That was a great highlight for me. The flowers were amazing and the guides English was wonderful.

Fascinating. The amount of restoration done to this temple is minimal compared to its more prominent cousins such as Bayon and Ta Prohm. It is something different as compared to the rest as well and definitely worth a visit.
nice photo can be took at here..... it is not a big temple.... mostly built by the sandstone. the most nice place to take a sandstone background picture here if compared to other big temple.
Fabulous Temple. take the time to get out to spend time at this temple...fabulous and quiet. But I guess that depends on when you are there . Our experience was wonderful. What a wonderful country
beautiful ladys temple. the oldest of temples its carvings are so intricate its amazing. did laugh at the monk on the ipad in the temple grounds though :)

Not as amazing as was made out. After seeing the likes of Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat we were still told this was one of the most beautiful temples. When we arrived the landscape was astonishingly beautiful. True Cambodian country, however upon arriving at the front of the temple it was clear that there was an air of disappointment. The temple was not the pink sandstone colour we were told of but instead a deeper red. The carvings in the stone were, as usual, amazing but I dont think it was worth the 1 hour bumpy bus ride. Also, the police were even trying to sell us things here and the markets seemed considerably more expensive.

Pretty, small and crowded. The building has intricate carvings that deserve a long time of observing. Really beautiful buildings. That said, it is small. It is minuscule compared to any other Angkor sight. Furthermore it was impossibly crowded when we went there, lessening the experience. Bantaey Srey is a long ways away from the rest of Angkor, and it's drawbacks can make a visit not be worth the long drive. If you go, be there as early as you can (only when it is less crowded can you enjoy this mini-sight) and combine it with a visit to the butterfly centre, pre rup, and/or the land-mine museum.

Perfect pink gem. Take the time to go a bit out of the way to see this small and beautiful temple. It is built from a pink stone that is very strong and has not crumbled (as have so many others of its more famous neighbors). The result is that the carving looks crisp and almost new. How marvelous. Although the entire temple has not yet been put back together, what is there is remarkable.

My favorite. I read about this temple and immediatly wanted to visit. It did not disappoint. It is smaller than the other temples, but I think it makes for its beauty. The temple itself is less preserved than other (fall more), but the site is really nice, preserved with a museum quality like. The ruins I thought were beautiful, in the details of the carving and I loved the different color. My favorite of the three I visited...
Lovely sandstone. One level. Less tourists, great carvings.Pink sandstone.Setting great. Lots of trees so cooler temps.Glad I saw.

Beautiful. This temple is small and out in the country and really beautiful. It is very highly detailed and constructed out of pink limestone. The carvings are really clear and not as worn as many of the other sites so you can really see what they were conveying. Lovely statues on each of the sides guard the center of the temple. I loved this site!

Early Hindu Temple. While Banteay Srei is about 25 kilometers from the larger temple complex at Angkor, it is a temple worth visiting, if you have the time. Considered to be the "citadel of beauty," it is famous for its intricate carvings. The buildings are smaller than many other Angkor area temples. (The opening to the sanctuary is a door only one meter in height!)
Beautiful. Small but the prettiest temple and worth the trip and seemingly never crowded. Hope it stays that way.
The jewel. It is small but finest carving and very well preserved. Stayed there in the middle of the day, we loved it so much.

Small surprise packet. Got up at 4.00 am , drove to this temple it was still dark, the sun came up and i was the only one there for at least one hour -MAGIC. The carvings are outstanding, the temple is volcanic rock and pink limestone and is well worth a look , the detailed inscriptions and carvings have been really well preserved. Go early miss the crowd and the hawkers!!

Serene setting. This Khmer temple is set in a nice rural serene setting. A bit different from the others as it is basically Hindu and not Buddhist and it is considerably smaller than most others in the Angkor area. It is made up of 3 chambers and there are some interesting and very detailed bas relief carvings on its wallsThe temple has been carefully restored and is well maintained and well worth a visit. Care must be taken if there has been rain as the stones underfoot are very slippery

Worth the trip. After seeing the temples close to Siem Reap we decided to go further afield to Banteay Srei. We hired a tuk tuk for the day ($25 for the day!) and headed out to the temple. Our driver was wonderful in offering us opportunities to stop anywhere along the way if we wanted which we had planned on doing on the way back.Banteay Srei is very different to the other main temples we had seen, it doesn't have quite as many hawkers (which is a nice change) and the tmeple itself seems to be made of different material, volcanic rock I think. The colours are different and the crowds are less.We spent the time wandering around the path at the back of the temple back to the main entrance which was worth the 10-15 minute detour.The ride in the tuk tuk to the temple was one of the memorable parts of the day as well. If you don't want a private tour guide each day hire a tuk tuk, it is so much fun trundling along to get to the sites.

One of the best sites there. In an entire province of beauty and mesmerizing views, this site stood out even more. It requires some time to get there as it is a little further away, but it is worth the trip.

A bit far but excellent. Do it as part of all the temples , will give you a chance to see the country side We hired the tuk tuk that picked us up from the airport , If you are comfortable walking then he will take you to Angor Wat , Angor Tom ( Bayon Temple ) , Ta Prom and Banteay Srei all in one day , so you can complete them in a day pass ( $20 per day ) and the next day you can do Beng Mealea the next day . The tuk tuk rental for the first day was $39 and I think it is $ 40 to visit Beng Mealea . The price list for tuk tuk will be in the room or the font desk can provide it., if you are solo you have the option to take the mini bus etc .. check with the front desk.The name if my driver was Toluah and his number is 0886644479. I stayed close to Pub StreetWe had to leave early to see the sunset ( 5 am ) , it will be crowded but I think you can miss this if you don't want a sun rise picture with the temple in backdrop , its mostly a photo event.However get there early say around 6 am before the crowds get there

A tiny jewel box, a perfect complement to massive Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat. Too bad about the rain squall timed to coincide with our visit.Not to worry. We came prepared. And it was the only squall while we were out of the van.

Best of Show. We were unprepared for the beauty of this sight. The detail in the carvings made this the jewel of the jungle. Only negative is, it was pretty crowded by the time we arrived and there's a fairly long walk to the exit with vendors hawking their wares.
Wow. Avoid the crowds, get here as early as possible. You may be on your own. You may have an experience you will never forget. Go !

Intimate and Beautiful. This was one of my favorite temples. It is about a 40 minute drive through the Cambodian countryside to arrive here. That alone is beautiful. Come early in the morning to beat the crowds and you will have a better experience. This temple has a very intimate feeling about it and the stone carvings are magnificent. Don't miss the photo exhibit depicting the history, discovery, and pre-restoration photography.

Pink stone and very delicate art work. Worth the extra time to get to this site. The color of the stone brings to life the vivid depictions. It is a miracle that so many details were left from 1400 years ago. Our guide told us it is the pink stone the most durable of its kind and the hardest to carve that is responsible for that

Intricate detailed carvings. The Lady Temple looks like a toy city compared to the size and scale of Angkor Wat. Well preserved with ropes surrounding the central area, it's a pity we cannot see the detailed carving at a closer range as I have done before. It is still amazingly interesting.

Breathless. This was absolutely unbelievable! This is not the biggest of the temples, but it is so beautiful. The colours of the stone and the skill it must have taken to carve some of the most intricate and beautiful shapes my partner and I have ever seen.
This is a definite must, completely breathtaking!

A Very Different Temple. The temple is at ground level, with no climbing, and full of exquisite, intricate carvings. Because of their beauty, said to be "designed by a woman." Most of the stonework is pinkish, which gives a great contrast to the other grey stone temples.It is about an hour out of Siem Reap, but there is always something interesting to see on the roadside. We stopped at a new restaurant for lunch just before the temple complex; a stopover for tour groups with good food and facilities.The temple complex has an extensive visitor centre and restaurants.Well worth the trip.

90 Minutes enough to see the Details. We took less than 90 minutes to enjoy the detail in this much smaller Wat (temple). The ruins are quite well preserved. Being smaller, crowds are very evident. We saw this in the afternoon and needed an umbrella for the short shower we encountered. Excellent photo opportunities available if you are patient. This is one archeological site I recommend seeing!

Small and beautifully formed. This temple gets forgotten about as smaller than Angkor Wat and Bayon, but this 'pink' temple was built for a lady and has such a fascinating story that I would certainly implore you to visit. It has stood the sands of time well and you can imagine this temple in its hay day. It was certainly a favourite for me in Siem Reap.
Worth the trip out. It takes about an hour in a car. We tagged this temple onto a walk through the jungle up to a water fall and stone carvings. A great day out

Definitely worth the trip. This was day 3 of our temple extravaganza and to be honest I was starting to feel a little templed out. The trip out on the tuk tuk was good in itself as we got to see a bit of countryside. My temple enthusiasm was pleasantly rejuvenated once at the temple. What it lacks in size it makes up in bucket loads in detail. The carvings were some of the best stone carvings I've seen. Combined with a very tranquil setting & this temple should definitely make it on your must see list. I would also recommend to take the time to stop at the Landmine Museum on your way back to Siem Reap. Gives a nice break from all the temples and an insight into the country's troubled history.
Worth the tuk tuk ride. Our wonderful tuk tuk driver Mr Vanna took us here for a look at a different architectural style of temple - definitely worth the 1 hour or trip each way from Siem Reap.
Worth the trip. This temple, though small in comparison to others in the area, is a beautiful example of detailed carving and should not be missed.

My favorite. Amazing carvings..in the morning light the warmth and beauty of this temple can't be beat. Exquisite detail in the carvings..on our own so we could out wait tour groups to see what we wanted without hassle.

The Jewel of the crown of temples. It's like a fairy tale castle, small (Angkor scale wise) and elegant with exquisite stone carvings. Banteay Srei predates Angkor Wat Going to Banteay Srei (about 45 min out of Siem Reap by TukTuk) is very much part of the pleasure as well, passing by rice fields, dappled with palm trees. Just lovely. Banteay Srei has only recently been rediscovered (some 100 years ago). Until then, it remained hidden by the jungle.

Stunning Stone Work. This temple is a jewel. The stone carving is stunning -elegant and graceful. While Angkor Wat is amazing, we were happy we saved this temple for our last day. It was like the jewel in the crown of this wonderful area.
Different than the other Temples. Pink temple complex. Looks different than the others. Smaller and quite intact. Visit early a.m. and late p.m. for less crowds.

Such a Little Pretty Temple!. I love the countryside and rural view along the way to the temple. The temple itself is pretty and still in very good condition compared others despite the fact that it was build few hundred years earlier than other popular temples.

A jewel. The most beautiful of the temples in my opinion, the most intricate carvings and detail. Make sure you don't miss this one if you go to Angkor! Go early for great light and to beat the crowds.

Great sight; abusive mean-spirited general manager at the entry. Our visit (with an 81 year old with Parkinson's Disease) was soured by the "general manager" 0060.Arriving after a day of touring other sites, she left her ticket on the tuk-tuk (the rest of us had ours). We pleaded with the guard (General Manager) to let her in and I would return with her ticket. No? I asked if he could pay her entry? No! I told him he was being irrational since we offered to a. get her ticket b. pay for her ticket. At one point he brought his fingers up to my chest to make a point but I intercepted him and strongly suggested he not touch me. Eventually, after my guest sitting in the sun for half an hour we were able to exit the area, find our tuk-tuk and return to enter without an apology or any understanding.The site is worth a visit and a great representation of the history and culture of the region. Having been in Cambodia three times previously I was surprised by this encounter with 0060 at Banteay Srei

Less than expected. If it was located somewhere in the middle of Angkor Tom, Banteay Srey would perfectly fit our itinerary and leave a better impression. However, wasting two hours on the roundtrip to this temple doesn't pay off. The temple ruins are small, you can easily explore it in 20 minutes. There're some beautiful carvings, however, you can see them at better preserved and less crowded temples, such as Banteay Samre.

The most intricate carvings and a very well preserved temple. All in pink, it is one of the more delicate and beautiful temples. Everything is very well preserved or restored. A little further away but well worth the effort.

Exquisite Carvings. Located a bit outside the other Angkor Temples, Banteay Srei, also known as the temple of women is must visit temple when you visit Siem Reap.The carvings are exquisite and the colour makes it look even more beautiful. The scenes from the Indina epic, the Ramayana and several of Vishnu's incarnation's can be seen here. No words to describe the beauty of Banteay Srei, be there to see it and feel it.

Worth the additional journey to visit. This very ornate and relatively small temple is 35 km from Siem Reap although still covered by the Angkor Temple pass.Probably our second favourite complex. Also becomes quite crowded once the large tour groups descend although a one way entry and exit system does ease the flow.
A gem. While a bit further away from Siem Reap than most of the temples this is well worth a visit. It is quite different and has a character all its own.

The colors of this temple ruin is amazing. Banteay Srel is worth seeing as it is different from most of the other temples in its color. It is smaller than most of the temples in the area but most beautiful.
Pink pretty temple. I loved that this temple is the only temple made of pink stones and it is a very small and quaint temple. One of my favourite temples to date :)

Pink lady, known for its pink colour and carefully carvings. This temple is not big, but is is known for its pink colour and carefully carvings. If you translate Banteay Srei, it makes "pink lady". And they also call it The Womans Temple.Normally locals in Cambodia are nice, but during our visit here we experienced that they still feel that they are in conflict with Thailand. We used ricehatt that we had bought in Thailand. A guard at Banteay Srai was angry because we used this in Cambodia. So, be careful

Best preserved Temple?. All the Temples around Siem Reap are well worth a visit but if you want to see the most ornate this should be top of your list.When you arrive in the car park it is clear that this is the most well organised & visitor friendly site of them all.Plenty of facilities including a market that is a respectful walk from the star attraction. The Temple is amongst a lovely backdrop of trees and if you're lucky the crowds won't be too bad.The condition of the temple is amazing with many of the original carvings intact.

The best of the temples. While it is one of the smallest it is definitely the most interesting and has the most intricate carvings of any of the temples. Don't miss this one, but have a guide so you can find out about the meanings of the carvings.

" Exceptional temple to visit and spend a few hours to enjoy ". Our visit to Banteay Srei was really worth the time and more of the expense we took during our second day in Siem Reap. We hired a tuktuk for a full day tour of Angkor Wat complex which included a visit to this temple for only $25. And it was one of the best looking temples we went to. Definitely worth recommending!
Particular, unique, astonishing. Pink stone made temple in the heart of the Cambodian jungle. Who can say having visited the Angkor Temples without seeing this unique temple dedicated to women ?
The most beautiful temple. A lot of Details and well preserved, it wasn't as overrun with tourists as many of the others and yet more lovely than many.

Red Monkey’s, Carvings & A funny HPPO. Left 0535 and arrived 0635 so exactly 1 hour by tuk tuk which the Hotel concierge said would cost $25. The countryside was interesting with rice fields, palm trees, locals on bicycles, road side stalls, firewood bundles...similar to Myanmar. The temple site is small and like Angkor Wat surrounded by a moat. A site heritage protection police officer (what’s on his badge) patrolled the temple and I slipped him US$5 which took me inside the roped part of Banteay Srei (you won’t get in otherwise) and he briskly walked me around and showed me the best photo spots and offered to take photos of me. He was all secretive and hush hush about it as if it were a big deal which made me laugh afterwards as I later saw him act it out with the next photographer! First thing in the morning is a good time to go. You would be a petrologist or a researcher of some kind to spend more than one hour here and that includes the nature walk after the temple and exit. The guy at the ticket control said it would take 20mins...it's that small. The striking thing about this temple is the guardian monkeys. The carvings are also intricate and the red sandstone prominent. The nature trail has 6 viewing platforms looking out over fields with their water lilies and is quite pretty. It ends at a main Street, double back and take the path to the restaurant and onto the car park. Best time: definitely early in the morning. I did Banteay Srei first, landmine museum second and the very underrated Pre Rup temple third and back in time for breakfast at the Hotel which for me finished at 10am. What I find amazing is Banteay Srei is the smallest temple out of the big names but has the best facilities; a visitors center, ATM, info on restoration, souvenir shop, cafe and restaurant…until you realize it’s a big money spinner for the locals.

My favourite. I visited many different temples in Siem Reap. The biggest Angkor Wat did not impress me. I visited Bantarey Srei in the morning when there is no crowds. It looks amazing. Definitely my favourite. The nicest curvings of all temples in SR.

My day exploring Banteay Srei Temple. I bought a $40 USD three day ticket and my Tuk Tuk driver suggested we go to Banteay Srei temple first and spent one hour driving to this temple through interesting countryside with plenty of village road side stalls for curios or food & drink. When I arrived at this temple which was quite busy but left these people and I explored the jungle and magnificent trees as well as boat rides and wetlands around this site which benefits the local villagers in financial work and after walked through the temple areas and was much impressed with the red volcanic rock and figures carved into the doorway lentils and the reflection pools are quite impressive. There is a museum on site under cover at exit which details with photographs and history every detail any historian or layman could desire, I recommend this Banteay Srei temple as well worth a visit.

Try not to miss this temple. This beautiful temple may be about 45/60 minutes out of Siem Reap in a tuk-tuk but so worth the effort. While much smaller than Angkor Wat and the Bayon, it is in such a different style with exquisite carvings in the red sandstone.

Most beautiful temple of them all!. Thanks to our tuk-tuk-driver who did the planning on our first day, we came here pretty early in the morning which is why the crowds were still not too bad. The carvings are just so beautiful and delicate, and it's like a miracle that they have endured the time and the climate. It's set in very nice and natural surroundings so you can take a stroll after you've admired the temple. It's really gorgeous and in my opinion the most beautiful of them all!

Mostly unknown but beautiful. We saw Banteay Srei after we saw Angkor Wat and I thought it would be difficult to impress me after Angkor...But it happened ! Banteay may be smaller, but the details are more beautiful that Angkor, and so is the colour. It is a very pleasant visit, well preserved and not quite as busy as Angkor. Well worth seeing !!

One of the must see. We took the Grand Tour guided tour from one of the many tour offices around Siem Reap for USD 15 for Banteay Srei and several more places. The facilities are all quite good in there, like there are bathrooms available for free for the tourists and small shops. Real great statues as well, so don't forget to visit if you ever get here.

Pretty, small temple. About 40 mins by tuk tuk, this temple is the most interesting, with all those intricate carvings. There are plenty of people when we came, but this didn't ruin the experience. There is an adjacent market, which has cheaper prices than in the night market (especially if you bargain) so it's good to check it out.

The prettiest of all Angkor temples!. Bantaey Srey is unarguably the prettiest of all temples in Angkor, and that is saying something because every single one of them is beautiful! It is built entirely from rose pink sandstone, and is also called the Citadel of Women because of its intricate carvings; and these make it a must visit on your Siem Reap itinerary.Would recommend you go really early morning or late afternoon, when it is less crowded.
Small so easier to 'take-in'. Small and pretty with deep intricate carvings into an attractive colour of sandstone. In my view it is well worth a visit.
Crisp detail despite age. This is a living art book. Fantastic carvings and bas-reliefs that are still quite sharp, after 800yrs. Have to be thankful the builder chose the harder pink sandstone.

Small and unique. This temple is a fair drive but it is very worth.It was built in the mid 10th century & is very well preserved. It is built from sandstone with a pinkish hue which makes it very unique next to other temples.The temple is quite small but the delicate nature of the carvings is not found in any other Khmer temple.Our awesome guide 'translated' many of the carvings into wonderful stories for us; it made our visit memorable.Best visited in the morning; you may just miss the tourist buses, but if you don't; hang back & enjoy what the outside of the temple has to offer, there are many carvings & sculptures to view. The tourist groups tends to speed on into the main section of the temple. Pretty soon you'll be practically on your own.Things to remember:* Cover up. Dress respectfully* Wear a hat & sunscreen - it's HOT* Take your time* Use a guide to fully appreciate the temple (PM me if you want details of a great guide)

Worth the drive. Its a smaller temple that is extremely well preserved. Because its a bit of a hike, you won't have the same crowds as at the close-in famous sites. The temple is called the Womens' Temple because of the delicate nature and detail in the carvings. This temple, we are told, was the temple of the teacher of Suryavarman II, and its made of pink stone.
Beautiful but small. This is the most ornate temple we saw in Angkor, but in the worse condition and a long drive up away from the main complex. Worth a visit I think, but not unmissable.

Most beautiful decorative wall carvings of all temples at Angkor Complex. Although it's out of the way, true temple buffs won't want to miss Banteay Srei, a beautiful 10th-century Hindu temple complex about 23 miles north of Angkor Wat. Love the carving sculptures, really deep and beautiful! Also a lot of interesting stories illustrating on the temple walls.

This is the one NOT to miss. What a gem in the forest. Exquisite carvings and beautifully preserved. Angkor Wat complex is so big you have to make choices about which temples to visit - and this one is a MUST

A jewel of a temple. Probably the temple I loved the most. It is on a more human scale than the huge temples. The carvings are sublime. It is truly amazing that such delicate has been preserved so well.

Beautiful carvings!. What people say is indeed true. The best carvings I saw... Only one down side, full of people, even n low season. Just like most temples, try to go early in the morning or later in the afternoon.
unique. the furthest UNESCO site in siem reap. it took me one hour fifteen minutes there by tuk-tuk. however, it is worth the trip
A unique temple. A unique temple compared to other temple in Angkor park as the carvings are extremely intricate and miniature compared to the rest of the park.
Beautiful carving. This temple is very beautiful. It has deep carvings and artistic decor is so fantastic. I love it so much!
different. It is best to go by car as it is a bit far by tuk tuk , but a real beautiful temple well worth the visit .

My favorite temple of all!. This was my favorite temple. I felt so calm and peaceful walking through the grounds. I'm not sure why but I felt so connected there. Maybe it is the scale, it is smaller and more intimate.
Bandeau Srei temple. This is an unusual temple in the Siemens Reap area, characterized by the pink sandstone construction and the miniature carvings in exquisite detail. Built in the 10th century.

Beautiful Ancient Carvings - Truly Unique. The red sandstone, the well-preserved ancient carvings, the intricate detail - what's not to like? What this temple lacks in size (relative to Angkor Wat and the other big temples) it makes up for in quality. A beautiful and unique temple, celebrating the female warriors that defeated the Chams. Worth making the extra trip.

Commendable effort by the Swiss govt. for the restoration work.. Banteay Srei is slightly further away from rest of the temple sites. But, the restoration work done by the Swiss government is commendable. They approach it in a more holistic way, not neglecting the surrounding vegetation, you find padi fields surrounding Banteay Srei, lakes and free-roaming fowls with their little chicks. There was a very well curated exhibition hall explaining the restored works in details. I felt a difference here that it doesn't gives the feeling of an abandoned historical sites. The carvings also did not suffer as much corrosion as compared to other temples. Debris or broken bricks were properly laid and displayed orderly. I would say I enjoyed my visit here the most, after the Bayon. There are comparatively fewer touters bugging me to buy their products.

Small Temple, but Great. This is temple is far from Siem Reap, city, but it is very nice temple. You would be there before 10:30 am and after 2:00pm. You will be get a beautiful color ( Pink Color ). The carving are clear, the location is wonderful.

Pink-sand temple. A temple that's more than 1000 years old. It's a much smaller temple compared to other temples in Siem Reap. Lots of detail stone carve works to see. Our tour guide was not very helpful in telling the stories but we were amazed by the architect and the details of this temple.

Loved this temple. This is much smaller than the other well known temples but it is really lovely. The intricate carvings and the pink sandstone make this worthwhile to visit even though it is a little further away. It is also set in a lovely treed area. Once again it requires a long walk to reach, so if you have some mobility issues and you have your own guide, he can arrange for a motor bike service to get you in closer. Highly recommended.

Must see site. The prettiest temples in the area. It is a bit far from the main Angkor Wat temple area, but that means less crowds. It is more than 1000 years old, but in remarkable shape with the unique stone color. It is a significantly smaller site, but the design and architecture is fabulous. A must see site.

Exquisite. This was a terrific surprise - and in such a lovely location. Navigating the challenges of the large crowds was a little frustrating but it was worth it. Facilities and the interpretative centre were high quality.

GORGEOUS!!. What at first annoyed me became my favorite thing -- the "inner sanctum" of this temple is cordoned off so you cannot climb around inside like you can at Angkor Wat, the Bayon or Ta Prohm. While initially miffed, as soon as I started taking photos, I was delighted with this choice as I have magical photos with no strangers in them! The delicate carvings are exquisite and probably my favorite among the 4 temples mentioned in this review. No visit to Siem Reap is complete without seeing these major and important sites.

The Pink Temple. Just perfect, this temple is more than a 1000 years old and in marvellous condition. The detail of the frescos is really unbelievable. My favourite of all the temples..... Built for the kings mother.

fantastic pink stone temple. We really loved this temple though it is small yet great carving on pink stone, it is an hour drive from town and it also worth visit. Banteay Srey is our favorite temple during our trip at Siem Reap Angkor Wat.
A bit further away. ...from the rest of the temples. It's not a big size, but the details in the stone carvings will leave you in awe. One of the must see temples if you go to Angkor.

The lady temple. This temple is different to the others, being almost pink in colour. The green moss growing makes it a great photo op. The other good thing is that a lot of the statues haven't been desecrated here. Sadly the faces of a lot of the statues at most temples have been stolen by poachers. There has been a big campaign to get them returned and repairs are evident at most temples. This temple area is a way out of town but makes a good op to see the country side.
The Pink Temple with great carvings. Worthwhile to go out there. Great carvings. Don't forget to make a short stop at the landmine museum.

Overhyped. Our driver talked constantly about this 'lady temple'. We asked to go to Beng Mealea, and drove us here instead. (He said it was on the way). If you are into viewing carvings from behind a rope, then go for it. Part of a terrible trend, the large parking lot, visitor's center, and tour buses ruin it. Yes, the carvings are good, but they are obviously reconstructed. The security guard offered to let us past the rope for $5. We declined, and left after 10 minutes.

Worth the 12km. This temple is about 12km or something away from the main archeological park, but it was worth ever km. This is the place where you need to go if you want to be charmed by the beautifully carved temples, built with pinkish stones.

Superb rock carvings. It's about 16 km or 40 mins by tuk tuk and around $13 extra dollars on top of the big circuit price. If you have time it's worth the trip just to drive through the country side. The temple itself had great rock carvings, best I have seen in Angkor. This was our second temple day on which we did the big circuit which only took half a day so we had time. Also had lunch on the way to fill the day in.
Amazing. Its far from those angkor wat temple area, 15KM ahead, but worth a visit, if the angkor wats are known for the kings, Banteay's are known for queens, marvelous showcase of architecture.

The most beautiful of all the Temples. This s perhaps the smallest of the temples, but nearly every piece of stone has been carved with magnificient figures. The pictures tell a story.
This place just amazes me each time I come here (my 3rd visit)
A must see on your visit list
beautiful. the carvings are well worth the visit and a visit to the Museum before hand would help most people to understand the stories and myths depicted on the sides of both this and Angkor Wat.

Stunning!. Of course all the temples are utterly captivating, but we fell in love with this one. The carvings are incredibly ornate and the beautiful red stone, all come together to make this a perfect little package.As some people have mentioned, it is quite a way out of town, but unlike a few of those, I would say its worth the trip.It should be noted that the main area has indeed been roped off, which at first does seem a shame, but it's a necessity if we wish to save this stunning piece of history for further generations and you aren't kept so far away you can't still appreciate the complexity of the stunning carvings

Beautiful as 'ruin'. At 37 km out of central Siem Reap, this is a bit out of the way. However, we travelled there by tuk tuk which went at just slow enough speed for us to take in life in the villages and paddy fields along the way. We also stopped at the Landmine museum which is also on the way - so it made a worthwhile half day trip.The temple is unusual in the colour of its stone (pink) but also in the intricacies and details of its deep carvings. Only the central part of the temple is restored but somehow the remaining "ruin" also reminded us of the passage of time and it's fight with the jungle. Altogether it makes for a beautiful site. There is also a good exhibition on the history and restoration of the temple with good descriptions and old photographs.Perhaps the tile "Lady temple' is a good description for this does remind someone of a delicate and refined lady, and not a big and muscular gesture like Ankor Wat.
nice but far away. Interesting site, but so far away from the other sites in Angkor. I wouldn't go out of my way to visit.

It was just okay. The road to reach this place is horrible and the sight was just okay. It was just a one level complex, quite small compared to the rest. The only difference is the color (orange) which they call it pink.

Amazing!. This temple is small but the carving so detail and fine. I think this is the most beautiful carving temple in Cambodia.The location is a bit far from Siem Reap, but along the way there you can drive through the local village which is so interesting.

Elaborated craving site. I personally think it is a cute site and having best craving of all. However, consider the size and location I don't think it is worth to go if you have one day trip. I took a car because it is 37kms away and we were taken to have lunch a very pricey restaurant. The car costed around $40 with other sites around Angkor Wat area as well.
Great introduction. See this site early in the day, before it's crowded. We had seen My Son in Vietnam, but this is far better -details much better preserved.

cute. while all other angkor temples are very large, this stands apart as the smallest temple, but one of the most beautiful for its fine intricate carvings. this was built by a rajguru and is a must see.

Beautifully preserved temple. Banteay Srei is one of best preserved temples and is elaborately decorated. It is built from rose-pink sandstone and the carved walls and entrances are really beautiful. It is known as a jewel of Khmer Art. It is about 30 km’s from Siem Riep and worth the visit.

Fantastic. It was a little bit further away from other, but I was also enjoyable to be there. The carving on the wall was the highlight of this temple. as well a little bit crowded, have to have time to manage to escape from this
Good for history and architecture buffs, a photographer's heaven.... great place to relax, and chill and surround yourself with the history that once filled this place..

My favourite. If temples can be called 'cute' then this is the temple that fits that description. A different style of architecture to the majority of other temples. Well worth the extra distance to visit.

Great temple, not my favourite, but in my top 3 in Angkor. Firstly ensure you buy a ticket from the one and only ticket office at the Angkor site. The ticket is $20 for a day, $40 for 3 days, or $60 for a week. The ticket will have your photo on it and is therefore non transferable. This temple is far from the other temples and if you get here without a ticket you could end up going all the way back! You cannot buy tickets here.If you don't have a driver negotiate a 'daily' price with a tuk tuk driver and tell them what temples you wish to see. $20 is a reasonable amount for the day.This temple has the best site information from any of the temples. There is a small visitor centre with toilets available. There is plenty of the temple still to see and some great photos to be taken.As you walk out the back of the temple there are a couple of signs to a viewpoint, and to boats. We followed both of these. The view point will take you to the right as you walk out the back, then round to the side. There is an elevated wooden platform where you can get great photos of the whole temple.We also went to the boats. They wanted $7 to take 2 people through the lilly/lotus lake, back to the car park. We negotiated $5. It took about 20 minutes and we had a lovely time going though the lake, well worth the $5 for two of us.If you only have a day then this probably is not worth the visit given the travelling time required. But if you have longer then its definitely worth a visit.

Nice temple though far and pricey to go.. The temple is different as those in the Angkor Park, unique and small. It look more organize than other because have better set up at the information counter area. Quite far from the town that why have to pay more than others like around 23 USD for tuk tuk and It's too far for bicycle.

Great temple. This temple is good and interesting but its in a place of incredible temples! Worth a visit but dont spend too long here - especially if you only have 1 day! The other temples are better!

The pink limestone temple. Often overlooked by tourists as the more popular Angkor Wat and Tah Phrom seem to top the lists, but this is a smaller temple which can be just as beautiful as the big brothers, its constructed from pink limestone which sets it apart from the rest and at the right time of day its such a great sight to see, it really does change color with the light, well worth the trip. Its quite run down but still is a magnificent sight to see.

Small but intricately designed temple. Banteay Srei was a small temple, but one of my favorites. The combination of colors, between the lava mud and the lichen and the color of the temple itself was quite exquisite. More than any of the other temples, this one has carvings that are very detailed. There are many carvings on door frames that tell many stories of the Hindu gods. There are a lot of locals selling postcards and trinkets here. They are selling them at all of the temples, but for some reason I felt like they were a bit pushier here than the other temples.

Must have in Siem Reap's itineary. Although the temple is located a bit far from Angkor Park (around 40-minute drive), you will not be dissapointed. The temple has a very detailed, yet beautiful reliefs in the fascinating pink/red laterite.Before you enter Banteay Srei, make sure you visit the interpretation center first. It is located in front of the restaurant near the parking area. As the temple is smaller compared to others inside Angkor Park, you can walk lightly while enjoying its reliefs and decoration. Unfortunately you cannot enter the main temple as there is a line preventing the visitors to enter. It is understandable to protect the detailed decorations.PanggahJogja, Indonesia

My first Angkor temple. The pink sandstone and red laterite walls give it a modestly weathered appearance. This wasn't the large monument I had expected, maybe 5mins walk around the outermost wall. Inside this is a wide lily covered moat, giving an incredible reflection of the central shrine towers. All over the temple walls there are well preserved carvings and ornate archways leading to the inner enclosures. Unfortunately due to increased visitor numbers the inner chambers have been roped off, but there is easily enough on the outside to keep you strolling for over an hour.

A different but beautiful temple. This is about 40 mins away from Angkor Wat but well worth the visit. Not as crowded, is more red in colour and beautiful contrasts on a sunny day. The kids played temple run in this one - small enough that we knew where they were!

Lovely Pink Temple. This temple is only small but has some beautiful carvings and statues and if you are lucky you might get to hear local musicians playing traditional music. Get there early, before the hordes of 'selfie posers' drape themselves in every door frame you are trying to photograph. Hire a tuk tuk and bounce your way out there early in morning. Nice ride through emerald rice fields and traditional country villages. It is worth the trip and a pleasant change after the overwhelming larger temples. Sneak out the entrance gate when you are finished and you will miss the shop lined exit with everyone wanting your business.

Beautiful Pink temple with very detailed carvings. This smaller pink sandstone temple is unique and definitely worth a visit. Build in 10 the century, the carvings are magnificent Be aware it can be very crowded. We use private Tuk tuk and guide and went early not going by a tour prevents you for stops at crappy tourists stops.Its a bit further away but worth the visit.
Beautiful little temple. Saw this on a rainy late morning. Well worth the trip. Lots of intricate carvings. Beautiful colour. A contrast to the vastness of Angkor Wat.

after visiting in the other temples you can skip this one. ok, so you visited ta-phrom, angkor watt and the bayoun, there are a lot more temples to discover but this one isn't one of them. The use of the red stones is nice and unique, but that's it. If you have time for another temple and a bit far from Siem Reap, go to Kbal Spean.

Beautiful temple. We visited Banteay Srei as part of an Intrepid tour through Cambodia. Banteay Srei was very different from the other temples. The pink sandstone and carvings were spectacular. This temple was quite small, and in a state of further disrepair, but that said, it was built in the 10th century. Definitely worth a visit.

Far but worth it. We paid USD15 to a tour agency to get us here. There were 5 of us in an air-con van, so it was fairly comfortable. I was glad we made the trip here. Though far, it's different from the other temples, but very beautiful. The bad thing, as with most tour trips, was that they stopped us at a CRAPPY place for lunch. Over-priced and bland. If I could have packed a sandwich I would! Included in the trip too was a palm-sugar experience. Hmm not sure experience is the right word - it was a stop along the side of the street, and we saw mini balls of palm sugar being made by 2 cambodians. And that was it.
very small. I was a little disappointed by it, it's very small. For me, the road and the money spent for the tuk-tuk were not it.

One of the best. It is part of the grand circuit tour. At first we thought the grand circuit temple tour would just be same as day 1 of Angkor but at the end of the day we were left spell bounded.we recommend not to miss this tour at all as the temples in this circuit are way different to the others.Banteay is one of the best temples in entire Angkor. It has amazing carvings which i could not see in entire Angkor. the temple is small but craftsmanship at this temple is unmatched.

The tour of the countryside made this tiny temple a great stop. Stop by the butterfly sanctuary.. The temple is super tiny. Yes, the carvings are amazing- but you can't get right up to many of them. The color of the sandstone is red, like brick, so that is unique. I think I would have gotten more out of it with a guide to tell me stories of all the carvings. But the drive... Oh- the drive was relaxing and lovely! We took a tuktuk so the pace was breezy and we got to see water buffalo swallowing in rice paddies, under blue skies and coconut tres. It was so lovely. This was definitely worth the trip. Also, on the way back, we stopped by the butterfly sanctuary and for $4 got to see many species and all the stages of metamorphosis. Also, there were huge stick bugs! So neat!

Worthwhile excursion!. We loved Banteay Srei - take a Tuk Tuk from Siem Reap to this amazing temple; great to be able to explore the temple without the hordes of tourists. Take time to stop at the Landmine museum on the way.
One of my favourites. Further out then some of the main temples but was worth the trip. A smaller Hindu temple with some beautiful carvings. Great views of the countryside on the way there
Great temple. I know it is further but you really have to see it, it is magnificent. The pink color of the stone is so nice.
Stunning. Another amazing attraction, when we arrived it was a bit busy but nothing major, set inside the lake it was absolutely stunning to see

Well worth the drive, don't miss it!. This one is a little away, just over 30 Kms from the others, so I wonder if it gets all the traffic, which is a real pity, as this one of the most beautiful of the Angkor temples we saw. The pink sandstone, the details on the carvings, the small yet pretty temple set against beautiful landscape, captures one's heart. Well worth the drive, and the journey there, through semi rural Cambodia, is also very picturesque!

The Lady Temple. Fantastic! This may be my favorite temple....or at least top three. It is off the beaten path. I enjoyed the long tuk tuk ride to the temple and didn't even mind the rain on our return. She is beautiful!
Fabulous carvings. Amazing temple - with the best intricate carvings in the area! The pink sandstone and detail in the carvings was amazing! Definitely worth a quick visit to see!

Off the beaten track but worth the trip. This is one of the best preserved compound we saw on our trip. The carvings look like they were just done. The area is not too large and is in fairly good shape.

Worth the extra travel. Although its an extra 20 klms or so North of the more popular temples, its worth the trip because of unique architecture and the type of stone used (red sandstone). We took a tuk tuk from Siem Reap and it was a pleasant ride (about 1 hr) and view of the country side in the fresh air. Did the landmine museum on the way back to town.

A bit disappointed. After traveling around the main temples the two hour trip to this temple seemed a little disappointing. The temple is small and though the carvings are amazing slot of it is roped off so you cannot get close enough to see or appreciate it.
Banteay Srei. Banteay Srei (also known as Citadel of the women) is a beautiful site where you can find the finest stone carving that I believer you cannot see anywhere on the planet

one of the most ancient. Located out of siem reap town, this temple is one of the oldest. The pink sandstone has a different charm. Many shiva carvings, mahabharatha, Ramayan stories carved. If you have knowledge about hinduism you understand better. The temple is one of the best restored ones.

Beautiful red sandstone temple with a wonderful pond to observe nature. Banteay Srei was one of the temples that my husband and I enjoyed the most, first because when we visited, there were only a handful of other tourists which made it great to explore, take wonderful pictures and truly spend time to enjoy such a beautiful place. Built in the 10th century, it is amazing how well some of the carvings were preserved. Also, there is a pond out front which we spend about 20min walking around and finding fish, frogs, etc which was fun for us adults and I think would be a great break for families to enjoy the natural surroundings and not just hop-on-hop-off around all the temples.

One of the temples to visit. If you do not want to visit all the temples, this is one of the temples you should visit. It is very different from Angkor Wat and you would appreciate this place. It was a bit far from other temples but it is definitely worth going to!

fine relief work worth a serious trip here. Tucked away from the Angkor Wat temple this one deserves a visit for its excellent display of intricate stone curving and solitary set-up. Take time off here as time stands still and enjoy the clamness and imagine the grandeur during its days.

The Women's Temple. No words can describe this Wat, it is exceptional, it's calming, it's the most amazing little temple I have ever been to. Get your guide to take you there at midday when everyone else is having lunch to avoid the crowds. Just go, you won't be disappointed.

Take your time to look at it all.. It can be hard to pick which temple you should spend more time in in the Angkor region as there are so many things to see.Personally, I think they're all great so I suggest a bit of research to thin the list if you prefer the main sites and a guide so the significance can be appreciated.

My Favorite. This so far is my favorite temple in Cambodia. It was worth the 37km car ride to the site. The temple is small but the structures and the elaborate sculptures on the wall compensates for the size. It is also one of the very few temples made of Pink Sandstone. I love the intricate carvings on the walls and columns.

So many details. The most preserved carvings in Angkor. Hire a tuk tuk and go first to Banteay Samre, then to Banteay Srey. You can also go by bike, and it's a nice ride, full of rice fields and palm sugar trees filling the horizon, but it will take you almost the morning to really enjoy the ride.

Off the beaten (tourist) trail...worth a visit. We took an excursion here from our hotel base in Siem Reap having spent the days previously visiting the much larger temple complex at Anghor Wat etc. This temple is also about 1000 years old but in reasonable good condition and located about 1 hour away from the much more busy temples at Anghor Wat. The drive is an experience in itself, the roads almost qualify as an oxymoron...however the sights from the coach as you pass through truly authentic Cambodia villages are remarkable in themselves and thats before you arrive at the temple. The carvings and bas reliefs are in very good repair and the whole place has an air of peace and tranquility not experienced at Anghor Wat.If you have the chnace its well worth a visit.

Stunning late in the day. After the long trip to Kulun Waterfalls, Banteay Srei is a beautifully laid out red stone temple with a surrounding moat. Easy to navigate yourself around, peaceful and stunning. The light changes over the structures will have you hard pressed to put your camera down. Under an hour is all you need here but well worth the journey.

Great artistry. I was amazed at the level of preservation of the temple carvings. The artistic ability is so evident and it is a gift to all who are fortunate enough to visit it. It is a smaller temple but the carving are so detailed and well preserved along with great natural colors in the stone. It was not crowded and I am happy that I made the effort to take a slight detour from the established tour for that day. Don't miss this temple when you visit Siem Reap!

Quite different from the rest, in a good way. Very intricate reddish sandstone stonework and well retained carving details. Although one of the oldest temples in the Angkor region it utilised the best stone, hence the well preserved nature of it. So much to look out for in the detail. Easy to get around, with no climbing. This temple complex is a little bit further out than others, but gives you a great chance to see some of the countryside, especially if your Cambodia experience is restricted to Siem Reap (like ours). We really liked this one...but the leaf blowing instrument of the musicians in the grounds is an acquired taste ;-). The people in the shops area outside are a bit persistent.
Beautiful red stones . Different from all the rest, the carvings and structures are all in red stone. Not much high ground to climb up and down and mostly a flat walking area.

The hike is worth it. The river has many hidden sculptures. Fortunately, one of the Apsara staff was incredibly helpful, pointing out sites that I would never have known about. The waterfall is cool and the river is clear.

Cute Temple!. Although much smaller than some other temples in the Angkor complex, it is noted for its pink sandstone walls and carved reliefs which they think may have been done by women as they are so delicate. Loved it! were done by women
Further away but still worth it!. Banteay Srei is further away so you'll need a tuk tuk to get there, but it is worth the ride. The carvings are just impressive!
The Eastern Mona Lisa. The carvings are breathtaking,most of them were well protected ,it's a pity that we can't walk close to the center.

Worth the trip to visit this unique Temple, a favourite. Banteay Srei is not in the main section of the Angkor Archeological Park. You will have to take a 30-45 minute tuktuk or bus ride to get here, but it is worth.Banteay Srei is so different from all the other temples around Angkor, not just for it's beautiful rusty colours but the style and quality of the carvings are incredible. Worth the time to visit and see a different style to the beauty of Angkor. A personal favourite.

Beautiful carving. This temple have very different carving from the others. Details of the carving is rich with Khmer culture.
Check this temple out.
Personal favourite. This was always my favourite temple before visiting and it lived up to expectation. A small site but with some amazing structures.. Lots of facilities at this temple too.

a little different than the other temples. This structure is relatively small and not to high. It got me thinking why. The monks must have had a hard time walking inside because they had to bend the whole time they are inside. I asked our tour guide Tep Nat (you can contact him at tep_nat_2007@yahoo.com) of the reason why. He said it was built that way to show respect/reverence even inside the temple. It's really better to go with a tour guide so you'll know more about the story behind the temples. The tour guides are lisenced and can speak English and other languages. The service of our groups' tour guide was $30 for the whole day.
far from the grand temple complex but worth visiting!. Located more than 20km from the city proper, it took almost an hour to get there but the trip was well worthit! The temple is sprawling :)

Stunning - Jewel of Khmer Art!. This lies about 20km north of Angkor and is considered the 'Jewel of Khmer Art' - and rightly so!! It is smaller in scale than other temples but is a temple of great beauty. The temple has exquisite decorative carvings in pink sandstone and is arranged in concentric enclosures. The carvings are beautiful, depicting narratives/stories from Hindu mythology and if you are familiar with the stories, the concentration of so many carvings and their intricacy will just blow you away!The best time to visit will be early-to-mid-morning and middle-to-late afternoon to catch the best light as the stone glows when the sun is low. It is generally peaceful as Banteay Srei does not get the huge groups of tourists like the Angkor complex.

The detail is amazing. This is one of the smallest temples in this region however a one not to be missed. What this temple does not have in size it makes up for in delicate detail. There is not a surface of this temple that is not covered in intricate carvings and sometimes it is not until you are up close that you can see the detail of fine writing. I was amazed that so much was preserved in the sandstone that it is carved out of and was so pleased to see how vigilant the wardens were in making sure people did not touch or sit on the walls (disappointingly there were quite a few people who tried). I really hope this approach continues as this is a stunning temple which I felt very honored to see and it would be a shame if it lost some of its delicacy because of thoughtless and selfish people who were more concerned about posing on a wall.

Not a "must do". Banteay Srei is one of the smaller temples within the Angkor. However, we were a bit disappointed when we arrived there. It is really a good place if you love the details and the art which is truly amazing. Anyway, compared to the big temples and considering the long way to drive, it is not a must do, especially if you are short of time.
My favourite temple. Lovely color, deep intricate carvings.....this is a little far from the main temples so you get a break from the crowds. Well worth the visit!

Old but still beautiful. Quite a long journey which full of locals houses and padi field and then you will be amazed with this orange red temple. Go early and the sunrise will make the temple looks more red and bright from far. It's one of the most beautiful temple and worth every road bump.
3D in ancient times!. The carvings in this temple is certainly intricate, until it feels like 3D. Somehow it have withstand the erosion throughout the centuries. Just marvelous.

The best temple for carvings!. A smaller temple but our guide took us there for the carvings and we were so glad that he did. They were simply stunning and in incredible condition. The details and intricacy of the carvings were very impressive. Well worth the visit.

Intricate carvings on colorful stones. Banteay Srei is (10th century) older than Angkor Wat (12th century) but appears to be more recent due to relatively better preserved condition.
The carving is beautiful. I particularly loved the spiraling leaves on temple gate arches. These gave a 3D effect.
This should not be missed if you have time after finishing temples in Angkor Archaeological Park.

Pretty but far from the other sites. A pretty and small site which can be covered easily within an hour. The carvings were more intricate than those found at the Angkor temples.
There are stalls at the entrance which sell drinks, souvenirs and some light snacks.
Recommended if you have the time to travel, as it is a little out of the way from Angkor Archaeological Park.

Small but beatiful Temple. Banteay Srei not very far from Angkor/Siem Reap area, the distance about 37 km. We go here using tuck-tuck it was a pleasant journey on the road here. The temple is not very big but packed with many decoration and also quite detail. Most preserve decoration are in the middle of the temple. Unfortunately, I was going here at wet season and got not many sun light. I think its best to go here on the dry season. This temple need more restoration effort, but still this temple its worth seeing and should on your visit list.

The Jewel of Khmer Architecture? - I think so. Banteay Srei is the only temple in the Angkor area that is built out of red sandstone. Also, the buildings are a lot smaller than in other temples which makes it unique and extra charming.We went there very early morning before the tour-bus crowds arrive and we almost had the temple to ourselves. I would recommend this to anyone since the temple is small and once you've got a busload or two going through them you will not be able to enjoy the peaceful serenity of this beautiful structure.The moat around the temple is filled with water which makes it perfect for reflection photos. The statues and carvings are very delicate and they make excellent detail shots.Also, if you like dragonflies and water lilies, there is plenty of both around the temple.Also, toilet facilities are relatively new and there is shops and little restaurants attached where one can enjoy a coconut or other refreshing beverages as well as a quick meal.
Wonderful Views. I enjoyed Banteay Sriei. The area offers significant detail. I was able to tour at my own pace. I enjoyed the tour. Dress appropriately, and take some water.

Banteay Srei( Bay Sei temple). this is the wonderful temple for tourist to visit because it show a lot of statue every wall of the temple. when we look the picture it seem smile at us gently and attractive.
Banteay Srei. An outstanding example of Khmer architecture. Excellent in every respect. On the day we visited we were ones of many, also enjoying the attraction.

Beautiful. A beautiful miniature temple located away from the giant temples in the Angkor complex. Containing the most delicate and intricate carvings of any of the temples we visited, it was one of the most memorable experiences of our trip. Highly recommended.

Very colorful. We were at this temple right around noon. There were not many other people here when we visiting, leading to a quieter visit. This temple is similar in layout and themes to the other temples, but the colors are very different. It makes a nice contrast to your other visits. The carvings here are well preserved and easy to see. The statues are in good shape as well. No climbing allowed, but that is probably why it is in better shape. Renovation is still in progress so you can see some pieces of the temple laid out on the ground waiting to be placed. We hired a taxi to take us out to here and our driver waited while we visited. I would recommend visiting this temple if you are going to be seeing other sights away from the mail temple complex.
Almost a must see. After the big three, this is the next from what i had heard and what our tour guide told us. Gets you further from town and a bit more flavor of the local area.

Strange pinkish hue but the best carvings anywhere in Angkor. There are several reasons to be include this temple in a tour of Angkor sites - smaller crowds (due to its distance from Siem Reap), small and easily manageable size, and the use of both pink and yellow sandstone which give it a unique look. But the most important reason has to be that it contains the most intricate carvings of any temple. Here, the sophistication of the carvings are taken to a whole new level, and embellished in areas with a certain rich delicacy.Interestingly, Banteay Srei was never part of the original Ankgor temple complex. Instead, it seems that it was privately commissioned by a prominent member of the Brahmin sect. Inscriptions at the site describe the meaning of Banteay Srei to mean 'Citadel of Shiva'; however, in recent times, it's been changed to 'Citadel of the Women'. Regardless of the true meaning, carvings of women (dancers?) and animal-headed characters are everywhere, many of which are stunning in their detail.

Quite and lovely carving in those pink stones. To avoid the crowd I left my accommodation at 5 since travel time is an hour. There I got the whole place all by myself. When I finished the first batch of those tour group is arriving. Worth visiting.

Worth getting a three-day pass for. A lot of people say that when you've seen one temple, you've seen them all. This is definitely not the case for Bantay Srei, which is made of a different material--pink sandstone. Hence, the bas reliefs and sculptures in the temple withstood time and the forces of nature, and are still as intricate and gorgeous.

Lovely in the morning. Got here early about 7.30 so very few people around. Definitely a good thing got great photos in the morning light with no one in them. Interesting to see such detailed carvings in a unique sandstone of pink. Again having a guide made it more memorable. Worth the 37km drive.
bai. a great way there , nice to see the country side , an interesting temple , can use your ticket there , reccommended .

Spectacular.
