The most intricate stone carving I have ever seen - it is said that a man could not have possibly carved this and it must have been done by a woman - unsure how accurate this is but I like to believe it's true. We spent a long time here - by far my favourite of all the temples. You can also take a boat ride around the surrounding lake and nature spot. IT is a little drive away (Maybe 40minutes from Angor Wat by Tuk Tuk) but well worth it. Make sure you got o the landmine museum (just $3 entry) on your way there or back!

Don't miss it. It's located about 45 mins from town by tuk-tuk but is definitely worth the extra time. The temple is one of the oldest remaining in Cambodia and is partly well preserved. The carvings are amazingly detailed and the temple was built with sandstone which gives it an apricot/orange/pink finish especially at sunrise/sundown. A bit down the road there is a restaurant that's called Banteay Kulen which has great, authentic cambodian food and an english menu (I recommend the khmer curries in young coconut).

Stunning. Stunning sculpture in pink sandstone. Intricate, delicate, and complex. I was lucky to have a friend along who knew every minute detail of Hindu mythology. Well preserved and one of the lovliest temples in the area

Stunning temple. Take a trip further afield (Tuk Tuk) whilst you are in Siem Reap out to Banteay Srei. You will find this stunning temple which is red in colour and has some fantastic photo opportunities with surrounding water. Its less busy than other temples as its further out and you can add a trip to the landmine museum along with it.
best of Angkor. This temple is worth the extra effort it takes to get here. Not the atmosphere of Ta Prohm but a well preserved jewel

Worth the drive!. Banteay Srei is fairly small compared to the other Angkor temples, but it's gorgeous. Also, because it is outside of central Angkor, it's a lot less crowded. We loved it. The carvings are gorgeous and the sandstone gives it a look that's distinctive from the other temples. Definitely worth the trip out there.

Totally worth the ride by Tuk Tuk!. Get there early. Quiet-you have the entire temple to yourself-or just a few other early morning risers. Pink sandstone-such amazing carvings, You will take many many pictures. Walk the trail after the temple that takes you back to the bathrooms and tourist stalls. look for a female seller by the name of Lourne Lourne, dark skin, about 27 years old. great person, will give you the best deal on items you want to purchase.

Maybe the highlight?. There are so many fantastic temples to see in the area that it would be hard to pick one out as the highlight but this one is up there. And it is unfortunate that too many tour companies don't allow enough time for it to be included. Not least there is the contrast of this place with others such as Angkor Thom and Bayon Temple.

Totally worth it! Can't miss it!. Some may be discouraged because it is 25km far from Siem Reap. But don't think and go there! The carvings are incredebly well-preserved: it looks like lace! I have never seen carvings of such quality! Do not miss it! We were there in July 2014 and we arrived in the temple around 10am, there wasn't so many people...Considering what we read before getting there, we were expecting much more!

Angkor on a smaller scale. I had to hire an armed guard when I went here in the early 90s but it's safe now - and there shouldn't be any landmines lying around any more. No reason not to go then! Stunning and intimate temple site.
A bit far. This temple is a bit further away from Siem Reap, but worth the effort, and the carving is really amazing.... small temple, but very impressive.
Beautiful. I felt like i was taken back in time. A beautiful temple which shows how the other temples would look like without restoration. It was my favourite temple to explore. What an adventure :)

Temple with Pink Sandstone. A 10th century remote Cambodian temple dedicated to Hindu god Shiva. Banteay Srei - citadel of the women, or citadel of beauty.Far off town, drive by car takes about 45min. Require more time for tuk tuk. You may visit the below places, which is nearby Banteay Srei before proceeding to other temples.* The Cambodian Landmine Museum* Banteay Srei Butterfly Centre* Cambodia Shooting RangeVisit Banteay Srei with Angkor Pass.

Red sandstone temple. Combine this with a trip to Kbal Spean and you will have a taste of the Cambodian countryside. This small scale temple has intricate carvings. A pool in front of the temple has the best photo op. We once visited when it had lotus in full bloom. This is called the Citadel of Women for its tiny architecture and it is said the carvings are so delicate they can only be carved by the hand of a woman. There are clean toilets here and a nice cafe. As always remember your temple pass for entry.
Small and beautiful. Beautiful pink temple. Very small but worth a visit. Long time ago, we could walk inside, now we couldn't. My most favourite gate keeper is here.

What a gem!. It was a definite must on my list and how wonderful it was to arrive in the rain to this magical small temple bathing in all colors of wet stone, it was late afternoon and the rain enhanced the colors, no matter how and what, I took my time and was thrilled to see this little gem, detail of stone carving is beautiful and the architecture of the place adds value to seeing most the of temples over a course of few days, one starts to see the difference in style and periods. I thoroughly enjoyed visiting this temple which one can do when visiting Kbal Spean on the same day. There weren't many people and the photo opps will be cherished for the future!

A beautiful temple, but way too crowded to enjoy!. Banteay Srei has a lot of exquisite carvings, and I'd give it 5 stars if the whole experience hadn't been ruined by the masses of (rude) visitors. If you can get here when there aren't many people, I'd bet it would be one of the best temple experiences of Angkor architecture, so if this is a priority, talk to someone about when to go to miss the crowds!

Pretty. Small and very out of the way but I am so glad I visited. Definitely very unique of its kind since it was a temple that was not commissioned by the King but rather a Priest. The temple is in excellent condition and love the pinkish sand color.

Simply beautiful. There is something stunningly beautiful about Banteay Srei. One of the smaller complexes of Angkor, there is something about it that calms the soul; the ambience, for me, was surreal. Although incomparable in many ways, certainly in size, Banteay Srei, is equal in beauty and majesty to Angkor Wat itself.The approximate 20 miles to get there is so full of lush green paddy fields and little villages that the tuk tuk ride itself was part of the amazing experience.

Pretty temple but far away.. We had only one day to do as much of Angkor as we could. We did the three main ones and decided to come here as it looked beautiful.We had hired a taxi driver to chaperone us all day but he wanted another ten dollars as this temple was about half an hour drive away. Having not had our fill of temples yet we accepted. It was a pretty temple but it isn't that big. There isn't a whole lot to see and the guide book made it sound bigger. Not the best temple but you may as well see it as you're here.

The Pink Beauty. Banteay Srei is worth every one of the 20 miles north of Siem Reap you will have to travel to get to this absolutely gorgeous temple who's name translates to "Citadel of Beauty". You will love the red sandstone entrance!

Excellent visitor center. While the temple is just partly reconstructed and while a good example for the early phases of construction not very illustrative for he children, the flat-roof visitor center helped a lot to close that gap, showing with drawings and photos the process of reconstruction and the different outline of the temple in its initial state.

Good journey to make outside the main area. The best part for me about visiting this temple was the long drive through the outskirts of Siem Reap. It does take time (30-40 minutes) but you get to see the more rural Cambodian lifestyle outside of the touristy city center. I recommend combining a visit here with stops at Eastern Mebon and Pre Rup, which I enjoyed more than this temple, primarily because they have stairs to climb and panoramic views.

So beautiful. Really was the most lovely temple we visited in the Angkor area.So many detailed and pretty carvings, and the site around the temple was also really lovely, walking around the pond.We ate in the restaurant and it was ok, nothing to rave about, but we were hungry and were pleased to sit down for a while.

Good things come in small packages. Banteay Srei is only a small temple but the detail of the carvings has to be seen. Beautifully restored in places but even the parts that aren't give you a clear idea that this must have been a standout temple in it's day.

Architecture at its best. The second best temple of Angkorwat according to us. The carvings are amazing and we just loved it.The detailing in each pillar is fascinating.It majorly the story of Goddess Mahishasur Mardini ( Durga).Must visit.

Beautiful carvings. This temple was actually built 200 years before Angkor Wat (900AD, according to an infograph displayed). The carvings are very well preserved though of a very different aesthetic - these look more similar to Balinese/Indonesian carvings for some reason? The pink sandstone is beautiful - that combined with the moss growing on the stone leads to the entire temple looking multicolored. We went to the temple very early - at about 8-9am? The entire temple was empty save for us and maybe 5 other tourists. Very serene. It may be further away from Siem Reap but I found it worth the drive.

Great temple, but overshadowed by others. Went to this very far away temple as it was touted to be one of the big 5 in Angkor. Many other minor temples were way more beautiful without the crowds. I would say, unless you have 4+ days in Angkor, feel free to skip it.

Pocket sized beauty of a temple. Probably my second favourite behind Beng Mealea, due to the stone colour and intricacy of the carvings. Wonderful temple that your eye can take in in its entirety, loved it.
A Jewel Temple. This temple was built in the last half of the 10th century by the King Rajendravarman II. It is also called the Lady temple. Beautiful cravings of Apsara

Favorite temple in Siem Reap. The carvings at this temple are incredibly intricate, all the more amazing that the temple was built in the 10th century. While it was one of the smaller temples in the area and more out of the way, it is definitely worth a visit. As with all the temples, a guide is a must as they can explain the stories behind the building and the carvings.

Small and out of the way, but quaint. It is a long way outside of town, but if you want to see something up close and not flooded with hundreds of tourists, this is an option for those that want to see a temple dedicated to Shiva in a small village area.

Very intricate carvings. This was a great Temple to start with. It is not as big as others but should not be missed as the pinkish colour of the rock and the very detailed carving set it apart. Go withe a guide to explain the place to you.
amazing!. although its ruined to a significant degree it is still a very impressive temple which i highly recommend not to skip

Nice and peaceful temple - Banteay Srei. When I was at Siem Reap, of course the first place I visited is Angkor Park as other visitors.There are so many temples in Siem Reap, so after Angkor I want to go some temples there, but I had not much time for all. Banteay Srei is place I liked most. It is far from the main Angkor temples,but maybe that is the reason why not many travelers come there. It is so quite, peaceful and I like its architecture.Highly recommend destination in Seam Reap.

Fascinating trip. As others have mentioned, this temple is beautiful with exquisite carvings. Others have also mentioned that it is far from town, which is true, but to me the trip to the temple was one of the highlights of our trip to Siem Reap. I was fascinated to see how the locals lived, from surprisingly nice new homes to places that can only be described as ramshackle. The rice fields and buffalo were beautiful. So, visit this temple for the temple itself and for the ride out and back.

Jewel of Khmer Art. The temple lies quite far from the main Angkor Park. It takes about 45 minutes to an hour to reach here from Siem Reap. You will pass the landmine Museum on the way. It is a small temple built largely from red sandstone. It is also of just one story, so there is no climbing involved. It was originally a Shiva temple, but both Shiva and Vishnu were worshipped. Apart from the beauty, the temple is also famous as Andre Malreux tried to steal four statues from here and got caught. From the parking spot, you have to walk nearly a kilometre to reach the temple proper. There are three enclosures, each decorated with carvings. The innermost enclosure contains 3 buildings - two libraries and the temple proper. For fear of vandalism, the area is roped off. So you can enter the inner enclosure but cannot enter the buildings. But even then it is well worth it as this is perhaps the most richly decorated structure in Angkor. Every inch of the buildings are richly decorated with either nature motifs or from Hindu religion and myths. There are six stairways leading up to the platform of the main temple; each is guarded by two kneeling statues of human figures with animal heads; most of those now in place are replicas, the originals were stolen stolen or removed to museums.

Nice but far. We went to banteay srei on the second day of our tour. The temple is quite far from the city center (about 45 min), and not nearly as large as the other temples in angkor wat. However, it is quite charming and the detail in the carvings is amazing. It is also the oldest temple in cambodia, dating back to the 9th century. Its definitely worth a visit.
raf. a temple well worth visiting , away from the main temples but in a very pretty location and really interesting .

Glorious pink jewel. Fantastic temple complex - considerably smaller than Angkor Wat and the others but beautiful none the less and different due to the use of the pink sandstone in its construction.Another must see when in the Siem Reap area.

best temple. Banteay srie it is very very nice temple ,Banteay srei temple it pink couler it is very nice . Banteay have alot of caving on the wall and in side it Banteay srei it far from siem reap town about 40km.

Very very beautiful carving. This place had the most delicate carvings out of all temples, and the slight pink tint on the structures due to the different materials used in construction made it ever so special. If I am not wrong this temple was dedicated to women, thus the special carvings and building materials. It takes about 1.5 hour to get here with Tuk Tuk from Angkor Wat, so it's a bit far but manageable. We highly recommend this place as it is definitely different from the other temples.

Beautiful. Don't miss this more remote temple in the Angkor complex. Pink sandstone and elaborate intricate carvings make this a very memorable experience. Very different than the other temples. Don't miss

A more intimate look at what Khmer and Cambodian history has to offer.. The pink stone and amazingly intricate carvings and sculptures on the walls of this temple are incredible, every wall is covered in unbelievable carvings up to 6-10 feet off the ground that just need to be seen, also it isn't on the tour circuit of the big tour buses, so going as a small group is a much more satisfying experience. It truly is a testament to feminine beauty.

Avoid the crowds, if you can....... Fifteen years ago, the road from Siem Reap to Banteay Srei was potholed and awful, and it took two hours to get there. The good news was - fewer tourists. Now it is easily reached via a well- paved road in 30 minutes or so. The bad news is - LOTS of group tours by the bus full. Banteay Srei is an exquisite, small temple, so it can get overwhelmed. Wait around a bit, and the tour groups may eventually leave, allowing you to savor the intricate carvings and lovely setting. Try getting there really early to have the place to yourself.

Citadel of Women. Small and detailed, this is a fine example of a 10th century Hindu temple. Exquisite bas relief carving and apsara. This temple has a strongly feminine influence. This is a must see and like nothing else in the Angkor area.
Pink and intricate carvings. After Angkor Wat I didn't expect this - completely different - again with intricate carvings and stories of Vishnu and Shiva - pink sandstone. Soecial

A Jewel of a Temple. his temple has a very feminine feeling about it. In fact, it is called Banteay Srei, or the "Lady Temple." Beautiful, unusual carvings and a more petite layout than the Bayon Temple, for example. For a temple enthusiast or someone interested in seeing a real gem of a temple, do see it. It is only a few miles from Siem Reap.

The Lady Temple. From what I got from my tour guide, the carvings on this temple is one of the two/few that are different from the rest of the temples in Cambodia.Absolutely stunning to see though I would like to note that my day was slightly hampered with a sudden storm when I was there. Still, a truly magnificent place to be at which is quite far away from town.
charm. well worth the effort , we got a taxi , about one hours drive , a stunning temple and lots to see on the way there .

Pink and proud. This was a beautiful temple a little further away from the rest of them. I really liked it especially because when we went, there were few other tourists there. The carvings are the most intricate out of all the temples.
Little treasure. Far from the rest of the big structures in Angkor, but really worth the effort. Little temple, cosy and beautiful, very well preserved.

My favorite temple!. I loved that when the sun hits the temple, it turns pink because it was built on red sandstone. I was extremely luck to had the place to myself when I visited. You can see the amazing details on the walls & to think this temple is older than Angkor Wat! Amazing!

Must see - about 30 mins away by car. You need at least 3 days for the main temple places and this is one of them. Have comfy shoes and your camera ready. One of the best in-tact temples. They have a pretty good market next to the entry. A very well organized place.

My favorite temple in Siem Reap. The bas reliefs are jut out of this world and very much incomparable to other temples of Siem Reap. Rather small compared to others but the beauty is in the details. About one and a half hour by tuktuk from town center but very well worth the trip.

worth a visit Lady Temple. It is outside the main temple area, 37km out of town, but it is still worth a trip. Temple is small in size, but rich in style. After visiting the temple, you can walk around the surrounding parkland, peaceful with no crowd. You can combine the trip with visiting the Kbal Spien where 1.5km beautiful jungle hike will lead you to a small waterfall and stone carvings along the river. Take a powerful shower under the waterfall to cool off! A tuk-tuk for this half day trip out of Siem Reap cost us $25. Well worth it to visit the temple, waterfall hike and pass through remote local villages and rice fields in a tuk- tuk.

Stone memories. The sand colored temple's size and intimacy enrapture the contemplative visitor. One should not hurry through this sight or the detailed carvings will be missed. Go early when there are not crowds.
This is one of the smaller temples. It's also known as the ladies temple. It's beautifully and intricately carved, very feminine and lady like looking. Totally worth seeing.

The Lady Temple! Don't Miss This!. This is further away from Siem Reap than most of the Angkor complex, but worth the visit. I would suggest going by taxi and not by tuk-tuk, because of the distance. You can also visit the ruined temple in the same trip.
Girlie trip. 4th visit in 10 years and still takes my breath away. Don't be templed out by trying to see them all . Take your time and have rest days in between if you can.
Wow. This is a fabulous temple and its so different as it is built in rose/pink sandstone and not the grey coloured stones seen at the other sites

Its a piece of art!. Banteay Srei has the most detailed and minute carvings out of all the temples.It is relatively small compared to other temples but definitely worth a visit. Head to Banteay Srei quickly after clicking the sunrise pictures at Angkor Wat to beat the crowds. Reaching before 9-9:30 AM is recommended.

The pink temple. Like all temples, beautiful. However I was surprised that it wasn't very big given some of the reviews I had read. I think what makes this temple unique is it's pink like colour on the stones and the intricate carvings. It is worth a visit but remember it's take about an hour to get there by tuk tuk and will cost you a little more for fuel costs. I'm glad I visited it but it was not my favourite temple.
Nice temple. Interesting temple to visit, since it was around noon time where the structures were bright red, It was kinda hot so I had to whistle hoping the wind wiuld come. and it did!

Best. We toured five temples in two days and my wife and I both felt Banteay Srei was the best. It is much smaller but the detail of the stone carvings was amazing. More intricate than any of the other temples and far fewer people.
Better Preserved and Elegant Temple. I liked Banteay Srei because of it's location in a lake, very picturesque. Also, it seems to be better maintained than the other temples.

Incredibly small and cute- in and out in 1/2 hour at most. I believe this one, although many love this temple because of it's uniqueness was a bit overrated. Although nice in it's own way, I guess I was a bit disappointed how little there was to see. And it is a long way to drive to see it. If you don't have much time, I would have preferred to spend longer in Angkor Wat and the neighboring temples, Bayon and Ta Prohm and looking at the elephant wall and Temple of the Leper King.

Beautiful Pink Temple. Among all the grand temples in Siem Reap, Banteay Srei has the best wall carvings. Hands-down!The temple is small, and is just one level--perfect for the older crowd/ kids because there isn't a need to go up and down a fleet of stairs unlike the bigger temples like Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom.Only downside is that this is a bit far from the town proper, where most of the hotels are. However, Banteay Srei is definitely worth a visit--just plan a whole day visiting other popular spots near this area, too.
best temple. Banteay Srei best temple i have o lot of the caving on the wall and it is very difference anther the temple . it far from siem reap town about 40 km but it is best temple
The best carvings. This temple had the best carvings and is great for photography. The carvings are typical of this temple and it is different from the ones in Angkor Wat or other temples.

Different. loved the ride to Banteay Srei. especially when it rained, the remorque-moto we were in had its own covers to protect us from the rain but we coudl still see outside through the plastic windows. loved the beauty of this temple.

Pink Sand stone temple. Banteay Srei is very beautiful temple and shiva temple. The carving is so wonderful. We like it so much. I recommended my tuk tuk driver, please contact Kiri Boutique Hotel to look for good driver and tour guide.

Most beautiful temple in Siem Reap!!. Exquisite detailed carvings make this the must-see temple. Most of the tour guides said this is their favorite temple. Of course Angkor Wat and Bayon in Angkor Thom are on the compulsory list as well.

Beautiful wood carvings. Banteay Srei is known as "Lady Temple" amongst some of the locals. In Khmer, it's "citadel of women/beauty". This place is quite a bit a ways from Angkor Wat and because I had an extra day, I decided to go see this as well. You are able to use your temple pass that you bought back in Siem Reap. I had a driver take me there via car and I would say that it was a good 40-50 minute drive to the northern parts of Siem Reap. The temple itself was beautiful. The wood carvings are etched so delicately and intricately and the amount of detail baffled me. There is a small market area at the end of your trip where they have a variety of "souvenirs" for sale - that are very similar to the souvenirs at night market. It is considerably smaller than Angkor Wat so it will only be a short walk. But a few things to keep in mind (which you'll probably already know after visiting Angkor Wat): 1) Bring water One of the things I love about Cambodia is its humidity but that means that all that walking will require you to bring some water. Banteay Srei is more "out in the open" so there was a lot more sun exposure than say Bayon Temple or Angkor Wat. 2) Children are not tourist attractions...You have probably encountered many children trying to sell you postcards or keychains or copies of books. Please act responsibly & do not snap photos of these kids nor give them money. While this may sound cruel, the sad reality is that tourists have caused an uprise of "orphanages" within Cambodia (and many other parts of developing Asia). For more information: <<www.thinkchildsafe.org>>. 3) Make sure you already have a "Temple Pass". Can be purchased in Siem Reap and grants you access to all the other temples (including Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Prohm, etc.) I believe that you can't purchase a temple pass at Banteay Srei.
good temple in siem reap.. Banteay srei good temple and good cooler . Banteay srei a lot of caving on the wall .and a lot of tree .please you goo to see Banteay srei.

"Pink colors Sandstone wonderful tenple". Banteay Sriey temple or(Citadal women)is situated 37km northeast of the main Angkor monument group.unlike other Angkorian temples,Banteay Srie is not of royal commission,it was constructed by Yajnavaraha who served as a couselo of king Rajendravarman and king Jayavarman V.This relatively tiny temple was completed in 967AD and dedicated to Lord Shiva.Banteay Srie is constructed of pink sandstone and consists of three primary tower.it's best know for its profusion of exquisitely detailed carvings and is hailed as the"Jewel of khmer art".

Place bit far but fantastic. We took about 30minutes from the town to this temple. We are very tired during the trip to there but we feel happy after we see the fantastic statue and forest. It is very nice place with fresh air, i love it!

Most Beatiful Temple in the Complex. This temple is out of the way and not visited by many tourists, but if you get a chance stop by. The carvings in the stone, look like they are carved of wood, the red clay is gorgeous and the temple is very well preserved. Well worth the 45 min drive out to the edge of the complex! This was the most beautiful temple that we have seen in the complex!
Magnificent. So well preserved and beautiful carvings! Especially love the one with twenty-something arms. Get there before the big tours do!

Beautiful Temple!. This temple is quite far away from everything. This temple also quite different from other temple in Siem Riep?. Does look more like Hindu's temple. The temple isn't that big but it is still standing strong and beautiful. Decoration are amazing. Lucky to be there. suggest to get a tuk tuk or motorbike to reach this place. You won't make it by bicycle unless you like to. I was taking a daily motorbike with local driver to this place for $15 including other places.

Advice to independent travellers. My colleague and I were travelling from Siem Reap across to Preah Vihear in the east of Cambodia, so decided to visit the famous temples at Banteay Srie on our way, having already been to Angkor Wat on an earlier occasion.When we attempt to purchase a ticket and enter the temple site, we were denied access.We were told that the only place to buy tickets is in Siem Reap, a fifty kilometre round trip! The staff explained, through an interpreter, they haven’t got the sophisticated equipment at their site and hinted that the managing company, Sokha Hotel Co. Ltd., do not wish their staff to handle cash.We were very disappointed, also not prepared to go back and get a ticket, so continued on our journey east. Fortunately as compensation, we stopped at the Beng Mealea temple site, managed by Kham Someth Co. Ltd., who were only too pleased to sell tickets at five dollars each near the site. The site is so different from Angkor Wat. The ruined temple has trees and vegetation growing through it, and has a certain beauty all of its own. Certainly worth a visit.So independent travellers beware – buy your tickets in Siem Reap before going to Banteay Srie!

Worth the Trip. This is the most beautiful temple in the Siem Riep area. It's a way farther than the other temples and your driver will want an upcharge to take you there. Go.The deep carvings in sandstone are breathtaking. On the way there or back you can stop and see the locals harvesting and making palm sugar. Take some home.
Does not disappoint.. Full of surprises. We were lucky to visit in the afternoon when it's not busy so we could spent time to explore.

Different from other temples. Unlike the main temple Angkor Wat, this temple is small and there are many fine carvings on the walls. If you'd like to see something different from other temples, this would be the place.

One of the best. This temple of women is out of the main area but is still worth the trip - you can combine it with a visit to the landmine museum on the way. It's a different colour than the other temples and is set in beautiful grounds

Favorite temple outside the small loop. This temple may be a but further out, but it is 100% worth the extra charge for distance from your driver (we paid $20 extra to add it to our big loop tour)! While smaller in scale, It is easily the most beautiful temple, and also has a distinctly different style than all the others. Best decision of the trip was adding this to the mix! Bring an umbrella or hat though, as there is no shade!

Amazing Details!. The place is about 40km away from the cluster of temples of the Archaeological Park, thus a bit out of the way but definitely worth the trip.This was one of my favorite temples in SR. The temple is relatively small but the details of the stone carvings were amazing! You could spend well over an hour examining the different carvings in the area. September being the rainy season, rainwater filled up the entrance, creating a moat with the elevated parts. It was a beautiful sight. Unfortunately, the hour we chose to visit was one of the crowded hours so we had to struggle to get shots without other wandering tourists like us in them.(Entrance fee covered in the Archaeological Park ticket)

Worth the extra distance. We didn't need a guide for this temple visit, it's quite small in comparison to Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, but it's incredible detailed and certainly worth travelling out to.Our only recommendation is to consider a car and driver rather than a tuk tuk. It's a reasonable distance and a car would have been more comfortable on this trip. We also went a little further to Kbal Spien where there was an animal sanctuary. It was well worth the visit to see endangered species being looked after and rehabilitated after being found injured or being traded illegally.There was a small selection of simple restaurants here and good bathroom facilities so a good place to grab a break and a bite. The Animal sanctuary is right next door and does a guided tour at 1pm sharp, it takes around 1.5 hours. All in all, a really good day out and a break from the bigger crowds in and around Angkor.

Wonderful. It's a bit out of the way compared to other Angkor sites, but Banteay Srei is among the most beautiful for sure. Despite the relatively diminutive size, the colors of the sandstone and intricacy of the carvings create a sense of immersion into the Angkor Empire.
Very different. This temple complex is unique from all the others I saw and is very interesting with the seated monkey statues in front of building and the beautiful reddish tone to the stone.

Beautiful temple. This is one of the smaller temple but stands apart from others. It was called citadel of Women or Citadel of beauty . Our your guide Mr.Chan, took great effort in explaining to us the history of the temple. This temple has exquisite carving in pink stand stone. A beautiful temple to visit.

Superb. Although smaller in scale, this is an absolute gem. The pink sandstone is harder than the sandstone used in the other temples, so that the details of the intricately carved decoration have been better preserved. Visiting this place is an absolute must.

Different to the others. Being made of different stone, this was a slightly different temple to the others - worth a visit for sure. The travel out makes it harder to combine with others but you can do other things when up in the north so spend half a day at least exploring this area

Incredible! The Loveliest Temple in Angkor Park. Yes, it's a bit of a hike to get to Banteay Srey - it's about 45 minutes there and back in a tuk-tuk from Angkor Wat. Was it worth it? I've lived in Siem Reap for a long time now and I can't believe I didn't make the effort earlier. This is the most spectacularly beautiful of all the temples here and it's also in a nice compact setting which makes for a pleasant walk (if it's not too hot out there).Tourist numbers are lower here than elsewhere. I suspect that's because of the insane advice that you can "tick off" all of Siem Reap and the temples in less than 3 days. You can't. You shouldn't but guidebooks keep selling the lie anyway. Don't run round this site like a gazelle being chased by lions. Take your time to really look at the carvings and stonework. Your patience will be well rewarded. I could easily spend a whole day here without going anywhere else. If you're "all templed out" take a break for a day in Siem Reap and enjoy the city before visiting; you'll be glad you did.

Small temple but worth seeing. Even though it's small, I find its reddish-orange color amazing. Great for photo ops. Go here in the morning for a better view. This temple is dedicated to Hindu God Shiva and it's very evident on the carvings.We experienced being "chased" by local vendors here. They won't stop from selling even though we already said "no". But as we stayed longer in Cambodia, I realized that they really need a living. Better to work hard for the money than to steal.There's this area meant for "bird watching" but when we went there, we didn't find any kind of bird. Don't walk to that area anymore. You'll only see grass.

A quick stop for a small temple.. You don't necessarily have to spend a great deal of time at this temple, especially if it's early in the afternoon. The red sandstone is unique and the size is definitely more on a human scale instead of some of the grander ruins. Worth a visit, but probably won't be the highlight of your trip.Check out the nearby information exhibit.

Small and interesting. Different from the rest of the Angkor temples. Go with a guide book so you can spot the interesting carvings and understand the stories, otherwise its a quick photo opportunity only.
The Red Temple. Defintely worth the drive to this temple. It is around 45 minutes to reach this temple. One of the oldest temples and it has amazing detail and colour. Definitely an eye-opener

Unparalleled Khmer Detail. Banteay Srei is quite small. It is well off the beaten path to Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. It's perhaps a 45 minute drive away. Perhaps because it's so small, Khmer sculptures embellished it with extraordinary detailed bas reliefs. Amazing detail. There's Gilbraltar, which is a really big, really impressive rock. And then there's the Hope Diamond, which is actually quite small compared to the Gibraltars of the world. But lf you appreciate quality as much as (or more than) quantity, wend your way to Banteay Srei.There is, by the way, a "Banteay Srei Community Tourist" area. They're trying. You can go to an overlook after you exit the temple, to look at muddy water, or take a boat ride through muddy water, or go to a botanical garden, and then wander though a bazaar. Rice paddies and dilapidated structures fighting back the inexorable Cambodian jungle. It actually can be quite scenic, sort of, but you'll get a good overview of the countryside and rice culture down in the paddies, as you drive up from Angkor Wat.
Gorgeous Banteay Srei. It may be about 37km away from Angkor Wat, but take time off to visit this gorgeous temple that will mesmerize and amaze you! One of the oldest temples around as well

Temple complex. Another amazing spectacle, each one unique and beautiful. Go early to avoid the crowds! Lots of hawkers at all the temples but they are only trying to make a living, no begging which makes a refreshing change from some European cities!

Beautiful. This temple is a little farther out but I was able to visit it on my way back from Phnom Kulen. Bantaey Srei which mean city of women has very beautiful carvings that you won't find in other temples. Carving are very well preserved and the level of detail of these carving is amazing.
Small & Far but Gorgeous Temple. Of all the temple, this on stood out for me , as the carvings and apsara were so beautiful . 150 years older than Angkor Watt but the designs is unique .

Beautiful temple with exquisite carvings. Amazing temple with such detailed carvings. Top tip is to get to the temple early before the big tour groups appear (before 8am) - as the temple is very small and can easily get overrun with people. If you love photography this temple is an absolute treat.The temple is a bit further away so we hired a car and did Banteay Samre, Beng Melea and the Rolous temples together - worth the effort to do!

Unlike the other temples - very intricate carvings. This temple is a little out of the way, but is worth the trip, Unlike the other temples in the Siem Reap area, this one has very intricate carvings all over the place. It's also a bright orange colour (the locals insist its pink - why that is, beats me). Tourist tip: when you get into the temple grounds, head to the moat on your right. It's a great spot for a photo opportunity.Tourist tip 2: get a good guide. He/she will ensure you don't miss any good photo opportunities, or more importantly, any of the valuable history.
Banteay Srei rocks. This is a truly beautiful and exquisitely carved temple. Options for memorable photography abound. Well worth the added time/distance

Worth the trip!. Banteay Srei is a small, pink sandstone temple with complex and intricate carvings. These details are so wonderful and detailed.The temple is quite small in comparison to the others in the Angkor area but NO OTHER TEMPLE comes close to the beautiful details and well preserved lintels, statues, walls and towers.Come visit! You are in for a treat!

Best preserved carivings. Banteay Srei has the best preserved carvings I have seen in Cambodia. The carved walls are roped off so a close inspection is not possible but you can still see a lot of details. A special feature here is the depth of the carvings which means that there are two or sometimes three interconnected layers of images, rather than the ususal one or two discrete layers.The fugures are from Hindu mythology and epics, especially the Ramayana. Some memorable examples would include the two monkey brothers fighting (central tower), Ravanna shaking Mount Kailasa, Kama shooting arrow at Shiva (both South Library).Another interesting thing about Banteay Srei is that the main entrance is well organized with visitor facilities. Normally you don't get more than jumble of food stalls and maybe a poster. But here, there is actually a visitor center with organized information and shops housed in a permanent building.
Gorgeous detailing. The temples themselves are not as impressive, but the level of detail is really incredible. Absolutely worth going if you have a second day at Angkor Wat.
Detailed carvings. Well maintained temple with intricate carvings on stone that have withstood centuries! Such a beautiful and peaceful place.

Nice carvings. Entry point to this temple is quite nice and would like the authorities to make such entry point(s) to the main Angkor wat temple. I had heard about the carvings in the temple and they are nice

The great, little Angkor. Not as impressive as the Angkors but this is charming in so many little ways. Built mainly of red sandstones (the stones used in bathroom walls of the hotel we stayed in). Our tour guide was so eager to explain the intricate details of this holy site, too bad it rained. The entrance to the temple looks like a royal crown but it's not for royalty unlike the Angkors.

One of the most beautiful places in the world. Get there at dawn. That was the second time I've done it, and it's still magical. You'll have the place to your own, and the light is just right to see the exquisite details of the carvings.
Different from others. Quite nice and different from others so thats way is good to see. Nice monuments and interesting history.
awesome. i went with a guide , best in a car as a bit further , a really interesting temple ., worth having the guide .

Miniature but lovely. Partly because it was so hot (got an umbrella at stall in front, which helped), I loved this temple less than others. It was the pre-monsoon season, the hottest of the year, I think. The art work is intricate and lovely. To my eyes it had a more Indian style, though I'm no expert. The Hindu gods and stories are subjects of statues and friezes, with high relief on decorative swirls. The pink sandstone is nice, though pretty dirty; the whole place is not in the best of condition. The buildings are tiny - there were doorways I would have had to duck to get through- I'm 5'5" - and the whole compound is relatively small. It's a long and bumpy drive, but it gives you a chance to see thatched huts on stilts, cows being tended by kids, roadside stands for melons, woven goods, etc. Photos taken at the temple are really striking; looks better than I remembered!

A bit farther but impresses nevertheless. See the Angkor Museum before visiting the temple. The museum has some of the well-preserved lintels and statues from the temple. This is located farther from Angkor Wat and smaller but the color of the temple and the intricate carving impress nevertheless

Amazing intricate carvings. This temple is beautiful. Commonly known as the Pink Temple and the Lady's temple, it is a fair way out of Siem Reap so I'd advise going in a car rather than a tuk tuk.Beautiful carvings throughout and very well preserved. Very good photo opportunities. The statues of the monkey and lion guards are not original but hopefully in time they will start to blend in a bit more. You can't go into the main temple as they're protecting the carvings but you can see so much from the outside.Well worth the visit.
Very delicate art. While other temples in this area scream power this is all about finesse. Very detailed and intricate Hindu mythological representations on the baas reliefs.

Smaller Temple with more intricate work. It is a much smaller temple, but with much more intricate work and very different from the the other temples in the area. Having said that, go there only if you have an extra day to spare. The temples in the main complex are a lot more impressive.

Carvings are phenomenal. This temple has a delicateness about it that I did not find any where else in the park. The carvings are deep and exquisitely rendered. If it had been a cooler day I would have loved to spend more time just looking at the walls.

Worth the trip. Banteay Srei was a last minute addition to our tour plans, and we're glad we did it. The place is less crowded, with beautiful carving details in pink sandstone..although much smaller than the more popular Angkor Wat or Bayon, it is still as marvelous!

Beautiful carvings at this temple.. Too far, about 1 hour, to travel in a tuk tuk. We hired a car and driver for the day at a cost of $40.00. The entrance is well set up with markets cafes and good toilets. The carvings at Banteay Srei are possibly the best in the area and I definitely recommend a visit here.
Khmer cuisine. This restaurant provides genuine Khmer food and is frequented by locals. Good service and good value for money.

Lovely. This temple has beautiful carvings. It is a bit of a drive but that allows you to watch the countryside go by. This is one of the older temples but it has unique colored stone and the best carvings by far. Not many people around - really enjoyed it.
Small but cutie. When you see the carving of Banteay Srei temple, there is no word to describe how beautiful it is. So please do not forget to see this temple. It is amazing!

Best Temple but go early. If you get there before 8.30am at the latest... noting it can take up to an hour's drive.. you will be able to appreciate the stunning artistry of this mini sandstone temple's intricate carvings in relative peace, before the swarms of group tours arrive on their temple ticking trip. Most impressive ...after the lovely walk back past water lily ponds teeming with dragonflies and butterfly... was the brilliantly presented information exhibit... called the Interpretation Centre. Housed in a wooden shelter reflecting local architecture and constructed with Swiss NGO support, this collection of photos and multi language text was a perfect model for how to present the history and restoration of the temple and fully explain it's beautiful features. Would love to see this at every temple.DO NOT MISS THIS TEMPLE even if you feel you have WAT overload.
Don't miss these amazing carving. This site far from the main circuit of the temples of Angkor, but it is worth doing if you have the time.
Wonderful. An amazing temple and one of our top 3. Get your timing right to avoid queues but excellent. Great for photography

Too many people. Left hotel in town at 7.30 am by tuktuk. Nice drive but when we arrived so many tourists. It was impossible to relax and enjoy. If this is low season I'd hate to be here when it's really busy. Nice surrounds away from temple

Banteay Srei. We went to Banteay Srei after watching the sun rise at Angkor Wat. Banteay Srei is a stunning pink sandstone temple with incredibly intricate carvings. This was one of my favourite temples in Angkor and I highly recommend going to visit it if you are there. Early morning it is quiter and the surrounding area is well wirth a look too as there are beautiful wetlands with viewing decks, where you can watch rice paddy's being plowed by water buffalo or even have a canoe ride through the lily pads and grasses looking at the miriad of butterflies and insects. Finish it all off with a iced vietnamese coffee on the dexk of the cafe' and its a fantastic way to spend a few hours.

Stunning. After 12+ temples in three days Banteay Srei was still an amazing site. A very intricate complex bathed in a soft red/pink I would definitely recommend you take a trip out here. It feels like a theatrical performance has been frozen in red stone. I think I went to a butterfly garden after which was just beautiful.

Beautiful, but go early!. We had the earliest breakfast our hotel would serve, and left immediately afterwards, which ended up working really well.When we arrived there were tourists already there, but not many.The temple is very small, but has very beautiful carvings, with a lot of it roped off to preserve them. We were able to explore it pretty much unencumbered, but as we were leaving there were many busloads more people arriving. The small temple was absolutely packed. So glad we were able to view it without the masses.There are some walks signposted after the temple, but they weren't amazing. The "lookout points" were all of empty swampland, which I guess was scenic, but not terribly so. One sign pointed to the "Botanical Gardens", but we couldn't find it at all, and when we told someone what we were looking for (after he queried where we were going) he seemed confused, and said there wasn't anything like that.But the temple itself was excellent, despite the long ride out there (I actually really enjoy the long tuk-tuk rides. It was a great way to see a lot of the area, and the locals' day-to-day lives).

A little far but worth the visit. We visited Banteay Srei on our second day of "temple-hopping" and it was quite lovely. This temple site is unique as all the sandstone (and I think lava stone) used for the temple construction is pink.Another nice thing is that because it's a little further out, there aren't as many tourists, as Angkor Wat & Angkor Thom are the big sites.If you're visiting Banteay Srei, you should also consider visiting Kbal Spean. It's a waterfall that requires you to hike about 25 minutes up where you'll find some old ruins. The hike up is beautiful, and the butterflies will amaze you. This for me was one of the highlights of the day!

One of the best preserved temples in the Angkor Temples Complex. Also called the lady's temple, is the only non-royal commissioned temple in the complex. Details of the walls and towers were really beautiful and well preserved. Thought I would only be staying short in this temple because its relatively small compared to the other temples but it took me quite a while appreciating the carvings. The 45 mins travel from angkor wat was all worth it.

Amazing Details!. We chose to go see this temple because our tuk tuk driver said it was a must see. Although it is not a massive temple like Angkor Wat we were not at all disappointed. The detail of the carvings were insane. There is no other temple that comes close to the intricate details and colors of this temple. It is simply unbelievable. It is quite a ways out from the other temples and you will have to pay extra to have your tuk tuk driver take you but it is well worth it. I find that after being home and talking about our trip this is the temple I talk about the most. So glad we chose to go! Don't miss this one.

Pink temples of abundance. This temple of abundance or sometimes referred to as the temple of the ladies is made with harder stone and therefore has retained it's intricate carvings. Constructed earlier than the Notre Dam, this is one of the oldest temple in Siem Riep.Trip takes 45 minutes from Angkor wat area. Should you have time after visiting this temple, try to make a trip 10 Kms away to Kbal Spean. This archaeological site has 1000 carvings of lingas on the surface of the river bed.

Beautiful temple and scenery. Banteay Srei is included in the ticket to the Angkor Complex so we visited on our 3rd day there. It looks very different to the other temples we saw- pink in colour and with very intricate carving. The countryside around is also beautiful and in the wet season you can take a boat ride (this was not possible when we visited). Would definitely recommend if you have seen enough of the main temples and have some more time to see something a bit different.

Must go EARLY. I was just here today. Started at 7 am from the city and it's a way out. Got there at 7:45 and I was only one of 5 people there. Quiet, no climbing or fear of height here. Very enjoyable if you go early. Not a huge place but the colors are amazing in the early morning. By the time I left the buses have gotten in and people are everywhere. On the way out there you will see the actual Cambodia country side and that's a real treat in itself. A must see!!!

Neat style- different. A different style from the others. Bring water and wear sunscreen. A guidebook will help make it a good experience- otherwise the ruins all just blend together after a few hours.

Intricately sculpted. The Banteay Srei Temple is the smallest of all the temples we have seen. But its design made on the stones were so intricately carved and sculpted. The stones were only placed on top of the other and were not cemented that we marvelled at another work of art.

something different. although it rather far off from the rest of the wat's bout a 40min ride with our trusty tuk tuk driver, its worth the visit. Here one would notice a total difference in architecture design where most carvings and statures still refer to the hindu religion. Its rather small but never the less a beautiful place to visit.
Prototype for Angkot Wat. A very beautiful temple, an hour's drive from Siem reap. It is perhaps the oldest temple in the area; with rare carvings of hindu gods such as Ketu (god of property).
Lots of stone carvings. Completely different from the ruins of the Tomb Raider Temple or Ta Prohm, it was a change of pace and very interesting.

Popular and crowded. This is a popular temple for tourists so you must prepare to spend more time after a 45 minutes' drive by tuk tuk from city. Unlike some other temples which have many levels to climb around, Banteay Srei is relatively flat so taking picture with crowds around can be a problem. Comparing to quite nearby temples from small and grand circuits, this temple requires you special effort to visit.

Worth the trip. Banteay Srei is a fairly long tuk-tuk ride away from Angkor Wat, but it is worth seeing. It is quite different from the other temples - smaller and more open and serene. The statues and carvings are amazing and the setting is lovely.However, if you go there, be prepared to be hassled by vendors and especially by small children begging.

Intricate Carvings. This temple has the most intricate carvings of all the temples in Siem Reap.Its located on a quiet road,do cover Kabl Spean when you are going to this temple.Its ticket is the same that is for Angkor National Park..
Stunning. Great change up from the other Angkor temples. Special in its own way and ended up being my favorite due to the intricate nature if the carvings and unique pink color.
Great ruins. There are so many must sees in the Angkor Wat complex and to us was another for me. It's well worth a stop and a walk around. Great craftsmanship yet again as in the whole complex.

Top 5 of all Angkor temples. This temple is in my top 5 of all Angkor temples. Although it is located outside of the small and big rounds, and you need to pay extra 15$ to the taxi driver(for fuel), it worth the visit.We had an awesome driver/guide, which I recommend to all of you:http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/Attraction_Review-g297390-d6522493-Reviews-Angkor_Guide_Sam_Day_Tour-Siem_Reap_Siem_Reap_Province.html

Awesome architecture. For Siem Reap traveler, it is a must place to go after Angkor Wat. The architecture is so amazing. All the stories of culture is amazing and I got very photography view in Siem Reap

Small, but fun to go to at sunrise. It's a small complex, relatively speaking. But the number of shops at the entrance seems to imply that it's very commercialised. So go early and miss the crowds.I came here to greet the sun rising to reflect on the pink sandstone.Also, if you come here early enough, the guards will offer to let you into the inner cordoned area for a fee. And after that, they'll even offer to sell you their official badge and police patch for a fee. Sad, but true. Just how desperate are you to get a perfect shot?But don't just spend all your time at the temple. Surrounding it is a natural park and if you go early enough and capture photos of the temple, then head out to the wetlands by 8am. Here, when it's still early, you'll find birds in the lakes. But walk and talk quietly, as your movements could scatter the flock of birds on the water (as I did) and you'll miss a great photo op with a good zoom lens.

Worth to see!. Far drive from the other temples so it is nice to drive here first then make your way back to the other temples. I love all the water and lakes at this temple. Not much shade so bring water for the heat. When visitors pay for the $20 one day ticket at Angkor Wat, this temple is included in that price. The bathroom are also free if you pay for that ticket.

Amazing craftsmanship!. The detail on this temple is incredible. There is so many carvings and all of them are all so different and tell different stories. Head to the expo before or after you visit to get more information about this temple as it is defo worth a visit. It is a little out of town so be prepared to pay more in a tuk tuk but it is definitely worth a visit.
Beautiful.. This temple is a bit further out but is well worth the trip. Get a tuk tuk to see the beautiful and fascinating countryside. And buy some sugar palm sweets along the way: delicious.

Intricate, small enough to absorb everything. This place had the most intricate carvings among all the temples. For such a small temple compared to the grandness of the others, being out of the way also helps in crowd control, which allows enjoying the place more. Also, it was surrounded by trees, which helped a lot in making the temperature more bearable. One thing I noticed is that all the tourists stayed INSIDE the temple walls, while my guide brought us outside the temple wall (after showing us the inside, of course), where there is an elevated platform whereby you can see the whole temple grounds. There were very few people at the platform, which allows us a pleasant, unrushed, uncommercialized view of the whole place.

Save the best for last. I came to Siem Reap on October 2012 and this was one of the last temples that I visited on my last day. I would say that this was one of the most beautiful temples that I've seen in Siem Reap. The path leading to the temple is laden with orange-red sand. Within the temple complex, you'll see intricate carvings, from the temple walls to the arches, preserved well despite the normal wear and tear by the environment.I visited afternoon around 3pm, so the sun was intense, but it showed the bright red color from the sandstone from which the temple is made from. One of my favorite temples in Siem Reap.

Stunning carvings.. It takes you about an hour from the siem riep center to Banteay Srei temple. But it's worth spending time on. The temple owns the best carvings which are at your eye-level. I visited 11 temples in my trip but I was totally impressed by Banteay Srei. You should visit this temple and Linga river which is 12 km away, but on the same road. It wl take you half day to observe these two places. Believe me, you wl have your finest moments.

Beautiful Sceneries. The location is a bit far but this is a place not to miss! Beautiful location with lush green grass and paddy field, lake and do drop by to the information centre. Beautiful temple.

Best carvings in Angkor site. Its a long way away from the rest of the site (about 40km away) but worth the trip as this temple has the best carvings - and still looks amazingly well preserved.On the way, you will pass through unspoilt countryside and will get a good idea of ordinary Cambodian life (in some of the villages, roadside stalls sell delicious palm sugar fudge for any passers by)

Worth the trip. Banteay Srei is worth an outing if you have time for a temple that is a little different to the others.We travelled by Tuk Tuk, slow maybe but the best way to enjoy the scenery along the way. Village life and lots of waves and happy greetings from the locals made this trip memorable.This Temple is small but I loved the remoteness and the surrounding lushness.... you can get a cool drink and a beer, it may be more expensive in town but you are probably only paying 50c more so why complain?On the way take time to visit the Land Mine Museum, rustic but the information is amazing.
Magical. It's smaller than other temples in Angkor, but the carvings are very pretty and delicate. You will not believe they're 1000-year-old stones there.
good. A trip well worth taking to go there , has a great walk through , the trees growing over the walls a fantastic sight .
A Beauty in Pink. We saw this temple in the morning sunlight and it was absolutely beautiful and peaceful. The colours and intricate stone work is really worth seeing.

Awesome carvings, cute lady's temple. Really liked the intricate carvings, small blocks, doors etc. it's a bit further away, but behind the big ones, this is another worthwhile temple to see. We did it on the way back from the waterfalls, and the lying down Buddha, that was also well worth the effort.

Artistic masterpiece. Well worth the 40 minute drive north from the main Angkor Temples. Carved in 967 AD out of pink sandstone, this is the finest example of Khmer art you will see in Cambodia. The name means "Temple of Women", but this is also a reference to the degree of beauty in the sculptures. Once inside you can't fail to be amazed by the level of detail in every little doorway and lintel. A sacred moat surrounds the site and you will find the usual kiosks selling drinks and artefacts just outside the entrance.

The Temple of Beauty.. This is my favourite temple simply for the magnificent and intricate carvings that cover almost every surface of the hard laterite and sandstone that the complex is made of. They are the finest Khmer carvings I've seen and would recommend that people should take the time to travel from Siem Reap to visit it.
Worth a visit. Bit of an effort to get to this temple but can visit the land mine museum in the same trip.It also isn't as big and striking as some other temples.all the same it has merit of its own.

A piece of jewllery in pink stone. My favorite one and one of the most ancient temples ( X° century)The sculpture are like laces. Refined representations of apsaras and female dancers. false doors and columns with flowers and complicated friezes. The reliefs are so exquisite that the french André Malraux tried to cut some of them for sale in 1923.

Don't miss it, awesome temple!. Smaller than the rest of the temples from Angkor area, but is much better preserved and more beautiful! The level of details of the carving in the red stone is amazing; also, the red color of the walls gives such a beautiful contrast with the green of the forest around! From the Siem Reap there are 32 km, but you won't feel it, even on the road there are interesting things to see.
The most beautiful of them all. The 3Dimesional carvings in the brittle pink stone were amazing. It's unbelievable how these were accomplished. Go in the morning for the best photos.

Don't miss this!. This is probably the most beautiful temple! The cravings are so detailed and the natural colour of the temple stones are beautiful. Don't not miss this temple and don't be turned away by its distance from town. I assure you that this is indeed one of the best.

Awesome temples. We visited these temples. The temples are great way to spend a day. quite hot though when we went.it is good to do some of the less visited ones as well.We had our tuk tuk driver take us to some of those.we also handed out some books and balls to kids along the way.
Gorgeous temple. This was one of the most beautiful temples in the Angkor Wat area, and different from all the others. Lots of detailing and definitely worth the trip to see.

Amazing. I love going to the temples, finding a quiet spot and just imagining what life must have been like. The work that went into creating these spaces is amazing that that they have laster for well over 1000 years...just amazing.

It amazing. It amazing temple, you will never forget when you visit this place.A view reflection of the temple in the pond is really amazing.The carving of Hindu culture shown the influence in 12th century.

Intricate designs - small in size but a worth a visit. Banteay Srei or the city of women is 27 kms away from the main city of Siem Reap and it takes time to reach this place.Suggested time to avoid crowds would be go in the late afternoon or early morning. Carry your photo-identified entry tickets. Angkor Wat is huge - but this one is a small site. But dont let the size fool you - the temples are in good state of preservation and exhibit intricate designs. If you travel without a guide there is an exhibition centre which gives the history , significance, designs and method of construction. Quite interesting and worth a visit !

Smaller but no less worthwhile. . Went to this temple on our second outing and glad we did. It's rather unique and having done the big ones, it was good to take it easy and enjoy this one. Swing by other smaller temples on route back including the land-mine museum. Go early and take a tuk tuk. My kids loved the ride although by the afternoon, the heat made it tougher. But enjoy stopping whenever you see something interesting - which you are less likely to do in a car.

Beautiful Temple. This was one of three temples we saw that are situated out of Siem Reap and easily the most interesting. It is a lovely rick pink colour, with many interesting carvings and statues. It is laid out on one level and easy to get around.
magic. we went by taxi as it is about an hours drive , great seeing the country side , this temple is well worth the time , we liked it the most , great photo opportunities .

Love this temple!. We visited Banteay Srei in the late afternoon the day we arrived. It was the first site we visited and the best. It's farther away from the park entrance than most of the other sites (about 45 minutes' drive) but well worth the extra time it takes to get there. En route, you will also see some of the villages where the descendents of the Kmer people still live.

Nice detailed carvings. The temple is located about 1 hour drive with a car north of Siem Reap. It is quite small, but the carvings are very detailed and nice. We were there on 12 noon, and the pink color was not very strong. It might be nicer to visit this temple in the morning or afternoon, so the color would be richer.After visiting this temple we went to the Landmine Museum, which is on the way back to Siem Reap (15 min from the temple). It was very informative and touching and I would recommend to combine the trip.

One of the oldest temples in a garden setting, lovely. Banteay Srei is a gem. I imagine that 20 years from now all of Angkor Wat will be like this. It is a park setting, lots of huge trees. The temple is beautifully preserved. Someone mentioned it is a distance from town. That's true, but it is a bare ten miles at most. You get a chance to see something of country life. Take a tuktuk, it's cheaper, you get the breeze and it's a pleasant way to spend an afternoon. This temple reminded me of temples in south India. You can hang here for a few hours. Enjoy!
Great place. This one is brilliant, the place is well preserved and also has the best market out of any in the area.

This temple contains the most detailed carvings. The women's temple is the one with the most detailed stone carvings of all. Because of the stone used in it, the color and the carvings remains almost as they used to be.
Favorite among the temples!. The intricate carvings on the structures of this temples left me spell bound! Carvings are beautiful! Out of this world completely!

Beautiful. This is one of my most favorite temples. Well worth the long travel. It seems to be more well kept from the other temples. The mini museum is very informative. The stones have a lovely shade.
My favourite temple. Small is beautiful! Fantastically detailed carvings, and stones that are a lovely colour in the afternoon sunshine.

A must see, worth the drive. Banteay Srey is one of my favorite temples of Siem Reap. It about 30 km out of the city (take a taxi instead of a Tuk Tuk). The intricate stone work is in most places still in very good condition and it makes for some fabulous photos. It's only a small temple but makes up with it's location, the water surrounding the temple and the stone carvings. A must see when visiting Siem Reap and the Angkor Wat temples and really worth the drive out.
2nd best in Siem Reap. Little temple, far from central area, but really worthy. Most elegent and beautiful temple in Siem Reap.

Smaller does not mean less. A small temple by size but the detailed carvings are great. This temple is further out but well worth the drive. Seeing the countryside and villages adds to the trip. You can also visit some very early brick temples on the way.
Beautiful and delightfully small. Easily accessible and a short walk around... The view on the way is awe inspiring. Don't forget to stop and stare... And carry enough water...

Much different. This temple is much more different than the ones around Angkor Wat because it's built from sandstone. The clay that they have used has turned it red, which is really interesting. The temple is about 30 minutes out from Angkor Wat, so if you plan on going to the Landmine Museum, you should stop by here as well. It's relatively small, but it has different architecture which makes it stand out.
Women city. Smaller than others but no less beautiful, the stone carvings are interesting and lovely and it's small enough that you feel you can explore it fully!

Quietly gorgeous. This is a smaller place that pack a big punch. The intricacies of the stone work are worth seeing plus the stone monkey/guards around the temples. If you get overheated stop at the little hut and have them crack open a coconut to replenish you!
excellent place to visit. this was the women city, so different architecture and many stories and style, a very intersting place to add to the tour

Pretty sandstone "lady temple". Banteay Srei is a decent drive out of town, but well worth it. The grounds are more landscaped that most other temple sites (thanks to Swiss sponsors), and are kept neat and tidy. The beautiful pink sandstone is amazing and it is a very serene site which also has it's own gift shop. Don't forget your camera - the pink sandstone photographs beautifully!

If time permits a must see ruin outside of Siem Reap. This ruin lies near the Kulen mountain (where heaps of Linga's are carved into the river rock + waterfalls) and is a remarkable place to visit if you have the time as it's a decent drive outside of Siem Reap. Also the tourist crowds are usually much lesser than those sites close to town.The decorations are fascinating and is quite well preserved, and as it's built from pink / red sandstone it offers great photo opportunities.Definitely worthwhile the effort to get here to experience this lovely ruin - recommended (in conjunction with a trip to Kulen Mountain).
Small but unique. It is small temple but unique. The temple is ruin and old, there are Khmer entertainment playing there and also there were little boys and girls follow us.
The beginning. Must see in Siem reap . About 30 minutes from the city. If do you have problems with you knee be prepared and schedule a massage for latter
great. Lots of temples but they all worth looking at. You do get tired after a day, but they worth seeing. Just be careful of the steep steps.

Well worth the extra few miles. The drive to the temple and its setting make it worth the trip. The temple is quite a few miles out in the countryside. It is quite different and the drive there and back is an additional bonus.

Enjoyed this one. Beautiful detailed carving on pinkish stone, also called the Women's Citadel, this was a real delight. My guide told me that it was because women had more patience than men to carve! It is worth the drive out here if you have a 2nd day. Everywhere is covered with carvings, some three dimensional that look as if they could have been completed yesterday.

Small and quiet. ...the women's temple is the the furthest out of siem reap but possibly the most beautiful. The pink sandstone shrines appear to change colour in different light. Again, an early arrival will help you get a better experience of the area without being hindered by tourists. If you like taking photos, as i do, getting here later in the day will make it more difficult to get pics without tourists in them. Patience and respect of your fellow traveller will get you your great pics. :)

A great alternative to the usual temples. Admittedly, this temple is a little further out than some of the others, but even that only means a few US dollars with a tuk tuk (and the journey there is pretty interesting as you get to see more of the "real" Siem Reap. While the favourites rightly remain Bayon, Ta Phrom and of course fabled Angkor Watt, Bateay Srei is different to these in that it is more ornamental than the others with many more female-centric carvings. The surrounding area has also been "upgraded" with little shops and and a cafe (which offers great coffee) and has clean faciliities. Highly recommended if you plan to remain in Siem Reap for an extra day.
It's one of the highlights of our trip. The sculpture was marvelous. There were not too many people as in Angkor Wat or Angkor Thom. The 1 hour drive is definitely worthwhile.

Exceptional Detail. See Angkor Wat because your guidebook tells you it is the world's largest religious structure and because everyone else goes there, and you need to keep up with your facebook friends, so you go.BUT, and this is a big BUT; for amazing beauty and outstanding craftsmanship & attention to detail then you need to see Banteay Srei. The striking & beautiful sculptures, lintels, pediments and friezes are said to have been carved by women for the details are too fine for the hands of a man!!!!!I visited Angkor Wat the next day and to be honest I was disappointed with it because it was mostly black and lacked the detail & beauty of Banteay Srei.
Beautiful lady temple. VERY ORNAte temple therefore called the lovely lady temple. Should be seen in addition to Ta proen; Angkor; and Banyon as is entirely different.

A beautiful little temple. This was a beautiful little temple full of exquisite details. Only problem we had was that it was crawling with tourists, very difficult to see some of the sights. Would recommend you go very early before the tourist buses arrive
'City of women'. Further from the main temple complex, and carved from red sandstone the colour of the temple is different here. Worth visiting.

Pick up your jaw from the ground. Yes, it's stone.. Situated far from Angkor Wat, but justifiably famous thus still attracting crowds, Banteay Srei is a couple of hours' drive from Siem Reap. Everybody knows that its stone carvings are the finest in the world, but it's better seen for real than read or looked at on a computer screen. Upon arriving at the site, one immediately sees that the temple is small. Unlike Angkor Wat, it's human in scale, kind of like a house. The plaza before the temple is earth, the deep red superfine dust of Cambodia that stains shoes and never really leaves. The color of the ground is reflected in the reddish-pink of the structure itself. Upon entering scattered gateways, one immediately sees the intricacy of the carvings - and we haven't gotten to the main temple yet!The stone was carved with high relief sculptures that have to be seen to be believed. Even humble door jambs are intricately carved. The pinnacle of stone carving is reached in the stone lintels. Among mythological creatures, heroes, and gods lie (almost) paper-thin petals and curlicues that miraculously have survived centuries later into our time. Beyond is a short causeway over an extant moat. Beyond it still lies the main temple. From a distance it's easy to see the intricacy of the carvings and the statues of Hanuman (?) but unfortunately, the inner sanctum was cordoned off. Sad. All over the place were those very intricate stone carvings. Yes, stone, not wood, stone.Towards the back was a Cambodian orchestra composed of landmine victims - a sad reminder of the recent traumatic events in Cambodian history. Nevertheless the music had this lilting character that seemed to complement the temple. I gave a donation, looked back, and thanked the gods I was able to see this temple.Highly recommended!
A Little Distance Away from the other temples, but worth the travel. This group of temples is unique for their very detailed carvings on pink sandstone. It is a must see.

My favorite one!. This temple is really amazing, especially in the early morning light when the pink color is better visible and gives you an absolutely beautiful perspective. You can also visit the river carvings and other marginal temples like the beautiful Bakong area.
Nice. I like the carvings of the walls, it shows the story of Cambodia. It is quite unique carvings and wishing that it will be preserved in the next century!
The pick of the temples. Exquisitely beautiful in peaceful surroundings. Because it's a long way from Siem Reap, it is not as crowded.
Best Temple. Loved this temple the carvings are the best in the group and in a delightful colour. It is very popular with Asian tours and can get crowded.

PINK TEMPLE. Because the entrance was flooded we had to line up as it is a
very small temple. Lots of tourists and very camera happy. It is
still worth a visit but try to go early or late to avoid crowds.

Much typed. As we are not archaeologists, but mere common tourists, it very difficult to appreciate the carvings of this temple. If you have seen temples in India, especially South, this temple looks much the same. We should definitely visit the temple if we are interested in architecture and understand the details.This temple is the only temple where the architect was a lady. Apart from that, nothing much to this temple.
Truly beautiful. Another highly impressive and memorable temple.....be prepared for lots of climbing. It does pay off though with unforgettable photo opportunities. Loved it!

temple highlight. An absolutely beautiful temple, the colour differs from the majority of Angkor temples, from oranges and light reds to soft pinks depending on the light. The intricacy of carvings is quite remarkable with basically every stone embossed with an incredible motif. This is a little further out of town, but beyond worth the journey, you will thank your self for the extra effort!!

What happens when business takes over. Bizarrely the most over-developed temple complex, yet one of the smallest. It's a pretty temple but spoiled by the crass commercial interests that have blossomed in a few short years. Even if on the way to the much better Being Melea, I wouldn't bother stopping here.

Completes the Angkor Temple tour. Banteay Srei is away from Siem Reap but worth the car ride - we did it on the way to Kbal Spean. It looks very different from the temples in Siem Reap due to its pink sandstone color. The carvings are much more intricate with several scenes from Ramayana and Krishna's avatar found on the temple here. This temple is in a slightly better state than some of the ruins in Siem Reap. Its also smaller and hence a bit more crowded but you should be able to complete it in about half hour.

A gem of Khmer architecture. This is definitely a gem of the Khmer architecture. Even after the ruins, the minuscule details of the carvings are amazing and I wonder how this temple would have looked like when it was built.Trip tips:This attraction is little away (30 mins drive) from the Angkor National Park, but the trip is definitely worth it. This will definitely add to your experience of visiting Khmer temples. *We visited this temple while our return from Phnom Kulen National Park*.
