Include this in your tour.. Very unique temple that must be included in your Angkor tour. Worth it. It contains pinkish temple, beautiful relief sculptures and several structures. Just make sure you wear a hat, sun block and good pair of shades.although it is a small temple, it's very pretty and a very distinct experience for every ankle trip. Although for a day trip is is not included, this is the reason you have to ask your travel guide to include this in your trip.
Exquisite. Worth travelling that little bit further for. It's outside the main temple complex. They call it "the ladies temple". Can't remember why. But the filigree carving in the sandstone
Nice little jewel. A bit further from the central temples, but worth the visit. The colour of the stones is different form the others and the carvings here are the most intricate.

Pink Sandstone Beauty. The name means 'temple of beauty' and it certainly is that. It is much smaller than Angkor Wat, but still imposing. The carvings are exquisite. It is worth traveling the distance from Siem Reap to reach this site.
Tip: the souvenir sellers are out in force here, and are very persistent.
My favorite Temple for sure. Amazing temple with so much detail and it will leave you in awe. After visiting temples in Angkor for 2 days this is definitely my fav. Enjoy

A Small but beautiful temple. A little more dilapidated than Angkor Wat, this delighful little temple a bit away from the main complex is worth the visit. It is being restored at the moment but the atmosphere is still amazing and the carvings beautiful.

Beautiful carving work on the walls. This temple you can really see the red color and its carving working still very beautiful , doesnt look the temple has been built ages ago. It is a small temple if you compare to Bayon or To Prom but to appreciate the carving work this is the best among all.

Most Beautiful Temple in Angkor. 25-30km away from Angkor Wat, small but super well decorated temple. Very different in style from the main temples in Angkor. I'd recomend you to start from this temple and then go to Ta Phrom and Angkor Thom

Must see very early in the morning. Probably the best stone carving in archaeological park. You can get some decent pics because much of it is fenced off and no one is milling through your sight lines. Since this is a very small place, you must get there VERY early because when the big tour buses come, it will be awful. We saw enough buses arriving as we were leaving around 9:00 AM to know it was going to get ugly

Banteay Srei, Siem Reap (Cambodia). Banteay Srei is a very beautiful temple in Cambodia. It was a SHIVA Temple and the image of NANDI is there in front of the Temple. The images of HANUMAN and other Ramayana characters are there in the temple premises. The presence of Hindu Religion and culture may be felt and recognized every where in the temple premises.

Chapel of the women . Amazingly beautiful this quaint temple in Angkor regeon is known for its detailed and superb carvings . the depiction if narasimha in the eastern gopura and the sita-parvati on the west is absolutely the best

Don't miss this Siem Reap temple attraction!. One if many Siem Reap attractions and one of the best displaying some of the finest examples of classical Khmer Art. Made of pink sandstone giving it a fairyland ambiance.

Ride down the river. We took a boat during the dry season. So had to board it about 7kms down river. but it meant a ride through the meandering river to the lake among the houses on stilts towering 10m above us, in the knowledge that come "the wet" the front doors of these houses will be at the water's edge. Brilliant. Do the 40 minute journey. It is well worth it.

Beautiful Colour & Carving. This is a small temple but an absolute gem. The pink colour of the sandstone used for this temple enhances the architedture and the quality of the carving is exquisite. This one is rather farther away from the main temples complex than most, but it is well worth the extra effort and transport cost to get to visit it

Maye my second favorite temple after Bayon. we managed to get here early in the AM and so mised some of the crowds that converge on the major sites all morning. This is a lovely temple, pinkish sandstone, with excellent Hindu carvings

Best temple in Siem Reap. This was the best temple we visited - the workmanship in this temple was brilliant and intricate. Stories from hindu mythology abound and the carvings on red sandstone were beautiful.
little charming temple. the temple is small but full of art work perfectly made by very talented people. the natural view of forest always make the temple much more attractive

Another one of our top temples in Siem Reap. This is another can not miss temple in Siem Reap. It is quite unique when compared to the other temples in the region, as it is made of a different stone which makes it pink in the light.We went early afternoon as it was most convenient, but think we would like to do a bit later, closer to sunset if we were to do it again. It is quite open, so gets very hot.It is relatively small, so about 30-60 minutes is probably enough.
Oldest ruins we saw. The quiet and peaceful feel of this ruin made for a serene journey. There were not big crowds and a smaller, easier to navigate site.

A really pretty little temple. This temple is about 12km or something away from the main archeological park, but it was worth ever km! This is the place where you need to go if you want to be charmed by the beautifully carved temples, built with pinkish stones.
small but perfectly formed. A really pretty little temple but absolutely exquisite and in very good condition. Complete antithesis of Angkor Wat in terms of scale but far more ornate.
Gorgeous. And worth the trip outside of town. Go in the afternoon when the light is perfect and there are fewer tourists. It is lovely small monument with amazingly preserved carvings
Worth the Drive. The stone work was beautiful. Couldn't get over the level of detail and colours. Loved how intimate the area felt.
A tiny temple, charming. Worth a visit if you have a little extra time. The pinkish stone and detailed, smaller carvings make this temple distinctive.

This is not to be missed.. This was my favourite temple. It is a little out of the way but oh wow, so worth doing the trip for it. the intricacy of the stonework is seriously unbelievable. You have to get up close to really believe that it is actually stonework. Incredible.

favourite temple. It is small and can feel crowded especially when there are big tour groups going through but worth it to see the carvings. They are elaborate and so detailed. Really amazing and about 400years older than Angkore Wat.

Intricate and incredible carvings. Spend a lot of time there -- if possible without a guide. The guides tend to rush one through the place; but each lintel and wall panel of this temple is worth hours of study and appreciation as they are filled with miniature carvings that are still fresh after a thousand or more years.

The most refined temple in the Angkor area. Banteay Srei is quite smaal but has extremely delicate and detailed carvings. There is a beautiful park created around the temple nowadays with nice views and paddy fields.

So beautiful!. This is quite a way out and we went by tuk tuk. Probably a little far for a tuk tuk to be very comfortable but we didn't mind it in the end. Banteay Srei is very small but it was well worth the journey to see the carvings. They are so intricate and still so defined, after all these centuries

Romantic sunrise. Everything has been said already but I just wanted to add that thgis place is a very good spot for sunrise, very ro;antic ;-) Although this temple is a bit far from the city, don t miss it!

An Exquisite Gem. A bit far but well worth it for those interested in art. The carvings here are so meticulous, it is believed only a woman's hands could have done it, hence the name "Banteay Srei" - Citadel of Women.It's an interesting temple built with rose sandstone, miniature in scale, and unlike the other temples, not built by a monarch but a courtier who served as counselor to the king.I recommend visiting early or in the afternoon as there isn't much shade in the compound and the sun can be unforgiving. I visited mid-noon and regretted it for the terrible shadows cast on the temple carvings that didn't make for good photos.
Beautiful temple. Much smaller than some of the other temples, but beautiful with the pink/ red sandstone. Wasn't as busy as some of the temples, so a more pleasant experience from that point of view

Little far for what it is. Nice and different, but rather small and considering the length of the trip - about 1 hour by tuktuk (through the country which is enjoyable, but not special) maybe not worth for everybody
Great temple - great photos. This temple was well worth a look and I got some really beautiful photos here due to the colours and little statues at the temple.

Beautiful. This is the first of the temples to be upgraded with sanitised 'tourist facilities' ie car parks, toilets, shopping market etc. The aim is to make Angkor Wat ready for the increasing number of tourists from all over the world (at the moment it is primarily Koreans, Japanese and, increasingly, Russians). Having visited some of the other temples it felt very 'organised' but the information boards at the entrance were interesting and useful if you had to queue. The temple itself is beautiful and different to the others being made of pinkish sandstone. It was here I bought a fantastic book called Ancient Angkor by French scholar Claude Jacques for much less than the current cover price of $28. But having bought one thing we were then followed by a myriad of children offering their wares.......luckily we were not too far from the exit!

Wonderfully intricate carvings. Quite a way out of Siem Reap, but an attractive drive through the countryside.A small Hindu temple complex built/completed in 967AD, with wonderful, intricate, deeply-incised carvings, quite different from the carvings on other temples I visited. I also found the different colours of the stone much more interesting than some of the other temples in the region: the rose-colour reminded me a bit of Petra, and there were some delightful honey-golds that looked great in the sunlight. Some nice reflections in the surrounding water too. I can recommend a visit here.
The Ladies favourite. Beautiful detailed carvings in pink sandstone. Wonderful setting. Numerous semi erotic carvings of beautiful women
Beautiful. We visited late afternoon and the sunset gave this small, pink and exquisitely carved temple even more ambience and beauty. Probably my favourite place in Angkor.

One of the hidden gems in Siem Reap. The ancient ruins were almost magical and spectacular, although it was a long ride from Siem Reap. You'll be amazed by the ruins and sets it apart from the other temples in Angkor. Try to visit it early in the morning to avoid the tourists crowds. You'll also get to see the beautiful countryside, villages and landmine museum on the way there.
Divine. Such magnificence and the detail was spectacular. Definitely worth a visit. We arrived via Tuk Tuk and it took about 30 mins I suppose to get there from Siem Reap. Beautiful!
Worth a visit. Beautiful, smaller temple complex worth visiting if you have the time. It has some lovely wall carvings and statues.

Magical.... A beautiful small 10th century Hindu Temple dedicated to Shiva located about 20km from Angkor. See the magnificent carvings of Vishnu and Shiva. Notice the pink sandstone and the beautiful carvings. Another favorite temple to see on your visit to Angkor Wat, Siem Reap.

save your energy here. banteay srei is very beautiful. if you could make it in the morning,then do it as you still have the energy(its very hot in the afternoon), shopping for souvenirs here is good, quality items. they have shops and restaurants in this area. vendors/salesladies are not pushy, you can get a good haggle for t-shirts $2.5-3 each if you buy 4 or more. shops here are better than the other areas considering quality.

A Must See Go Early. This the Lady Temple, is different to most of the others in the Siem area. Lovely pink stone, much more delicate , intficate carving , beautiful in the misty dawn light. Arrange to go at 8.00am at the latest and enjoy the peace and beauty before the hordes of rude Japanese coaches arrive. Wonderful spot.

One of the best. Banteay Srei is a must see in the pantheon of Angkor Temples. It has some of the best and intricate carvings that you will see while in the Siem Reap area. Make sure to include this complex along with Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm when you visit.

the most beautiful temple. The carvings are in excellent condition (apart from the looted heads) and very detailed. Shockingly the guards will offer you to go into the fenced off (white cord) area for some extra money (and will show you pics on their mobiles). You can see everything without the bribery. Just walk around it a bit and help to keep it as beautiful as it (still) is...

Quite, serene, beautiful !!. Away from the crowds, Banteay Srei is a bit off the main guided tour routes. Yet, it is worth every bit of time spent to reach this place. A petite wonder, so beautifully carved, it will keep you immersed in its beauty for a good amount of time. Its very quite surroundings make for the more relaxing experience. Pictures can only tell a bit about this place. Absolutely worth being in the itenary of every Siem Reap tour.. Simply loved it !!

Top of Khmer art. Refined, lovely, beautiful,and all those other words that can reveal our emotions at seeing this masterpiece of human expression. Take the time, the spacial arrangement of the buildings and statues, as well as the crafts qualities are amazing. Within the best things you can see on earth, and, remember, at what time was it again?
to add in your list. Very interesting places to visit. Should not be missed in addition to otehr places in your agenda. It's all within Angkor Wat areas.

Very detailed stone carvings. The temples has very detailed stone carvings, telling the story of Ramayana and hindu Gods (and their avatars). The whole thing looks like carved in the wood, and looks like brand new, although it's been almost 1000 years old.

Was expecting more. I was expecting more as people say it has the best carvings and is the most intricate. Not sure it was worth the hours trip out there. I found all the other Temples we visited a more rewarding experience. We hired a car and driver for the day and visited this temple plus one other and the Land Mine Museum (which I would recommend)

nice but far - good for a second day. Let me start by saying this was a very good site and definitely worth going to. However, I didn't feel that it was quite as spectacular as everyone says (I kept hearing that this was the MOST delicate/beautiful ruin) and if you are only sight-seeing for a day I would nix it just bc of the distance.That being said, if you have 2 days or more, then this is worth the trip as it is beautiful (but really, all these ruins are beautiful!).

"Temple of Women" has intricate carvings. We visited on the way back from Kbal Spean. The temple is smaller but has unique red sandstone with very intricate carvings. Grass grows from the roofs and there is a reflecting pool in front. Worth a stop as part of a trip but would recommend a van or bus, it's a bit far for a tuk-tuk.

What a detailed work - red stone temple - built for women. This is a great place to visit . What nice and fine details carved in the stones. Like dental broidery . Unbelievable how this was done in previous centuries with simple mechanical help very probably .

Beautiful, fine details. I really enjoyed this temple for the very preserved details and colors of the stones. I am not sure why, but this location did have a lot of orphan children that bugged us. I did enjoy the musicians though

The "Gem of Women" is gorgeous!. Our guide saved this one for last as she wanted us to have a special finish to our temple visit. Not just another temple ruin, this one has incredible stone carvings, stone monkeys and beautiful bas-relief work. Don't miss it!
Too Crowded !. It was a bit crowded as the site was pretty small. It would be better if crowd control could be applied for greater viewing comfort.

Red sandstone Temple a few miles from Angkor Wat... Smaller than some of the other Temples, but still a marvel of construction work so many years ago.The whole area is also in unspoilt forests. Temples everywhere! Unbelievable how they built them so many years ago.
Ladies' Temple. One of the oldest and prettiest temples. Absolutely beautiful bas reliefs. A must-see. Not a royal temple.
Beautiful!. This is the most beautiful temple in Angkor and well worth the drive to visit it. Its small size is a surprise but the detailing of its reliefs is exquisite.
The fine & intricate carvings were out of this world. The stone carvings were different from other parts of the Angkor complex and definitely one of the high points of the trip.

A jewel within Angkor. This Temple dedicated to Shiva is made of red sandstone which glows in the sunlight. The decorative carvings are well preserved considering it was built in the 10th Century. The reflections in the water of the surrounding moat add to its serenity. Take your time to take when you visit this gem - well worth the visit.

Beautiful. Eleven years ago, this temple was not open - it is now and worth the trip almost on its won! While small in comparison, the carvings are superior. Spend some time hear and enjoy something only recently available for viewing.

nicest temple of Angor. About 22km NE of Angor Wat - takes about 45min by tuk - very different in many ways: small area, rose color stones, very detailed carving - almost 3D, compact layout, nice park-like temple.DO NOT MISS.Note, tour buses arrives at 0830- so need to get own transportation to arrive at least 45min before they do, otherwise the area will be too crowded.

A little gem. Worth the 30km drive to see this little gem dedicated to Shiva. Built in 967 AD (almost 200 years before Angkor Wat) the pink sandstone sits snugly within the jungle surroundings, reflecting its towers in the sunshine off the moat.

Quiet. We arrived before the buses at about 7:30 a.m . On our first day and we found this place magical . The colours in the morning sun were beautiful. We were lucky enough to have a great driver who knew when where and how to miss most of the large tour groups. Very beautiful park like setting ,with some nice outer trails.

Awesome out of the way temples. Definitely worth the drive out there. Incredible detail in the carvings is still preserved despite the fact that they predate most temples at Angkor Wat. Highly recommened

Beautiful carvings. We did this temple first; we wanted to do the big circle first and then the more impressive temples of the small circle last in order to avoid temple fatigue. I think this was a good strategy, as we enjoyed Preah Khan and the other large circle temples immensely, while still having the bigger, more impressive temples to look forward to.

Breath-taking!!!. An amazing place to visit and breathe in the history. Came here on a tour with Beyond Unique Tours and the guide told us many many many many facts on the temple's history and construction. Really worth the trip here!

The most beautiful temple near Siem Reap. The citadel of the Women, that's what they named it and this is the most beautiful carved temple we've seen in this area!! The deep and intricate carvings in the pink sandstone from the 10th Century are a must see, even though the temple is 38km from Siem Reap. At the rear of the temple victims from land mines are playing Khmer music. Beautiful!!

Not Our Favourite Temple. I am very glad that we took a car here & not a tuk tuk, as it is about 35km from Siem Reap & part of the road is not good. There was not that much to see compared to most of the other temples for coming quite a bit further. It was also extremely busy when we went & the site is very small, which made it feel worse. If you do go, call in the land mine museum, which is on the road to the temple & is well worth a visit.

Don't miss this...exquisite and interesting. Of course you will do the majors, but this was well worth the trip out. The road there was interesting and typical and gave more depth to the local experience. And the temple was marvelous. Deep, detailed carving...a pinky sandstone, and a beautiful predecessor to Angkors and with less diluted Hindu influence. Read up or get a guide to fully appreciate, but don't miss out on this experience.

Beautiful, different but so packed. This was an amazing temple to visit as it was so different from the others not only in the style of the different buildings, but in the couleur of the stone and the stunning carvings.Unfortunately we didn't see it in the best light as the morning was overcast and the beautiful pink stone didn't glow like in the sun.It was also terribly overcrowded with tour groups even at 8.00 am which took a lot of pleasure out of the visit as it is such a compact place that fills up very fast.

Many would say this is the most beautiful of all!. This temple, although not as big and imposing as some of the others has the most beautiful stone carving. We were told by the guide that it is thought that this temple had been carved by women as the stonework is so detailed. The temple is situated about 28 kilometers from Siem Reap so is not so easy to get to but if possible do go and see it as it is beautiful and not as busy as some of the other attractions.

Lovely temple - Must see. This is 30 odd Km from SiemReap and you can club this visit along with Kbal spean. This is on the way to Kabl spean. First stop here and then do the Kabl Spean so that when you are tired after the climb etc. you can go home straight.This temple has better carvings than Angkore thome Bayon etc.
gem. beautiful architectural gem in well-designed original and modern setting. the ride through the country and small villages to get there is also interesting.

amazing temple. Loved the small carvings of Apsara's females...the ride there was about 25 minutes past a butterfly garden which was cool The temple was one of our favorites. I highly recommend heading out there at 7am. We got there at 8 and there was only about 20 people there..when we were leaving at 9 or so there were hundreds of people entering and tour bus after tour bus.It is worth the trip to see this temple.

Fine temple but avoid the restaurant in the visitors centre. Banteay Srei was one of the first temple to have been restored and it is also the first one to be fitted with a modern visitors centre with shops and a restaurant. I have nothing to add to the previous reviews of the temple, the carving are as fine as everyone says and it is definitely worth the visit, but God forbid you should stay for lunch in their restaurant. This was by far the worst Khmer food we had in Siem Reap: the yellow curry was a bowl full of yellowish water with a few large chucks of vegetables, one (yes, one!) shred of chicken and one human hair. When I complained, they fished out the hair, added three more pieces of chicken and brought it back. I refused to pay for it and walked out. Avoid!

Worth the journey. This temple is so different to the others - style, art, colour. The pink sandstone is different to other materials used and the detail of the decoration is so incredibly fastidious. It's really worth the trip as it's a bit further out than the other temples. It was only discovered quite recently and is in a beautiful setting. Our tour guide was very professional and warned us that the police will ask for money (ie. a bribe) to go into the cordoned off sections, which leads to destruction and erosion of the some of the more susceptible parts of the temple. Tourists should understand that it's cordoned off for a reason and we shouldn't be risking damaging the temple further just because we want 'that perfect photo'. We did not pay the bribe and were disappointed to see others (including tour guides) doing so. Otherwise a beautiful experience - definitely recommended.

One for the ladies. It's a bit of a hike to get to but it's totally worth it. The detail in the carvings of the 'Lady Temple' is spectacular. It's no surprise that the ladies are responsible for this one - it would have taken a nimble hand and A LOT of patience.
such detail. This temple is well worth the visit - the detail in the carvings is truly incredible. Take the time to visit.

Wow! But too crowded.. This small site is truly amazing! I spent about 30 minutes strolling around the area and it took me slightly less than 1 hour to get there from Siem Reap with tuk tuk. Make sure to bring a jacket for the ride though, since the wind in the morning makes it a quite cold one.I would have given this spot a 5 if it wasn't for the huge amount of tourists. There were something like 500 people inside and thus impossible to get beautiful pictures. Limit it to 100 and let people queue would be a better solution in my opinion.

Beautiful!. Make sure you're very early or wait until late afternoon ..... the morning was full of large tour groups and this temple is too small to be enjoyed when fighting your way through large throngs of people pointing large cameras in your way.Go when its quieter and enjoy the stunning carvings

Worth the trip. its a little bit out of the way...its a bit of a trek to get there from AW but it is so worth the trip. Try and get there early - before the tours. its small but perfectly formed and is very well set up for tourists with restaurant, rest rooms, shopping area etc.

Excellent!. Recommended by a friend, it was highlight of the Angror Temples visit.Banteay Srei is well worth visiting, despite the fact that it’s not in the main temple area. Although there were not that many people as in main Angkor area, it seems that many still decide to go 37km out of Siem Reap to visit this jewel of Angkor. “Pink” temple, as they call it, is master piece which shouldn’t be missed.Pleasant surprise was very well maintained and clean area in front of the temple.You might want to combine this trip with Kbal Spean visit.

A temple away from most of them. Banteay Srei is a temple restored in the 1930s. It's telltale red-orange color is unique among temples in the Angkor Archaeological Park, due largely to the red sandstone used to build the temple.

Love the country side scenery on the way to this temple.. Quite a distance to get to this temple. On the way we stopped at the palm sugar making village....love that! We stopped over and bought some souvenirs. Lovely drive through the local country side enjoying the local scenery and country lifestyle. Not suitable to go on the Tuk Tuk as it is quite far and hot as well as dusty.Historically unique temple and definitely a must visit. Absolutely amazing detailed designs. Very crowded with Chinese tourists.Can be quite difficult to take photos as the temple is not that big
Hidden. Not as well kept but gives you a much better feel of how Angkor wat may have felt in earlier days. Worth the drive getting there.
must. After visiting the main temples , this was well worth the effort , a little further out but really beautiful and interesting well worth a visit .

Good but not really worth the trip.. A well maintained temple with clear carvings but quite small, the most annoying aspect of this temple is the huge number of Chinese holiday spots advertised, I assume that there is a lot of Chinese investment but it should not obliterate the entrance as it does at the moment. The drive is very pleasant as Cambodian countryside is beautiful! suggest that you buy your. 3 day pass the day before your planned visit to avoid losing 2 hrs on the day, they are valid for 7 days and you can use any 3 days.

This was one of my favorites!. First, I loved the ride out to the temple. We got there really early with our tour guide(www.angkordriverguide.com) and I am so glad we did. After we were done hundreds of tourists were coming in as we were leaving. Because we went so early we got a lot of great photos. I still can't believe the details of the temple. Yes, it is smaller but personally I think it is worth it especially if you have a personal tour guide informing you of all the history before you get there.

Long road trip to see the temple ruins. I was not particularly impressed by the Temple. Firstly, our guide told us that most of the temple has been restored however there are huge parts of it that are still broken down. The carvings are intricate and the pink stone is different however for the price to drive out with a car to see this I did not think that it was worth it. Also, because the grounds are smaller it feels a lot more cramped (we went in the peak season) There were bus loads of tourists trying to take pictures and making a noise so the whole effect of the temple was lost on us. Most tour companies/hotels charge $40 to hire a car to get there. Sure the drive along the countryside is interesting but not amazing and a tuk-tuk ride will be horrible.

Not To Be Missed!. We took the tuk tuk ride all the way out and actually enjoyed seeing the countryside. We stopped on the road to see how palm sugar is extracted from the palm flour and how it is then cooked and made into small cubes.Banteay Srei is not large, but the carvings are intricate and amazingly detailed. Definitely one of the highlights of our tour!

Incredible pink intricate carvings. Spend some time in the front of the site to read the timelines, they are helpful to put this smaller and out of the way site into perspective.The temple is smaller but no less important than the other sites in the area of Angkor Wat, so it is easier to see more intricately. The carvings are so detailed it is worth taking a good look. Interesting monkey statues guard one of the rooms. The crowds lessen at the end of the day, but if you are going at dusk carry insect repellent.

Beautiful small temple. Well worth a visit. Away from Siem Reap about 15-20 miles. I saw people going there in tuk tuks, but that would be a l-o-n-g way in a tuk tuk. Our hotel arranged for a car to take us there. We also had a guide who really added to the experience, imparting a lot of knowledge. The site itself is a smaller one, but it is also one of the more beautiful ones. There are some great and intricate carvings. Make sure you have comfortable shoes, a camera, water, and sunscreen.

Lovely old temple. We visited Banteay Srei in early December and found it to be a really lovely, old temple. It is about a 30 minute car ride from Siem Reap but worth the trip to see the beautiful carvings that adorn its walls.This temple is not very large, like Angkor Wat or Bayon but has a style all its own with amazing bas reliefs craved into pink sandstone. We did not go with a guide or group so we were able to take our time to really admire the temple and take some great pictures. Put on your "must see" list when visiting Siem Reap.

worth the drive. But, don't go by Tuk Tuk - too far. Get a car and driver. A small site, but worth it as it is special and at sunset is beautiful. A lot of tourists and a small and tacky but organised market. The drive there is an insight into cambodian countryside - and don't forget to take water. Facilities are good, and the site is interesting - but, not worth the boat tour or 'garden' hike.

great temple with a twist. Another great temple with a twist, made with sandstone that looks pink. There is still a lot of detail to see. These out the way temples are enjoyable, especially since they are not as busy as the main temples.

Only if you have the time. This temple is about 45 minutes away from Siem Reap area and although the pink sandstone makes the carvings more interesting and different from the others it's worth it to go only if you have the time to spare. Else just concentrate on the Angkor wat and Angkor thom. It's a small temple attraction and if there's a couple of tourist groups it becomes too crowded. Also middle section closed now for viewing to keep it intact I guess. Also there's a lot of sand and dust around this temple.
Intricate carvings. The small scale of the temple made it more manageable than other Angkor temples and the intricate and detailed carvings are well worth the trip there.

Jewel of the temples. This temple is so worth a visit, we went on the way to Lake Tonle Sap. It dates from the 10th century and is known as the Lady Temple AND is the only temple not built by a king but but by a courtier and was in use up to the 14th century then not discovered again until 1914. The jungle and earth had to be cleared and then the temple restored.It has a style and beauty of its own and IS a must see temple.

My most favorite temple in SR - make time to go!. Since this place takes almost two hours away from the city, most travelers don't get the chance to go there. But we did! And I'm sooo glad we did because Bantay Srei is a must see. Its beauty is so unique that when I said all temples look the same anyway, I ate my words. Make sure to include this one on your Siem Reap tour!
Distinctive. Although it's a way out from the city etc it has such a different and distinctive style that it is definitely worth the visit.

Tuk Tuk ride all the way well worth it.. Very intricate carvings, great tuk tuk ride, great with the correct sunlight but avoid the tours if you can. Facilities great and I even bought a coffee. Don't miss it. Close to my favorite. And I also got a t shirt for $2.50.

A small jewel with amazing detail. Must be visited early.. This exquisite pink sandstone temple is covered in carvings and was perfectly restored and the detail is amazing. Walking around it is like reading pages of the Hindu mythology, so read about the carvings beforehand to understand them a little.Many, many people want to enjoy this wonder and its small size makes it easily overrun. I went there at 7:15 and it was already quite full, it only takes about 30 people for that. I can't imagine how it looks like when the parking lot is full of buses.If you are a photography buff, consider being there earlier. It's crazy, but the colour of the stone really changes after 8 am.The exhibition explaining the restoration and Khmer architecture is also very well presented.
Exquisite. Make sure to visit this temple when you are in Angkor Wat! It is exquisite and has a nice pavilion with background information as well. (There is also a decent restaurant there)

Our first look at the temples. Our guide took us the 23 km to Banteay Srei as our first stop, early in the morning. So no crowds and a chance to explore at our own pace and learn of the extent of the sites to see in Siem Reap.
Beautiful!. Too many people - I was there mid-day. To do this one again, I'd go early in the morning. Beautiful, surreal.
Delicate and beautiful. A bit further away, but worth the trip. The sculptures are magnificent. It is just as crowded here as in Angkor Wat.
Bandeay seri. This place is totally different from Angkor wat, bayon temple.....if you have enough time, highly recommend to spend your morning there.

Nice trip through the mainland. The temple is different from the Angkor ones although we were more interested in the Tuk Tuk ride through the deep Cambodia. Book a $14 gran tour day trip, while in negociate with the driver to take you to Banteay Srei for additional $7 (instead of a $25 pre-booked tour)

red sandstone beauty. I loved the drive out through the countryside to see this temple. You get a feel for the daily lives of the people in the villages and see some amazing things. The red sandstone was very unique and has a different look than the other temples, so I enjoyed that.
Inspiring. Inspires the soul. Truly the temples and the area make you want more from life than spending time in shopping malls cropping up across Asia.

A beautiful & unique Pink Temple!. We loved this temple and it was one of our most favourite. The carvings and sculptures were some of the best we saw during all our temple visits. Just get there before 10:30 or after 2pm to get the best lighting. Our guide didn't manage to get us there on time but it was still a great experience. Beware of folks selling stuff aggressively and the scam of $1 for the Angkor Book until you pass them the dollar and they say not I said $21. By the time I was leaving the price was $8 but I was too pissed off at that point.
Worth the effort. This was a bit out of the way, but it was worth, everything was miniaturized and perfect formed. The size of this temple made it feel somehow a bit more accessible. Loved it!

Small, but beautiful. Very beautiful temple, but small, therefre gets crowded. We went there straight after sunrise at Angor Wat and it was alright, not too many people and we took nice pictures, however later more and more people were coming

Rose Pink and gorgeous.. This was temple number 4 for us so my feet were still in good order.Built between 967 and 1001, this temple was the only one we saw which was wholly Hindu. It is made of pink sandstone and volcanic rock. It is extremely decorative and well preserved- you can easily see the decorations and figurines as if they were only afew years old.Her the lingga was not overtaken so you see a Hindu original as the temples were prior to the influence of Buddhism. I learned that when they had the Hindu-Buddhist wars the hindus would desecrate images of the buddhas from the walls and frescoes, that is why when you enter some of the other temples you will see headless buddha statues which were placed on the lingga plinths- reminded me of the Egyptians who tried to erase the memory of one of the sun kings in the pyramids.The grounds of the temple hold a few rosewood trees. Well worth the trecking around.

delicate intricate carvings. Situated a fair distance from all the other temples, one often would leave it out. but It you do, you would need to return to see it. One of the best temples of the area with beautiful intricate carvings .

Pink Palace. A beautiful temple and drive in the countryside to observe this pink stoned temple. Well preserved and decorated. Please do not miss, have lunch here if anything, and research the many Hindu god stories BEFORE vsisitng here to truly enjoy the carvings on the walls of these temples.

Stunning. Picturesque temple with stunning carvings - well worth the extra time to visit here. Take a tuk tuk as there's some interesting scenery & village life to see on the way & the breeze as you travel is refreshing.

Small is beautiful. Great temple, beautifully preserved/ restored well worth visiting. The drive there is really interesting too. The intricate carvings and stonework are stunning and well worth the effort. Some great photographic opportunities too with late afternoon sun and fabulous reflections in the pools.

Truly a 'Shining Pearl'. No wonder people call it the Shining Pearl in the Angkor Monuments - the carvings there is soooooooo delicate. It's beyond words - you have to be there and to be amazed. Learn a bit about stories and legends in great Hindu epics - the knowledge will be very helpful when you visit Banteay Srei.

beautiful carving BUT tourism overdone. Sadly the only site in 5 days and 20 temples that left us feeling sad about tourism in siem reap. partly because of design to funnel tourists through areas advertising Chinese holidays and selling tourist stuff but mainly because their are just too many people in such a small temple complex to appreciate the unique carvings. not a fault with the site and if I came back I would either not bother or get there very late in the day.

Gives a good historic perspective. Unlike most of the popular temples Banteay Srei is constructed primarily of red bricks and it is one of the older temples in the Siem Reap area. Less crowded than Angkor Wat, it allows you to see the way temple architecture developed. Well worth a visit.

SMALL AND BEAUTIFUL. Srei Banteay is about 20 miles from Siem Reap, and well worth the effort to get there. This pink sandstone Hindu temple has some of the most intricate stone carvings of any temple in the Angkor area. Somewhat isolated, almost a miniature, built in the 10th century this temple is completely different from Angkor Wat which was built about 200 years later.

A small Gem!. Banteay Srei was small and fairly handicap-friendly. I loved that you coud walk leisurely around, looking at the elaborately decorated sandstone. we were lucky to com at a time with very few people, so we could enjoy the more than 1000 year old temple, which is in quite good conditions - some of the carvings are exquisite! it is also fun to see the children playing in and around the ruins; bring some fruit for them and you can have a good time crossing language barriers!

A beautiful temple. This temple has beautiful carvings that have survived very well.The temple is also beautifully reflected from the pool. This is a small temple that does not have a lot of climbing.

Pollution taking its toll....... Visited here 2011 - beautiful red sandstone, quiet, access all areas temple. 2013 - sandstone has blackened and worn (possibly from the many wood fired local brick kiln factories?) plus the centre of the temple is cordoned off. A real disappointment - some urgent investment ($50m a year in Park revenues!) is required here by experts... An attraction which will lose visitors.

My favorite of all of the temples. this place is magical. So pretty, unique and tranquil. I really fell for this temple with its artistry. Make sure you add this temple to your Siem Reap/Angkor Wat itinerary.

Well Worth a Visit. The bas relief carvings that have been preserved in this sandstone temple make it one of the "must see" stops in the Angkor complex. Very limited shade in the temple so plan accordingly. This is also one of the only temples that is "flat" meaning almost no stair climbing.

Underwhelming and busy.... arrive early/late to avoid tour groups!. This one was a bit underwhelming, not a must see in my estimation. The main draw are the many intricate bas reliefs. The temple itself is relatively small; we spent only about 30 mins there. I would highly recommend planning this one in the early morning or late afternoon.... By 9am as we were walking out, swarms of tour buses were descending on the site.

The Star Attraction during My 3rd Day Temple Hopping. The uniqueness of this temple are the intricate wall carvings made of pink sandstone. It registers well on camera and is considered as one of the top 5 temples to visit in Siem Reap. When you visit this temple, you can also see a nearby lake where you can do some boat riding.
First Khmer Temple I've seen. This is my first introduction to Khmer Temples and found it very fascinating. Most cool was all the faces on the statues.

Stunning Temple. Excellent facilities / rest room/ stalls just before /after the Temple. Good walking approach to temple. Beautiful pink sandstone temple with the most amazing detailed carvings. This temple is a must see , don't miss it

MIND BLOWING CARVINGS!. It does live up to its name (Banteay Srei meaning citadel of Women): The carvings are so exquisite, so delicate, as if the Khmer used needles. The carvings were so uniform, like made by machines. They were almost in 3D and covered practically the whole surface of the temple. My eyes kind of went crazy looking at all the intricate designs. Definitely worth the 40ish km distance. If you arrive at around 10, you should be done by noon. (this is without a guided tour). And that leaves you just enough time to go to Kbal Spean, about 10K away, which is a river that has carvings of linga on the rocks. I mean, you've already made it all the way to Banteay Srei, might as well check it. Very beautiful, but does require some hiking.

breathtaking. my favourite site in Angkor! The Angokr site is one of the most breathtaking situation in the Earth and Banteay Srei is the apex of this extraordinaire site! The Carvings are precious!!! togheter with Angkor Wat this is the place where is possible to feel the greatness of man!!

Excellent. A short distance from Siem Reap, this temple is well worth visiting. Not crowded, smaller and well preserved it has some of the best carvings I've ever seen, and with the setting sun the pink colour of the stone really impresses.

Great despite the crowds. Get there by tuktuk or car as it's a ways out of town and go early. The restored temple is amazing, well organized and on a smaller scale so more manageable in many ways. Incredible carvings that are of very high quality. The crowds are pretty oppressive (some groups rather rude in their determination)....but this is still worth the the trip

They call this the city of women temple. We were really lucky that our driver told us about this temple and the story behind it. We went and this is one of the few that has really clean layout and there were snacks and drinks stalls hence not as hot and much walking as other temples. One of the must see temples around Angkor watt. Have fun!:)

Very Well Maintained. It is a very well organized temple. They have very clean toilets here . The walkway is covered initially and is very clean. every carving on the doors has some significant Hinduism story to it, make sure to get to know about it .
must visit. This is another of the temples away from the main complex. equally impressive architecture and sights. early morning is good time

You cannot miss it.. The two ''must visit ''places i.e. Angkor Wat and Bayon Temple apart, this temple is the best and
After having seen almost all the similar temples, my conclusion is to visit only those three places and relax afterwards would have been better.

Pink Temple - aka Ladies Temple. Banteay Srei features pink/red sandstone and low walls so this provides easy access to tourists. Located within 37km (1hr drive) away from main town area, best ways to get there include renting a tuktuk or a full/half day car booking which costs around USD40-45. I used driver Sophean (+855 92 986 353) who spoke good English and told of tales and history of Cambodia as we passed the serene countryside. Entrace is included in the Angkor Heritage Pass - USD20 for one day and USD40 for up to 3days. I recommend the 3day pass as it is not possible to visit all in a single day. Hire a guide if you must for more elaborate understanding of the temples but I went temple hopping alone. Dress code recommended for temple visit include light sleeved tops, pants and comfy shoes.

one of the most beautiful temples, but overcrowded with busloads of tourists. When I was first here in 2006, it was still a quiet place, with a few food vendors and souvenirs on the roadside.Meanwhile they have by-passed the place and established a huge parking ground and 'professional' restaurants, which serve you (the same ) fried rice you get in Siem Reap for $ 1.75 , for $ 5.50. So, either stay hungry or grasp the nettle.A short walk will bring you to the temple now, which from the 10th century is one of the older ones, and most beautiful in early or late hours of sunshine.About 45 to 60 minutes by TukTuk from Siem Reap.

Hidden Gem away from Angkor Wat. Locals call this temple the Lady Temple because it is pink.Manage your expectations because this temple was made during the 12th century so its not that pink right now. But it is still great! I can't imagine how great it was back then.This is a flat temple so if you are tired of getting up the stairs of the other temples, you can have a break here.Although this temple is located some 30+Kilometers away from Angkor Wat temples, this place is worth the visit!

A gem. It is a little out of the way from Siem Reap but the hour long trip is worth the time. The scenery on the way there and back is entertaining. Once you get to the temple (try to get there first thing in the morning to avoid be by yourself and get great pictures). The temple is small and has a very warm feeling with it's terra-cotta color. It's also surrounded by a water feature that's reflects beautifully. The carvings are the most detailed and spectacular you will see in Siem Reap. Definitively one of my favorites and worth visiting.

One of the best kept temples in Angkor.. It is about 35 kilometers from siemp reap. It is must visit without which trip is not over. You have to go to see really old temple as it is. The have parking outside and clean toilets. It is a long walk inside the temple but just amazing. I just loved it. It is on one level so very easy to walk . Worth the visit. The same Angkor ticket is valid. If thirsty have fresh coconut water.
worth the trip. it's only 35 km from siem reap but it take an hour or more to get there but it's worth the trip, try to go early to avoid the crowd, you will love it
Smaller but nice. The rain sent everyone away around lunch. The rain stopped and there were very few people there. Great photos.

Very Detailed Relief Carvings. This is out of the way and of modest size but the carvings are very detailed. Arrive before the buses for the best photographs. Ask your driver to stop at the Land Mine Museum for an honest educational event.

Citadel of the women. Carved for pink sandstone and about 35 km from Siem Reap through picturesque untouristed villages. Everything is I miniature compared to Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. Banteay Srei is surrounded by some forest with a little trail to give views of rice fields, the famous hill where the stones of Angkor Wat was quarried and the first Jayavarman declared the Khmer empire in 802 AD. Lots of information, a small museum and of course no end of stalls where you can purchase everything from a fresh pineapple, a cappuccino and even an academic book not to mention then beautiful clothes, bags, and llamas..

A little out of the way, but worth it. After Bayon, Ta Prohm, and Angkor Wat - this is the remaining "can't miss" temple in the area, in my opinion.The carvings still look like new, and the pink/orange sandstone is really unique. If you're spending more than 1 day in this area (and have hit the temples I already listed, as well as the Phare circus), definitely make the trip here.On the way back to Siem Reap, consider stopping at the Cambodian Land Mine Museum, so you don't have to make a separate special trip just for that.I listed "fee for this attraction - yes" due to the $20 (for a one-day pass) charge for ANY temple in Angkor Archaeological Park.

A bit far from Siem Reap - Excellent Carvings. Banteay Srei is a bit far away from Siem Reap and most temples. It is, however, a jewel. Small, but contains probably the best carvings in Angkor. It worth a visist.It takes about 1 hour to get there by tuk tuk. We chose to mix the visit with the Grand Tour, and it worked out pretty well.Even standing a bit far from Siem Reap, this is not a remote place. All the basic infrastrcture can be found there: parking, food, clean toillets, the omnipresent souvenir shops.If you have more than 1 day in Siem Reap, you must visit Banteay Srei. It is one of the finest temples you will visit, but it will take some time.P.S. Very crowded.

Don't miss this!. Of all the temples we saw, this was my all time favorite. The temple is smaller and surrounded by water filled with lotus flowers. The fine detailed carvings from the stone masters of long ago are an absolute wonder! It is easier here to get a feeling of what life must have been like as the temple complex is more compact. I must repeat the, details are incredible and complex! The Hindu story that are carved in stone are fascinating. Getting here is easy with a Tuk Tuk or a standard taxi. We took a Tuk Tuk so we could enjoy the sights on the way and the fresh air. The driver waited for us the whole day ( we were so fascinated with Banteay Srei that we did not want to leave). I hope I have been able to convey to you the reader what an incredible experience this Temple is and deeply encourage and recommend that you take the time to visit Banteay Srei temple.

Take a tuk tuk. We wanted to see this beautiful temple, but it's a ways out. We got a tuk tuk and drove through the countryside, very exciting! Our driver mr pheng was great, knows the country, good restaurants, speaks English well and has a great sense of humor, highly recommend him! You won't be disappointed by the temple or pheng, great day!

Small but beautiful. This one was worth the drive and getting up early. When we arrived there were no buses on the lot...only a few cars so the visit was relaxing. There are so many carvings to see here. Once again we were happy to have a guide to point things out to us and show us the best views. Everyone must leave town at the same time because when we left the lot was full of buses so get an early start if you don't like the crowds.

Out of the Way, But Well Worth It. Banteay Srei is substantially further away than the bulk of the Angkor area temples, but it is well worth the trip. It is covered by your temple pass for admission. We went by tuktuk to get there, and while it takes longer that way than by car, it's quite a pleasant drive, with much to see on the way. Its location is not far from Kbal Spean, a place I also highly recommend visiting; the two combined make an excellent day trip in Siem Reap.The main temple structure is very well preserved and its carvings are lovely and quite intricate. It's a relatively small temple and there are no stairs to climb, which can be a plus if you've need of a bit of a break. If you go during the rainy season the moat will be filled in and can make for some very eye-catching photographs.

One of the best!. This really could have been my favourite, we were lucky enough to visit at a time with no tourists and pretty much had it to ourselves. It is a bit further from the main temples but not to be missed.

Fairytale Temple. Banteay Srei is a bit of a distance from the main Archeological Park, although it is still covered by the park entrance fee, but is definitely worth the trip. You will probably need to take a car as opposed to using your tuk tuk, but a visit here can be combined with a visit to the Landmine Museum, which is on the way, or in a "long" loop to visit some of the other outlying temples such as Beng Melea, or Tonle Sap lake (bear in mind, if you plan such an itinerary, you will need to be up VERY early, and it will take all day). It is a lovely, fairly quiet temple, made of a gorgeous pink/red sandstone. Since it was buried until fairly recently, many of the carvings are remarkably preserved in all their detail. The best time to visit is apparently early morning and late afternoon, but the temple retains its lovely delicate, fairyland feel at all times. It is a fair bit smaller than most temples, and flat, so you won't need to dedicate too much time, although once you see it you may want too! There is a very nice, clean toilet on the park grounds as well.

gem. Banteay Srei is a small gem. Human scale, with such exquisite sandstone carvings. As with any of the temples, one must do homework first and have some knowledge of Hindu iconography and contemporaneous history and temples of neighboring countries. Alas, nothing can be done about the overwhelming crowds- most of whom have little idea of why they're there. One more thing to check off the bucket list? Go to Disneyworld instead?

Delicate carvings. Walking in the Angkor monuments, was just like walking into a giant sculpture museum. If you see carefully, you will find stunning works everywhere. Among them, the Banteay Srei has the most outstanding craft art, which seems to be expressing the ancient story of Indian mythology. From those vivid images, rich layers, fine lines, elegant style, I was admired by the ancient Angkor's exquisite carving skills , and their persistence to continue working on the hard rock for years and years...穿行在吴哥古迹中，仿佛进入了雕刻博物馆，仔细观赏，处处都有令人惊艳的作品。其中，又以女王宫(Banteay Srei)的精雕细琢最为出色。一幅幅精美绝伦，巧夺天工的浮雕，叙述着印度古诗的神话故事，其生动的形象，丰富的层次，细腻的线条，高雅的风格，无一不让人对古吴哥精湛的雕刻技艺而佩服，更为古人在坚硬的岩石上经年雕琢的耐力与坚持而感动。

Worth the trip. Even thou it's abit far from the city (30kms), the Banteay Srey is definitely worth the trip. Although it's quite small, and tuk tuk ride is a pain in the bum; the carvings and sculptures are detailed and are in good condition. The green moss growing on the pinkish stones really make my pictures stand out.

Worth The Trip. This was a nice side trip to breakup the day. Beautiful stone and beautiful carvings not to be missed and not to be rushed through. I would also recommend that when you visit the temples out of the main area that you hire a car and not take a tuk-tuk due to the dust and heat. We enjoyed the tuk-tuks but were so glad that we were traveling in a nice air conditioned car.

Slight respite from the main temple complex. While a short drive from Siem Reap and the majority of other temple ruins, the "women's temple" is worth a visit. The carvings are very intricate and the stone a much more vibrant pink/red colour - the atmosphere is also a little more relaxed in comparison to some of the other major attraction in the area. We did see some officers offering souvenirs for tourists, over and above the children who are ever-present on the temple visits, but you are mostly free to wander around the ruins to take photographs as you wish. Our guide advised us to stop and visit some of the stalls on the drive over to see how palm sugar is made, which was very interesting. (You can also visit the independent landmine museum which in en route, but we did not stop here on out trip.)

One of the best. Worth the trip out there. It's a smaller temple with more detail and pinker stone. Very glad we went out to see it. It's worth the stop at the land mine museum on the way there or back. Some of the best detail pictures I got from the temple park were from here.

Worth the journey from Siem Reap!. While this temple is a 1.5 hour journey from town, make every effort to come to view the best preserved carvings in the area on unique tan/ochre/red sandstone hardly seen elsewhere. The temple underwent substantial restoration as nicely explained with photographs at the small visitor's gallery. In direct contrast from the immensity of Angkor Wat, this temple is very compact; it is packed with numinous carvings throughout. We ate lunch at the nice restaurant onsite. We visited in the 1pm hot sun in July 2013; not the best time. I imagine early morning or late afternoon light would make the stone colors glow! I would make this priority #4 after Angkor Wat, Bayon, and Ta Prohm.
delicate and incredible craving. I felt the cravings here on the wall is more better preserved, but long ride here may not be worth it to some

My favorite temple!. This one is out of the way and worth the trip. Its smaller than the others, but it's just beautiful to see in the setting sun. We loved the color of the stones and it's story. We wanted to stay and photograph all day! The crowds were bearable in the afternoon as it was heading towards dark.

beautful and atmospheric. much smaller than the other main temples, but so much more delicate and intimate an experience. Takes a while to get there, but you can start the grand tour by going there if desired. Get there early - it was crowded by the time we got there and it's very small.

underwhelmed. The carvings here are great. Perhaps because I did this on my last day, I was too templed out. The temple is immensely popular with tour groups, and i counted about 20 large tour buses the day I was there. That really ruins the whole experience, as it is a smaller temple and best enjoyed in quiet, which is impossible with large groups around, all wanting to get their photo taken in front of something or other.

A piece of ancient art. Some people may be disappointed because not much left of this temple but the remaining remnants of a relatively small temple are definitely worth seeing. Why? Because the carvings are stunningly beautiful. Each piece is a proof of unique skills of ancient artists in the 10th century. Yes, it is bit distant from other attractions of Siem Reap but it is definitely worth taking 40 km (or so) trip to see it.Should not be missed while you are there

Disappointed a bit. Intricate carvings were not what I expected. Was expecting more from this temple and was disappointed there were not more carvings left. I think more carvings are in museums than left here. Don't make a special visit here

be early. Beautiful temple with nearby visitors centre full of very interesting historical facts. Cafe attached and market stalls selling clothing etc.Originally my driver was to pick me up from Siem Reap at 8am however I changed it to 7am which turned out to be a good call because as I was leaving swarms of tourists by busloads were heading down the path towards the temple traffic. I felt very relieved indeed!

Out of the way but worth it?. It's certainly a few kilometers away from the main temples so that needs to be taken into consideration. The women's temple is awash in great detail and is accentuated by the red/pink colouring. I may not be giving it justice but it was a rainy day when I saw. I'm sure a sunny day would have made the red/pink hue seem more vibrant.. I actually liked the walk up to the temples more. Although it was a muddy walk the young children playing in the rain with the backdrop of the temples was quite enjoyable to see.

Incredible detail and a worthy trip. As other reviewers comment this temple is quite far out from the main temple stops (Angkor wat, bayon and Ta Prohm) but in my opinion worth it. If you only have a day of temple exploring (with so many amazing places to explore to spend only a day doing so should be a crime!) then I imagine you will see the big aforementioned temples and not bother with this one. We saw this temple at the end of our second day of temple exploration, going round the 'big circuit' with our tuktuk driver stopping at many of the smaller, less crowd heavy temples (but not less interesting). The level of detail in the stone carvings is incredible here and perhaps the most thorough of any of the temples I have visited.This isn't worth the long drive to see this temple alone but can easily be combined with several other sights of the bigger circuit and well worth a visit if you have purchased a 3 day pass to the temple area.

A stunningly beautiful, distinctive temple. Don't miss it.. Often, the architecture of the many temples at Angkor run together in one's mind. Not Banteay Srei. This is a delicate, pink temple with unusual, lace-like carvings. The themes of the carvings are also different from many other temples. It is about an hour out of Siem Reap but the drive is important to make.Absolutely book the best guide you can find to accompany you. There is too much to learn about these sites without having professional input along the way.There are a large number of temples in the Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, and outlying areas as well. Don't feel you have to see them all. Three full days of touring are important to do this world-class venue justice but these are the Don't Miss sites, in this order of priority: Angkor Wat, of course, the stellar, Number One site; Bayon; Terrace of the Elephants and Terrace of the Leper King; Ta Prohm; Bandrey Srei; Preah Kahn; Pre Rup; Neak Prean.Give yourself time to visit your three favorites a second time within your three day itinerary. Many are so overwhelming in their interest, architecture, and artistry that you must see them at least twice to begin to appreciate them. We had to see the Churning of the River of Milk at Angkor Wat three times, as it was so artistically stunning, and is comparable to the greatest carvings anywhere in the World.

The best art of all the temples.. The temple is about 1 hour out of Siem Reap. It is well worth the trip. The temple carvings are the best of any of the temples. They are preserved better than other temples due to using a better pinkish stone. The temple is small and you won't need to walk much. We were thinking of skipping this one due to being out of town, but we are so glad we made the effort to see it. On the way back you might want to stop a the land mine museum.

very well maintained but worth the extra 20km?. to be honest i was lucky that i used a jeep willis that day. bantay srei is a bit distant and once u get there it is very nice and very well maintained and carvings are clear. however is it worth the extra 20kms? in a tuk tuk or on bike? no unless you do one of the other activities there (i heard there are fishing trips in the lake and stuff but ddnt go there)
the Lady temple. It's a little far to reach, but would be nice if you can. He place is big as well, and the temple is a marvel to the eyes,
Beautiful. Must see as it is pre Angor Wat and the detail in the work is beautiful. The colours of the stone is very different and beautiful look for the scriptures in the doorway

Details carvings. The moment walking into this small beautiful temple with incredible details carving also known as Lady Temple, immediately i felt the peace and calmness around me. This pink stone make this temple unique as compare to other bigger temple. Must visit!!

Amazing Details. Beautiful pinkish temple. Relief carvings are the most detailed of them all. Photographer's dream especially during sunset.Not as large as Ta Prohm or Angkor Wat, but just as spectacular. Quite a long way off so plan this for a separate day from the other temples. One caveat, be prepared to be mobbed by Cambodian children beggars and vendors on the way in and out.
Lady temple casts a Rosie glow in the sunlight. Quieter than many temples. Small in size. Beautiful pink sandstone. Beautifully and lovingly restored. My favorite temple

Very pretty. This was a fair drive out. It had very intricate carvings, very beautiful. We had a good lunch on the way out there that had a shop of wood carvings, furniture etc which were amazing. Worth the trip.

Exquisite. We loved the intricate carvings and the beautiful color of the sandstone at this temple. We took a tuk tuk to the temple which took about an hour. It's a little bit long for a tuk tuk ride but definitely doable. We spent a lot of this time at this temple because there is so much beauty to absorb. This is on my list of must sees at Angkor Wat.

must have a look. This temple is small in size in comparison to the larger Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat. The temple itself is made from pink sandstone and is very pretty. Our guide told us that the temple translates to "Citadel of Women". The carvings are very delicate and amazingly are still visible and well maintained. There were small children wandering around the temple happily trying to sell their wares of fish. It was a drizzly day when we were there, but, it was still worth the drive there to visit and have a look around.

Very beautiful! Highly recommended. If you only have time to do just 2 sites - make this your second, after Angkor Wat itself. The beautiful pink sandstone still had carvings so intricate and deep you have to see it up close to appreciate it.

Well worth a visit... exquisite carvings!. This temple is quite different from others - the colour of the sandstone alone, is very different - much softer pink and red tones, not greys nor browns like other temples. Banteay Srei consists of low walls surrounding "peaked, carved structures" (thought to be libraries). Banteay Srei means "Citadel of Women," and it is said that the carvings in this temple are so delicate that they could only have been done by women. They are extremley well preserved and many of the pictures depict scenes from ancient Hindu tales.

Stunning Temple Complex. A favorite of travellers and we could quickly see why - smaller and more compact than the sprawling and spectacular Angkor Wat - Banteay Srei is worth the trip. We benefitted greatly from the company of our guide, Chong Sang, of Indochina Odyssey Tours. His knowledge of the temple and the history surrounding it brought it to life in front of our eyes. A photographers dream the architecture and details so close you can touch them - this is a must visit on any trip in Cambodia. Just amazing.
Worth the travel. This temple is unique by its styke and age. Lovely settings. A bit away from the complex in Angkhor wat but it is absolutely worth the drive.

just beautiful. worth the drive, especially by tuk tuk, it was fun and you got to see so much (Mr Ral 855 12713557, was the best $15-$20/day) such amazing architecture, and so old, really undescribable

Older than Angkor Wat. Banteay Srei is site that is north of Angkor Wat. If you have an extra day to explore, I would recommend seeing this great site. The ruins are smaller than Angkor but the art is amazing. We took a tuk tuk there and it took about 45 min to 1 hour to get there.
Favourite temple. A bit out of the way but worth the effort. Being smaller it allowed you to take in the whole spectacle in on easy viewing. Thoroughly enjoyed the visit

Hindu temple in a buddhist land. Banteay Srei is very beautiful, with many elaborate carvings throughout the complex. It is particularly interesting because of its pure Hindu origins, reflected in the carvings not of Buddha, but Vishnu.

Don't forget an umbrella for shade!. This was one of the best restored temples (or possibly just less deteriorated than some of the others)The carvings were amazing.BUT it was hot - we were there after lunch so there weren't many people around. Take a little umbrealla with you for some shade if you're going any time after about 10:00am. A nice little temple to visit on the way home.

Pretty but a bit slick. This tiny temple complex with it’s beautiful, intricate carvings and pink sandstone offers something different from most of the other temples around Siem Reap but for us it lacked the magic of the larger jungle clad temples. We arrived late in the morning on a sunny day and this is one of the complexes where you really feel the heat. There were a few tour buses visiting and it seemed more crowded than anywhere else we had been to because of the restricted walkways around the temples. The entrance to the site is more highly commercialized than the other temples around Siem Reap, and very well maintained, slick even. Seems like a place that’s used to receiving the more affluent tour buses (reflected in the prices of the stalls). As there were 5 of us we had hired a mini-van to visit further away places. I’m glad we combined our trip out here with a few other sites (Landmine museum, Beng Melea and Komplong Phluk), otherwise it wouldn’t have been worth the expense for us

Small, but perfectly formed. Its quite a distance to get here, so probably best to combine it with a visit elsewhere. We were the first people to arrive and the 'security guard' was happy to offer to let us into the roped off area for a couple of dollars - we declined. It is very pretty and the carvings are amazing.

Best place to see sunset. You have to walk to the mountain almost 1 km. so you should were a good shoes which can walk in a long and rough distant.Don't forget to prepare flashlight for your return to car park when the sun already set and it's turn to dark
Worth the Extra Distance. 10th Century sandstone temple in excellent condition. Very special. Superbly detailed carvings. About 45 minute drive from Siem Reap--worth the trip.

Little Jewel. This temple must be visited to see the intricate stone carving on rare pink stone. It is small but exquisitely detailed in it's storytelling. It's a "flat temple"---mo climbing necessary---and is ideal for people who have difficulty with heights.

Smaller than most but makes up in the details. Despite the smaller scale compared to the others, by far my favorite stop. The detailed carvings that many others will mention are amazing. Our guide mentioned that many of the Hindu gods are represented here. Each stone face had the most detailed intricate patterns and images. It's a small space and much more enjoyable at non peak hours I'm sure, if there is such a thing.

Detailed stonework. Bit of a trek out but the detailed stonework is worth it. Don't eat there though as the food is expensive. The temple is quiet as the crowds don't go there. The drive through the countryside is also worthwhile.

Beautiful. Excursions must be done early in the morning, preferably before 9 AM because if not flocks of tourists come and it becomes really difficult to shoot pictures and truly enjoy the ambiance of Banteay Srei
Great surrounds. Beautiful small temple greets you after an hours tuk tuk ride thru the countryside...the ride was a worthwhile event on its own with so much to see... Gives insight into rural life

Beautiful temple. This is probably #2 on our list of temples for photo ops. It truly is beautiful and the fact that you can only walk in certain areas gives it a much more pleasant atmosphere than some of the other temples - untouched as it were. The intricate carvings here are much more preserved than others and there are even security guards of sorts to ensure you stick to the designated pathways. Far less crowded than anywhere else we visited so some really good time for thinking, reflection and letting your imagination run a little bit wild. It took about an hour in a tuk tuk to reach but it definitely worth it. The area in which this temple lies could take up half a day at least as there are various paths trailing off to the surrounding areas but due to monsoon rains sweeping in we legged it past most of these back to the "visitor's centre" area! Go to the Landmine Museum if you're coming this way out as that too is a must visit location.

Bantey Srei : Poetry in Pink Stone. Bantey Srei This is a small and an extremely elegant temple built using the pink sand stones with very fine carvings. This was built by by a Brahmin named Yajnavaraha. All the pediments have Hindu mythological incidents well carved - Gaja Lakshmi, three headed Airavata, Narasimha (half lion half man avatar of Vishnu) killing demon Hiranyakashibu, Ravan shaking Kailash with Shiva on top, Indraprasta involving Indra, Agni, Krishna and Arjun - a lovely tale of Arjun blocking the downpour of Indra and a little pond born out of the blocked water, Monkey kings vali and Sugriva fight etc. Some of the guardians like garuda, vanara and yaksha are impressive. Small temple built using pink stones keeps you engaged. We spent close to two hours here. There are so many interesting temples and places like 1) Rolous group - Preah Ko (Sacred Bull), Bakong, Lolei; Bakong is beautiful especially 2) Bantey Samre with towers resembling the popular ones in South India (Dravidian architecture - Pallava style) 3) Pre Rup We spent half a day for the above three 1) Srah Srang - a lake built by J7. It was to the brim and we visited it in the midst of rain. It was used for Naval exercise to prepare well to fight Chams who were adept in Naval warfare 2) Prasat Kravan - Temple with Mahalakshmi and Vishnu 3) Ta Promh - awe inspiring sight of silk cotton trees and temples intertwined with each other. Site where 'Tomb Raider' was shot 4) Thommanon We spent a half day for the above four temples

Breathtaking. This off the beaten path temple was worth the drive. Banteay Srei or "Citadel of Women" is a 10th century Hindu temple with magnificent relief carvings. Easily accessible as it is built on one level and made of deep red sandstone.

Worth the Drive. Take a Tuk Tuk out (about an hour)-see the countryside, gasp at the rose rising from the jungle at Banteay Srei-finest application of Angkor artisans. Stop at Pre Rup on way back. Make a day of this-a pinnacle of Angkor exploration

Great building ruined by so many people at once. Lovely pink sandstone temple, but the continual stream of people makes it hard to stand back and appreciate the building. The path is narrow, and like stepping stones so will not be preserved for long, I felt sad that more is not done to help people enjoy this site without ruining it.

The Pink Temple. We visited this temple on a long day trip to Banteay Srei, Kbal Spean and Preah Vihear. This is a must for everybody. It's a gem made of red sandstone, extremely rich with intricate and delicate carvings. A real pleasure to look at, if you are interested in Khmer art. But everybody knows it, so the temple is small, you cannot visit the central prasat (this is restricted area) and the flock of tourists swarm around the small pathways, making it difficult to fully enjoy the peaceful area, let alone take decent photos without arms and legs in between. But it DOES deserve a visit.We arrived very early in the morning, around 6am and enjoyed its beauty at sunrise with nobody else around for about 15 minutes ! When the sun hits the surface the colour effects are absolutely stunning.
Lovely. This is probably the best Temple outside of India representing what is does. The colors and textures are sweetness and make for great photography.

Interesting temple. The temple and grounds are very well kept and interesting.
I enjoyed a few hours there.
Restaurant is "tourist" prices.
Toilets charge 500 riel for locals and 2,000 for foreigners.

A sweet little temple. A lovely little temple in the complex. Worth some time and some camera space. Also in amongst the jungle more. Sadly the temple area is one of the few spots that still has some of what must have been some amazing jungle area with majestic trees at some time. Pity the Khmer Rouge, and succeeding governments thought it appropriate to decimate the Forrest's. Interesting to note the money from all of the entry fees paid for all of the temples goes to the Vietnamese government......? Pity as Cambodia desperately needs money to develop.

very different but not near Angkor wat. This is 37 Km away -But you can visit temples on route-as we did it's a good visit if have 2-3 days in Siem Riep -made of red sand stone type-lot of details and carvings seen clearly

Beautiful Temple. Having read in the guide books about the beauty of this temple I rented a Tuk Tuk for the nearly 40km journey through the Cambodian country side (eye opening in itself).The temple was as expected cut in an unusual red sandstone and on a small scale. The area leading to the temple was slightly over developed and commercial for my taste which was a detraction for me. Another downside is that it wasn't possible to walk through the central shrine area as foot traffic was confined to the outer enclosure.Despite the negatives, the unusual character of this temple, the compact scale and the extensive inscriptions mean a visit to this temple is worth while if only as a counterpoint to the scale and splender of the main temples around the Angkor Wat area.

Beautiful and often overlooked temple. This temple built from red sandstone is well preserved and contains many beautiful carvings. It is an incredibly photogenic place. Though a somewhat longer drive than the larger temples, you get to see the Cambodian countryside and how people live outside of the city.
DELICATE carving. A very differnt experience to Angkor Wat. Delicate carving and a more human scale. A MUST to add to the itinerary
Worth the trip!. The colors are unlike the others. Somehow it seems more intimate, I guess because it is smaller. Get off the beaten path a bit and enjoy the amazing hues.
