Must visit Bantay Srei, early morning.. Definitely worth to visit this temple far the accommodation is much better run, pink color sandstone signage, also the way tuk-tuk to there is very nice. it's not a big temple, but very nicely restored.

Small wbut with intricately carved pink sandstone. We saw many temples in the Angkor Archeological Park but this small Hindu temple stood out with its intricate carvings of the Hindu gods among various local scenes, The carvings have survived well despite it being built in the tenth centur=.It is somewhat ruined, but being restored.Worth a visit
Favorite temple!. The 40-minute drive outside of Angkor Wat complex to get here is totally worth it. Made of pink sandstone and has the most delicate and intricate carvings, this temple is beautiful!

Beautiful. Cambodia was a wonderful surprise, it's beautiful, the people are so welcoming and friendly. We stayed at The Privilege Floor and were treated as honored guests. The suites were comfortable and beautiful! The food was great we had breakfasts included with out suites and also a Top Shelf "Happy Hour" every day also include in our $200. Per night suite. We also had free use of a car and driver 24 hours a day. We'll come back someday just to enjoy the amenities of the resort!

Small temple but worth the drive. This temple can be combined with a visit to the landmine museum and the butterfly place on the way. Nice cafe as well. Shame about the tourists who drop rubbish and spoil the beauty. Saw one tourist blatantly drop rubbish and when I commented, had no intention of picking it up.

Further from Siem Reap, but worth the effort.. Banteay Srei is a much smaller temple than Angkor Wat or Bayon, and is almost forty kilometres from Siem Reap, but it's definitely worth the longer trip. We cycled there along completely flat, lightly trafficked roads, as part of a three day cycling package. Banteay Srei's highlight is the detailed and intricate carving of the pinkish sandstone from which the temple is constructed. This carving covers almost every stone surface and is in remarkable condition considering it has been there for a millenium. The trip there and back also passes through several villages where local subsistence farmers supplement their income by making and selling palm sugar in roadside stalls.

Visually appealing but smallish. We took a tuk-tuk the 39 km to Bantreay Srei about 8 am, thoroughly enjoying both the scenery and natural air conditioning along the way. There was quite a crowd when we arrived which made photographing and negotiating the small site a bit cumbersome. Its distinctive coloration and features were beautiful but we had seen it all in 30 minutes which didn't seem to be worth the long trip. Fortunately we also had the Landmine Museum on our itinerary which is a few klicks south of Bantreay Srei making the journey worthwhile. Between the scenery, Bantreay Srei and the Landmine Museum, the experience was well worth the distance.

Really beautiful and worth the extra distance. Banteay Srei is a little further than the other temples but really worth seeing. It's a really beautiful site with the stonework a lovely red shade, different from most others. I was there in the morning and there were quite a few people but not extreme. The site is lovely and has a heap of character and easy to get around. The story behind it is really interesting so worth reading up on first.

Small vishnu temple. It took around an hour by tuktuk to reach it. Its a 'small' temple,dedicated to vishnu,though I cud see shiva as well.its not really well-restored. And the crowd was just too much. But still its a good spot to take some pic.

Banteay Srei - the pink temple. Brilliant - bit out of Siem Reap (40kms) and we went by tuk tuk - what a wonderful experience. The temple was smaller, with fewer visitors than some of the others, but far more intricate and preserved. Well worth the venture
Another beauty. This is one of the temples that are preserved beautifully, although not as popular as the other bigger temples.

beautiful, serene temple. We arrived her in the early afternoon, and had the pleasure of exploring it for some time without hoards of people. It enabled us to see the intricate pink sandstone carvings, and just enjoy this small but wonderful temple. Definitely worth visiting, agree that a guide or book will help interpret it well.

Family with teens. Very hot when we went to bantay srei the actual temple was good but the crowds were huge had to line up for photos in most spots. Can't handle some of the pushy tourists, drives me a bit crazy.

don't miss it!. My favorite temple, a marvel!
I suggest you to have a guide very prepared, it's better if he/she is teacher, and be prepared to enjoy a splendid place.
I always suggest to go there in the hours with fewer tourists, such as dawn or invert your tour time.

Worth the effort to get to. This is a wonderful little gem of a temple, and worth the extra effort it takes to visit. As with all temples, it really enhances the experience if you have a guide or good guide book with you to help interpret what you are seeing.

Amazing Carving and relief work.. It is one of my favorite temples in Siem Reap.Little far from the main temple area but definitely worth the visit as it only takes 30 minutes to get there by car.The color of the stone make it stand apart from the other temples and the relief work is in a better condition due to the better quality of material used for the construction of the temple.
Dedicated for ladies. the buildings have smaller doors compared to other temples, although is older than other temples, the carvings are still vivid and beautiful.
Small but perfectly formed. On a very much more human scale than some of the other temples. Exquisite carvings. Beautiful sandstone.

Stunning. I thought this was wonderful. Obviously not on the scale of Angkor Wat or even Angkor Thom but stunning in the detailed carvings and a much more sympathetic size; much easier to relate to than the grandeur of some of the other temples. It was quite a way out of town, particularly by tuk tuk, but the trip there was interesting in it's own right. I don't see how anyone could be disappointed by this.

many regrets if missing this place. the most dedicated and beautiful "wat" we ever seen during the visit of Angkor wats, not so severely destroyed by human beings, the sculpture on the pediments and lintels are clearly seen, vivid and pretty. the structure is similar to Angkor wat but the size is smaller, easy for us to observe in details. exhibitions ticketing and guiding system are well done, including the commercial activities outside are designed to keep the same feeling of the temple.

Not in the heat of the day. Unlike other temples, there is zero sun cover.It's pink, which is different.It's delicately carved, that's kinda different.It's single story.It's ages out of town, not worth a trip by itself.Pretty though.

Intricate carvings of pinkish stone. This temple is one of the most intricate. It is also pretty far outside of Siem Reap. Our wonderful Tuktuk driver Piseth took us out here early one morning. It is one of the first temples to get fully restored and made into a tourist attraction, with a proper parking lot, restrooms, and even a gift shop. It's very well done, but not obtrusive about it. There is a tremendous amount of detail on the carvings of this temple. The stone was brought from a different place than most of the temples in the area, so the stone is more of a pink hue than the rest, which adds to it's beauty.Called the temple of the women because it was said that the carving was too fine and delicate to have been done by a man's hands, so it must have been done by women.Many of the center temple pieces are reproductions, but the temple looks closer to what it must have looked like in it's heyday with the level of care that was done to the restoration process.Definitely worth the ride out there through the countryside, and be sure to check out the Butterfly Museum when you're out that way. There is also a landmine museum nearby, but I didn't decide to check that one out.

small charming temple. It is a bit far from the city. However, it is great that i didn't miss that place. Even it is small but the carving on the wall is unique in the world. Beside the temple, there is a community restaurant where i had lunch cooked by local people and enjoy board riding.

Citadel of the women. Bentay Sreyloosely translated to "citadel of the women", but in this case it probably refers to the delicate beauty of the carvings. It displays some of the finest examples of classic Khmer art. the walls are densly covered with some of the most beautiful,deep and intricate carvings of any Angkorian temple . Its pink sandstone construction and ornate design give it a fairyland ambiance. The colors are best before 10.30 am and after 2.00 pm. the consolation is there is less tourists in the afternoon. Take note....it is 38 km from Siem reap,requring extra travel time and incures an extra levy by the driver...but its worth the effort. Combine your trip with a visit to Banteay Samre.
Great but you should sale Up early. Great landscapes, wonderful history columns but so many people around u And so many cambodia's girls trying to sell you something

Different Style. This is very different to the temples in the Angkor Wat area. The architecture is just stunning, you can see more at the museum as well, don't forget to go it is worth the visit. Banteay Srei is a good stop off on the way to the floating village.

Great relief's. Another great temple with its wonderful intricately carved and well preserved relief's carved on sandstone. There are many photo opportunities and you can spend a lot of time wandering around.

Great sculptures beautifull surrounding. Good place to see have food and rest room facility nice pics don't miss the small temple group with deep carvings its cute monkey sculpture everything is worth seeing easily accessible

Well worth the 37 km ride with a Tuk-Tuk!. Best temple for detailed carvings and the reddish colour of the sandstone makes it a different experience than all others! Small temple area, easy to cover, all flat terrain. Huge trees around the whole area. Entrance fee is covered with the Temple Pass.What a treat to go there the extra miles. A nice ride on country roads through villages alongside rice fields. Occasional stalls along the road with tropical fruit, baskets, incense etc., the Tuk-Tuk Drivers know a good restaurant to eat, they also sell wood furniture and local handicrafts there.
Favorite Temple. This was my favorite temple to visit because of all the detail! It was so beautiful. I definitely recommend stoping to see this one. Fee for this is included with your Angkor Pass.
Prettiest temple. The carvings in this temple are so ornate and well-preserved. After seeing dozens of sandstone temples, the pink sandstone in Banteay Srey is both refreshing and intriguing.

One of our favourites. The colour and detail of this smaller temple is amazing. We visited late afternoon so not so mnay people and the colour of the stone against the bright blue sky and green landscape was spectacular. Well worth the the visit

So beautiful, go with a guide. We went to this temple as part of a 2 - day guided tour package. It's a beautiful temple because the carvings in the stone were so deep that time has not weathered them as much as others in the area. I suggest you go with some sort of guide to point out the significance of the carvings, the design, and even the recent history of how the temples were used during the civil wars in the 70-80's.

Must see. We didn't get time to go here last year, so this was the first stop this time in Siem Reap. Just lovely. Different style to some of the other Temples, the carvings are very small and intricate. Beautiful pinkish colour also. Only a small Temple, but certainly worth the trip out to see

Not worth the effort. Despite the hundreds waiting for the sunset, we joined them by scrambling up 50 or so very steep and tall stone steps. Not for the faint hearted. However the view from the top could have been anywhere!
Group Angkor Tours September 2013

Unique temple outside the city. This was my wife's favorite temple. Though small, the intricate carving are incredible. It is worth the trip outside of town. I'd recommend taking a tuk tuk vs. a car. We really enjoyed the experience driving here in a tuk tuk and feeling as though we were outside as we headed to the temple and drove through towns.

Banteay Srei - Serene, detailed carvings, and worth the ride. This temple is one hour by car from Siem Reap but if you have the time you'll want to stop along the way to visit with some of the local vendors and get a bite to eat. This temple is the Women's Temple and dedicated to the Hindu deity Shiva. It is three concentric rectangular buildings with the inner one being the sanctuary. The carvings here are smaller and much more detailed - they are carved in red sandstone which has allowed them to persist and makes for some amazing photos. The site is smaller than most others so you'll want to visit other temples near this site. Along the way we stopped to see a girl cooking a rice and bean dish in bamboo by the side of the road. The items are so inexpensive and all handmade - great gifts and I really like supporting the people on their own land and talking to them as well.

Very Extrinsic Bantay Srei. For me this is a MUST visit temple even it is far. It is a 45minute ride from Lotus Blanc Resort. But when we got there, I don't know what's about it but I really like the extrinsic look of it. It looks very clean and well maintained. Even though most part of the temple is already destroyed, the remaining walls are very extrinsic. It's very appealing and made me appreciate the beauty of a hundred years old temple.

Stunning. We really loved this one - It is a little out of the way, however that also seemed to keep the droves away. I think that most people would either start or end here, When we went it was right in the middle of the day and there was only 1 or 2 other couples and then it was just us when they left, We might have been just lucky though. The tuk tuk ride out there was a nice way to break up a scorcher of an afternoon.

Beautiful temple. We visited this temple on our way back from Kulen mountain. Built of red sandstone, the temple has intricate carvings and in the evening light it just looked amazing. Entry to the inside of the temple is not allowed, though we saw some tourists going inside and when we asked the security guards they said that if we give them money they will allow us, which was just ridiculous.

elaborate carvings!. Banteay Srei or citadel of women is a little temple compared to others. Interesting to know that this temple was actually dedicated for the Hindu god Shiva. What caught my attention is the wall carvings, its very elaborate up to the smallest details. The smooth curves on each carvings are still very evident until now and its just amazing! It also has less tourists so its peaceful- you can really take time to roam around, reflect and just take in all these amazing history and culture of Khmer people. Heads up, there are many children selling stuff at the gate and they are really persistent.My two cents: Don't buy from children selling bracelets, magnets and other stuff. Its for their own good. Once people start buying from them (out of pity or generosity) and they get more income from it, they are more likely to just stay in the temples and miss school. We may be able to help them get by for a day but we might also take away their education which could be their only chance for a better future.

Pink laterite temple. Main reason we visited very early so there were less people and could take pictures of the temple without the crowd. The cravings were very unique. Color was brownish pink. Should visit this place despite the distance.
fascinating. well worth the time to get there , , a little bit far for the tuk-tuk , but the temple and surrounds and the country side beautiful
one of the temples. as you konwn, there are so many temples in siem reap. this is one of the many temples. Not very special, not very impressive...
Well worth a visit. A little bit further away and a bit smaller than the other temples, Banteay Srei is is still a beautiful and well-preserved temple

Lovely. Nice and small. Really beautiful and well preserved. The fact that this temple was created entirely in sandstone has left the carvings very intact. A bit further out of town, I would recommend getting here with a car and driver as opposed to a tuk-tuk.
Beautiful. So worth the hour or so to get there (by tuk tuk) Beautiful temple in a wonderful setting and not so touristy. Definitely another temple to see.

Smaller temple, quick tour. Temple is small and a quick tour can be made in 20-30 minutes or less. Carvings are well defined. Access inside the temple is not allowed. A square: From the front take right, follow the path but pass the exit to get a view of the left side, nearer the front entrance, then back track to the exit. good photo op at the far left corner of the temple yard, outside the gate-- two boulders offer good photographer height to get a full shot of the temple.

Intricate carvings small temple. Visit this together with a trip to Kbal Spean. Recommend going there by tuk-tuk, though far will give you a real feel and flavour of the Cambodian countryside. A good place to take photos is in front of the pool of water at the front of the temple. Beautiful intricate carvings and very small scale as compared to the rest of the angkor temples. There are food and refreshment outlets nearby and also clean toilets. We also enjoyed watching the water buffalos in the lake next to the temple.

Worth the trip. The best time to go to Banteay Srei is first thing in the morning. If you try head out about 6am you will beat the rush and get there in time to see it's beauty in the sunlight.There are few more temples surrounding it so it's not a wasted journey in the slightest. The trip to Banteay Srei was beautiful - being able to drive through Cambodian country side and see how many Cambodians live. Beautiful.
Worth the journey!. Smaller than others but no less beautiful, the stone carvings are interesting and lovely and it's small enough that you feel you can explore it fully!

Wheelchair accessibility. While many of Siem Reap's temples are beyond the access for the wheelchair user, Banteay Srei is as good as it gets. Long way from Siem Reap, but worth the tuk-tuk ride. The available food is good, the entrance displays excellent, and the accessible toilet OK (although getting to it is a challenge).

Really nice. This temple is quite further away from city, and the roads are average, so if you are visiting, do ensure that you get a good car. The temple itself is amazing!!! the scale of blocks humbles you; my 4 year old son thoroughly enjoyed climbing up and down the blocks.. gave him a sense of adventure. :) and clicking pictures was a pleasure here!

Tiny temple, 45 mins out of town.. Interesting countryside tuk-tuk ride from Siem Reap town to Banteay Srei. Lots of large noisy tourists groups here that turn up by the coach load but sit patiently-the groups will disperse & you could get the place almost to yourself. Would time my next visit mid to late afternoon by which time the coaches will have gone. Brilliant carving detail on this temple-take a good camera.

Beautiful temple, intricate carvings on walls. The reddish color of this temple made it stand out from the other temples in Siem Reap. Though not as huge as the other temples, it has very intricately designed walls and quite colorful. Good to visit in early a.m. since it gets so very very hot in late a.m. to early p.m.
Amazing temple made of red sandstone. Banteay Srei is a good distance from Siem Reap, but sets itself apart from the other ruins. It is more interesting, as is its history.

A bit of a drive, but worth it.. Although there are lots of children waiting to sell you postcards and books, after you wade past them, the temple of women are REALLY cool, with some of the best preserved intricate carvings that I saw in my entire visit. It is a bit different than the other structures, because this one is made of red sandstone.
Pink limestone. While this is a smaller temple it was built years before Angkor Wat and contains the best rock carvings we have seen. Not a bad meal at the diner on the way out.
Best choice. I really love this temple for its structure and nature view. It is so entirely displayed how great and beautiful archtechture it is to be a combination of both Brahminism and Buddhism.

Early morning beauty. We left the hotel at 5:30 AM to get there before anyone else and it was worth it. The temple was practically deserted and beautiful. The carvings are so intricate and well-preserved; you could spend hours. It's well kept and well worth seeing. The trip there is also worth it, just for the gorgeous views of the countryside and the chance you get to see the natives at their everyday lives, working in the rice fields and such. Only one thing marred our visit - the CORRUPT "guards" who shoo you away from certain roped off areas, only to whisper offerings of "special tour for five dolla." It is an insult to their uniform and the temple both.

Very intricate and colored. Yes, it's out of the way but I liked the drive and scenery getting there. This temple gives you a break from the other temples by being unique as it's only one level, smaller in scale and uses colored peach stone. The 3-D effect and details of the carvings make it so beautiful that even the French stole some of the statues. It was funny that while our guide was explaining about the French stealing the statues, a couple of French tourists walked by and apologized for their behavior!

Jewel of the Khmer Empire. Most beautiful of all Khmer temples in terms of carvings, coloring and setup. The Swiss really did a great job in restoring the temple plus providing facilities and commercial areas for tourists.Only downside is the charging for parking within the compound.Include in your itinerary

Worth the trip out. My favourite. Such a stunning temple. One of the older ones, built of pink sandstone with intricate carvings. Built on a smaller scale than many others but the detail I the carving is worth the trip.

Beautiful!. Bateay Srei is about 30/40km outside of Siem Reap but getting there provides an excellent opportunity to see the traditional villages that exist in the Angkor National Park. You need an Angkor Wat pass and it was checked by the guards so don't forget it!! This temple is smaller than the others but the carvings are absolutely beautiful and there were plenty of picture opportunities. You can go there for sunrise and can apparently sit on the temple if you are willing to pay the police/guards (our guide told us this). We arrived at 7am and had the temple almost to ourselves before the buses arrived as it only takes about 100 people for the area to feel very crowded. The deep carvings give a real contrast to the shallower bas relief seen elsewhere in Angkor. It was definitely one of our favourite temples.
The finest. Like many would agree, this is the finest of them all. It is a little bit far, thus you could plan with other activities and take a day trip.

Our favourite.. Despite its small size, it delivered some stunning carvings and is also less popular with the big buses and easy to visit. We simply loved this temple and have spoken to many other travellers who were so pleased they made the effort to visit.

Banteay Srei. This temple is rather small. I must admit I was a little disappointed with this one. Even though it was the lost temple and the history that goes with it. It is very small and not really a lot of photo opportunities.

Intricate temple. Completely different than the temples of Angkor. This was apparently designed by a woman and you can see by the architecture that it is far more intricate and the stone is like a pinky colour. It is a little way from Siem Reap but, well worth a visit, just seeing all the countryside on the way is a pleasure. Barter a price with a tuktuk driver

Farther await but worth the trip!. Banteay Srei is a small, pink sandstone temple with complex and intricate carvings. Because these carvings are so detailed and beautiful, it was originally thought to have been done by women. Our guide told us that this turned out to be not true. The temple is quite small in comparison to the others in the Angkor area because it was actually built by the monks themselves. Wonderful temple and peaceful--only three or four other visitors at the time--but it was overwhelmingly hot when we went. Try to avoid noon to 3:00 pm.

Amazing architecture. We went there in the late morning, it is 30km from the city center. Before we enter the temple, our guide brought us to the pond to take the picture of the reflection. No other tourist realized the spot. I love the architecture....is beautiful with pinkish hue. The carvings are deep and exquisite.

Beautiful and Quaint. Picturesque...don't miss seeing the paddy fields behind the temple. Lovely carvings, many photo opportunities. Intricate carvings and although it's about a 7-10 minute walk to the temple from the parking lot, the temple is relatively small.

Worth the effort?. It's a reasonably long hike (50 minutes by tuk tuk) and there is absolutely no doubt the carvings are intricate and impressive (read all the reviews). However unless you get there in the very early morning or late afternoon the crowds in such a small temple are overwhelming. The endless line of tuk tuk's going to and from will give you a great idea of what I meanIm guessing given the well developed tourist facilities at Banteay Srey there is an element of self promotion. If you have limited time would suggest your time would be better spent exploring more of the main park or perhaps visiting the Roulos Group.

Different completely from the other temples and worth the visit. Different completely from the other temples and worth the visit. Go as early as possible to avoid the large contingents of bus tours and combine a hike to the waterfalls and the landmine museum to make a day of it.

beautiful temple; annoying touts. on the whole, this is a very nice temple, and I would disagree that it is too far to be worth it, especially as you can combine the trip with a visit to the Landmine museum (very good) and butterfly sanctuary (didn't actually go, but it's meant to be good, especially for children)Two words of CAUTION, however: the temple grounds are arranged in one way paths, littered with touts (I know it's to be excessive, but given the one-way and often narrow paths, there's no escaping them, and it can feel intimidating).Also watch out for police officers, who try and approach those without a guide, and expect a lot of money (often for very little, and inaccurate information). Don't risk having to say "no", just try and avoid them if possible.

Exquisite!!. It is an exquisitely carved miniature Hindu temple and a must see. Every inch of the temple is artistically carved. The Angkor temple and many others have beautiful carvings but the ones on Banteay Srei are the most finely done. It's a little away from the main temple circle and takes about 45 min to go on tuk tuk but it is certainly worth a visit. Your trip to Siem Reap is incomplete without it.

Small temple with intricate carvings. This is a unique temple in a sense that this temple was not built by royalty but by the Counsellor to the Khmer kings. This is a small temple but it's intricate and detailed carvings make up for a worthwhile visit. The red sandstone structure is unlike other Angkor ruins. It's best to come prepared with a cap or umbrella as there is not much shade. This temple is also well preserved.
Magnificent and well preserved. Go there in the afternoon about 3 pm the light is great for photography. Make sure you buy a book about the temples as this is the best way to understand the carvings.
Pink Temple... Long way out...about 30 to 40 minutes by tuk-tuk. Has unique features and a pink tinge to much of the stonework. Doesn't take long to take in the whole site...very photogenic.

Totally unique temple. Worth the longer drive. This is probably our most favourite temple of all. It is built from pink sandstone, and it is well preserved. It is tiny compared to the other temples / wats, but that is what is so appealing. It is a fair distance from town, and the atmosphere is so different from the popular sites. It is a Jewel onto itself

Jewel of the crown of Cambodian classical arts.. Banteay Srei temple is one of my most favorite temples in Siem Reap. Its because of the intricately carvings with pink sanstone. It is quite far from the other temples but the sight on the way there is extremely awesome.

Less astonishing than the other temples. Less astonishing than the other temples maybe, but it had somehing that made me want to sit down in one of the courtyards and read a book for a while, and then have some nice conversation with some locals working there.
Beautiful. Great photo opportunities and a worthy contender in Angkor Park. A bit further away then Angkor Wat but worth the visit. Beautiful carvings and the pink sandstone is spectacular.

Not like the others.... We enjoyed visited this temple because it was so different than the rest. Made entirely of brick, this temple was well preserved and in excellent condition. We visited late in July shortly after a brief rain shower. There were no crowds though this temple for some reason doesn't seem to draw the same number of visitors. Our private guide provided excellent detail about the structure, the carvings and its design. It really is lovely and worth a visit.

The reliefs at this temple are pretty well conserved. The reliefs at this temple are pretty well conserved. So that you can observe the magnificence of the work done hundreds of years ago. Although you cannot have a closest look to the middle of the temple were the pink statues are located it is still very nice

This is the real jewel in the crown on the Angkor temples. You will have to go a little further out from Siem Reap but this is the jewel you should not miss. It is smaller than the other temples but very beautiful and well worth seeing. It was actually in the best condition of all the temples I saw so you can get a better feel for what they would have looked like when they were actively used. The red sandstone is in remarkable condition and the carvings are breathtaking. If you are looking for size and grandeur, you might be disappointed. If you want to see close hand the intricacies of the sculptural carving and have an artistic eye, don't miss it. I hired a private car to go and was able to see this and another temple as well as a lot of the countryside out beyond Siem Reap. The price of the car and guide was less than going with an arranged tour and was well worth it.

Something different. A temple made by women? About 45 minutes from Siem Reap, go for a nice, albeit dusty, drive to see something different. Combine with a visit to Banteay Srei butterfly sanctuary and the Cambodian Landline museum as well - a great trip!

Finest of classical khmer art. Banteay Steyn !This temple covered with some of the most beautiful , deep and intricateCavings of any Angkorian temple . The temple relatively small size , pink sandstone construction and ornate design give it a fairyland ambiance .the color are best before 10:30 amAnd after around 2.00PM and this temple was discovered by French archaeologists relativelyLate in 1914 this temple is well worth the extra effort. Combine a visit to banteay srey with banteay samre to me I thinkThis temple excellent stone caving in the word

Nothing Special. It took an additional hour to reach here from Angkor Archeological Park. Personally, I do not think it's worth the extra cost. This is a very small temple and the ruin that remains are few. They have some nice shops and exhibitions around the area, but price wise it's quite costly and expensive. Not worth the extra travel time in my opinion.

A unique temple in the incredible Angkor precinct. My husband and I are travelling with our 19 month old daughter - our visit to Banteay Srei was a fantastic experience and we have some incredible photos from it: unlike the other sites in the area, this temple uses red sandstone and the carvings are more ornate / detailed than at other sites. There is also more information available on site than at other temples (i.e. The Interpretation Centre has a room of display boards that describe the archaelogical history of the site) Just note that:- Visitors can go almost anywhere, and there are very few stairs. However some areas may be slippery or muddy in the wet season, 'roped off' or unsafe - our toddler was carried in a backpack for most of our visit here.- Tuk Tuk was the best transport for us - took us just over an hour to get here from Siem Reap - and gave us flexibility to go anywhere and anytime. Most tuk tuks have a legal maximum of 3 passengers.- We got a 7 day pass, and spent an early morning here (6am - 8.30am) to avoid crowds. Tour buses started arriving at 8am.

The Ladies temple. When visiting the temples, you must include this one. They're all different.They call it the Ladies temple - supposedly because of the pink stone.It has a huge amount of very intricate carving.

The carvings were extremely detailed and very well preserved. We initially were not keen to visit the temple due to the additional cost which had to be incurred for the transport. However, after some urging and brief descriptions by the tour guide, we decided to go ahead, and we did not, for a second, regret it. The Bantaey Srei temple is alot smaller compared to Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and other more popular temples. However, what it lacks in size, it more then makes up in its carving complexity. The carvings were extremely detailed and very well preserved. What i enjoyed the most was the colours. Naturally coloured sandstone was used to build this temple and the pink and yellow sandstone were a joy to photograph.

Pretty in pink. This temple is about 12km or something away from the main archeological park, but it was worth ever km! This is the place where you need to go if you want to be charmed by the beautifully carved temples, built with pinkish stones.It's not going to win any prize in terms of size, unlike Angkor Wat, but here you'll find the most beautiful carvings of The Hindu deities along with their beloved beasts: Hanuman, Garuda, kumbakarna. The artists who built the temple did not spare any details, and the result of their hard work is this a gem of a temple.

Most Beautiful Carvings. Probably the best preserved carvings of the Angkor temples. Very intricate designs cover the predominantly red sandstone walls giving the temple a beautiful pink hue. Gorgeous and worth seeing though this is approximately an 1 1/2 drive from Siem Reap. You can combine visiting this temple with Beng Mealea (untouched and not to be missed) and the landmine museum (very interesting) as a day trip (cost about $100 with good English speaking guide chuomcheak@ymail.com and driver in air conditioned car).
Small but beautiful temple. This was our first temple, is not as large as the other ones, but is very special in history. Is regarded as the crown of the classical Khmer art.

really nice. very well preserved and really nice. it has undergone a couple of restorations though, so not all areas of it is completely authentic, but the restoration does not touch on the main temple complex. It can get very crowded at times which makes taking pictures a little hard since everyone is here to take beautiful photos. we did not need a guide since we were Hindu and it was easy enough for us to pick up on what the carvings and statues represented. And at times, i even heard a guide or two say the wrong thing about a certain deity, had a good laugh about it! however if you do need a guide you cal always get one from the area, there are all always ready to serve if money if not an issue.

you could spend hours to see all the fine sculptures in details. The beautiful site of Bantey Srei is very attractively organised with nicely presented information and a pleasant little natural path with viewpoints. It is not very big, but you could spend hours to see all the fine sculptures in details....
Impressive Architecture. I like the carvings of the walls, it shows the story of Cambodia. It is quite unique carvings and wishing that it will be preserved in the next century!
Gorgeous. This temple is like a little miniature with intricate carvings. Almost like a small world. Very good visitors centre and information.

elegant and sublimely beautiful. Banteay Srei is one of the oldest temples in the Angkor archeological park, and one of the most elegant and sublimely beautiful. This red sandstone temple was created at a much more human scale than the masterpieces of Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat.

Beautiful and lovely drive out. Worth it, worth it!. Very much worth the journey out, even in a creaking tuk tuk. Such a beautiful temple, so incredibly ornate it was impossible to take it all in. I combined it with a trip to the Kbai Spean, which I went to first, immediately after watching sunrise over Angkor Wat (beautiful and the masses of people was very entertaining). It meant I was one of the first people at the river, which meant for a really nice, quiet, and cooler walk. Nice woman there showed me some carvings which I wouldn't have seen otherwise - yes of course you need to tip her, but she was gracious about it!

The Citadel of Women. We hired a driver to take us the 30Km to this beautiful & peaceful temple. The drive there was interesting through lush countryside & villages, giving one an insight into local life. The temple was full of people although we had left our hotel early but we still enjoyed the wonderfully elaborate carvings on the pink sandstone shrines & lintels. This temple is completely unlike the rest of Angkor, being more delicate, & is well worth the journey.

Citadel of Beauty. Made of pink sandstone, it was one temple not built by king. Built by King Rajendravarman's advisor, Yajnavaraha, There are elaborate carvings and finely detailed gods and goddess. Intricately carved lintels reproduce scene from the Hindu epic, Ramayana.Representations of Shiva; his consort Parvati; the Monkey God,Hanuman; the divine cowherd, Krishna, and the Demon King, Ravana are all beautifully etched.

Really beautiful surreal place.. Set out early in the morning from Siem Reap, by a private taxi. The countryside to Banteay Srei was beautiful, and lush green when I went, and one feels one has travelled into the past as you go to the temple. Amazing 8th and 12th century temple

Detail, fine, beautiful Carving. There were 4 most attractive temples in Angkor: Loluos Group, Angkor Thom, Angkor Wat & Banteay Srei (the smallest of all). The carving were so detail, fine and beautiful that I am sure that the new Khmer generation should have acquired this craftsmanship if no lost.

Put it near the top of your list. Banteay Srei should be close to top of your list of temples to visit. Try to visit in the late afternoon when the setting sun enhances the colour of the pink sandstone.
It's worth the extra kilometre. Less well visited, but do go as it is so well preserved and beautiful. A great introduction to the Angkor temples and you appreciate Angkor Wat even more.

Amazing Little Carvings. Again, on our third day of tour or so. Loved the little details on their carvings. And when the tour guide shares the stories, the carvings somehow turned to be so alive! Living the history once again.
Fascinating. Worth the trip out to this telmple , I used a tuk- tuk , maybe better by taxi , but well worth the effort , highly recommended

Different kind of stones. Visit this temple on our second day here at Angkor complex, and here is it not so crowed as it is a little bit away from the complex. They carving here on this temple is very beautiful

Not to be missed. A little further away from Siem Riep than the other main temple sites, it is worth the journey, especially if you have more than one day of touring planned. If you have only a single day, I would still strongly consider going as well. Not only will you see the best carving in the whole area, the trip will let you see the countryside. Passing through the rice growing villages is its own experience.

Ever best carvings. when you are visiting Angkor in Siem Reap, one of those temples is Banteay Srei.even if it is away from Siem Reap about 37km but it is the one you must see it.I fall in love with its sculptures, it's so fine and very details,I can't believe to see it with my eyes. The carvings are small...deep..and detailed and I just know that only this temple built from pink sandstone.Even it is older than Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom.I recommend you have to see this temple.

much better organised. Made from pink sandstone and quite small relative to the mass of Angkor Wat and Angkot Thom, this temple has quite exquisite carvings wich have stood the test of time and are really very good. The whole site is much better organised and laid out than the bigger temples.

Banteay Srei. Approximately 45 minutes drive from Siem Reap, The oldest temple of Khmer Era, built in early 800 A.D. I am very sure that trip of Cambodia is definitely incomplete without visiting this temple. Temple is dedicated to lord Shiva, who is supposed to be a god of destruction. If he opens 3rd eye he is having an ability to fire and destroy whole world. The temple is built in pink stone and carved with stories of Ramayana including Ram-Rawana war, a war between Wali & Sugreev [monkey headed soldiers of Rama]. An excellent work of ancient times. A must watch site.
Awesome. Worth the trip! Take your time and see it slowly. Nothing like it anywhwere in the world. Truly Amazing!

Simply beautiful. My favorite temple by far. We ended up getting there VERY early in the morning and were alone for almost an hour before anyone else showed up. The carvings were just beautiful and soooo intricate. It looks like they were just done yesterday. And I loved the smaller scale and the redness of the stone. Stunning.

best detail. made by women and it proves that they are best in detail
like - detail
not like - sellers at entrance

Good, but a long way out. Tis temple is a bit smaller than many of them and is 38km from town. The journey there is as good as the temple as you get such a good look at rural Cambodian life. Our visit was not well timed as there was a huge amount of Chinese tourists, all stopping to have their photos taken at every gate and vantage point, which held up everyone else.

Red stone work with intricate carvings. The red stone work apparently comes from the Khorat plateau in Thailand. It's the same colored stone work that one can see at the Preah Vihear site. Banteay Srey is small compared with the other sites but no less interesting. Intricate murals and stone carving.

The Lady Statue. A very small temple but with great carvings. Was not aware of the lady statue at first, as I thought it was supposed to be a big statue. I just never do any reading before I visit Siem Reap.

batnteay srei. I can only imagine, if the temple is still intact from the beginning of creation until now, probably many carvings that can memceritakan complete history of this place, I like it, I suggest to you

Small beautiful temple. Banteay Srei is known or could be translated as the "Citadel of the Women". Why women? Because in the Khmer they believed that the women work will have the best result and the carvings at Banteay Srei are exquisite that made them assume that the women are making the carvings, but this is not really true. Banteay Srei is also known because of it's pink color stone which comes from the local stone available there, just as you can see the road path has the same color as the stones to build the temple.The carvings here are exquisite, it's like every inch where they intended to carve no area is bare. There are also inscription carved in the pillars in Sanskrit (letter used in Hindu time here before Pali being used as a sign of Buddhist time) here and there are warnings not to touch the carvings to preserve it.At the time when Cambodia was still in turmoil and the Khmer Rouge still exist, Banteay Srei was filled with landmines and there were crossfire happened here, you can still see some of the bullet holes causing some damage on the ruins and the carvings. But rest assured said our guide that they have cleared the landmines here now and I do believe him (but personally I won't stray away from the usual path).Still being in the APP complex, we don't have to pay extra fee to enter this temple, just make sure you have your AAP pass with you to show the ticket checker.

Banteay Srei is a must see when you visit Siem Reap. Banteay Srei is a must see when you visit Siem Reap. It is small, beautiful and surely a unique temple. The workmanship in the intricate carvings is a wonder to behold. Don’t miss it.

pink as Preety. The amazing red color giving the temple its looks. The perfect temple for it size, carving and long entry walk. The temple is also known as 'city of Women'. The sculpture and carving is amazing. The details are preserved very nicely. The entrances have devi's carving (female godess) with elephants, flowers etc surronded to give a female touch. Inside the complex, more temples and more nice carving you will see. We were in May'13 and was 40 degree C or 100 F was the temperature. We sat under a tree and we saw some musicians paying their instrument. We sat, listen the music for few minutes, had a drink of water and got energized. At the end of the building, they have little history museum also.

Much smaller. The temple is a very small red sandstone complex. It is renowned for its excellent carved decorations that show a great level of detail. Everything is at one level - you only need to step a few times over some sills.

It's a small temple but a beautiful one.. The cravings on the wall of this temple is practically a 'must-see'. Cravings here a well preserved and it is wrong to touch it. Be careful when entering the gate of the temple. Knocked my head on it and guess what? The blocks are seriously hard.

Far but worth the trip!. Compared to Angkor Wat this site is very small. It is the carvings, bas-reliefs and sculptures that makes the trip worthwhile. It includes a Devata who is presented by the local guides as the "Mona Lisa of the East". Unlike many other temples, this one has a set of display panels that covers the history of the Angkor temples. It is by the restaurant and shop area. Do not miss it.Practical tips: 1. Consider tuk-tuk. Most visitors come by cars or vans because of the distance. We did it by tuk-tuk and that gave us a much better feel of the countryside.2. Do not miss the Landmine museum. It is on the way.3. Leave Siem Reap by 0830 or 0800 so you can go to Kbal Spean (River of 1000 lingas) which is only 15Km further.

See the temple, eat the Toddy syrup. This is such a beautiful temple, the delicate pink carvings, the size of the complex, everything was perfect. I'm reading a lot about large groups, overcrowding, etc. we visited in May, when temperatures hovered around 100F or 40 C and guess what, not crowded. So that's one way to avoid the crowds, if you can take the heat. I don't see anyone writing about the lovely ride through the countryside.and it is a long ride. Make the time to stop and watch the villagers making Toddy Palm syrup. OMG, I love this stuff sooo much. The Toddy Palm syrup is made much the way maple syrup is made, the tree is tapped, then they cook it down, in a wok over an open fire while it gets thicker and thicker, to a thick honey consistency. The last stage is pouring it into little tiny bamboo circles where it firms up and becomes a candy, just like maple sugar candy. The syrup is heavy to pack and bring back,and although I bought 3kilos, I now wish I'd emptied my suitcase of clothes and filed it with this syrup. Some places even sell the toddy fruit, refreshing and interesting. There are also some villages devoted to Rattan. And the temple is wonderful.

Mind Blowing. This is the best the temple to see, first because it is made of pink stone so it has a reddish hue when the sun hits it. Photos taken from this temple is very nice. Second for the carvings itself it so intricate.
Small but Special. This Wat is a ways out of the way but is definitely worth seeing if you have the time. The stone is a reddish color and has the most intricate carvings of all the Wats.

Must See. A little different from the main Angkor Wat area temples. Loved the intricate carvings, and colours. Very glad we did the extra travel to see it. (Also see the land mine museum on way back to Siem Reap)

Lucky enough. I was just on a 4days backpacking trip while my buddy has more time than me, we bought a 3day tour at the temples it was my second day when I visited this temple I got what expected to see. Must see one.. I'm lucky enough was able to come over and see the temple where I only admire on pictures.

true craftmanship. come on peeps stop moaning about the ride out there, I have been several times n will go lots more ime sure. this is Cambodia not the ritz. I enjoy the ride out there, ime sure tuk tuk diver gets fed up of me stopping him ever five mins for photo. a big shout out to mr tuk tuk. ho horn.I would rather go to see bantaey srei than look at gloomy London any day. yes its smaller than the other temples the carvings are as many have said before me amazing, wish we still had craftsmen that can do this kind of work. def worth the ride.

Intricate carvings in red stone. This temple is quite a ways away from Siem Reap. We went by tuk-tuk which is a bit of a stretch. By the time you get back, you are a bit shook up and tired of tuk-tuks! The temple itself is very impressive. The carvings are exquisite and much more intricate than the other temples. Tie this temple in with a visit to Kbal Spean, the Butterfly Centre at Banteay Srei or the Landmine Museum.

Beautiful and delicate. Banteay Srei is about a 20 minute drive from the other Angkor complexes and while it is certainly worth the drive, I was left a bit underwhelmed by my visit. I couldn't say why because it has a delicateness about it that the other temples of Angkor don't have. Great back story too (built for the 200+ concubines to pray in) and some of the bas relief carvings look like they were carved just yesterday (no, they weren't reconstructions. They were restored original carvings). Visit Banteay Srei and make up your own minds
Need to see. One of the must see temples when you visit Siem ReapThe only red temple in the area(made of red sandstone). Red you say? Yes, go and see this in addition of the others.
nice. worth the drive to see this temple , an interesting drive , took some great pics and had lunch there , not so delicious but a nice setting

Pink Sandstone and incredible carving.. Our awesome tour guide took us here during our two day tour of Angkor. The incredible detail and pink sandstone are hard to describe because there aren't enough words to describe its beauty. Lets just say that if you live intricate and decorative details on stone, this cannot be missed.
One of the most beautiful temples!. Simply breath taking! It is so beautiful and so well preserved! Made a great afternoon walk:-) A must see as it is unique in colour and so ornate!

Different Color. Once it was built in different stone the city color is different from others of the archaeological site and the coolest thing is once this kind of stone is harder the details and sculptures are standing.Worthy the visit once is a little bit far from Siem Reap (35 km).

Very small compared to other temples!. This temple is very small compared to other temples, but has its own charms. Especially if you wish to see carvings that are hundreds of years old but look like they were done yesterday. Beautiful and quiet if you pick the right time of day. But if you go when the tourists are out and about, getting a photograph that doesn't include tourists will take a bit of skill. Well worth a visit though!

This is the lady Temple. The color of the temple is majority in pink. But people are crowded at the entrance taking pictures. Its just a 1 way road, you need to turn around to get bat to the entrance and retake your picture.

Best Carvings of all Temples-Bit of a Drive. Banteay Srei was my wife and I's favorite temple within the Angkor complex. We took a tuk tuk from Siem Reap and it was about a 45 min trip to get there, a bit far on tuk tuk but we enjoyed the long ride and nice breeze along the way. This temple is smaller but has the best carvings and most color of any temple we visited. After arriving, you can probably feel satisfied with your trip after about 30-45 mins. Visit this temple first during the day and on the way back you can stop at Cambodia Landmine Museum (incredibly eye opening!), Banteay Samre, Pre Rup, and Ta Phrom easily which were all really great locations as well. This was our second day of tours and we enjoyed it immensly. Tuk Tuk from downtown Siem Reap was $25 for the day,not bad really. Prob $40 for a cab at least.

Wonderful temple. This is my favourite temple of them all. What it lacks in size, it makes up for in beauty. The carvings are so different from the other temples, and the colour of the stone is too. Lovely, a bit further away from the other temples but worth the visit.

Not worth visiting. This temple looked attractive on paper as it promised wonderful carvings on pink sandstone etc.So we decided to make the long trip from Siem Reap to see this site and the more distant Kbal Spean. To say it was disappointing is an understatement and I would recommend not wasting time to visit this temple especially as there are so many better sights closer to Siem Reap.

Intricate carvings. The drive from Siem Reap to this temple, provides an opportunity to see the outskirts of Siem Reap and the rural areas. This temple is small but has very intricate cravings (see photos). We enjoyed our visit and also enjoyed the views during the drive in an air-conditioned car (with a tour guide and separate driver).
One of the well-maintained temple. Comparing to others, this is one of the well-maintained temple and surrounded by small lakes. you still can see the door panel with the carvings clearly.
By far the best temple that I visited.. This temple is approximately 30km out of Siem Reap, but well worth the visit. Amazing carvings and stone work.
city of women. city of women, or some called itu pinky temple.worth to see for a while to see different kind of temple besides angkor wat.if you have spare time about 2 - 3hour, can go there...

Best temple by far. This temple should not be missed. We enjoyed it far more than another. The carvings are fabulous. We spent more time here than at any other temple. It is away from the other temples and crowds were not heavy. We had plenty of time for photographs.

Stunning!. It's a bit of a drive from the 'main' temples, but it is SO worth it!! The intricate, detailed carvings that adorn it is something you really do not want to miss! So intricate that it is apprently known as a 'Lady Temple,'since people have said that no man can pay so much attention to detail!And, it is the only temple built of PINK sandstone, while Angkor Wat, Bayon Temple etc. are built from gray sandstone. The contrast of colors due to the moss as a result of the heavy rainfall was also quite interesting. None of the temples had carvings as detailed as this one. I highly recommend that every one go see this gem!

A worthwhile dusty drive. It was a hot dusty drive out to Banteay srei but it was worth it. Make sure you go right out to the back and take your photo throughout the gap in the surrounding wall, the reflection on the water and the angle means you can capture the whole thing.

Beautiful small temple.. Half an hour car ride from Angkor Wat, this is also another temple not to be missed! However, it's kind of a disappointment since the colour of the temple which is supposed to be pink, turned into somewhat wooden-brown colour because of the deforestation that happened there.

Beautiful carving at sunrise. This temple is quite far from the center but I liked it better than Angkor Wat -- simply because it has retained all the beautiful carving from centuries ago.Tip: Visit either at sunrise or sunset when there are less people. It also pays to visit the National Museum first so that you get an idea of who and what the carvings are.

Pink temple. There is exquisite decorative carving in pink sandstone, and the miniature proportions are a major highlight of Banteay Srei. Banteay Srei means “Citadel of the Women”. This temple is not so big. A lot of souvenir shop and restaurant outside the temple.
Amazing Architectural designs. This is an amazing places, the ruins of the temple is admirable. You should not miss this place. Be sure to bring umbrella as protection for the heat of the sun.

Second favourite after Beng Melea. This is a lot smaller than some of the other temple complexes but makes up for it with the amazing intricacies of the carving. The work seems beyond human capabilities sometimes and is a must see.

Little far but worth a visit. It's a temple complex dedicated to Shiva. The carvings are beautiful and the complex is well maintained with dining and other facilities. It's a little far from the main Angkor complex, perhaps about 40 km, but is worth a visit. We went there by tuk-tuk in the morning and the journey was enjoyable too. It also gives a little break from the otherwise very tiring visits around innumerable temples around the Angkor complex.

Worth it. This temple was well worth the trip. I tagged this on to the 'Grand Circuit' and because I'd started at sunrise the site was pretty quiet when I was there (about 10am). As I was leaving the tour buses were starting to arrive!

Exquisite little temple. An hour out of Siem Reap is this unique little temple carved from pink stone. It was my favourite temple outside the amazing Angkor Wat itself. The craftsmanship is, as mentioned elsewhere, a real pinnacle in the art of Khmer stone carving. Later temples are enormous in size in comparison but carve with a broad brush and nothing like the delicacy of detail. The women dancers looked to be genuine village girls each with individual stance and a real sense of movement in their bodies. The setting is lovely, we caught the most gorgeous sunset shots across the fields, and the opportunity to see the countryside on the trip out was another bonus. Consider calling in to see the Golden Silk Farm on the trip out. You need to arrange your visit there by appointment but it is well worth it.

No ticket, no temple. I couldn't see this temple, a very stupid ticketing system didn't allow me to visit. This place is 40 kms north of Siem Reap and I was travelling from north to south. The guards wanted me to drive 40+40 kms to buy the ticket in Siem Reap where the only ticket desk is located. Absolutely idiotic!

The Pinnacle of Khmer Stonecarving. This 10th century temple takes around 1 hour by tuk-tuk to reach, from Siem Reap. You will be rewarded with a very pleasant drive through the countryside as well as seeing one of the most stunning temples in Cambodia. This relatively small pink-stone temple is in a lovely setting but what makes it so remarkable is the exquisite stone carving covering almost every surface. Some of the carving is so fine it almost looks like lace! You will not see finer stone craftsmanship anywhere else (perhaps in the world). This temple was not commissioned by a King but a Brahmin. The name has been translated as 'citadel of women' perhaps referring to its size and delicacy of decortion. It is well worth the time to visit this temple. On the way back it is also worth popping in to Banteay Samre.
Amazing!. So worth the trip out of town to see this very special compound. It is nothing like the temples in Angkor Thom, Angkor Wat, Bayon or Ta Prohm. If you have the time, make the effort.

Most Beautiful Temple...a must-see!. We saw this temple in the pouring rain but we found it the most beautiful of all the temples with its red stone and intricate carvings...don't miss this one! It is on the way to Kbal Spean and ACCB.

A most delicately carved pink temple. A Hindu temple dedicated to Shiva, cut from a pinkish stone - hence often called the pink temple - It is the smallest site at Angkor but the quality of the fine 3D carving makes up for that.Built in 967 and 32 km from Siem Reap - about 45 mins - well worthwhile. Unusually for the Angkor area it was commissioned by a brahman not a king.Entrance is included in the Angkor Wat day ticket. The site is well laid out with very modern facilities (shops, café, toilets etc) and decent car park - all away from the temple so providing the best of both worlds. A guide is not necessary but having read a decent guide book before would be an advantage. Get there before the crowds - two of us saw the sun rise at Angkor Wat then came up here directly afterwards and it was deserted, when we left at 09:00 the visitors were building up.

An Exquisitely Beautiful Temple - Not to be Missed. Banteay Srei is some distance from the main cluster of temples in the Angkor area, but it is well worth a visit. If possible, combine it with a visit to Kbal Spean, which is a little bit further in the same direction.The temple is distinguished by its small, intimate scale and exquisite carvings - and also by its beautiful location. You should walk around the outside, away from the crowds, to enjoy views of the temple against the background of trees.The temple can be overwhelmed by tour groups, which tend to arrive by the busload. But there are also long stretches of time (between buses) when it is almost deserted. So don't be deterred if you meet a crowd - withdraw to the pleasant cafe* and bide your time till the crowds disappear.Tip* There is a poorly-signposted but very good cafe with an excellent exhibition about temple construction. To get there: Walk from the parking area in the direction of the temple (ignoring the mass of gift stalls, the toilets, and the food places on the way). You come to a junction in the path, which goes left towards the temple. From here you can see the cafe/exhibition area a couple of hundred metres away on the right. The cafe is a little haven of peace. The coffee is magnificent. The exhibition is very well presented. And when the crowds are gone you can have Banteay Srei temple all to yourself.

Enjoy the mythical stories. A temple tour guide is a must, he pour out all the stories that were carved into the stone, he can also explain to you the material and decaying of the stone, this place got the best well kept fine detailed carvings.

Small and far away from Ankor. We ment to go to a different temple, but I told the TukTuk driver the name of this one. He did not object and so we went. Only after over half an hour drive I thought something is wrong. Nevertheless we were there and its a very beautiful little temple with a big visitors center (best coffee there I had in Cambodia). Make sure you have the time to go there and back.
Well worth the trip. This is a very small pre-Angkor temple but very different from all the others because of its exquisite carvings and stone color.
Red Sand. The very first thing I notice is the very red sand. The temple has nice carvings.travel time to Banteay Srei from the Angkor temple proper is around an hour with a tuktuk.

What a Beautiful Surprise!. This temple is some distance from Angkor Wat. It is some 200 years older than AW, it is smaller and built of pink sandstone giving it a very interesting color. The carving on the temple is much deeper, clearer and it's beauty easily appreciated. I really liked this very special and unique temple.
Fabulous!. Gorgeous temple. It can take 1 hour or 3... We took 3 just marvelling at the fine sculpture and taking photos. A must...

lovely carvings. This temple was built in 10th century by the Brahman spiritual teacher of king Jayavarman V. Its a Shiva temple. It's built mostly out of pink sandstone. It's got some lovely carvings. It's worth a visit.

Crowded. It's very nice carving...the best we saw in Angkor temples. But it's so crowded and hard to look in details or take good pics even it's not high season. We took tuk tuk there and quite nice breeze on the way. Don't have to take cars, not very long journey.

Well worth the trip. This temle is a little further out than the other temples.
Well worth the visit if you have time, extremely beautiful temple, but small!
Except for the crowds. I think we simply visited this beautiful temple at the wrong time; overrun by rude Koreans! It was better to view it from behind the first wall with reflections in the moat.

In one word...."Exquisite". Quite a long way out of Siem Reap, but well worth the journey. The carving here is quite unbelievable. Although large parts of the temple are roped off to prevent visitors climbing over everything, there are many examples of the beautiful craftsmanship on almost every surface. Some of the statues are copies (you can see the originals in the National Museum in Phnom Penh). We were there at about 2pm, so it was (relatively) quiet - but very hot! There are a few stalls to buy food and drinks but visitors are regarded as a lucrative source of income and the prices are extortionate. Due to the sheer heat of the day and the amount of water we got through (which, thankfully, we brought with us), something containing plenty of salt was also required. Not the finest by any means, but certainly the most expensive 2 packets of crisps I have ever purchased!

Braving the Summer Heat at Banteay Srei!. The temple's location is a bit far from the Angkor Wat Complex. It was the hottest time of the day for a temple visit but since I really liked to see Banteay Srei, which is known as "citadel of women," I braved the summer heat just to see the most beautiful, deep and intricate carvings of the temple. it is of small size and made of pink sandstones, which sets it apart from all the other temples.
Worth the drive. Banteay Srei is a good distance from Siem Reap, but sets itself apart from the other ruins. It is more interesting, as is its history.
Unique. First day viewing, small but nice, hard to recall all the temples I saw in 3-days. I liked Angkor Thom the best.

Intricately Beautiful. Despite Banteay Srei's small size compared to Angkor Wat, it is intricately beautiful. It is made of reddish sandstone carved so carefully, intricately, beautifully.This temple dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva is quite an attractive site. Remember to bring plenty of water to drink whenever visiting any of the wats/temples.

Remote nice temple with well preserve carvings, but not essential visit. Banteay Srei is a nice temple. It is the smallest we've seen but also the one with the nicest and most preserved carvings. The temple is made of red stones, so it's a bit different from the other temples and there are probably beautiful colours when the sun light it in the early morning and late afternoon (it was cloudy when we went there unfortunately). It's quite small and if you want to be able to observe quietly the carvings, you'd better be there before 8 am. We arrived at 7.50am; at 8.15am there was a first group, by 9am when we left, the car park was packed with buses.It takes 1 hour to go there by tuk tuk and $25. The temple is nice and if you have time, why not go there. You can probably combine it with other remote temples, waterfalls or local village visits or include it in your tuk tuk day trip, which is what we did. If you don't have much time, it's not a big deal if you miss it.
Just love it!. Small but its so pretty. One of my fav place. The details of carving is just amazing! Is a must to visit
A gem. Although much smaller this is really perhaps the most accessible and intricate of all the temples we've seen. We loved it.

Temples of pink sandstone. A small but very beautiful temple complex. The carvings in the buildings are very detailed and amazing how intricate. The temple was built as a tribute to the beauty of women.

Small temple gets real crowded. This is a pretty small temple but beautiful indeed. Due to its small size it gets crowded real fast. A couple of group tours will fill it up.
The temple is a bit far from the others but well worth the extra ride.

must see. Unfortunately it is dry season, so the temples didn't have the usual water we see on pictures. Nevertheless, we still enjoy the scenery. like i mentioned in my other reviews, all of these temples gave me a feeling of solemnity and serenity. It gives me time to reflect on things. Walking through each of them is an inner journey despite the number of tourist who come each day. It is indeed a precious gem...But again, please bring water with u...its a must...

Beautiful. Banteay Srei is definitely worth a visit. The colour, the carvings, the history all combine to make this a beautiful temple. It's a long drive out, but it makes a good change from the other temples.

Pretty. Small. Overcrowded. Great music from land mine victims.. This pink-stoned "Citadel of Women" is gorgeous, if you can find a few moments between the waves of teenage tourists to absorb what you are seeing. The statuary, the little courts, the carvings, the series of doors and gateways, the little carved details everywhere will amaze and delight you. But, as I am very musically oriented, the most charming part was viewing this while hearing the strains of traditional Cambodian music, so gentle and danceable. Upon exiting the temple, I discovered where the music was coming from: a band of land-mine victims playing beautifully despite their deformities (not all visible, and not so disturbing as to detract from the pleasure of their music.) I had to be dragged away from their area by my trip leader, but not before spending $10 for a CD of their music - one of my favorite souvenirs from my trip.

A Truly Lovely Place. This place is just beautiful. Crowded but delightful. Take your time and also hang out afterwards to listen the wonderful sound of Khmer Traditional Music performed by the handicap of Banteay Srey and buy their CD for $10 and help support them.

One of the nicer temples i've visited. I think the red temple is in my top 3 of SR's temples. It's a welcome change to see a different colour of stone being used. There's also great detail in most of the stone carvings. Though it's quite a drive away from the big guns like angkor and Ta Phrom I think it's really worth the drive. Especially if most of the other temples don't quite attract your attention anymore after seeing Angkor Wat.

Get a cart and see the exhibition centre. Initially I got here and thought, big deal - especially for the long drive.But it is a lovely little temple with really ornate carvings.the best part is that they had an exhibition centre, something needed at some of the others. it ws very informative on how they move the stones, rebuilding etc - it answered our question as to whether or not the steel reinforcements we were seeing was modern or old.I do nto recommend bouncing in a tuk tuk all the way - and i would highly recommend including the landmine Museum which you pass on the road to it and turn off to Banteay Samre is also worth it whislt out that way - beautiful in the afternoon

Small But Stunning - Must See. Finally after 4 visits to Siem Reap I made it to this Temple. Compared to a lot of the temples that you visit, this one seemed to me to be in Very Good Condition. Which was great to see. A beautiful mote/ponds surround the area where the temple lies which allows a great resting area from the heat or if you just need to take a rest. Great photo opportunities and quieter if you head out during the busier times traditional at Angkor Wat etc.

Worth the time and extra cost. We initially were not keen to visit the temple due to the additional cost which had to be incurred for the transport. However, after some urging and brief descriptions by the tour guide, we decided to go ahead, and we did not, for a second, regret it.The Bantaey Srei temple is alot smaller compared to Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and other more popular temples. However, what it lacks in size, it more then makes up in its carving complexity. The carvings were extremely detailed and very well preserved. What i enjoyed the most was the colours. Naturally coloured sandstone was used to build this temple and the pink and yellow sandstone were a joy to photograph.We went in the early afternoon (2pm) and the crowd was manageable. Highly recommended as it is distinctly different from all the other temples.

Well worth the visit. Although a bit out, it is still worth a visit much smaller and compact than the others but lovely non the less and a nice drive out through the countryside seeing how the locals live suggest very early morning before the tour busses arrive we got there about 7.20 and only a few people there by the time we left there were hoards arriving.

Worth the extra effort.... We umm-ed and ah-ed about whether to bother heading out to this outlying temple, but we had a spare day and we had heard good things so we made the effort. And boy was it worth it. It was my favourite of all the temples we had seen, whilst quite small, it's just beautifully sculpted and detailed and the pink colour of the stone is stunning. On a sunny day it was just the most wonderful place to be. Definitely worth the extra trip!

Very crowded with tour groups. An interesting site which was good to see before seeing the larger temple complexes of Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat. we went in the afternoon and it was very crowded with tour groups. maybe much earlier int he day would be quieter. Look out for the traditional music played by a band of landmine victims and think about buying one of their cds rather than just donating.

Ancient red wonder. This temple features red-hue stones that give an almost brick-like appearance to the temple. The intricate carvings are really well preserved, more-so than other temples. It wasn't too full of tourists, so my friends and I were able to capture many great photos here!

Worth a trip if there for a few days.. This temple is quite far out of the way. One of the best reasons I found for visiting was the journey itself. The tuk tuk ride will take you through very rural areas north of Siem Reap town. You will pass by houses, villages, roadside shops and stands, and none of it for tourists. All of it is real daily Cambodian life. The trip was part of the experience for me. Don't get me wrong the temple is beautiful, and of all the areas on the Angkor park it is the most visitor friendly. It has a cafe, visitor centre and information area like an outdoor museum on how the temple was built and restored.

Pink Temple. The walls are covered with some of the most beautiful, deep and intricate carvings of any Angkor temple. The temple's quite small , pink sandstone and very ornate. The colors are best before 10:30 AM and after 2:00 PM, but there were fewer tourists in the afternoon when I visited

What a surprise!. What a pleasant surprise Banteay Srei was and well worth the trip out through villages where we could see life in Cambodia. The red stone is so different to the other Temples that we had visited and the intricate carvings were breathtaking. I got some great photos here, a play of light and colour. A must and be prepared to be blown away.

The Citadel of Women. This site is the farthest from Siem Reap about 32 km. It is well worth the visit to see the pink sandstone temple as well as the people at work in the surrounding countryside. The temple is known for its beautiful and intricate carvings adorning the entire structure. It is unique in the fact the women are venerated for a change as this is a part of the world that is decidedly patriarchal!

Worth the trip out to this temple. Again, go early. We took a car which was took around 45 minutes. We didn't have a guide but again were mesmorised but the carvings and detail of this temple. The kids loved exploring and climbing around the ruins.

Nice reliefs. The reliefs at this temple are pretty well conserved. So that you can observe the magnificence of the work done hundreds of years ago. Although you cannot have a closest look to the middle of the temple were the pink statues are located it is still very nice

Beautiful but very busy in the mornings!. Banteay Srey is a 10th century Temple that is dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva; the name loosely translates to Citadel of the Women so it is often called the Women’s Temple. This is only a recent title and it is thought to be due to the delicate carvings. The colors of the pink sandstone here are beautiful and this Temple has some of the finest examples of Khmer classical art. Here you will find walls covered with deep intricate carvings, more so than any other Ankorian Temple.  Banteay Srey was discovered by French archaeologists’ late in 1914.Visiting here in the morning is very popular, so much so we really did not enjoy looking around as there were busloads of tourists everywhere pushing and shoving past. After 2pm is apparently better due to fewer tourists.Banteay Srey is about a 40 kilometer drive from Siem Reap, so combine a visit with Banteay Samre.

Quiet temple. Less astonishing than the other temples maybe, but it had somehing that made me want to sit down in one of the courtyards and read a book for a while, and then have some nice conversation with some locals working there

Must see. If Angkor Wat is the top attraction, and Bayon temple the runner up, then Banteay Srei must certainly be in the top 3. Yet because it is some distance away from Siemreap, it gets fewer visitors than it deserves, which is a real bonus. It has been beautifully restored, and the carvings are amazingly well preserved. Although much smaller than the others in the top 3, it is arguably the most beautiful of all the Angkorian temples. Truly not to be missed.
An amazing architechtual. This was the 1st temple that we visited on 24/3/2013. Facinated with the architechtual during the 10th century.

Well worth the visit. My family, including a 10- and 12-year old absolutely loved visiting the temples in Siem Reap, and this was one of our favourites. It was the last temple we visited, and as such, there was some question as to whether we would visit or spend the morning poolside (we visited at the hottest time of year and were flagging by then!).In the end, we decided to go and were very glad we did. It is the smallest of the temples we visited, but also one of the more interesting. The intricate carvings were amazing.

Nice!. Ensure you spend at least 1.5 to 2 hours here to do justice to the place, the arcitecture, the carvings on the wall and most importantly get a good English speaking guide who can explain everything and the History to you to make the trip memorable, that is, provided you like history.

Beautiful. This was the 4th temple of 6 we visited as part of the Outlying Adventure Tour with Beyond Unique Escapes. Built in the 10th century and dedicated to the Hindu God Shiva. Some wonderful statues and fantastic carved doorways. Beautiful.
