worth the trip. outside Angkor group, the tuktuk trip went through local villages living life so was an engaging journey. This 'women's temple had magnificent carvings & well worth the visit, if you have the time

Intricate carvings. This temple had the most detailed carvings which could be admired from afar and up close. it was the most stunning orange colour in the early-ish morning (7:30) and definitely worth the longer journey see it.

A wonderful surprise. Banteay Srei was by far one of my favorites. It might not have the grandeur of Angkor Wat but it more than makes up for it in charm. The carvings are very detailed and the temple was peaceful, serene and calm. It might be a bit out of the way but it is so worth it. Highly recommended.

Great things come in small packages!. This is one of the smaller temples. It's also known as the ladies temple. It's beautifully and intricately carved, very feminine and lady like looking. And it's reddish in colour. Totally worth seeing. It's a bit more far off than the main temples but worth the tuc tuc or car drive.
Don't miss it.

A true gem. This is a little "ground floor" temple but the most beautiful of all. The walls are covered with some of the most intricate carvings of any temple. Delicate beauty of the carvings are breathtaking. Pink sandstone construction give it an extraordinary beauty. The colors are best in the morning and before sunset.

Women's temple is worth the visit. Slightly (and I mean very slightly) less visited temple about an hour from Angkor, this site has a very different feel and honors women. Well worth the trip. Also on the way back you can visit the Cambodian Land Mine Removal museum -- very inspiring!

Older than Angkor Wat. This temple takes about an hour from Siem Riep city by tuk-tuk and it cost USD30. Worth the trip. It offer different view than Angkor Wat temples. Different style and carvings. Combine the trip to visit Lolei and Bakong.

Beautiful temple. We got here early in the morning leaving our hotel with our guide at 6:30am. This way we avoided the heat and most of the tourists. (Also starting early left us time in the heat of the the day to cool off in the hotel pool before heading out again.) There were not many people around while we were there and the morning light made the temple carvings more beautiful. Australian, Italian, German Japanese and French UNESCO are helping to restore to the temple and put broken pieces back place.There is a good photo spot from behind the moat at the back of the temple.Well worth a visit even though it is a bit further out of town. We combined it with Banteay Samre and Kbal Spean that morning.

Wonderful Decoration!. Banteay Srei is the only temple in angkor, not built by a king but by a counselor of the king Rajendravarman. This is a beautiful temple built of sandstone, decorated with every detail and is dedicated to Lord shiva. It has very intricate carvings in all of its pediments and gopuras. This is one of the most beautiful temples and truly praised as 'jewel of Khmer art'! Combine the visit with Pre rup and Kblan spean.

Amongst the most ornate temples. Even though Banteay Srei is a good 45 minutes ride from Angkor Wat by Tuktuk, everyone should make the effort to go and see it. Architecturally, it is very different from Angkor Wat or Ta Prohm or any of the other temples closer to Siem Reap town.A ruin just like all other temples in the area, Banteay Srei is exquisitely carved and is very ornate. The red stone looks fabulous in the setting sun, with the light gleaming of its intricate carvings. It remains crowded most of the time, what with tour buses having this place as a fixture on their itineraries. However, don't let the crowds or the distance dissuade you. And on the way stop at the road-side shops to taste some wonderful palm-sugar jaggery - maybe buy some.Another must see place on the Siem Reap trail.

great temple. if you ask me, this is the most beautiful and well preserved temple of all the Angkor temples.unfortunately,the constant harassment from the sellers and beggers makes the temple and Cambodia experience very tireing.
Well laid out. Check out the map at the entrance to get oriented. More of the temple was in ruins than some of the other temples; interesting to note how the some of the stones have been reassembled.

Absolutely Stunning!!!. Temple is in peaceful, isolated, semi - wooded setting and has exquisite decorative carving in pink sandstone in minature proportions. Extraordinary concentration of mythological narratives in pediments and lintels. A temple of great beauty, and compares with little else in Angkor. Minature scale of carvings is a surprise when you visit, and the near-total decoration of its surfaces is exceptional.

A Carved Wonder. This temple, like many others, is built of a brownish-red stone. What makes it unique, to me, is the close-up view one can get of its exquisite carvings. We walked around through the temple area and could see walls and towers having these wonderfully-intricate carvings. It's a bit northeast of the main Angkor temple complex, but well worth the time to get there.
Don't miss the stone crafting. very beautiful and elaborative crafting with minimal weathering. Very worth visiting, though a bit far from Angkor Wat.
nice small temple. A nice small temple, but too many tourist. Too many unrespectfull Korean people.If you go there try to go on afternoon should be less people

Smal, but beautiful. Very small temple, but it has so much to offer. it has a lot of beautiful carvings. Very different than the other temples around here. Definitely worth a visit. Rent a tuktuk and go... Can be combined with a visit to Kbal Spean. A tuktuk from Siem Reap costed us 30$.

The most beautiful temple. I found that Banteay Srei was the most beautiful Khmer temple with the most delicate and detailed carving. Not as large as Angkor Wat or Bayon and further from Siem Reap. But it is worth the trip!

Brilliant. Great to see a mostly unrestored temple.Fascinating the way the jungle is reclaiming the land and astonishing the way the trees are combining with the buildnings they are growing through into weird shapes.

The Temple of Lady. It was what been told by my tour guide. The wall has been built with red stone. It's beautiful & amazing. We have been walking around the temple in order to get a best shot. Give it a try!

Not like before, but not at all dissapointing.. I first was here with my parents in 2002 and you could walk all around the temple because there were no ropes or walkways to guide you. It's different now but still holds a special place in my heart. They said that only the hand of a woman can make such ornate, intricate carvings. I am especially attached to the stone guards in the center. Its blocked off now but i have a picture standing next to it from years ago. I would say, GO NOW. before it gets to become a destination of dissapointments because of other people. It's hard to appreciate what's around you when all you smell is body odor. So go with the assumption of bumping into a few people. I promise this temple, because of the carvings, is one not to miss. Get a tour guide because its not fun seeing such beautiful temples without any sort of explanation of what you're looking at. On the road to and from there are vendors that look almost alike, one by one and very colorful. They sell Palm sugar and Palm Sugar candy. You can smell them making it as you pass by. Stop by and buy some cambodian candy. They will even show you how they make it. What's a dollar or two?
gorgeous carvings. This small and compact temple is a must see even if it is a further drive. The carvings are ornate, detailed and very beautiful almost ginger bread like.
A birt of a treck from Seam Reap. The temple was worth a visit but requires a fairly lengthy Tuck Tuck ride fro the centre of Seam reapGiven time it is worth a visit

Beautiful carvings in red stone. Unlike many of the temples, this is in red rather than dark grey stone, which makes it colourful. The carvings are in great condition and it is quite small so it is easy to walk round and see everything
high quality sandstone rocks!. the best carvings. it's a bit far but if you go by tuk-tuk, you'll get an excellent view of the countryside

One of the 4 must-see temples. This temple is a beautiful coloured one located about half an hour or more out of town (long with a tuk tuk). It is a Hindu temple and has been well reconstructed. It is different to the others around Angkor Wat as it is one level. You can't access the very inside (central shrine) but it makes it easier to photograph as there isn't someone constantly walking into your photos. There are other things to do nearby such as the Animal Conservation Centre (well worth a visit- see reviews) , Kbal Spean (we didn't go there), the Landmine Museum (well worth the visit - see reviews) and the Butterfly Centre (we didn't make it there as it closes at 4pm). We combined our visit with a trip to Phnom Kulen which was great fun (see reviews) and highly recommended. A car is required as tuk tuks can't access it. Must go to the mountain first as cars allowed up until 11.30 then only down after 12pm as the road is narrow.
A must to include. This 10 th century Hindu temple is in remarkable condition with extensive detailed carvings in the red sandstone. Compact site which is full of photo opportunities.

Siva temple with extraordinary carvings. Must see, if you dont mind travelling aprox. 30kms just to see this lone temple made of special pink stone & carvings as if it was on wood. Enroute you can see Pre Rup, Mine museum & a lot of country side scenery, rice fields etc. A ride in Tuk Tuk is somewhat bumpy (depends on the quality of vehicle you get). Try taking a good condition as the road is not so level although completely tarmac. I had to hold my body tight to avoid muscles (or fat) getting seperated from bones...:) There are curio shops, well kept toilets, restaraunts at the entrance. Take a walk among the woody road following the exit sign to see the wonderful scenerey around. There are bird watching points along this stretch. Do not walk back as you came in as everybody does.

Stunning. This small yet gorgeous temple is an absolute must-see. The details are exquisite in every way. Be sure to go there early and beat the crowds as it can easily get a bit claustrophobic. It's definitely worth the long (tuk tuk) drive.
awesome. a little bit further to get to see but well worth the effort , early morning the best time to see this temple

Beautiful Temple. This was the last temple ruin we visited on our trip and it definitely was a good way to end it.The ruin itself was quite small, but the detail is amazing as well as the pink stone that the carvings are made in. Well worth the trip.
One of the many 'must sees'. If you like detailed stone carvings, this is THE temple to visit. Some 30 km from Siem Reap it is not as crowded as Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat. Highly recommended
Go early. This is one of the sites that is a favourite with tours. Best get there early to avoid the jostling and noisy groups that detract from the serenity of the place.

Small and intricately carved. This is a very tiny temple. Most of it is in ruins and there are some remnants of beautiful carvings. It's also different because of the pink sandstone. Too bad that it was not fully restored.

Most delicate carvings within the Angkor Complex. This is a beautiful temple, not as imposing at Angkor Wat or Bayoun but the carvings are very delicate and detailed. Go here in the afternoon since the tour groups seem to congregate in the morning. We went at about 3:30 PM after a visit to Kbal spean and ACCB and had the temple pretty much to ourselves and were able to take many pictures of the carvings without people wanting to be the photo next to the carvings.

A pearl away from the world. The temple is quite far from the complex of Angkor, about 30 km, but well worth the visit. You can choose the mode of transport by which reach, in our case we used a tuktuk. The temple is different from those of the complex of Angkor, for the color, a pink hues vary depending on time of day, and it is the only temple not built by the will of a king, but on the initiative of a rich philanthropist. It was later worshiped Shiva, and, hovering within its walls you can admire sculptures, reliefs and friezes perfectly preserved, that jaw-dropping visitors. Around a pond where water lilies create a wonderful frame to the temple. In my opinion one of the best temples in Siem Reap, where they are still present in all their glory, to protect the sculptures of the temple guards with the face of a monkey or crocodile. Very interesting and well maintained (although a bit too touristy) is the structure built near the entrance to the site, where there is a record of the restoration and a brief history of the temples of Angkor.

Best Temple, GO EARLY!!. Loved this temple best for its small but extravagant carvings! Went at sunrise, got excellent pics and left before the convoy of tourist buses arrived...best of all we visited bar none

Small-scale delight. Here's a temple that is human scale, but still awe-inspiring. It's off the beaten track, but a tuk-tuk will get you there and give you a good sense of the countryside along the way. The red sandstone is magnificent, and so much of the carving is amazing and still intact. Definitely worth the effort!

Delicate. We went there at 16:00 but it still had many visitors who fortunately were leaving at that time.This temple, dedicated to Shiva, is different, costructed from sandstone (red-colored) and very delicately decorated. In this Temple there are also some buildings looking like mausoleums but they were libraries. Don't miss it.!

Banteay Srei. Our Tour Guide, Ok.... explained the details of this temple and I find that the pink/coral-like color of this temple very intriguing. The intricate designs and carvings could only satisfy the visitors' quest for historical interpretation!

Small and unique. This small and somewhat remote temple is utterly unique. The pink sandstone and the intricate carvings are spectacular. Be patient as it can be crowded, leaving little room to move. Early morning is the best time for photography.One tip, if they try to sell you the Angkor guide book ( which is excellent and worth buying ) don't pay more than $5.

Sheer beauty!. Banteay Srei is my second (after Bayon) favourite temple. Each of the temples has something unique, but these delicate carvings and the colour of the rock made my day! You can visit it on the way to The River of 1,000 Lingas, which is also worth visiting.

A beautiful temple, and an beautiful journey!. The carvings all over this pretty little pink temple are truely stunning - so detailed!However, for me the best part of the journey to the temple was the journey itself - you drive through the countryside where all of the fantastically rustic Khmer houses have little stalls out the front selling fresh-picked fruits, freshly made palm suger, etc; and when you stop the local kids (they have half-days of school, so you don't need to worry that you're encouraging kids to drop out) come out to sell you their ultra-cute handicrafts!The road is is good condition, it's nice to have an air-conditioned car as I did, but I think it'd be safe and comfortable enough to go in a tuktuk or even a motorcycle taxi.
A small but fairly decent temple. This temple is not overly large,but worth checking out..30 to 40 minutes is enough.The stone carvings are fairly decent.Part of Angkor ticket price
Small but nice site.. The sandstone used here is pink so very unique. This is a small site and in my opinion not as good as some of the others but worth seeing.

One of my favorites. The detailed stone carving here is amazing. This was one of my top two sites. Get there in the morning. Had some trouble joining up on a tour, (despite the grand tours being advertised everywhere, no agent could find a van that was going the entire week i was there) so I went in a taxi. It takes an hour to get there, so I was glad to not be in a tuk tuk.
Lovely. This temple is located far off from the city central. But it was so worth the travel in a tuktuk!the stone carvings in this small temple were intricately made

Beautiful Temple ------Not to be missed!. Banteay Srei is a jewel of a temple further out from Siem Reap but well worth visiting. It is advisable to come very early as seeing the stunning reliefs here is easier without crowds.The pink sandstone gives a wonderful color to this Khmer temple with its examples of Kymer art.The walls are covered with deep and intricate carvings in very ornate designs.There are not the same number of steep steps involved in seeing this temple .

The hidden jewel of Angkor. Before deciding to go, we heard a lot of people that said that it wasn't worth it because it was way too far, and too small. We finally decided to go, and it was a decision we'll never regret. Banteay Srei can be small, but has incredible detail, and is very different from other places in Angkor. Every single door, window, column is beautifully decorated, and the small pink temples are amazing. Don't miss it!

Not worth the sunset visit. Despite the hundreds waoting for the sunset, we joined them by scrambling up 50 or so very steep and tall stone steps. Not for the faint hearted. However the view from the top could have been anywhere! Not worth the effort!

a beautiful lay out. a beautiful lay out and i felt it was different to the other temples you see, lovely carvings good to have a real look around, fairly large place so you need a good hour min i think. the huge crowds are a let down so just take you time and let them pass so you can actually look and enjoy the site.

Monkeys and Sandstone Oh My!. A bit more isolated than some of the other temples, but still gets crowded. If I remember correctly, this was the only temple that was roped off, where you couldn't actually walk in the courtyard area. The monkeys and reddish orange sandstone color make for some nice pictures. This is a small temple, but has many details to be seen. I walked all around the site as well as around the outer wall and was well worth it.

A temple in pink. The least crowded, the most compact and the most well preserved temple i saw. Don't miss this place. The pink sandstone gives it so much character. When you come home and spot the little pink dust still on your shoes, you will remember how you felt looking at all the detailed reliefs that have been amazingly preserved for centuries. Its pretty special, this feeling :)
worth the extra trip. a place not to be missed while in Siem Reap. Sandstone has unique colors not seen at other temples in the area.
I liked how remote it was. Because it was much further away than Angkor, I got a very nice view of the countryside. And the carvings were very intricate.

Pretty and not too crowded. We stopped here on the way to the place with the lingas.. It was very beautiful and there weren't too many people, compared to the other temples. The tuk tuk ride out is also very peaceful. :)

Another temple to visit. This is also located inside the Angkor Complex . . . near a lake where monks fish and swim :-) Easily neglected by other tourist, but the details are great, if you are a photographer :-D

Most beautiful Hindu temple in Siem Reap. This place does not need any introduction: best preserved, most refined arts displayed here (just look at multiple pictures already posted). Just for a tip, my favorite place to photograph is outside the temple after turning to left side, see picture. Just do not forget, temple pass needed although it is outside Siem Reap and also consider to visit Phnom Kulen National Park/waterfall as part of the trip to B. Seri (which is almost half way out of town)

Beautiful and often crowd-free alterhative to the "Big Three". Although it's quite a drive from town, it is an excellent alternative to Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm and The Bayon, especially in high season or when the others are mobbed! There are alos a number of other great sights nearby too like Banteay Kdei, Pre Rup, Banteay Samre, The butterfly farm and The Landmine museum so it makes a really good day or half day out.When you get to Banteay Srei, there is also a lovely peaceful; walk around a lake if it happens to be crowded.
Exquisite Detail. Between the pink limestone and the intricate and deep carving, this temple was magnificent. Make Banteay Srei a priority on your visit to Angkor.

Angkor magnificence in miniature. Banteay Srei (Citadel of Women) has buildings of the old Khmer style, but on a smaller scale, that does not leave you gasping at the enormity of it. However the intricacy of the construction, and the rugged but delicate appearance (can you use those two words about one thing) is mesmerising, and one can while away large amounts of time here. Banteay Srei is on the "MUST" list.

Unique experience. This lies a longish drive from the main temples at Angkor, but is well worth the journey (I took the opportunity for a bit of a kip on the way there). Fantastically restored 10th century temple with incredible reliefs.

Swiss perfection. I thought this was the best of the Angkor sites; restored by the Swiss, who have done a remarkable job. The surrounds are very pleasant and orderly, including the loo's! It takes a while to get out there, (l hour in our tuk tuk) but you see some lovely countryside on the way. Well worth it.
intricate carvings. Citadel of Women, or Banteay Srei, a red sandstone temple known for its intricate carvings. It is beautiful. And dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva

Fabulous carvings. This temple is a bit far off the beaten track, but has some of the finest carvings that we have seen in Cambodia. Truly lovely. The only problem is the hoards of people viewing the site through their cameras.
Too many people, too many vehicles.... Second visit, and probably the last. It's time to put some controls into place before the powers that be find people stop visiting.

The best of all the wonders of Angkor. Banteay Srei is beautiful, thought provoking and well presented. In many ways this would be the best temple to visit first: there is a helpful interpretative centre, and the scale of the temple enables you to get a really good idea of layout before going to the larger ones. And, of course, the stone is coloured pinkish. But get there as early as you can to avoid the tourist hordes.

The most beautiful temple. Don't leave Angkor without having visited bantey Srei. This small temple built in pink sandstone is arguably the most beautiful temple of Angkor. You could fall in love with it...

Out of the way, but worth the trip. Miniature scale compared to some of the other sites, but more intricate carvings here. The stone has a pinkish hue and much less crowded than other sites as well. Hindu theme.

Wonderful carvings well conserved. Really enjoyed this site, in part because of the obvious efforts to conserve and restore it while doing everything possible to protect the site from damage by tourist hordes. Also enjoyed the small interpretive exhibition building which provided useful insight into the origins and history of the sight.

Amazing carvings, fascinating stories. The intricate carving is just amazing. The stories they told were fascinating. This temple with its pink hued structure was a wonderful site. It would be good to get there early to beat the ‘madding crowds’. We walked from one carving to the other relishing the intricacy of workmanship. This is possibly the only major temple which has been constructed by a nobleman rather than the king himself. The buildings themselves are not as large or as high as most of the other Angkor Temples. Thus walking around the site is far easier than most others. We enjoyed the visit very much
must see. completes the stay in Siem Reap. A bit further a field but worth the trek and a beautiful site. a must see

Small Temple Photo Op. This temple is 25-30 miles outside of Siem Reap, Cambodia and it's worth the ride. It is set on a moat that makes for beautiful pictures of the temple reflected in it. More importantly, the detail in the stone work are magnificent and definitely of interest. The pure beauty of the temple is inspiring. Really enjoyed being here.
Worth the extra distance to explore. Beautiful location and fabulous detailed stone work. Well worth the journey north of Siem Reap. Share a taxi, it is a bit far by Tuk Tuk.

My favorite site. Small enough to be able to appreciate the whole temple complex. Exceptionally fine carvings and the buildings are constructed of lovely pink/orange sandstone. It wasn't quite as crowded as others and as a bonus, we got to see a colorful Cambodian wedding along the way!

Small beautiful temple. This temple is a small beautiful temple that lies about 32km away from Siem Reap city.But the way it arise in the misty morning day made it really beautiful.Try to come here early to see the beauty and to avoid tourists from your sight. It's a small temple, so it can be really annoying to enjoy the temple with a really crowd tourists around you.

Superb!! Worth visit!. visited there early in the morning, it's kind of crowded full with Korean and Chinese tourist. The site is really small, but beautifully made. At the moment the site is restored by the support of Swiss government. Very nicely done! All the craving and sculptures are still clear and remain as its original design. Worth the visit and the travel. The local shop keeper said that usually they got most tourist in the morning. So perhaps an evening visit is better.

Gorgeous detail. Gorgeous temple - lots of details and a beautiful pink colour. We chose to walk around the edge of the temple first while the masses headed inside and we just sat for a while across the moat watching the world go by. There is also a very informative display here of the renovations that took place. Watch out for the kids trying to sell things - very persistant, best to not acknowledge them with a hello if you don't want to be hounded.

Translation - Happy Women Fortress. Life is great if the women are happy, or so the story goes from my tour guide. Couldn't disagree with this logical logic.3000 visitors per day so be patient and take your time.... more to see there than Ankor....IMO.
Beautiful. This temple is just beautiful, the carvings are still quite clear, and colours are amazing, given how old it is. Get a guide and do all main temples and dont miss this out.
Worth the trip. Quiet small temple with beautiful carving - nice change to have a trip into the countryside. You can include a stop at the Land mines museum - it's on the way.

Intricate Carvings in Banteay Srei. Banteay Srei is around 1-2 hours trip by tuktuk but it was definitely worth the trouble. It has the finest carvings in all of the temples I've visited. Despite its small size, it was one of the highlights of my temples tour. Going there gives you a glimpse of how Cambodians are in their daily life.

Very well preserved temples but it so far away!!. I do not know why I visited this place a second time. I have forgotten how far this place is (or how long it takes to get there) by tut tut.It is however a very well preserved temple, abeit small. Its a great place to come if you have the extra time.

Intricate carvings. A fair bit away from the other temples. 1:15 hours (one-way) by tuk-tuk, but totally worth it. Tuk tuk takes $16-18 for the entire trip & the same angkor ticket is valid here as well.
King's swimming pool. Is where the king's swimming pool is located. Bigger than olympic size, all natural. Clean water free from mud. local kids were taking a plunge and ask for USD1 for photos!
Small but beautiful. Banteay Srei is made of red sandstone. The carvings are detailed and it is worth the drive to get there. Appropriately named as citadel of the women, or citadel of beauty.
For 1000 years old, it's in pretty good shape. Because the stone was soft, the cutters cut deep into the stone, allowing preservation over the centuries. Lots of people, but very interesting

The intricacy of the stone work is unique. I had heard that this temple was beautiful and had not expected the evidence of the craftsmanship of the genius Khmer people. It's amazing.. But again, while signs say, 'Don't touch the stone engravings', it seemed to me that everyone .. yes, everyone from the huge crowd of touring tourists ran their hands on the 12th Century inscriptions. Must be managed for its preservation.

Different to the rest, shoul be seen. Made from pink sandstone and quite small relativel to the mass of Angkor Wat and Angkot Thom, this temple has quite exquisite carvings wich have stood the test of time and are really very good. The whole site is much better organised and laid out than the bigger temples. There were information boards, a gift shop, a nice cafe and good toilets.Takes about one hour to stroll around, there is plenty of shade under the trees. as to be expectecit was crowded but are'nt all the temples.It takes about one hour to reach but is a nice ride through the countryside, stop at the stalls making palm sugar and try some of their sweets.The Landmine Museum is about half way.Well worth the visit, your main temple pass covers this site.

Well worth the drive from Siem Reap. The temple was wonderful but I really liked the interpretative center. Whoever was responsible for it put in a lot of time to strike a great balance between the written word and photographs. This was the 3rd temple I had been too and the center answered a lot of questions that I had been having regarding the change in styles between the temples I had seen. The text is only in Khmer and English but even if you don't read either, the photographs displaying the history and differences between Angkor styles are still worth the trip.My fellow travelers had been there many years ago and pointed out that as part of preservation (they had driven right up to the temple), the entrance had been moved and the interpretative center and all the local restaurants, etc. had been added as a way of preserving the site and keeping vehicles further away.The temple area is well worth the trip but the interpretative center makes it a must for anyone who is interested in the history and background of the various sites. It added valuable information I didn't find in my books I had purchased.

Out of the way of tourists.. There are so many tourists at all the temples, but get here before 9am and you'll have the place to yourselves. It's well preserved and offers great viewpoints to get some really great photos.

Worth the trip!. This temple requires an hour or so trip out of town but it was definitely one of our favorites and the drive lets you see some of the Siem Reap countryside. We would definitely recommend seeing this one!

Beautiful carvings out in the country. A 30 min ride out into the countryside, this temple is visited by tourists as it contains the best carvings - all with intricate detail and all stunning. The ride there and back is good too as you see the ordinary life of Cambodians - working in the paddy fields or tapping the palm trees to make palm sugar fudge (delicious and available at roadside stall)
The small gem. This temple is not on the main drag but it is well worth the cost of getting there. It is a small temple but the carvings are some of the most beautiful that you may ever see.

The crowds ruin the atmosphere. Wonderful place but it's quite small so when there are so many visitors, we counted 8 large groups just from Korea alone, it becomes unpleasant. Either visit at the very start or end of the day.

Not worth the trip. Only see this temple if you are in Angkor for a week.I beg to differ with most of the other reviews, this temple is not worth the trip. Yes, I understand that they made a large tourist centre around it, which is in dire need of customers, so they are trying to convince everyone to come here. Then when you have made the trip, it's hard to tell yourself that it wasn't worth it, but the temple itself is nothing special. Don't get me wrong, it is beautiful, with wonderful carvings, but it is so far out of the way, that your time will be better spent elsewhere. You'll be able to see two other sites instead of this one. Or you can visit Tonle Sap lake and see how people live on the water.Especially skip this place if you have been to Khajuraho, or any other Indian temple with elaborate carvings. As much as the reliefs in Banteay Srei are nice, they are crude and very few in comparison with what you can see on old Indian temples.

Rose pink temple. Well worth the drive out from Angkor into the countryside because this is different to other temples because of its colour, the intricate carvings and the countryside that surrounds it. You also get a sense of the way villagers live in this part of Cambodia. It's a small temple and only takes half an hour to look around.

A must. For me it's a must after Angor Wat.So different for all the temples.Try to get to site around 8 am to avoide Japanese crowd with many cameras as site it not large and you need to stop by many sculptures.
A real gem. Unique among the temples in the area, much smaller scale, the best preserved carvings, lovely reflections in the surrounding moat.

Best Carving. This temple had the most intricate and perfectly preserved carving of any that I saw. I saw it on the way back from Kbal Spean and am glad that we stopped there. My driver kept saying I should see it because it is "your temple...woman temple :)" It is small and doesn't take long to see.

Beautiful lighting early in the morning. This was my personal favorite of all the temples we saw. Get their early in the morning before all the crowds arrive and the lighting and ruins are simply magic. The carvings are exquisite an the beautiful coloring in the stone make this site special.
Beautiful. This temple although a little further out is well worth the visit. Its not too big and is easily navigated with the help of a good guide book

The Lady Temple. Banteay Srei is a long tuk-tuk ride but it is worth the visit. It is a small and well preserved temple ruin but the pink stone makes it worth the visit. Arrive about 9 am to avoid the 10 am crowds and have good lighting.
amazing. a little bit further out but worth the effort , not so many tourists , worth going early morning , we did go by tuk-tuk , maybe a taxi would have been more comfortable

Our favourite!. Stunning temple, take a guide with you - not only will they get you there when the masses have left (we were there with one other couple in high season), but you also get the history of the site which is invaluable.
Beautiful!. We went early in the morning (arrived before 8am) and avoided the crowds. This is definitely worth visiting. It's a serene location in the forest. About 45 minutes from Siem Reap.
Superb stonework. One of the smaller temples but certainly the one with the best stone carvings. Given the right light the pink sandstone is certainly very photogenic.
Like lace... the gentle stone carvings seems like lace in twilight. Get there in the morning or late afternoon and admire the ancient sculptures.
beautiful, very romantic spot. try not to go at mid day- simply too hot to wander, reflect and enjoy, Take wet wipe, tissues and water
Impressive carvings. Despite of being a littel far away, the carvings a the sitting scultures are the finest. But avoid it at noon.

Out there a ways, but still integral. This one is still a part of the Angkor Wat experience. It's a bit of a drive, but a beautiful drive though. You can also knock out one or two more sites and the landmine museum along the route. We did this one on day three.

Long tuktuk drive but worth it. It took us almost an hour with our tuktuk and more than an hour to climb to the waterfall and the temple. Dont go with shorts and flip flops. The waterfall is beautifull but small and you cant swim.
HOwever its nice to see the jungle and the nature around.
Worth a visit. This temple was built by ladies and the intricate details make it different to the other temples we visited. It is definitely worth a visit.
Lovely temple. This is a beautiful temple with fantastic carvings. It's worth the ride out to it. Only downside is the distance

Get there early before the crowds. This is a great temple to visit, just get there early before the buses arrive. There is also a visitor center onsite which helps explain a lot of the history and construction and conservation that has been done on the site. Makes quite a difference.
Shopping spree. Visit it if you have spare time. Of relax learn and enjoy. Can do shopping und a roof but very expensive and exquisite

My favourite temple in Siem Reap area. There is a reason why this is called Pink Temple. The workmanship is excellent. Get there as early as you can. By 9am there will be around 1000 people already. I was there at 7.30 and there were maybe 20 people. Do walk around and inspect all details. Do walk around the moat at sunrise. Highly recommended the 40km tuk tuk ride from Siem Reap to see the countryside and local life.
Best carvings. Crowded but amazing. The carvings are so beautiful. Nice drive through the country. Tuktuk is fine for the trip.
Great place to see. While there are many temples to see I would make sure to add this one to the list. This temple had more intricate and detailed sculptures then most of the others.

worth the trip!. A lovely temple, set apart from the major temples of Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, Bayon, but not that far. Beautiful engravings, lovely sandstone color. Our guide pointed out how different scenes from the Ramayana were carved into the temple. I'd seen a video on it before going, which was helpful. I'm sure if I knew it in even better detail, I would've benefitted. It was kind of weird how the heads of Garuda were pillaged from both sides of one of the temple gables, but that was the only disappointment.As an aside, there are kids around the temple selling anything from postcards (10 for $1) to books which are marked with a retail price of $20+. I was informed that they get the books from a distributor for around $4 and try to sell them for $15, and particularly like to approach Americans (incessantly) because we are apparently an easy mark. One person followed me for two blocks, constantly trying to get me to buy a book, even offering it to me for $1. Afterward, it was suggested to me to say "ok" to the next person who offered me the book for $1, and see what happens. Sure enough, leaving the temple, the same guy who followed me in the beginning found me and started hawking me again, offering the book to me for $1, at which point I said ok for $1. He quickly said no, and that I could buy the book for $5 or postcards for $1.I used to feel very bad for these kids (the teenage boys are selling books, the younger girls and boys sell postcards and crafts) until I found out that these kids do very well by Cambodian standards by their selling techniques - very, very well - and well-intentioned tourist dollars only encourage them to quit school and make a living of doing it more.If you really want to help them, donate to the school or hospital in a local community. Or, if you'd like to compliment the kids, it was recommended that we ask them if they can pose for a photo and then, if they agree, show them the photo that you have taken. If you want to go one step further, share a digital copy of the photo with someone who is local (your guide, perhaps?) who could give it to the kids upon their next visit.

Great detailed carvings. This was the second best site after Angkor Wat. The carvings of the ramayana stories were done extremely precisely in a red sand-stone. Very beautiful. Be avare of begging children - give them fruit or food rather than money.

Lovely. The carvings and the colour of the stone make this stand out. It was a bit out of the way but well worth the trip out to see it. It was very busy as was expected but this did not detract from the atmosphere of the place.

beautifully different. Delicate carvings, fine detail, a complete contrast to Angkor, again we hit a tropical rainstorm but with no place to hide, but we could still appreciate the restored beauty of the place in our relatively brief visit.
Different again. A neat temple you can explore in twenty minutes, with almost Roman features, lots of good pictures, especially the monkey creature statues
The most detailed, newest temple there. Do not miss it while there, and visit Beng MeLeu as well! A bit more distant, albeit ranks at the Ta Phrom experience

A Angkor architectural beauty. A small temple structure when compared to other Angkor temples - Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, and Ta Prohm, but it has all the architectural beauty. The engravings are well protected and exhibit the details of the carvings. A must visit site.

Surprise I was not templed out. I saw Bateay Srei on my 3rd day of touring the temples around Ankor Wat so I was very surprised at how much I still loved it. The reddish colouring is different from the other sites though the best part was the intricate carvings in the site. It is also less busy as it is further out.
Pretty in pink. The colours and intricate carvings are very beautiful. A bit of a trek but worth it. The drive out through farmland was interesting... Must go via zircon car
Remote but a beauty. Much smaller than the known temples at Angor Wat, but such a fine crafted and delicate structure, Worht a visit when you can spare the time.

Just beautiful!. Make sure you do this trip with a Tuktuk - car drives can be boring. A tuktuk ride gives you a glimpse of the Combodian countryside which is so serene and laid back. I envy the lifestyle of these people. After almost an hours ride, we reached the temples. This temple is truly beautiful and different than the others. Its unbelievable that people have actually hand carved out this beautiful temple. Though our 7yr old daughter was templed out already, it was fun to have her see the carvings and relate them to the stories from Ramyana. The carvings of fight between Bali and Sugrava and the stories of Indra, the rain god left us speechless. Though there are certain spots which are now not accessible to the tourists and I completely agree to this step. The temple is too precious for our future generations. This was the most favourite of our temples. For two hours we kept going round and round the temple soaking in every curve every carving and almost every stone. it was just not enough ! A must add in to your buckets!

The nice Inner are is closed for tourist. The good part of it is the inner part. There are all the nice Carvings and Statues. BUT: it's closed. nobody is allowed to enter the center. You can only see some parts from outside. This destroys the experience. First they let foreign County pay the Restoration (in this case Switzerland) and when it would be nice to visit the close it. anyway the Swiss tax payer has so much money, the probably don't care.
My wifes favorite place. I recommend visiting during morning as the sun gets bright and your photos will not get all the details of the wonderful carvings.

Pink Temple!. Banteay Srei is a short distance (about 30 minutes) outside Siem Reap but it is worth the visit. This temple has been restored to some extent and there is a visitor centre and good facilities surrounding the temple.The sculptures and carvings at the temple are in very good condition and there are some great photo opportunities.There were a lot of bus tours when we were there, but it wasn't overly busy.The temple is included in the Angkor Pass fee.

Great carvings. Constructed of pink sandstone, the statues of this temple retain their elegance and suppleness despite the test of time. The decorations are highly refined. A "must see" when in Siem Reap.

One of my favourites. The pink sandstone sets this apart as well as it's well preserved carvings. We found having a guide added to the experience by explaining the history and culture associated with each temple.

Make sure you see this one !!. Banteay Srei is certainly worth a visit , it's quite amazing how much more intricate the carvings are. The temple is very small but well worth making the trip out from the popular sites. It took about an hour from the French quarter in our van to reach Banteay Srei , we also included a visit to the butterfly farm and Pre Rup temple on our return.. All up this took about three and a half hours, a lovely way to spend the afternoon.

My favourite of the Temples of Angkor. For me this was the most beautiful of the Temples of Angkor, and well worth the extra effort (a Tuk Tuk ride through some nice villages). Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm and the Bayon are all impressive but the intricacy and beauty of the carvings at Banteay Srei really blew me away. Well worth the trip!

Pink temple. Beautiful carvings. Further out from Siem Reap but we felt it was worth a visit. Along the way you will see beautiful countryside of Cambodian farming life. Stopped along the way and saw palm sugar being made. Go there!
One of the nicest temples to visit. Much smaller than most of its cousins, but worth visiting for its intricate carvings. It's a slightly longer drive but well worth it.

The Pink Lady. My personal favorite because of the pink limestone and the intricacy of the carvings. (Hubby liked Ta Proehm better.) Lots of excellent photo opportunities which includes the water lilies in the pond. Early morning light was fabulous plus no crowds! We went right after going to Angkor for sunrise. Perfect!

Central area of the temple cordoned off. Regrettably the crowds make it necessary to cordon off the interior areas of the temple. You walk around the ruins basically on a catwalk. This most feminine of temple structures has lost much of its atmosphere.

A ruddy marvel. Awesome place, well worth a visit - cannot believe what these folks did to build these Temples and Palaces a mere thousand years ago.Makes Stonehenge inEngland look like an MFI accident and as for the Pyramids - a doddle in those days and in that weather.We were and remain Gobsmacked

The journey is more interesting than the destination. Beautiful temple, with incredible detail. Much smaller in scale and far less crowded. However after spending the first day on the small circuit, the extended journey on the second day starting the big circuit off at Banteay Srei was overrated. It felt out of place, far from Khmer origin and more of Indian decent. I did not have temple fatigue until at least the third day, and was far more content with other temples on the big circuit, Prea Kahn, Ta Som and my favourite on that route was Banteay samre. There was hardly anyone there, complete silence in the jungle and very well preserved temple, don't miss this one.Don't kill to much time at Banteay Srei , there is far superior temples on the big circuit to spend time on.

The sandstone temple. Yes, it is worth coming out to see the so-called 'pink temple' as the carvings and bas reliefs are intricate and unique. From a photographer's point of view, they stand out better because of the sandstone. It is worth mentioning that the journey to these temples was worth it as you can see the rural side of Cambodia, the pretty wooden houses, the basket weave stalls and palm sugar products all at the side of the road for very little money.
Only for aficionados. I realise it supposed to be one of the highlights, but it is brutally unshaded and unless you are interested in the fine carving detail, it is not particularly interesting.
worth the drive. I know it is further but you really have to see it, it is magnificient.The pink color of the stone is so nice. Great temple.

worth the trip out to it. it takes a while to get there - can be done by car or tuk tuk.. but is worth it. Clean toilets available at the ticket booth area. market of stores and food options. smaller temple then the main ones but much more detail in the carvings. Different feeling to the place. Not much shade covering options so be ready for lots of sun.. but on the good side.. no stairs to do ! Went twice.. once late morning and it was good but chaotic with tour groups and the second time was just before closing and it was magical... it was cooler, the shadowing made the place mystical and we were almost the only people at the whole site..

a good day trip. worth the trip out in the NE direction -lovely tuk tuk ride in the countryside.... combine with the ACCB animal rescue centre if you are interested in helping out animals who are being rehabilitated after being treated badly by traders or 'pet' owners.... interesting place.

well worth the trip out here. Spent a week in Siem Reap and had a lot of time, we decided to do this and Kbael Spean in one day and with tuk tuk which cost us $16 for the day, was well worth it, this temple is one of the best in the area and has amazing detail! the drive through is excellent as well, you pass through many villages. Make sure this is your last stop as its best late in the day.
Far and small. But the carvings in this site are well worth it. The exhibition area gives you a nice bit of history on the area and it is well kept.

Stunning but .... ... get there before the tour buses ! groups tend to gather and block door and passageways as it isn't a very big temple. The details in the carvings is magnificent, no trip to SR would be complete without going to Banteay Srei (and Beng Mealea).Kids selling guide books outside the temple try it on, one tried to sell us a guidebook for $15 and eventually went down to $4. On the way out, another offered us the same guidebook for $1.
Another temple. All part of tour of temples within Cambodia - each temple had it's own charm and details, this was amongst the best visited.

Well worth the trip!. Fantastic site, well worth the extra money, time and effort to get here. We went on a scorching hot day and had to have umbrellas, but the bright sunlight made my photos come to life! It's small but beautifully formed. It really wasn't that busy in my opinion, but I guess that depends on the time of year and time of day. The only thing is for those who get travel sick and do this by tuk-tuk- I did wonder if that would be an issue for someone not used to it, because the speed limit on a tuk-tuk means the journey takes a really long time and your open to the elements, so it does get a bit tiring and nauseating (as wimpy westerner as that sounds) from the constant wind rush. Just a thought!Also going here can be coupled with a trip to Kbal spean- this is more for those interested in the history of the temples, not just the big 'wow temples' side of it. Here, there's not lots to see but once I knew the story behind what is there, I was fascinated. There is a long walk for this one uphill by the way!

Pink temple. This is further away but a must see. This is a smaller temple for Helene and is older than the other temples
Built from different sandstone which gives it it's name h intricate carvings show a definite Indian influence. One again I suggest a guide well worth the cost

Beatiful detailed temple. Although small and a bit of a tuk tuk ride away this is for me definitely a worthwhile trip. The detailing on the temple is amazing and considering how much is preserved it is a highlight of the Angkor complex.

Tsunami of tourists take the sight away. It takes some time to get there but the road is worth the travel. If you go by tuc tuc you can enjoy watching local life. The beautiful site of Bantey Srei is very attractively organised with nicely presented information and a pleasant little natural path with viewpoints. It is not very big, but you could spend hours to see all the fine sculptures in details.... If possible! Because big groups of guided tourists might block the ways and disturb all sights.
A bit further but worth it. This temple is a bit further away from Siem Reap, but worth the effort, and the carving is really good.... small temple, but very impressive
Beautiful temple. Small temple but very beautiful. We went early morning and it was quite busy so allow time for tour groups to pass through and then soak up the atmosphere

"Small, but elegant". This was one of my favourite temples in a place filled with wonder. This temple had such intricately designed carvings, I was in awe, absolutely stunning artwork and carving. This is worth the drive to see, it truly is. (Combine with Rolous Group temples to make it worth your while.)

Jewel of temples. This temple is located in Rolous, some 30 km away from the city, but is worth a visit. It is small temple with intricate ornaments, such jewel. Located amidst the beautiful nature it makes you gasp at the elegant beauty of its walls and towers of unusual color

Small but so delicate. This is a different temple. Different stone from the others, different buildings and different stone carvings, maybe the best and certainly the most delicate. If you have the time you may combine an excursion to Phnom Koulen park with this visit. Taking a bath under the waterfall at phnom Koulen is great and the forest, the budist Ashram with the huge reclining Buda are not to be missed.

Absolutely Stunning!. Start at this site before the tour buses arrive! This is a most beautiful place to see. It is small, but a real treasure. Because it is small, it's better to get there early to avoid having so many people in the way of the photos. There is a landmine musician group who play their instruments outside of the site. They are great and you can buy CDs from them.

some of the best carvings. You must include this as part of the tour round the temples .. a little off the track and get there either late in the day or early in the morning to avoid the other tourists .. really a part of the "to do" when visiting the area" check out sophana yous (yes this is a strong recommendation for a really good guide .. )

One of the loveliest temples in Siem Reap. A bit of a drive but oh so worth it (still easily reached by tuk tuk). Banteay Srei is one of the oldest temples in the Angkor archeological park, and one of the most elegant and sublimely beautiful. This red sandstone temple was created at a much more human scale than the masterpieces of Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat, and feels more intimate. The carvings are magnificent, especially above the entryways. Also worth noting; Banteay Srei has facilities not found at some of the other sites like a small visitor center, restaurant and clean modern restrooms. if you have the time include this beautiful little temple in your visit to Siem Reap. You will always remember it.

Not to be missed. Do not miss this site. Brilliant. The cops patrol it to stop visitors messing it up. they will let you touch the carving if you pay them when crowds are light. DONT PAY - dont do damage.

Possibly the 'prettiest' of all the temples in the Angkor area.. Best viewed in the afternoon sun when the lovely pink sandstone comes to life. One of the smallest but also finest of the Angkor Temples despite being one of the earliest (10th century).

Worth a visit but not spectacular. This is supposedly one of the more beautiful temples in the area. It is especially small compared to many of the other temples. It is also slightly further away from the main Angkor temples and will involve a bumpy ride past many traditional Cambodian villages along the way. While the roofs have mostly fallen, many of the intricate carvings are still in relatively good condition. Because it is small, it is inevitable that congestion starts, especially when the big tour groups come by their busloads.When the midday sun comes out, it becomes extremely hot, even on the verge of being unbearable. Wear cool clothing and hydrate yourself.

Be amazed by Banteay Srei. It takes about 30 minutes from Siem Reap to get to the temple. The enchanting temple of Banteay Srei is nearly everyone's favorite site. The special charm of this temple lies in its remarkable state of preservation, small size and excellence of decoration. Definitely worth the 1 hour excursion.
Beauty in pink sandstone. An ancient crumbling temple. Beautiful carvings on pink sandstone. Check out the carved lintels for the Narasimha avatar.
Get there early to avoid the crows. In order to enjoy this small temple, get there early before all tourist buses and also the morning frenzy of the villages along the road.
So much detail. One of my favourite temples with such detailed carvings. The wonderful tour guide made this temple come alive with explanations about it's history and use.

Beautiful, but disappointing. This is a nice temple, but it wasn't quite what I expected. The temple is much smaller than the huge car park and visitors centre would suggest, and the carvings in the temples are nice, but not so much more beautiful than the other temples than I was lead to believe.

Very pretty. Different completely from the other temples and worth the visit. Go as early as possible to avoid the large contingents of bus tours and combine a hike to the waterfalls and the landmine museum to make a day of it.
far and diferent. a little far from the rest of the temple but very different less crowd and nice to take a break. it worth the time.

Beautiful carvings.. For a small temple- the carving was the most spectacular. Enjoyed the great designs so well preserved on the walls- disliked hoards of tourist buses - temple small- not room for all the sightseers.
Worth the trip. Compared with the geat structures around Angkor this is a small temple but well worth visiting for the superb decorations on the walls.

Worth the trek, go to see the carvings.. This temple was an hour tuk tuk ride from the main grounds, but worth the trek. By far, the best temple with the detailed, intricate carvings. One of my favorites of the visit. Skip the nearby, hike to the waterfall. It's not really a jungle, or a waterfall. More like a stream.

Pretty and wonderfully carved detailing. the carvings in the temple stones are really intricate and beautiful. but on a whole so much smaller and honestly less impressive than the other temples (Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Prohm). a ways out too--30-40 mins from the others. also, LOTS of school children begging you to buy postcards for $1. they need the money for school--otherwise they can't afford to attend; it's legit and i wanted to give them all a little something. so if you go, be prepared with small bills.

A far away temple with the BEST carvings in all of Angkor.. I don't often write tips on the very first paragraph of my reviews, but if I did, it is worth a try and, if you're lucky, you'll really be glad to have done it. TIP: Go to Banteay Srei very early. This means leaving your hotel as early as 5:00 or 6:00 (if you can't wake up so early) in the morning to go to Banteay Srei. It is an hour or so ride away from Siem Reap by tuktuk. When you get there, you will see an eerily quiet temple with very, very few people (you, some guards, and a couple or so of tourists). What is great is that you may be allowed, for a price ($2.00 for me), but with supervision by the guards (if they like you as they liked me), to view the finest of fine carvings at its central sanctuary (which is basically what you came for to see at Banteay Srei). In Banteay Srei, like other temples, there is sightseeing route markers to guide you in your visit. Follow these as they are the best way to see the temple. Now, the temple's central sanctuary (where the most intricate carvings still in its original state and in best condition in all of Angkor is located) is cordoned off. So, the best of the best carvings might be too far to reach to take photos if your camera has low zooming capabilities.There are guards there watching to apprehend violators (unless they themselves allow you, of course). When you exit the main temple, follow the route once more until it forks. Take the right route. When you take this route, it will lead you to a raised platform. Go up this raised platform and you can see a panoramic view of the whole temple from the causeway to the central sanctuary. This view is worthy of a shot, of course. Before you go, there are some rocks outside the second enclosure which you can take a photo of the whole front of the temple with the causeway and with the two ponds surrounding this causeway. This temple is quite far. Added to this, the temple is quite small. However, the temple is popular to tour groups. So if you go there, say 9:00 in the morning, a tour group would be there already and you might not be able to do my tip because there are many other visitors wanting to do the same and the guards might not like it. Also, small temple plus lots of tourists is not a nice place to be at. If you would love to see THE Angkor carvings, go here, but go early in the morning (I was there by 7:30 in the morning). Otherwise, if you find carvings boring, better for you not to go.

Little bit far from town center and so many people.. I had bad experience with mid age Chinese woman. She wanted to take friend photo. So I step back but pushed hard with no word. Wasn't happy. If didn't happened to me, I would enjoy more there. Sad!

The ride to Banteay Srei, best part. My favorite part of Banteay Srei was the ride out to the temple. You pass by lots of green rice fields and cute villages. I thought it was very nice to get out of Siem Reap and see a bit of the country side. We went by tuk tuk and would highly recommend that mode of transportation over a car as it is comfortable and fun to be in open air.

It's worth it to see the carvings. A little bit outside of Siem Reap but the fineness of the carving makes all the difference. There is a nice nature walk around the outside of the temple too. We were there in the later afternoon so there were fewer visitors although some buses still come out there.
Pink Temple. This temple were relly meant for the ladies :) The pink bricks which built this temple is really amazing. Worth the long ride!

Pink Sandstone devoted for the ladies. While Siem Reap has many sandstone architecture inherited from the ancient Hinduism era, this Banteay Srei differ a little with its natural color being pink instead of grey. The temple was built to pay homage to female goddess for her beauty. Worth a visit!

Small and Gorgeous. Very small and intimate with beautifully preserved carvings, all in reddish sandstone. Stunning. Surrounded by lovely, peaceful countryside, lily-covered ponds, etc. The 37 km drive out from Siem Reap is worthwhile in itself, passing through villages and rice fields.
Very well preserved. Beautiful color and nice carving: to my opinion the most preserved temple in Angkor. Not too crowded with tourists.

Beauty to behold!. Really really loved Banteay Srei and the great history behind the temple. The detail in the structures are intricate and you could spend and entire day there. Do not miss this, it does not attract the large crowds that Angkor Wat does, and has more of a relaxed feel to it. The waterfalls are not too far away and the Thousand Lingas which are pretty cool. We had a 10 year old guide who was hilarious and made the trip well worth while the monkeys are well worth a visit too!

Beautiful temple with excellent, intricate carving!. This is a relatively well preserved temple, in terms of the carving. The carving is beautiful and very intricate. The color of the temple is gorgeous, ESP. If you see this temple in the evening. The drive to it is beautiful. You see the country side which is green and very rural. We took a tuk- tuk so that we didn't rush through the country side. It took us 45 minutes from our hotel but we enjoyed every minute of it.
Pink Sandstone wonder. Probably my favorite temple and well worth the drive. It is a wonder in pink sandstone with deep and impressive carvings.
My favorite temple. My favorite temple by far. It is extremley well preserved compared to others. A while out of town but worth it.
Cute.... Also known as lady temple. Quite small, have pinkish structure and carvings worth seeing. Less crowd here.

Not as crowded but equally not as spectacular. Slightly further out than many other temples so not as visited therefore less crowds, its not as spectacular as many others Pre Rup, Eastern Mebon, Ta Prohm are far more spectaular. If on a coach or mini bus well worth the drive but would splash out for a special visit on a tuk tuk.

Small Temple. Known as the Lady Temple for its pinkish colored sandstone, this temple is being renovated. It is fune to contrast this temples being restored to that of some of the more intact ones such as Angkor Wat.
a tiny gem. Not as big as most temples but exquisite colour and detail in the stonework. Worth the long tuk tuk trip here and as an added bonus not as crowded as the other temples

Must not be missed!. The temple is quite far from Angkor. But you can hire tuktuk for USD25 rather than paying USD60 for a car (the trip will include Bantey Srei, Landmine Museum, Pre Rup, Sra Srang). This is a masterpiece of Angkorian art and architecture. The finest carving you'll ever see.

Temple is Ok, Scenic Driver Better. It takes about an hour to drive out the this temple. The temple itself is okay if you see it after the others. What makes it great is the scenic drive out to the temple, where you see many small houses and villages on the way.

A citadel of art, of passion. We visited this temple in the morning. It took about 40 minutes drive from Siem Reap, through beautiful rural Cambodia - across rice fields, past small shops, past roadside stalls, past small villages.Locals call Banteay Srey as the 'temple of the ladies', the 'pink stone temple' and as the ‘citadel of the women.’ Call what they may, we were awed by the delicate beauty of its intricate carvings, the soft resplendent color of the stone, and how beautiful this small temple is.The temple is perhaps the finest example of classical Khmer art and generations of able artists that blessed Cambodia some 1000+ years ago. The walls are densely covered with deep and intricate carvings, more beautiful and better preserved than all Angkorian temples we visited. The walls display Hindu stories from Vedas, and from epics such as Ramayana, Mahabharatha, etc. Buddhist influences were also visible, since this temple too along with Khmer people witnessed the tug of change between the cycles of Buddhism and Hinduism, over the centuries. Banteay Srei is evidence of Khmer respect for the arts - because, despite significant turmoil, change in its religious beliefs and wars, the temples and the carvings remain preserved for folks of our generation to be inspired by. Banteay Srei is also evidence of the extraordinary accomplishment of southeast Asian arts, one that matches the beauty in stone carvings in Italy, Turkey or Central Asia. Banteay Srei is just a few centuries older, on stone that is more difficult to carve than marble.Banteay Srei is a must see.
Dont miss this different temple. Pinkish stone and design are different from the other Temples. Temple honors women in ancient Cambodia.

Amazing sandstone carving! Different than other temples! Worth the drive!. Amazing amazing temple. Took me a couple trips to Angkor before I went here! Must see! Small temple preserved very well! Do not miss!
The smallest, but the most beautiful. I was amazed at the intricate details in all the structures of this small Hindu temple complex, located like one hour away from Siem Reap.

Jewel of a temple. We visited this temple on our first day of our tuk tuk tour with Angkor Tuk Tuks. Suvuth took us to a couple of other temples first and then we insisted that we go to Banteay Srei. We are glad we did. It is a long journey to this temple so an early start would have been good. Nevertheless, we enjoyed the road there watching how people lived and noticing that there was a dearth of ducks and pigs as in other Asian countries. The villages are small and one can see that life is generally a struggle.Banteay Srei (aka Citadel of Women or Lady Temple) is one of the smallest temples and it is built of red sandstone so it has a beautiful welcoming hue to it. Built in the 10thC is was dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva. The entrance is through beautifully carved doors. Don't forget to admire the excuisite Khmer writing on the pillars. Part of the temple is also dedicated to Vishnu. Again you have to climb over doorways. Be particularly careful here as you can step out of a door way (as I did) expecting to place your food on the ground, but instead you could catch your foot on a small unseen step and over you go - much to the delight of the Chinese tourists who will not even make an effort to assist you.This is a beautiful temple and you should be prepared to spend quite a bit of time here. There are small temples/rooms everywhere - you can guage that they were small people. The doorways in the central tower (you can get to it) are only 18 inches high. Some of the best dancer carvings are on this central tower. This temple is on one level so you do not have to climb stairs at all - there are a few small steps around but nothing too difficult.Watch your step and your head if you are tall. You could easily knock yourself out. Hats, sunglasses, sunscreen, good walking shoes and plenty of water are a must.When you exit the temple, take a walk around the outer walls - listening to the sounds of children in a nearby school and then enjoying the reflections in the moat. Watch out for small frogs and the lovely coloured dragon flies.At the right time, the moat will be full of beautiful water lilies.Be sure to stop at the Angkor Butterfly Centre on your way back. Have lunch at the Angkor Kitchen.

my favorite. This was my favorite temple in the Angkor area. I was surprised how detailed the carvings were from 10th-11th century. The pink stone is gorgeous. If you only have one day, include this on the tour! A must-see!

Small but beautiful. Known as the lady temple because of the amazing women carvings in the stone work. As a recommendation go at various times so you can see how light/shadows reflect from the carvings.

Red Beauty!. This temple complex has a charm that's quite different from the others. The red limestone carvings of the temple are spectacular and they deflect the sun's rays to give itself a magical hue.
A definite must visit. But make sure to visit early in the mornings, to beat the heat.
Beautiful surrounds. A stunning temple in a lush garden setting. Well worth the trip, especially if you combine it with the butterflies and accd.
Banteay Srei. Great detailed carving. A gem of a site. Not overly crowded as it is not on the beaten path of most visited sites. Our guide took us there because he knew it has such beautiful carving.

Sandstone Carved Amazingly. This smaller in scale temple is really a work of art. The sand stone carvings are delicate yet have withstood the sands of time, tourists, weather and just about everything else. This temple is much smaller than Angkor Wat but because of the size it is not overwhelming. Beautiful artwork done in sandstone, this Hindu temple is amazing. Do not miss the display that has the photographs of the temple as restoration was underway. Temple will not take long to see, but take your time as it was not as crowded as Angkor Wat was.

Good, but so many people. This place has changed in the last few years, the first time I visited there were no markets, no restaurants/cafes but now it caters for the tourist bus trade. The carvings are so detailed and interesting, but the number of people there really makes it unpleasant.

Beautiful carving. Really nice trip further up north than most of the Angkor monuments, the carving on this temple is fantastic. Double up with a trip to the carved streambed of Kbal Spean for an amazing half day trip.

Small but beautiful.. Banteay Srei was unlike many of the other temples that we saw, Unfortunately it is quite small, which can mean you have to jostle with tour groups in order to have a decent look at some of the intricate carvings. Still well worth a look but try and get there before the buses!
Small but detailed. This is a true gems, it is all in the details. Worth the visit! Take your time and avoid the crowds and tour buses. Plan your day to see other of the nearby attractions.

The best carvings in Angkor. A must see temple with the most exquisite and intricate carvings among the Angkor temples. Do not miss this temple dedicated to Siva, though it is now called the citadel of woman, built of red sandstone.
One of our favorites. Togheter with Ankor Wat and Ta Prohm our favorites especially the nice wall sculptures are amazing at Banteay Srei.

a gem. This was the first temple I visited on a 4 day 'temple tour' and it remains in my mind as one of the best for several reasons.The carvings are beautiful and generally in very good condition and many of them are at a level where they are easy to see and photograph. It's not very big, so by the time you've seen it all it is still exciting - unlike some of the larger temples when I felt glad to get out of them.The pink sandstone does make it quite different to most of the others that you will see, especially if you visit early (I mean just after sun up) when the stone seems to glow. This also means that you should have the place pretty much to yourself - and it will be cooler !. As everyone comments it is out of the way, but I think this is a bonus as the trip out through the villages is very interesting and you'll certainly see sights you won't see if you stick to the main temple circuit.

Worth th trip. A bit further away from Siem Reap that the main temple complexes but this small temple is well worth a visit and the carvings are better preserved than in most of the main temples. Combine with a visit to Kbal Spean (linga river) or Kulen Mountains National Park. The latter is said to be the origin on the Kymer Empires. The latter part of the trip to Kulen is over muddy rutted roads. At the end is a temple with a reclining Buddha, one linga carving in the river and waterfalls with restaurants to have lunch and a pleasant dip in the river. At Kbal Spean there are more linga carvings although a longer walk from the road. My recommendation is Kbal Spean over Kulen but in any case stop at Banteay Srei
Well Preserved Temple. The red-coloured sandstones were very unique and very different from the normal stones that we saw in Angkor Wat.

Quite a trek but a little gem. Pretty much everyone who visits Angkor will visit the temples around Angkor Thomas. This little beauty is further out but is worth a day trip and there are a few more really nice temples lose by.

small but excellent. The temple is a very small red sandstone complex. It is renowned for its excellent carved decorations that show a great level of detail.Everything is at one level - you only need to step a few times over some sills.The temple is approximately 36 km away from the main temples, so it is worth organising a car to go there. The drive to get there is very enjoyable as well: you drive through small villages with wooden houses on stilts and through rice paddies. Some villages on the road to the temple do very nice wicker baskets and articles

Simply Amazing Temple!. Banteay Srei - or Ladies Temple - is an amazing temple and it is easy to see why it is a favorite of those who visit the Angkor Wat Archaeological Park. The temple differs from others in that it is made of pink sandstone which gives it a different look than many of the other temples. The pink sandstone also seems to have stood the wear of time better than the grey sandstone, in that the carvings are without much sign of wear. Hard to believe they were done more than 1000 years ago!Banteay Srei is a compact temple compared to many of the others, but you could spend hours there - especially if taking photographs. Beautiful temple and one that should certainly be on any temple-visitors itinerary.

Its nice but Bayon is better. When we landed at Siem Reap, our taxi driver told us that the best temple to visit is Banteay Srei even though its very far. Well, we got taken in and hired a cab to take us there the next morning. We did not find anything as outstanding as the driver stated, which led me to think that maybe he wanted to earn more money since it was much further than Angkor Wat and the other temples. So go only if you have the time, otherwsie see the closer temples.

Hard to get to, but amazing to see. We hired a guide and a traveling and requested to visit Banteay Srei. It took us about an hour by car to get there, so it is pretty far out of the city (although no one goes that fast on the roads). Yet, it was completely worth it. The temple was beautiful and quite different from those we saw at the main Angkor Complex. Additionally, it was fun to get out of the city and see the gorgeous green rice paddies that surrounded the temple.If you can get out of the city this is a worthwhile place to visit!

city of women!. A UNESCO heritage. Banteay Srei is built largely of a hard red sandstone that can be carved like wood. Though this is the smallest among the temples but you will be amazed of the handiwork on its images carved in its finest in the wall. If you are an art enthusiast, then this temple is for you. The intricate carvings will awe anyone. Have this in your list!

All Hand Carved. This is one of the oldest temples at around 1200 years old. The volcanic stone is very impressive. Our guide mentioned that it's better not to buy things from the child touts, as if they don't make money there they will be more likely to go to school, where they should be.

Banteay Srei or Banteay Srey. Is a 10th century Cambodian temple dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva. Banteay Srei is built largely of red sandstone, a medium that lends itself to the elaborate decorative wall carvings which are still observable today. Also well known as 'pink temple' by the local people. This temple is a bit far from town. Around the temple, you will get to see local paddy field!

worth the travel. Although this one is slightly out of the way and your tuk tuk driver will want a little extra (its around 37km from siem reap so ours agreed to an extra $5)it is definately worth the visit. Its only a very small temply but the carvings are beautiful, its also set in some beautiful countryside and the tuk tuk drive there in itself is worth it as you get a glimpse of 'real' cambodia outside of siem reap
Do not miss this site. Carvings are really fantastic. Worth a stop. Beautiful pink sandstone. On the way to the River of a Thousand Lingas.

The Ladies Temple. Special by virtue of its different pinkish stone and the intricacy of the carvings thought to have been crafted by the smaller and more detailed focused hands of women. I would recommend visiting before the larger temples of Ankor Wat and Ankor Thom.
Lovely. I believe this is the one called the 'pink' temple or women'stemple. It is a bit of ride out of town in a tuk-tuk but it was bonus to see the country side.
beautiful. even though this a little further out its well worth the visit. one of my favorites. delicate carvings very feminine, it is the womens temple. not to be missed

Favorite of all the temples. Long ride through the countryside gave us a more realistic glimpse at Cambodian life. We enjoyed it, but might be rough on someone older or with back trouble to ride in a tuk-tuk that long. This was our favorite temple site because (probably due to its remote location) it was really peaceful & less crowded.
