Yes, you still have people pestering you to sell things, but fewer (& only at entrance/exit points). It was very quiet in the ruins. We could hear enchanting music, played by a local band at the edge of the park - they weren't asking for money, & you wouldn't even have seen them unless you walked in a fairly remote area.One unique aspect of this complex is that it's carved from pink sandstone. The carvings seemed more intricate, maybe even feminine. There's also an interesting exhibit chronicling the excavation of the ruins.At the exit are several vendors selling food & drinks, in a covered area with seats.

A must see when you get up early. Very different from the other temples and a bit far out (1 hour in a tuk tuk), this temple made of clay is very nice. Dedicated to Lakshmi (Hindu goddess), it's also called the "Lady Temple". The carvings are amazing. I would recommend to early in the morning before all the groups arrive. It's a pretty small temple so you can easily feel claustrophobic when it's crowded.

Away from it all, closer to nature. This is a little far, but worth the trip. Exquisite carvings and much quieter than the more visited temples. Stay out of the shops unless you are willing to engage in the hard selling, but we had a nice snack and drink at the restaurant. Stop at the Banteay Srei Butterfly Center on the return to fill up on even more nature and a great discussion with a local family.

a little ways away, but worth the trip. 37km from main Angkor area, but very different than the type of temples you will see in the main Angkor area. Your driver (by car) will charge an extra $15 to make the trip, so you can see buildings that are much better preserved and with far deeper carvings. The type of rock used is reddish and seemed to stand up much better to the elements over time. On the way, you'll pass by the landmine museum which is worth a stop (sadly we did not, and I regret it). You can also make a stop to see where they harvest palm sugar and make the candies and syrup
Small and Beautiful. This was one of the last temples we visited and was feeling a bit templed out, but this was a joy as the carving were beautiful and it was not too big to get around.

Intricate carvings at Banteay Srei. This temple is bit of the Angkor Wat Circuit but a must see.The Angkor Wat entrance ticket includes this temple too.The whole experience from the gates to the temple is different from other Wats. It is a fairly small temple on one level so no climbing required.The carvings were so intricate that it left me spellbound and I could not stop taking photographs. Having been raised in the Hindu culture I always imagined Hiranyakaspu as . The whole ambiance with the lotus ponds and trees is must to soak in .I found that the shops here had good quality handicrafts and the prices matched the night market with the bargaining.Natural light sure makes things look better!!

Stunning. Although this Temple is 45 minutes from Siem Reap it is well worth the vist Not as big as Angkor Wat but very impressive as it is constructed from pink sandstone The carvings and reliefs are far more detailed than those at Angkor Wat Also as this temple is furthuer out there was not as many people about and one could wander about at leisure and really enjoy this remarkable templeAgain would well suggest a visit

Highlight of the Angkor temples. Went to this temple just because it was on the way back from 1000 Lingas and was so glad I did. It is just beautiful from the minute you get to the grounds entrance. Lovely exhibition centre and cafe with lots of information in english before you get to the temple. Small but ornate. Dont miss.

A very pretty temple. we loved this temple, it is unique in that it was crafted from pink and yellow standstones, it was a temple dedicated to women. It looks a lot more delicate and very pretty, all sprawled out.
Beautiful Temple. The intricate carvings were unbelievably beautiful and well worth the extra travelling time to visit.

Very different from the other temples. Banteay Srey is a very different kind of temple. No climbing of stairs. It is has a smaller scale of structures with exquisite carvings in the reddish stone. It is definitely worth the trip by Tuk Tuk, about 45 min., approx. 30/35 km outside of Siem Reap.Once you exit the temple site you will find a short walk to a platform to oversee rice fields. We also observed a herd of water buffalo's. You will also find a platform outside the walls to oversee the whole temple.What I found really annoying at that site were the book/DVD vendors. They just did not seem to understand "no". Lot's of them, also a fair amount of kids. They did have the tendency to be quite nasty (verbal) which I did not notice at other sites.Banteay Srey has no separate entrance fee, it is included in the temple pass.On the premises you will find restaurants/clean toilets and souvenir vendors.

One of the best Siem Reap Temples. Dont get me wrong, the temple of Banteay Srei is a great site to see, but the real experience comes with the ride to see it. I would highly suggest taking a half day Tuk Tuk ($15). If you do, you will truly take a trip back in time. The rice fields, the local villages, the amazing people. There is just so much to experience when visiting this place.If you're visiting Siem Reap don't miss this opportunity

Fine carving. The most spectacular for carvings and fine workmanship. Small but a must see. Go early and the gaurds may escort you past the roped areas for close-ups...so long as you promise not to touch and get there before the bus groups arrive

The carvings are spectacular. This temple is not very big but it is just a must-see. The carvings on the stone are fabulous. It is called the lady Temple. They say that the carving is so intricate that only a lady could have done it.

Beautiful and not to be missed. We took the long trip to see this amazing complex. A huge thunderstorm chased us out just as we finished walking through the complex. Wish we had more time, but it is not to be missed. Well worth the drive and in a tuktuk, the drive allows you to see how most Cambodians live.

Small but stunning arts carved on every corner. Srei: Like Sarai or Saray means Palace. It's 32 km away from entrance. Tuk tuk is recomended. But Dry season is the best to visit. Cause road can be occupied by flood during rainy season. Early hours is the best to hit the road. It takes 50 mins to reach by Tuk-tuk. The worst thing is you need very well zoom camera like 15x. Otherwise you cannot picturize your trip attracted: Structures has been surrounded by rope lines.
Whow!. Small HIndu temple dedicated to Shriva but the most fabulous carvings. 10th Century temple further out from the main temple complexes but definitely worth the trip.
a small but briliant temple. smaller that angkor wat and thom but for carvings and emgravings on the walls you cant beat it! very tranqill
My favorite. All carvings done by women, the detail was amazing. We visited early in the morning there were hardly any tourists we took some great photos. What an experience.

A Khmer Jewel. Built of red sandstone, the temple is full of elaborative & decorative wall carvings. It simply beautiful. The structure are miniature in scale, hence unusual compared to the other temples.

thought this was marvellous. lots of temples are similar but each has a unique atsmosphere we felt, again, travel in mornings if possible by tuk tuk with lots of water and small notes for the kids selling stuff

Small and far away. Visit if you are heading that direction to do something else. Not worth driving to so far if you are going to see just this temple. Unless you are a real history or architecture buff... We combined this trip with Phnom Kulen but it wasn't that interesting either. Just a hill with small waterfalls and few carvings under the water.
Definitely one of it's kind. Located about 30 odd km from Siem Reap. The bas relief in this site is definitely the most intricately carved. A must visit if you are on a 3 or 7 day ticket!
Worth the journey. This is older than Angkor Wat so if you have at least 2 days in Siem Reap, I thoroughly recommend you visit here - you won't be disappointed..

So totally different. This temple site had a very "english" feel to it - set in a park like setting with a lovely walk around the outskirts with viewpoints over the countryside. A very pretty , elegant temple. Consider combining witha day trip to Kbal Spean and the Landmine Museum

Small but lovely. We were lucky enough to get here between tourist buses--and for that 10 minutes it was magical--carving was well preserved, intricate--in reddish stone. If you can time it right its great. If you can't its still worth it, just be prepared for other tourists to tell you to "get out of my shot" in any world language.

Amazing, but so crowded. It is such a beautiful temple, far away but so beautiful. However, it was so crowded at 9pm... Maybe choose another time, because it is not that big and it can be difficult to enjoy with tens of people coming and coming and standing in the way and coming some more.

HAVE TO SEE!!. Lots of travelers only see the major temples of Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm, and skip Banteay Srei as it is further away, but this perhaps is the most amazing temple we've seen during our trip to Angkor! Don't forget to take a large camera lens with you to capture the details of the central part, now off limits to visitors!

Banteay Srei. Banteay Srei is totally different than other temples in Siem Reap, though it is a small one the red bricks used for its construction gives the temple a different look. Plan one of your days to visit this temple along with the 1500 meter trekking to Kabal Spean - the river of thousand lingas, water fall and the land mine museum

Banteay Srei Temple, Cambodia. One of the jewells of the visit to Angkor Wat. This small temple is located about 30 kilometers outside Siem Reap. About an hour by Tuk Tuk. I used to go there in the afternoon, but, I am advised that its also very good in the morning.Interesting ride there by tuk tuk, as you pass through some small villages as well. Immaculate pink sandstone carvings. One of the " must sees" of a visit to Angkor Wat.There is no fee to go in, as this is covered in the cost of the pass to the Angkor area.

The oldest temples!. Bantey Srei is almost 38 kilometers from main Ankor. These temples were not made by the kings, but by one of the courtiers who was one of the intellectuals. Well, when you look at the architecture, you believe that!The temple has idols of Apsaras (dancers). From inside, the whole premise is not too big, but it is still worthwhile to have a look and appreciate the place. Believe me, not everyone gets this opportunity to visit Angkor!
nice place. u can see amzing place,, so many tourists visit it, i love the lake the surround this place,, it deserves to visit it .

Beautiful. The carvings at Banteay Srei are unbelievable; carved so deeply with the most incredible detail, they really stand out on a sunny day! It is quite a distance from the main temples at Angkor but well worth the journey.

Spectacular. Unlike the massive Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, Banteay Srei is on small scale and has been lovingly restored, especially the detailed work above the doors and the beautiful statues of the monkeys. Many consider this temple the crowning achievement of Angkor artistry.

Beautiful and different to other temples. A little bit out of the way but easily done in combination with a trip to Kulen mountain.
A beautiful and unique temple, definitely worth going!

Interesting and Cool. I would maybe not make this my priority depending on how much time you have, but it was different than a lot of the ruins that we traveled to in terms of the color. It wasn't as large or massive in scale and it was a bit of a ways out traveling.

Beautiful Pink Temple. Even though this temple is a little further to get to, it is still well worth a visit. The overall colour of the temple is pink-ish, making it beautiful to look at. Eating/drinking/toilet facilities have been placed near by, making it a visit to this temple a very nice experience. You can make a nice day by visiting Kbal Spean and Banteay Samre, which are near this temple.
Amazing carvings. I love the details on the carvings. I also like that its pink. Some visitors do not adhere to the sign against touching the carvings.
Calm and serenity. Calm and serenity in this temple situated a bit outside of the main angkor area, certainly worse a visit together with the River of 1000 lingam on the same day.

Interesting carvings but too far of a drive. I expected more but this was not a very big temple and very far out (30min drive). The carvings were intricate and somewhat worth the drive but maybe for day 2.

Very Feminine Appearance. It's pink so that alone made it feel very feminine. The designs were also very intricate. The ride felt long (we hired a car) but I can't remember how long it took exactly. It was worth seeing though!

if you e more then 1 day worth a visit. Bit far but if you have more then 1 day you can combine it with a visit of the remote rolous group. It is a temple with a lot of details and you can walk in it for an hour or so. Hire a tuktuk for $ 12,- enjoy the ride and the visit :)
Amazing details. a bit far from the rest of the temples but worth a visit. the artwork here is preserved a million times better that in any of the other temples.

Worth the 45 minute tuk-tuk ride. Gorgeous - beautifully intricate carvings. And the temple grounds are very well preserved - and bathrooms are not bad at all. If you can afford it I would rent a car just for that leg of the trip because the tuk-tuk ride is a bit long and takes a chunk out of your day - 45 mintues one way.

Just Magnificient.. Having taken a day off to just visit the temples outside the tourist trail of Angkor temples, this one came as a pleasant surprise. What made it more interesting was the fact that there were absolutely no tourist when we went there. Felt like we had the whole temple to ourselves.
Too crowded. Too much visitor during my visit,squeeze like sardin during my visit. Temple is beautiful, just dislike the crowd,made me unable to view and snap photo properly.
fantastic sandstone carving. This temple is a little further out, but well worth the trip. The carvings in sandstone are very well preserved and well worth the visit.

Beautiful and graceful temple. It's small but the most beautiful of the 6 temples we visited. Very apt as it's the fortress for women.
Best to wear bright colors for photography purposes hehe. Bright garments such as aquas and greens complement a beautiful background of reddish soil and gorgeous temple.

Like a jewel. Banteay Srei has been always considered the most "artistic" temple of Angkor. It actually is a small jewel.
Sin e we have stayed here in previous times, we realky appreciated the new stilying of the acess to temple. It gives a furher value to tis small temple, at about one our from the Angkor temples.
Go by tuk tuk!

Absolutely magnificent. Take time to explore this beautiful temple. Yes, its smaller in size but absolutely grand in its complex artistry and beauty! A wonderful treasure... you will only have regrets if you miss this site!

Worth it. Banteay Srei is a little far from other attractions in Siem Reap but it is worth it. The temple is very different from any other that you might see in Siem Reap. The color combination is very unique and amazing. You will need one ahour to get there from Angkor Thom (stopping in some temples on the way there) and once there plan for 1 hour walking around and enjoying the magnificent place.

Intimately gentle, feminity bubbles to the surface here. Its a hour or so drive from Siem Reap, so be prepared - stop for a cold coconut and hang with some locals? What a delight - gentle and softer in every respect this temple is smaller and perhaps in the best condition of all the temples as many of the wonderful carvings still survive. Smaller doorways and narrower walkways, you feel softer after a visit. Maybe an Ipod to keep you in your meditation and keep that pilgrimage going. Do change some $ into local Riel to give to the many poor kids and really have a all round wonderful time~!

Enchanting Pink Temple. We went to Banteay Srei on our 2nd day. The morning we spent to watch the sunrise in Angkor Wat and trekthe grand circuit temples. The afternoon we spent to visit Banteay Srei, then sunset in Phnom Bakheng.After lunch with Sokha our cool driver, we went to Banteay Srei, an hour drive from Siem Reap. I love this long drive with our tuktuk. Plenty to see along the way. I noticed how each Cambodian home is usually in stilts, the space below always with a hammock. Locals love hammocks; we do to in the Philippines. Along the way, we passed by the Angkor Butterfly Garden and Landmine Museum though we gave these places a miss. It’s a monastic complex, therefore it’s flat. Nonetheless, the exquisite carvings make it stand out among the temples in Angkor. Every surface is so detailed. Its pink sandstone and the monkey statues giving an Indian scent make it so unique. The music played by a local group sets a magical mood while strolling around the temple. An hour is enough to explore the exquisite Banteay Srei so we were able to get back to Siem Reap before 3pm.

Oldest and yet still standing. Thanks to the Apsara Foundation to keep maintaining the oldest temple of pre Angkorian. The temple reminds me of Lembah Bujang in Kedah,Malaysia as both have similar materials in contruction.
My favorite temple. This is the Temple of Women. The colors in the late afternoon are stunning, and it is so small compared to others. Truly beautiful.

A jewel box outside of Siem Reap. This is totally worth the time to visit. Until recently, this area was unreachable due to landmines. The temple is made of pink sandstone with delicate carvings, and is a beautiful example of Khmer architecture. Our guide told us that the interior of the temple would be closed to the public sometime in the next couple of years due to the tourist threat to the carvings (after watching several people climb all over it, I think this is probably a good idea). After that, people will only be able to view it from outside the walls- still worth it, but not the same.
Pink Temple. Beautiful temple with fantastic carved stone reliefs, we were giving a tour by the chief of police for the local area which was fun.

a bit out of the way, but worth the visit. Its charming and lovely spot - such a delicate temple, even if you have been sightseeing for 3 days, this one is well worth the hour tuk tuk rive to get there. And its a lovely countryside drive along the way ....Plan to get there at 0700, you will have the place to yourself ...great images of the temple relfected in its little moat, and the carvings are the best in all of Angkor Wat complex, there are nice surrounding jungle paths too.

Charming and Delicate. This temple is a 40 minute tuk tuk ride from the Angkor area but we did not mind because we saw the scenic countryside on your way to Banteay Srei. This temple is smaller in comparison to the ones in the Small and Grand Circuit but possesses a unique charm because of the pink sandstone and intricacy of the carvings. Once we walked through the temple, we trekked though the dirt path and saw this global view platform that will show you the temple at a vantage point. You will also see trees that are sky-high and rice paddies on your way. I am thankful that these temples are well restored and we are able to witness this kind of historical structure in the modern times. It is a must-see and really worth the trip.

nice carvings but not so much to see. we didn't catch it at its best.... 10 mins in the rain! the carvings were really wonderful, but the compound is quite small and the tourist center and carpark lead you to believe there is a lot more there than in face is actually the case.

Cute little temple - Amazing carvings. This is a masterpiece merely for the amazing sculpture that the temple has. Unlike other Angkor Temples, it is not huge in size, but very cute. It was a hindu temple, and you find several plots of Indian mythology engraved on the temple. Banteay Srei is about 35 kms from Siem Reap, but worth the time.

far out, but worth the visit.. After seeing temple after temple, this one was a breath of fresh air. The tuk tuk ride out was through beautiful countryside and villages. The temple is small, but with ornate detail. We went right after watching the sunrise over Angkor Wat and beat most of the buses. Worked out well.

Small temple but very different. Although Banteay Srei is a very small complex, the construction makes it worth the trip out to contrast with the temples around Angkor Wat. I recommend hiring a local guide to help you appreciate the differences between the sites in terms of the construction methodology and the architecture, carving and history. The guides we had really brought the temples alive.
Intricately beautiful. Like the reddish colour of the stones and the intricate carvings. So detailed and makes the temple different from the rest of the temples. Worth the time visiting!

The lady temple. Banteay Sreis has some of sthe most intricate stone carvings in the world. The quality of the work still shows through now, even after almost 1000 years of ageing, with the glowing pink hued stones showing incredible 3D detail stone carvings. The site may be small but it is well worth spending a few hours truly exploring the carvings and looking at the ingenious old drainage systems in place (there are diagrams and some of it has been re-engineered in recent years). A phenomenal site, that has been given a lot of well worthy attention in recent years, making it all the more worth the while taking a 45 min ride out to it!
Beautiful temple. The temple is not too big but it is beautiful and the landscape to go there (it is 37 km away from Siem) is awesome. If you have time, dont miss it!
The little pink ruin. This ruin is highly carved and petite. I could not believe the detail. It is a bit farther than the other ruins, but well worth the trip.

Long way out but worth trip. The scale is easier to manage than other temples. The carvings are beautiful. The site is very well organised for parking and walking round. There is a nice place for drinks on the site and we enjoyed the walk through the grounds which they are laying out very well. On way back we stopped at The butterfly farm -well worth seeing as a social enterprise.

Worth the trip. We took a lovely trip out to Banteay Srei on our tuk tuk, through the Cambodian country side. The temple has been beautifully restored and has a really well laid out tourist trail round it.

Best carving in the area. Visit to siem reap will not complete if you not visiting this temple.The finest carving they had among other tamples, worth your time to visit and if your are into photography, DO NOT MISS this one!

The best example of carving in the area!. This was by far my favorite of all the temples we visited in the Angkor area. The carving is exquisite and the pink limestone used is very unique. I also liked that this is the only temple dedicated to women and as our guide said: "it is small like the Cambodian woman."
Smaller Temple. The carvings were great and the History center tells about the era. It was a little far away from town to visit but it was worth the trip

Travelling with an Infant - Good but a lot further north than I thought. We travelled with a 15 month old. We had her in a back pack. We bought the 3 day pass, enabling us to use the ticket on any day within the week (from purchase). Cost $US40 each.In the 3 days we visited:Day 1: Angkor Wat and Banyon Temple (4 hours total from the point we left the Hotel to the point we returned)Day 2: Preah Kahn and Ta Prohm (4 hours total from the point we left the Hotel to the point we returned)Day 3: Banteay Srei, Butterfly Museum and Landmine Museum. (5 hours total from the point we left the Hotel to the point we returned)We hired a car to take us (Day 1 = $30, Day 2 = $30, Day 3 = $40)A very different temple with very elegant carvings. We enjoyed seeing it but probably would have avoided had we not wanted our daughter to see the butterflies (which se loved).If I was doing it again I would have left the hotel each day at 6:30 to avoid the heat and tourists.

Nice place to avoid the big crowds. Banteay Srei is far enough from Siem Reap that not everyone makes the journey. Still a very nice and unique ruin with intricately carved sandstone everywhere. Not like any others in Angkor. We rode our bikes from Siem Reap and it made for a nice day. Plenty of decent restaurants at the site to have lunch.

Built by not by kings but the carvings are more detailed. I would defitely include this temple as a must-see in Angkor. Not built by kings but by royal familes and dedicated to Shiva and Vishnu by half and half. A pity is that you are not allowed to go into the temple complex core area but from outer view you can still a lot. Though it is quite a bit of the Angkor park the ride is worth. You can also combine this with a ride to Phnom Kulen (it is on the way), the holy mountain where all Khmer civilization had it roots.

My Favorite Temple. Unlike the Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, and Ta Prohm; Banteay Srei is small...It doesn't overwhelm you. However, it's really pretty and beautiful. True to its name, Banteay Srei - Citadel of Women, is really a feminine temple.

Shiva Temple. Being a Hindu myself, gave me an insight on how Hinduism spread to far off countries and still exists in some of these places is unbelievable, with the sheer beauty of this temple, you get lost in a time warp

Nice carvings on the walls. Go early. Small temple so tends to be very packed. Take your time admiring the carvings and taking pictures. If it is not to pack they will allow you to go up to see the carvings in the restricted area for a small fee.

Worth taking the drive. This temple is further away from the main Angkor site (if you hire a car + driver it will cost an extra $15) but is well worth it as it is a beautiful temple in a lovely setting. It is made of pink stone while most of the other temples are grey. Take a guide book as there is very little info at the site itself. There are food stalls and other traders by the parking area.

It is absolutely worth the trip. We visited this temple on our first day. It is well up north (I believe like 30km) from Angkor Wat and the other main temples, but it is absolutely worth the ride. The level of detail in the carvings is unparalleled and not seen at any other temple in Angkor. The color of the sandstone is pinkish and specially later in the day the light gives the place a very warm exposure. It is not big, but this is more than compensated by the abundance of detail.....

Beautiful. Beautiful carvings! Very delicate and intricate. Unfortunately, very small and very popular. At peak hour, you can only see other tourists... Come late in the afternoon (after 4PM) when the tour groups have rushed off for sunset. It has no shade so avoid in mid-afternoon.

Don't forget the expo. A gorgeous little temple. Not as big as alot of the others which makes it a bit more accessible. They also have a little expo with pictures and details on how it was found and the restoration process, we thought this was great.
Good temple but no my favourite. this temple in good but there is too many people, try to get there very early and you will se the difference.
Worth the special trip. Worth seeing it, as it was finer carvings than other temples. Now that it has been opened for public, give it a try. We really enjoyed the fine details!

Banteay Srei. The carvings are by far the best. It is far out of town and the size is smaller than most other temples. The ride to the temple through little towns was interesting but tour buses were ripping through the tiny roads. The welcome center there has the most official feel of any of the temples. You can not get as close to the center of this temple as it is roped off.

Beautiful, Intricate Carvings. This temple was absolutely beautiful. Perfectly cut pink stone. If you love carvings and perfectly cut stone than you will love this temple. The reason I am not giving it 5 stars is that it is such a small temple for such a long drive. We were in this temple for less time than it took to get there and back. If you have the time, don't miss it. If you only have one day, you are better off spending it closer to the site.
Amazing Khmer Art. The most exquisite and astoundingly beautiful Hinduism carvings we've seen amongst the Angkor temples.

Pink sunset. Got here i time for sunset. It sent shivers through me as the already pink stone of the beautiful temple of the goddess became even pinker and deeper and fabulously serene. Thank you to the guards who let us in to those sealed off areas. I know we made you $5 richer, but we, too, became richer from the experience!
Nothing special. It wasn't as breathtaking as the Angkor temples - I didn't feel it was worth the distance.

My favorite. His temple was originally designed for Shiva and the tuktuk driver called it the "woman's temple". We loved the drive out there which gave us an opportunity to see villages and countryside along the way. We were surprised how many tourists were there, bit it was possible to find quiet places. The intricate carving is wonderful and the pinkish color different to the other temples. Well worth a visit.

The most exquisite carvings in pink sandstone. One of the smaller temples in terms of footprint, but ranks near the top of my list. The pink sandstone carvings on the walls and arch ways are exquisite! The intricate and finely-detailed carvings make Banteay Srei one of the more beautiful temples there is... And there are a lot of them in Siem Reap. Found out this is older than Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. Long drive to get to this remote temple -- a little over half an hour by tutktuk -- but you get to see the country side and observe everyday life in Siem Reap along the way. The distance is a disincentive to some, so it won't have the coach load of tourists that flock to the larger, more popular spots like Angkor Wat and Bayon, which for me was the bonus as you get to appreciate it more without the large crowds.

Very Small But Very Nice. While not as large as the other sites, our guide added this to our tour and it was worth the visit. Just annoying all the hawkers - especially kids - who pretty much attached themselves to you when you exit your vehicle and when you return. Worth the stop if you are out this way doing the Banteay Samre and TA Prohm

Over-rated. This place comes complete with nice parking lots and a visitor welcome centre, which kinda kill the whole feel of the place. The temple itself was small and a total letdown. Unless you have all the time in the whole, if not, skip it.
Interesting journey there too!. Worth the trip with the road lined with local life and living. Temple has such relief detail and deep colours.

Beautiful temple 35 kilometers outside Siem Reap. We visited Banteay Srei combined with Kbal Spean (walk, waterfall, stone carvings) and went out in the early morning. First buy the Angkor Wat-pass at the ticket boots of Angkor Wat near Siem Reap, as they do not sell those on location (costs USD 20 for one day, USD 40 for 3 days either consecutive or not - indicate clearly what you want!). The temple is not as big as Angkor Wat - naturally - but much bigger than you would expect. Nice stone carving and nice walk through the parc surrounding the temple.
Do not miss!. Beautiful little temple with more intricate carvings then any other in the angkor area, worth doing the trip.

intricate carvings quite a distance outside Angkor Wat. This rather small temple complex stands out of the crowd thanks to its well preserved sandstone wall carvings. It's really quite far out though. I wouldn't say it's a must-see, but if you have the time, it is definitely well worth the ride. I was lucky and arrived at a time when only a handful of people were at the site and could admire the carvings at a nice slow pace sitting in a corner of the complex in the shade. The temple is fenced off quite widely, which is a pitty, because it makes it harder to really admire the beauty of the intricate carvings. Still very nice overall.

Very Informative. The standard of information here is terrific, a lot of the history and meaning of the place set out on information boards. The smaller size makes it easy to get the site in perspective. A bit out of the way but well worth it and it is a nice TukTuk drive out there.
Not bad. I think everyone had overrated this temple. It was a nice pretty temple. A defnite see...but some other temples had more magic to them. The carvings in this temple are beautiful.
My favorite!. This smaller temple is truly my favorite - amazing detail in the carvings and just peaceful. Don't miss it!
I liked it a lot!. It was terribly hot, but I liked it a lot. Small, pink, incredible stone carving.
Lovely. All the temples are different - and amazing in their own right. This one is very pretty, having been carved in pink sandstone. Lots of beautifully ornate large carvings of apsaras.
so girly. it's pink stone... at sunset it's more obvious. It's worse to go there after Phnom Kulen trip as it's on the way to sieam reap.

It was sinking!. The wall is collapsing, the restoration work seems halted. The condition of the whole temple is seem decreasing.Visitor is not allow to approach the best craving of fairy but the only way to see it is by usnig telephoto camera with high zoom power.Lots of Chinese speaking tour guide is giving nonsense explanation compare to our english speaking tour guide. Any certified tour guide trainer can provide some quality control?Where does the revenue from entrance ticket gone, any monitoring from Unesco?
spectacular. after a rainstorm, it was spectacular to observe this temple that is made in an authentic stone filigree. It is worthwhile to leave the perimeter of Angkor to visit this gem.

Another favorite of the ruins. The carvings are quite incredible, besides Ta Phrom, this one is a favorite of mine - and my group of friends. A bit away from the other ruins, but definitely worth the trip!

queen place. The grand tour of Angkor provides entry sites for 3 days at a cost of $ 40 the first day in a photograph taken at the counter where you buy the tickets and therefore will be printed on the ticket to enter / exit the site during the days included in the ticket. We start from a more distant site, about 25km from Angkor, the Banteay Srei, the "City of Women" carved in stone that turns pink when illuminated by the sun (unfortunately we have some rain). Our guide tries to avoid being too large for me to be nicknamed "termites" in order to pause to tell the Hindu mythology represented on the lintels. Much effect because it makes the first contact with these fabulous temples, very impressive

ladies Temple. Is a ruins of a beautiful red color as a feminine name in the ruins smallish compared to other ruins. The number of relief and chiseled Debata known as the "Mona Lisa of the Orient," particularly people. I think its beauty and scale is a small but Angkor. You forget the passage of time and closely watching. Want to see is the ruins of a little more slowly if not tour.
Very nice!. I loved the drive there in the tuk tuk, you can see many rural houses and places and scenery. I also thought the Banteay Srei itself was pretty great! Many carvings and ruins!!!
Number 1. This was my number 1 Temple, not to be missed....The local market was also good for shopping and food.

from where Malraux stole the devatas.. I knew this temple from André Malraux's La via Real. (Famous french poet who stole some statues from Banteay srei in 1923 and got caught. Thanks to him, the temple became known and got a restoration budget a few years later.) Him and his friend Louis Chevasson got prison sentences in 1924. He had his fiancee with him, Clara, but she was found "not guilty." as a foot note: Clara returns to France, asks for favors. Poets and writers including Aragon et Gide write a petition and save Malraux. I wish I had seen this temple first. The road to go there is long but really nice. I took a tuktuk which cost me 18 usd for the day. On the way to return, I visited Ta Som and Neak Pean. (you can visit more but i prefer to see few places taking my time. otherwise they all look similar fater some point) NP. is in my opinion one of the really different temples. Small but interesting. Now back to Banteay Srei. This is a Shiva temple. (Angkor and most others are dedicated to Vishnu). At the entrance there is a lot of interesting information (They explain which ones are devatas, which ones are apsaras etc...) It is said that this is a "2 god temple" since the south is dedicated to Shiva, but at the north you see dedications to Vishnu as well. And Brahma has not been forgotten, i was told. But official guides say that this is a Shiva temple in essence.
I love this place!. I am particularly fascinated about this place. I will visit Cambodia again just because I want to come back and see this place again.

Amazing. Translated it means citadel of woman it is a tiny enchanting temple and is one of the jewels, built of red sandstone in the 10th century and dedicated to the Hindu god shiva this is the most Indian of all the temples in Angkor and is well worth a visit

Go before you not Angkor Wat or Angkor Thom/Bayon. This small red sandstone temple is pretty neat, and the carving is exquisite, but it is so much tinier than some of the large temple complexes that I recommend: 1) getting there really early and 2) going before you see some of the big ones, as you will likely appreciate it more by seeing it early on when your sense of scale is not so warped.

The remarkably preserved carving temple in Angkor. The best intricated carving temple with pink and yellow color sandstone in argeological site of Angkor, I would recommend every body to visit in the afternoon in order to avoid from the crowed as this one is the most appreciation by the majorities of passengers.

Not my favourite temple. This one was perhaps the most disappointing - it didn't look very pink when I was there! It's very small and compared to the other temples, lacked the wow factor for me at least. It's a long journey from the other temples, so plan for that

A bit of a drive. If you are looking for more unique temple look no further! Here is the most intricately carved masonry you will find in the region. Quite stunning. It is a little smaller and not overly reconstructed so in magnitude it is not as imposing though the craftsmanship outweighs that of any other temple in the region. The temple is also made of a different stone than the sandstone you see at the other temples.

gorgeous pink stones. go here either early a.m. or late aft since the suns color temp will illuminate these structures evenmore....this place is small but for me its the best detailed carving style of its era

A little far but you need to go. We had a great guide to visit this place, we went directly to the information center in the middle of Siem Reap and got our guide there, cheap and very knowledgeable guy.This place is a little far away but it is a must see, we had so much fun there, you can go out of the regular tourist trail and really visit what you want. AWESOME!

Intricate Banteay Srei. A bit distance from the city about 35km, took a while to get there , got there about 11am, not so busy.Great. stores had great bargains- cotton 100% scarves(kroma) $3, guidebooks from $5 ,

Delicate and beautiful. .We reached this location after a late lunch and there weren't many people about, probably because it's about 40mins from the main Angkor Wat area. The entry fee, however, is covered within the main 3 day pass we bought for the main Angkor AreaThe site is like a miniature of the larger temples, with a small moat and shortish walls. The stone used here is distinctively reddish pink and apparently softer than that used at temples like Angkor Wat, thereby allowing the artisans to carve the reliefs in much greater detail and delicacy. Much of the carvings are in very good condition and as with the other temples, are Hindu myths and stories told in stone. The central portion of the temple was cordoned off but what can be seen from outside is well worth it.As befitting this delicate masterwork, the temple had the best visitor reception area amongst the temples I visited. Do check with your guide what would be the best time to visit when the site is less congested, so you have more time to enjoy these intricate carvings.

Beautiful carvings. For a lot of people, Banteay Srei is the most beautiful temple within the Angkor Archaeological Park. It is a relatively small temple full of exquisite carvings. The carvings are very detailed and really beautiful.Also quite crowded, even off season.
One of my favorites. Lovely temple. I enjoyed walking around and seeing the carvings
Worth the trip.. According the map this temple is 37km of the main complex, but it sure is worth the trip.This womans temple has the richest carvings and it's red color makes it even more prettier.

Walk Lots. We hiked for approx 5hrs all up for this day and 3 temples later
Good walking shoes are the key to completing this day and a lot of water we had 3l each in camelbacks both were empty by the end of the day
One of the three manin ancient attractions. A must see. Tour guides wil take you there. Don't miss it.
The best carvings. This temple is a bit far and it cost $20 for the tuk tuk but this temple is unique and the trip to get there is splendid. .

A gem of a temple. Pink stone carvings, best of all in Siem Reap.
Dont miss the temple but you should try to miss the hordes of tourists as the temple is small and area limited.

Shiva temple made out of rose coloured sandstone. This elegant but small Shiva temple is located about 37 km. north of Siem Reap. I combined my visit to this place with that of the temple of thousand Lingas as both are situated on the same road. This is small temple but with magnificient lace like designs and carvings above the panels of entrances. The fine and intricate details on the figures called Apsaras is truly admirable. The rose coloured sandstone perhaps adds glamour to the extremly detailed carvings on panels and pillars. It is a wonder that this monument had withstood the extremes of the elements for hundreds of years and still appears in pristine condition. A place well worth the visit. Another fine monument for your travel photographs. There are many stalls selling food and reasonably priced souvenirs near the entrance. An entrance fee US $20 is charged. (Included in your day pass for Angkor Wat) It opens very early in the morning at 0500hrs and closes at 1800 hrs.

Add it on your'e Itinerary. The place is quite far from from Siem Reap or Angkor area, and you must add a little more $$$ for the trip, yet its very worth visiting, here you can see the best stone carvings on the temples and you'll appreciate more the history and the craftsmanship of the Khmer people during their era.

Beautiful Temple. Small but beautiful. The bantey srey or citadel of women temple is the most beautiful temple in the Angkor. I love the deep sandstone carving. this temple is so famous make this place never empty with tourists from both local and foreigners.

Intricate carvings. Banteay Srei means Citadel of Women and is 23 km north of Angkor Wat. It is a beautiful low red sandstone Hindu temple with intricate relief carvings. Surprising it has been well preserved. The intricate carvings depict scenes from Hindu tales. Lotus flowers in the ponds fronting the temple add to the beauty of the place.

Beautiful set of temples. One of my favorites in the area. About an hour's drive away, but well worth it. Beautiful red brick/rock. The detail is finer than most of the other temples. Beautiful reflection of the temples in the moat. Try to get there when the busloads of tourists aren't if possible, as it is small, and can seem a little overun when too many tourists are there. Don't miss if possible. I would include it in the top 4 (Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Phrom, Banteay Srei).

A master piece in architecture. It is one of the oldest monument,probably in the 10th century built by the Hindu kings.the beauty of the temple is the intricate carvings of the temples.so amazing one shd spend hrs looking@the fine works.One shdnt miss the truncated Bull in front of the main temple,which is proff enough that the temple was the abode of Lord Shiva.Srei is derived from Shri in Sanskrit..meaning the main deity here was PARVATHI.

miniature temple, with breathtaking carvings. a little out of the way (the taxi driver should charge you about 10 USD more for this.), but another MUST SEE at siem reap.
a miniature temple in red sandstone, dedicated to the hindu god SHIVA, with amazing intricate work on the facades

Detail, details details!. It is a little fat but worth the trip if u read about the place first. The details are excellent. Could you imagine The details of the carvings back when this temple was built several centuries ago! This site have a little padi field at the front and a couple of lotus ponds. Make sure to visit the butterfly park and land mind museum while there. Both really worth a visit!Been there and did all 3. Remember to brin your camera

Pink temple. Using different stones than the Angkor Wat. It was built before Angkor Wat (about 200 years before). Unlike many other great temples it wasn't built by a king, but rather a courtier. It's a bit further from town but if you have the time and means this is a place you must visit other than the obvious Angkor Wat.Here you would find that the carvings are incredibly detailed and fine. Very different from the scale compared to Angkor Wat. Angkor Wat was all about being BIG while Banteay Srei was not huge but fine and tiny. Outside the temple there is a place to buy tourist products and some restaurants runned by locals serving food at tourist price. The rolling/roast beef with pepper was particularly good. As well as the curry in the coconut.

Possibly the best temple?. Fairly small and quite a way outside Siem Reap, but well worth the visit. The carvings are fantastic and the 'pink' sandstone gives it a more delicate feel. Even though this is a well away from the main Angkor group, you will still need a temple pass to get in. But it is well worth the trip.
Worth the trip. A long way out from Siem Reap, but well worth the trip.

Stunning detail. The detail of this temple is amazing! Definitely the most beautiful we saw during our visit. If heading out there, travel another 12km and there's a place called the Angkor Centre for Conservation of Biodiversity which is well worth a visit too.

Loved it. We booked a guide in advance to take us to this temple and It was worth the extra effort and trip. What a great place Im so glad we were able to see it, the work involved in this place is amazing I can"t even imagin how long it must have taken and in that heat to creat such amazing art!
amazing art. the most beautiful temple of all of them. you must not miss this one!

"Ladies Temple". This beautiful temple is pinkish in hue. The bas reliefs are beautiful. Meters away from the temple also includes a photo presentation on the restoration done in Banteay Srei which is worth stopping to.

the place where I lost my pride. this is the place where i missed a step and twisted my ankle with some acrobatic moves.....it was so humiliating that I just laughed it off. It didn't stop me from pursuing the place and miss a great view. The place is quite small compared to other temples....but its still an awesome place....just mind your steps ok?

Exquisite, though small. Compared to all other huge temples we saw, this seemed like a doll house at 1st glance & I was wondering if the long tuk-tuk drive to see this was worth it. But it is exquisite in detailing and well worth the visit. There are excellent photo opportunities at this temple - some arched doorways are shorter than humans, making the temple itself more humane.Look out for a stunning bamboo roofed visitors waiting area near the entrance - a fantastic piece of Japanese minilmalistic design

Long trip out of Siem Reap .. but well worth the visit. At the insistence of a friend, we made our way in the morning of our last day in Siem Reap, and it was well worth the trip. Banteay Srei is approximately 38km out of Siem Reap, which means a really, really long trip by tuktuk. Our tuktuk driver highly recommended a stop by Ta Prohm on the way to Banteay Srei, which we took in, but the direct trip back to the city took us almost 1.5 hours by tuktuk. For a return trip, our driver asked for USD22, which I thought was more than fair. On top of that, we gave him a decent tip for being such a stellar fellow (and for having to ride through sun & a short drizzle for 2 x 38km journey without a single complaint.)Banteay Srei is a very, very small complex, but unlike the other temple complexes, Banteay Srei's carvings have withstood the tests of time wonderfully well. The intricacy and delicacy of the carvings are breathtaking. And yes, after three solid days of temple-gawking, temple-fatigue had long ago set in, but Banteay Srei still blew our minds away. All in all, because Banteay Srei was so small, we spent maybe only an hour touring it and taking a stroll around its compound. There were also birdwatching options and a few stalls to have lunch at on the compound, but we opted to escape the sticky noon heat and head back into town for lunch instead.And, to be honest, the long ride out there and back was completely refreshing as well. It was a welcomed difference to see the Khmer countryside and quaint little villages instead of the typical town-and-temples scene. A little extra info:There are lots and lots of basket-weave products available as well as traditional Khmer scarves on sale intermittently along the road to Banteay Srei, which are significantly cheaper than what you'll find in town itself. The Landmine Museum is also on this road, so if you've the time (we didn't) it would be worth it to plan another hour or two into your schedule to stop by for a visit as well.We left for Banteay Srei at 8am and made it back into town for lunch by 2pm (including the time it took us to go to & tour Ta Prohm). Given the hellish heat of the afternoons we had had to put up with the previous days visiting Angkor Wat & Angkor Thom, this timing was excellent for enjoying the temples in the coolness of the morning, having lunch back in town, then heading back to the hotel to cool off over the worst of the Siem Reap heat.

Beauty on A Smaller Scale. This is the smallest temple I have seen in the Angkor area. The foot print is smaller and the buildings are smaller. The carvings are very intricate. This site often feels crowded due to its small size.

Small and delicate. Banteay Srei is a smaller temple but extraordinary carvings adorn every surface of the inner temple. Amazing crafts(woman)ship, as the delicacy and intricacy of the design is deemed too fine for men to have created.

Always mobbed. Our guesthouse owner warned us ahead of time that no matter what time of the day it is, this temple is always mobbed, and she was absolutely right. We went during the hottest time of the day, and still there were too many people. In fact, there were so many, that I did not enjoy my time at all. Of course, I cannot take away too many points from the attraction itself on account of bad people traffic management. Banteay Srei is also known as the citadel of the women or of beauty. It is considered among the finest because of the very delicate stonework that is evident in the carvings. Famous for its pink/red sandstone, this temple is on a miniature scale when compared to all the other temples in the Angkor complex. I personally was disappointed that they roped off the middle section of the temple, so that combined with the mob, it was basically impossible to observe the fine stone work.

Fairy-tale-like. Its a grand, ornate temple in pinkish...miniature. No steps to ascend. Its tucked away in a forest. The sandstone carvings are beautiful! The entrance to the banteay srei compound is the cleanest and most organized of all in siem reap! Also, the cluster of shops nearby have a good selection of souvenirs and handicrafts but at much, much, much cheaper prices than at the angkor area and at the old market in town. For example, silken scarves sold at 3 for 10USD in town could go as low as 4 for 10USD! Table cloths that sold for 10USD at the Old Market were sold for 4USD!!! Be patient and shrewd in bargaining!

Worth the travel. This is my favorite among all the temples I have visited in Cambodia. I loved the intricate stone carvings! We hired a car from Steung Hotel---near pub street and we were charged $40 for the day. The trip took about an hour. Tuktuks are a cheaper option at $20 for the day but the trip may take longer.

Who said it's worth the trip!!?. I decided to visit this temple after reading the review in trip advisor saying it will worth the trip. The trip was about 45 mins from town, 90 mins for two way journey. When I reached there, I expected something spectacular, and I was disappointed.Well, yeah, the stone was rose colored which make it so unique, but the temple is 80% broken. So it's LITERALLY an ancient ruins.Anyway, it was surprisingly good for photos.

Cool temple but far drive. The carvings on this temple were incredible but it was a good 45-60 minute drive outside of Siem Reap. Made from different materials than Ankgor Wat, it definitely looked different and the carvings were well preserved.
long trip out. to be honest, lot of temples, by this time we were templed out. more impressive temples closer to town
Intricate carvings. This temple has intricate carvings that are still very well maintained. But visit early in the morning to avoid the crowds.

My favorite temple in Siem Reap. I loved the intricate carvings. The style is different from the other temples. It is a little bit further out from the other temples but that means it's also less crowded, especially if you get there early.

The Sainte-Chapelle of Cambodian Temples. Just as Notre Dame tends to overshadow the little gem that is Sainte-Chapelle in Paris, it's easy to miss little Banteay Srei. It's a good hour away from Siem Reap by tuk-tuk, and it's smaller size may cause some to skip the temple, but like Sainte-Chapelle, it's amazing. Because it's smaller, so many of the carvings are just above your head and plainly visible. If you go, arrive early before the busloads of tourists overwhelm the site in late morning. We chose to go first thing in the morning, and then followed it up with a visit to Aki Ra's Cambodia Landmine Museum. The grounds surrounding the temple are also well worth walking through.

pleasant tuktuk ride!. although a bit of a drive on a tuktuk it was nice to see more of the countryside and when you get there the temple is not so big but equally as impressive as the others . just make sure you have a good guide to explain it all that makes it more interesting...

Beautiful place... If only it weren't so far from the others!. Banteay Srei (or Women's Citadel) is a beautiful temple because of its amazing intricate carvings. Even if it's far from the other main temples (Angkor Wat, Bayon and Ta Prohm), it's worth visiting.

Great temple in Siem Reap. Banteay Srei or Banteay Srey is a 10th century Cambodian temple dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva. Located in the area of Angkor in Cambodia. It lies near the hill of Phnom Dei, 25 km (16 mi) north-east of the main group of temples that once belonged to the medieval capitals of Yasodharapura and Angkor Thom. Banteay Srei is built largely of red sandstone, a medium that lends itself to the elaborate decorative wall carvings which are still observable today. The buildings themselves are miniature in scale, unusually so when measured by the standards of Angkorian construction.
Beautiful. The intricacies and colour's of Banteay Srei are just quite different to the other temples and are worth going to see.......

Pink, grey and cream. This temple complex was my husbands favourite, the carving is intricate and the stories rich. Get a good guide and take your time. Get a 3 day ticket at the least and take a break from each temple to reflect on the various architectures and design.

Worth the trip out!. This lovely little temple is a great spot to visit, despite it's distance from the main temples of the Angkor complex. This was originally the women's temple so it has some staggeringly intricate and beautiful carvings, as well as extremely well-preserved statues. Unfortunately the inner part of the temple itself was cordoned off for renovations when we visited, but it is still a very pretty place to visit with herds of water buffalo strolling through picturesque rice paddies nearby. The April heat was almost overbearing when we went but there is a restaurant and markets at the site where you can buy a cold coconut or sugar cane juice. An enjoyable experience with some great views of traditional Cambodia on the way out!

Great ride there. This temple is outside the park, but still covered by your pass. The temple is interesting, and the area around it is beautiful to explore. But don't underestimate the enjoyment of a tuk-tuk ride to get there - we saw a lot of countryside and village life that was worth it in and of itself.
Maybe really the most beautiful temple. Wonderful carvings, beautifully maintained and a mystical atmosphere about it, just lovely

The contruction with red sandstone. Banteay Srei was a place dedicated to the worship of the Hindu god Shiva. Apart from being amongst the oldest temples in Angkor, if not the oldest. Although the temple is a little out of the way fro, the main area of Angkor, it's well worth the visit as it's mainly constructed from red sandstone, the colour makes it unique in comparison to the other Angkor Wat temples. The stone was obviously easier to work with as the temple has so many highly-detailed carvings. Though the temple is much smaller than the other ones, I really think that the carvings and colour of the temple make it a very worthy visit.
Beautiful. Very intricate carvings in a pretty pink stone- no wonder its called the ladies temple! A little way out but oh so worth the visit
It was worth the trip. It was good to see all of the different sites around Siem Reap
A womens temple. This is a small temple but one of the prettiest. The colors are great and the carvings very beautiful. I loved every second spent there and recommend it to everyone.

Worth the trek out - unbelievable. My wife and I weren't sure about leaving our hotel at 5am and making the long trek out to Banteay Sri for sunrise, but it was probably the highlight of our trip. It is truly extraordinary, and worth the trip. The cops have a little scam going - if you get there early they will let you into the enclosed area for $5 for 10 minute to take photos. Now THAT'S worth getting up early for!

Great view. Wonderful shady walk up, we went at 3.30pm after advice and glad we did as huge crowds were on their way up as we descended for the sunset which is not til much later but the park closes at 5.30pm ! Don't think they would see much except each other!

The most elaborately carved. Sheer beauty at this Citadel of Women of pink sandstone. This is one of the "smaller" temples. Said to have the most elaborate carvings of all the temples. Check out the lintels. Definitely one of the highlights of the Angkor Park.

Excellent Ruins. The intricacy and detail of the carvings here is exquisite. The scale of the temple is not as monumental as Angkor Wat, but that makes the site feel more intimate and accessible. The site closes at 5:00pm, and if you can work it into your day, go during the last hour. The lighting is softer, as is the heat, and best of all - you'll have the place to yourself as we did.

Worth the Traveling Time. As this place is away from the rest it offers some peace and quiet to enjoy the atmosphere. Tuk-Tuk to here is tough on your back and back-side, but we are oldish and enjoyed the opportunity to observe some of the rural life along the way.
Great. worth the trip, and there are several smaller temples you can visit on the way

Small temple, Great carvings. The Banteay Srei Temple is small but very well preserved its definately worth the journey to the temple its a little further out but the journey by tuk tuk is great through the countryside, you can also take in land mine museum , shooting range and an other few sites in the same day if you are pushed for time as they are all along the same way and can easily be fitted into one day.

Beautiful, intricate carvings but.... My husband and I are still not sure if this temple is worth the trip out to see it. So..Pros1. incredibly detailed and beautiful carvings.2. it isn't crowded.3. It dates back to the 9th C and is the oldest temple.4. Gives you a good 40 minute drive out to the country , so you do get to see how the Cambodians traditionally live and the country side.5. There are great amenities here - clean toilets and nice restaurant.Cons1. There isn't too much of the temple left, only the inner sanctuary is left and you cannot get near it.2.The temple is quite small so the drive out may not be worth it.Hope this helps!

Quaint and Picturesque!. What drew me to this place is its minimal flow of tourists which is advantageous for taking photos (i.e., no people obstructing the view, etc.). Although quite small compared to the other temples, Banteay Srei is as picturesque as it can get. There's also a "nature" walk surrounding the temple so you can enjoy the breeze and feel of the countryside.
Best of all the temples. This is a small temple, but what a gem. Worth the 40 minute ride

Small but well preserved. It is a little further away from Siem Reap but the journey there gives a real feel for the countryside and the temple is well worth the time.Beautiful red sandstone with carvings in a much better condition than at Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom.
my favourite of the temples. a stunning temple made from pink sandstone, the carvings are superb, the temple is small and well worth the visit, it is about 30km away from Angkor Wat but a must see
Don't miss this temple of women!. Take your time to view the many carvings of beautiful women at this very special temple.
Great Temple. This site has some of the best relief carving of the Archeological Park and is well with the 20 km trip out there to see.

far from Angkor Wat but well worth visiting - beautiful!. It takes about 1 hour to get there by tuk tuk as it is about 35km from Angkor Wat. If you buy 3 day pass you just have to go there! It is small but extremely beautiful and no crowds around. Fabulous red/pink sandstone and amazing decorative motives everywhere. Definitely one of the most beautiful temples. Traveling there by tuk tuk ask your driver to stop at Landmine Museum ran by Mr Akira - another place worth paying attention to.
Most beautiful temple site nearby. It took about half and hour ride on tuk tuk to this site. Don't miss it, it has one of the best carvings on display in my opinion. And less crowded too.

See this AFTER Angkor Wat. After seeing Angkor Wat and Bayon the first day, we took the tuk-tuk 35 km to Banteay Srei. Loved it! Completely different from AW, and much smaller. We thoroughly enjoyed the beauty of this one, and fell in love with its intimacy and intricacy. Easy to do in an hour or two, and make sure you stop at one or two of the other temples on the way back. Not many tourists stop at these, and you can scamper all over them. They seem to be in pretty good shape as well.

Must GO!. Visit to siem reap will not complete if you not visiting this temple..the finest carving they had among other tamples..worth your time to visit and if your are into photography, DO NOT MISS this one! :)

A refreshing change.. Once you have 'done the Angkor Wat temples' it is refreshing to see something different. The colours and the intricaies of the carvings / sculptures make this a must see - if only to get some contrast.

Lovely place to visit. Once again we can't stress enough to make sure you have a great guide to tell you all about the temples and the area. Also recommend air conditioned vehicle as it was quiet hot there and to go back to air con in vehicle between temples was fantastic. See our review for Angkor Wat for great review of our guide Voeun Savuth at angkorsavuth@yahoo.com
More intricate carvings than any other temple, worth the drive!. beautiful and less tourists- a little small comparatively, but worth it

Don't forget this temple. This temple is way off from Siam Reap, but very worth a visit. It is very different from the others due to the fact that it is built of pink sandstone, not built by a king, very delicate in its features & very small in size.
Must see!. A lot of ppl skip this temple cause it's too far. But it is ver much worth the ride.Do visit Bantaey Shrei
The ladies temple. Very fine carvings and intricate detail. Liked the scale of the buildings - not too overwhelming

Tiny but best. It is very good temple in Siem Reap with lively caving, it has been called pink temple because the stone is pink and very different from Angkorwat temple and other. it is just only 37 km away from the city center, on the way there you will see a lot of souvenir stores from the local people, they are selling basket, scarf.... the good thing that you will see is sugar palm. if you go in the morning you will see how they make sugar from palm juice.Ps. if you come to Seim Reap don't forget this temple. thanks
Don't miss it!. A little further out but part of the adventure is getting there. Hire a guide and it will mean so much more.
Beautiful. The most beautiful temple. It's small and you need to get there early to avoid the crowds, but go!
Tomb raider type again Brilliant. You really can't describe how awesome all these sites are, we wish we'd had more time in Siem Reap, a week wouldn't be too much
Incredible detail. Temple was small but the detail in every corner was incredible. Definitely worth seeing and exploring. I loved it.

Totally unique and charming....... This temple is only small but very well organised. It has the most beautiful and detailed carvings on all the stonework. The history of this temple is also interetsting with a full exhibition of when it was found and by whom and how some of the reliefs were stolen by a European couple who were caught and the husband put in gaol in Phnom Penh. Fascinating. Even though this temple is quite far it is totally worth it. A trip to this temple can be combined with a trip to the Cambodian Land Mine Museum which is on the same road leading to the temple.

Small but interesting. Our tuk tuk driver asked what we thought of Banteay Srei and the response what 'small but interesting.' He smiled and said that's what everyone says. I'm not surprised, given the size of the temples and structures in and around Angkor Wat. However, what Banteay Srei lacks in size it makes up in complexity and beauty. Banteay Srei is one of the earliest temples being constructed in the early 9th century. Of particular interest for me were the architectural differences and similarities between this temple and future generations. Some things seemed to work and were repeated in larger scale elsewhere, where other structures appeared altered in later temples. The relief work was often very well restored and featured some unique pieces I had not seen elsewhere. I was very impressed by the quality of the restoration of the inner temple, which even had replica statues which allowed us to gain a better image of what it looked like over 1000 years ago. If you go, don't forget to visit the Exhibition Centre. It offers some great pictures on the restoration as well as some history on the Bas reliefs and columns and other architectural structures as they varied between Buddhist sects and as they spanned over years. The whole temple area is surrounded by well landscaped grounds, though the 'nature trails' and botanical garden, are really nothing more than dirt paths that take you back to the exit. From there you have to run the unfortunate gauntlet of souvenir shops and drink stands in order to leave the complex.Its a real trek to get out to Banteay Srei and I would highly recommend a motorized option but however you choose to get their I think you'll appreciate the beauty of Banteay Srei.

Very, very small but the best preserved carvings. I was only here for three days I'd skip Banteay Srei simply because it takes so long to get here and the site is small and quite crowded. I was in Siem Reap for over a week, so I combined this with a couple of other places on the same trip. The intricate carvings are beautiful and I felt my visit was worthwhile, but I'd already seen most of the other temples by the time I made it out here. The site is quite small. I generally take a lot more time to explore than most people and I spent no more than 45 minutes here. Compare that to the hour it takes each way to travel out here. The countryside is lovely to see, although a trip on a tuk tuk can be a little harrowing given Cambodian traffic.

Fourth best place in the Angkor area. Small compared to most of the other places, but twice as beautful! The temples themselves are so much prettier than every other location that you'd be crazy to skip this place. So much more detail and charm than use about every other place. Only Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm are more impressive.
A Great Site. a very nice complex outside of Siem Reap. They have put a lot of work at this site and it shows. Nice facilites, eating, shopping, and a very nice temple site. Worth the visit.

Citadel of Woman. The temple is considered by many to be the highest achievement of art from the Angkor period,The Preservation of the temple reveals covered terraces of which only the columns remain. The whole temple is dedicated to Brahma and was never intended to be used by a king, which goes some way towards explaining its small size. You need to duck to get through all the doorways, The carvings on this temple are fantastic and still very clear, its roof pediments and lintels, are magnificently carved with tongues of flames, serpents tails, gods, demons and floral garlands, truly well worth a visit.
my favourite. it is of incredible beauty, not as busy as the others as it is a little farther away from siem reap.

Complications Galore. Loved the unique sandstone and the exquisite carvings. I'm normally not much into Hindu carvings but the detail had to be seen to be believed. Beware the sellers of a book on Angkor. They are all fakes so don't pay too much. I dont think any orginal ones can be found in Siem Reap.
Day trip. You need to include this in a day trip to other sites to make it worth the tuk tuk day hire of $15

Not my favourite. It is a long way to travel just to see a miniature temple which I cannot walk through but can only admire from the outside. Too many tourists, not worth the extra effort to view this.
female temple. I do like the carving and i dont like some story on the wall and cared -or to visit during afternoon.
Women's Temple. Don't miss this beautiful temple with exquisite carvings.

Beautiful but much smaller than other nearby temples. This temple is about a 35 minute drive from the other main temples like Angkor Wat. It is much smaller and there is no place for you to "enter" the temple and go inside. However the architecture is much more detailed than many of the other temples!
Pretty little temple. More delicate than many of the main temples and very beautiful. Quite many tourists here as well. Go early in the morning!

the best time to see this is finished. After reading about this place,in my guide books I was anticipating a great temple experience, having seeing many other ones in the area. The sight which first greeted me as I arrived by tuktuk was.. a huge modern visitor center, next to an even larger parking lot. I had visions of all those National parks I had seen in the USA when I saw that, and it right away destroyed my feeling of seeing something akin to Ta Phrom. On entering the site proper, at the end of a dirt path, I was greeted with crowds of tourists from the buses I had seen in the parking lot. Trying to get a decent picture that was not filled with heads was impossible. The center of the site was roped off completely blocking any access to it. I enjoyed what I could of the stonework, and tried to imagine the replacement statues as being real ones. The stonework WAS pretty, and I am glad I saw it, but I suggest that unless you REALLY want to see this place, go someplace else.

Temple experience so-so, drive is interesting. Despite the long drive from the main Angkor site (about 40 min.), the temple is pretty crowded. It's in good repair, but the crowds keep it from feeling too special. We actually enjoyed the drive more, which took us through some local countryside where we could see some authentic Cambodian villages.

Isolated temple !. Worthwhile visit even it was a way from Angkor region but our passes still included. It was a women temple that made from pink sandstones with detailed carving. The both things made this temple became very well tourist temple.

Beautiful!. It is believed this temple is built by women, and is often referred to as "Citadel of Women". It's small and easy to explore, but you can't help but admire the elaborate, intricate designs carved on the roof of the temples and so according to our guide, the roof design is often used on expensive hotels and other buildings. It's also different from other temples we've seen because of the pinkish sandstone used.
The Pink Temple. Different look compare to other temples in Siem Reap, the Color of the stone of this temple is red mud when most others is black grey stones, beautiful and unique !

fun day if combined with landmine museum and butterfly center. My tuk-tuk driver took me to Banteay Srei, located about an hour past the main temples, for $19. I’m not sure the trip is worth it for just the temple, but combined with the landmine museum and butterfly center it made for a fun day.“Banteay Srei is considered by many to be the jewel in the crown of Angkorian art” (thanks Lonely Planet). It is cut from a pinkish-colored stone and has many intricate carvings, which makes it interesting to explore. In fact, the carvings are so precise that it is believed that women created this temple.Word of advice:I read that there were a lot of “touts” near the temples but they weren't nearly as aggressive as I though they would be... Until Banteay Srei. This was the only place where it was really bad. There were mobs of kids that swarmed me selling postcards. For more info and photos, check out my blog post at http://growninsouthernground.wordpress.com/2012/03/22/siem-reap-day-4-banteay-srei-landmine-museum-butterfly-center-angkor-balloon/.

Lovely temple but hugely crowded. This small, delightful temple far away from the temple complex is unfortunately hugely popular. Even going early, we were jostled by dozens of tourists and because the temple is so small you really noticed it. If there's any way to see this lovely temple without the hordes then take it.
Make sure you visit this one.... Well worth the short drive. You will not be disappointed. Small, but immense in it's detail. Very impressive compared to a lot of other larger tourist destinations.
Well worth the drive. Visit villages along the way. The carvings are truly amazing, an amazing site.

A definite highlight. We visited this temple on day two of our three day pass. It was undoubtedly the highlight of the day and ranks alongside the Bayon and Ta Prohm as the stars of a brilliant show. Unlike the other temples it was built not by a King but by a Brahmin and, while lacking the royal grandeur - ie huge size - of some of the other temples it more than makes up for it in some of the finest examples of decorative art youll find this side of the Valley of the Kings in Egypt. The sandstone from which it is carved is also very much redder than the others which serves to make this place stand out from the crowd. It is also 35 km out of town and the glimpse of rural life in Cambodia along the way is a treat in itself. A definite must-do.

Detailed carvings !. Got recommendation from our tour guide and read an article about this temple we decided to spend half day to explore Bantey Srei. It was turned out great and very artistic temple with best intricate-d carving adorned on the lintel, pediment and itself pink sandstone.
A litte gem. What a beautiful little temple. Don't mss this one.
Out of the way and delicate. It was away from the main sites, so did not have many visitors. The colors and the carvings were unique. It was a more compact area, so easier to visit. Go in the morning

The Northern gem. The youngest and most detailed, most well preserved of the temples, a bit on the smaller scale then the rest of the temples, a slightly different experience, a must see who come here, not to be missed! An extra 25 kms North, but worth the ride since it is across a characteristic Khmer countryside, a great ride!
Mystical Magic. These temples an ode to the divine feminity were full of exquisite sculpture. Red temples dedicated to hindu gods.

The red temple. Small, but the most detail in the carvings of any of the temples. Incredibly well preserved. It isn't imposing or huge like AW, but it's definitely one to see. Also enjoyed listening to the mine victims who play here, and walking around the forest alongside of the temple. A bit far away (30 min drive from SR).
Very well managed ruin site. spectacular carving on pink sandstone. well managed information centre at the entrance.

Great Temple. I loved my visit to Banteay Srei, it is different from the other temples and had very few other tourists visiting while I was there. It was really nice to just sit inside and try to imagine how it must have been in time gone past.

Stunning carvings and stone. A small temple with incredibly well presrved carvings in beautiful pink stone. Definitely visit during a quiet period. We found the middle of the day good, despite the heat as the morning crowds had dissipated.

Worth the 40 minute drive to get there. This temple is a little further than most but well worth it. It is smaller than the others but the architecture is different. Well worth the visit. You get to see local life in the country on the way. Choose a tuk tuk to get there it is cheaper than a taxi and fun and you get shade and a nice breeze to keep the heat of the day off you. Just amazing
Brilliant carvings. A small temple covered with brilliant carvings in excellent condition although perhaps a long way to travel just to see this.
Small but beautiful. A pocket sized temple in the Angkor complex, it's definitely worth seeing if you have time and have seen all the other biggies.

Well worth the journey out of town. The red stone, the light of late afternoon, the trip out through the villages - it all makes the journey to the "Citadel of Women" worthwhile. The carvings are exquisite and the temple is so compact that it was a nice way to end the day.
