Destroyed by Nature. Many trees have grown through this architectural wonder and destroyed it. But feel free to climb all over it, in and through it! You would never be able to get away with that in the US!
Spectacular. Piece de resistance. Check it out. A highlight, with lovely details, apsaras, buddhas
wonderful bas relief. A bit farther away, but well worth the ride from Siem Reap. The bas relief are the best of all the siem reap temples

It is in the Details. When you tour Banteay Srei, you will not be overwhelmed by the towering hight and scale of the temple like you are with Angkor Wat or Bayon. Instead, you will be swept into a world of detail, as almost every surface has been covered with stunningly exquisite carvings of amazing artistic beauty. This is a temple to be savoured rather then gawked at. With a knowledgeable guide, you will find that there is a story behind this smaller temple, and its artistic beauty. It was the only major temple in Angkor not built by a monarch, but instead by a king's counsellor. Well worth the 25 miles it takes to travel to this wonderful gem.
Feminine. Gorgeous ruins. Well preserved and reconstructed. The detail was fantastic.

Exquisite but Banteay Samre has my vote. The carvings are exquisite but for my money nearby Banteay Samre is much more interesting - fewer people, more to explore: wander round to the far side of Banteay Samre where a large terrace with broken statues gazes out into the jungle. You feel as if you've stepped into another world.

Relatively quite temple with exquisite carving. This 'pink' temple is quite different to the others and worth the trip out of town. Stunning carving and great reflections in the lake surrounding it in the late afternoon sun.
Very colorful site. This small temple is well preserved with amazing carvings and a red color that differs from the other sites. Get there early to avoid the crows.

exquisite carvings. this is said to be the jewel of Ankor. The carved reliefs in the hall of dancers is fine under cut pink sandstone with so much life and movement that they almost come alive and you can feel the music of the dance.
Worth the drive. The temple is older but the carvings are better preserved and much more intricate. I loved it.

Shiva Temple. Arrived this Pink Temple early morning after sunrise at Angkor Wat. Loved and impressed its ambiance atmosphere, unique intricated carvings, art style, pink sandstone and beat out the crowds. We finished Bantey Srei before tour buses arrived. Totally truly amazing.

The prettiest little temple I've seen !. It was small enough that we didn't tire ourselves walking around !
The intricate carving and general style was slightly different from the other temples in the area and some parts were quite well preserved.

Jewel. Visiting here was great. This is one of the first sites which has been greatly restored and the facilities here at top notch. At the front there was a nice market area and also shops selling drinks etc. even though its a bit out of the way from other attractions, I truly recommend visiting here. the best part of it was the trip there, driving through the many rice paddies and farming area. Culture just blows you away.

Farther but worth it. Incredible carvings!. Many people skip this temple because it is not close to the others but our guide (Thy - Cambodian Trails) took us for 40 minutes to see this one at a time when the crowds were fewest. It was an incredible experience seeing the carvings which were much deeper and more pronounced than the others temples. Our guide explained that much of it is because of the type of stone that was used for the various temples. If you have the time, this temple is very unique and must be seen. We recommend Cambodian Trails.

Beautiful Temple...But small and 25 Miles from Town. Worth a drive or visit...If you go early...Do Not...I repeat Do not take a Tuk Tuk...Too far on the Highway...During high season can be quite crowded by mid afternoon.....Check out the villages on the way as a bonus....

Worth the trip and time!. Its a bit further from Siem Reap but definitly worth the visit. The fine sandstone/brickwork is truelly a masterpiece with all the statues. also the nice colours of the temple (red and green) is photogenetic!

Small but stunning. At first i was a bit of a let down, after Bayon and Angkor Wat in scale its much smaller, but the carvings are very fine and much better preserved. When u walk around and perch yourself at corners and gaze u see much more, there is so much detail in the panels, especially if u like carvings and your guide is able to explain the significance of the mythical figures in the panels.There are a lot of shops and restaurants attached to the temple complex so its a good idea to take a break inbetween walk out and have a coffee or a drink and maybe a bite and come back.Again go early as there are lots of tourists in the day...

This was definitely one of my favorites.... Banteay Srei is just beautiful. The intricacy of the carvings in the pink sandstone make this temple one of the most beautiful we visited. Do not miss this temple.

Pink Temple.. Felt impressed about its stunning detailed carvings adorned on the walls, lintels, doorways and pediment of this temple. We were lucky to arrived Bantey Srei at early morning around 7 am and very quiet ambiance so we can absorbed very dept experience and wonderful tours before tour groups arrived.

Small but very nice. It was a bit of a tuk-tuk ride to Banteay Srei, being about 23 miles from Siem Reap, but it was worth the trip. You get to see the countryside and how the people live. That was particularly interesting to me since this was my first trip to Asia. Once you arrive at the temple, you see that it is very different from the ones closer to Siem Reap. The carvings in the temple are really ornate and the sandstone used in this temple is red in color, instead of the gray stone used in other temples. You can walk around a small lake near the temple. There was a small band of disabled musicians. Several of the temples in the Siem Reap area have bands like this. The musicians were injured from mines laid during the Khmer Rouge rule from 1975 to 1979. It is said that several million land mines were laid during this time and many are still there. The tourist areas have been cleared, so it is safe to visit them. Take the time to visit Banteay Srei and you will enjoy your visit there.

visual delight. bantay srei is not in the angkor wat complex, its about 20 minutes away from the other temples but this should not stop you from seeing it if you're in siem reap. its called a ladies temple mainly because (according to our guide) it was built in honor of a woman. of all the temples we visited, this one had the most intricate and beautiful wall carvings. really worth a trip even if it is out of the way.
good trip into the countryside. The temple is not that different to elswhere in Angkor, but we enjoyed the tuk-tuk ride, and the quiter pace, and were pleased that we went.

Women's Temple. This temple is a little further out and the guides and drivers will charge more to take you to this one. It is worth it to go as the carvings are much more pronounced and the color of the sandstone is beautiful. There are many other temples along the way that can be added to this trip.
Far away but not to be missed. The ornamentation of the site is really beautiful. Though it is out of the mains circuits it is worthwhile the effort

Banteay Srei temple best carving in Cambodia. i like this small temple very much, because this temple was built by hard pink sand stone and i see the carving are deep into the stone. the towers and carving are in good condition. Nice to walk around and see from outside of the moat before going to inside of the temple and to see the beautiful view of reflection of towers in moat water. I would recommend this temple to visitors who would like to see the best carving in Cambodia.
The art and the carving still look great. 35km from Angkor Wat, but do not miss to visit this ladies temple ( Banteay Srei
Hot. This is a very touristed place to visit try early in the morning or late at night well worth visiting as it is a different style to the other temles at Angkor

In a word - beautiful. This temple was amazing and so beautiful. I was surprised at how small it was but it's size did not diminish it's beauty. The carvings here are superb and the colour and sculptures are just so different from any of the other temples you'll see in the Angkor province. The information hut is well worth a visit as the photo's and pictures on display are amazing - you can really see the Before and After effects. Well worth the effort to travel to and visit.

Worth the travel out to the temple. Banteay Srei, for me, was one of my favourite temples. It was really different to the others, and also was very well looked after in comparison to the other temples. There is a wealth of information you can read about it, and the art and architecture behind it, as well as photographs etc. I went early in the morning; around 7:30 - 9am, and practically had the temple to myself, besides a couple of small children who followed me around, asking for money. I'd recommend going before 9am, because that is when hoards of tourist buses arrive. Also, combine your trip out here with the Cambodian Land Mine Museum.
Exquisite!. Notthe biggest or the grandest, but surely the most equisite temple.the detail in the carvings, the statues. truly amazing
Shiva temple, ladies citadel as is.... beautiful temple full of secrets. much stones left as puzzle, much to do for the future. as is a truly secretive culture full of elegance and sacred beliefs.

The unbelievably incredible perfection of Banteay Srei Temple. Imagine a pink sandstone temple that looks like a miniature of the real thing, even when you are standing in the middle of it. Located a short distance from Siem Reap, Banteay Srei is a very small temple with intricate carvings, that seem even more incredible when you find out that it pre-dates the incredible temples surrounding Angkor Wat. Best visited very early in the morning (before the crowds arrive) and then to wait for the sun to rise above the trees and bathe the temple in a golden glow.
worth the treck. The carvings what more can one say.There are so many temples but this one is a lot special.

Among the most beautiful Khmer sculptures. This little temple is a gem and is a must, even if it is some distance from Siem Reap. The quality of the decoration is truly outstanding. With it's relatively modest dimensions, the whole complex is easier to grasp than many other temples.Go there by car or tuk-tuk and visit the nearby Landmine Museum as well!
Loved the carvings. I absolutely loved the hundreds of small carvings at this temple. On the downside it is very small which means it can get a bit crowded with tourists

Its a long way to travel but the countryside is most enjoyable. It was another amazing temple but it is a long way out of Siem Reap but if you have the time why not and certainly if you do make sure you visit the Butterfly Centre on your return trip.
The most beautiful. Don't miss this - worth the extra time for the stunning bas-relief

You wont realize how beautiful it is in the crowds. After seeing temples for about 3 days straight, they "do" unfortunately start to look alike and mesh into one giant temple hidden in your memories, thank goodness for photos!This one in particular, stands out. It has a lovely blush colour to the walls and probably, from my point of view, the most amazing carvings you will see in Angkor. So small, so detailed, just so beautiful and telling of the culture. It's a pretty magical place and also pretty romantic; I'd suggest this as a prime proposal place for a woman who can appreciate this kind of thing ;) you might just have a lot of onlookers.We went when it was raining to avoid crowds. Do it, it's even more colourful!I suggest you go when it's not busy (super early or late). Like all touristy spots, they get overly crowded with rude and photo-opp greedy people; it's just not the same getting lost in the artwork when you have some "....". nudging you or basically yelling at you in some crazy language. When you walk in, you'll see lots of stand alone doorframes, those actually have some of the best artwork and some nice Sanskrit... Go to your right to avoid the crowds and check out the lone doorframe amongst some sparse rubble, it'll be worth it. Keep in mind, if you look too interested and hang out there too long, you'll attract groups lol I'm not kidding, it's actually really funny. HAVE FUN!

Absolutely beautiful. Don't miss this temple. It is much more intimate than the others, and in a lovely setting. Allow plenty of time to look at all the intricate carving, which is in much better condition than in other temples.

Cool beauty that stands against time. It's cold since it's close to Phnom Dei, making it a welcome change from Angkor's sizzling heat. Older than Angkor, Srey houses very detailed carvings that are different from Angkor's. There are a lot of spots to induce yourself amidst the ruins.

A LONG WAY FROM SIEM REAP BUT STILL WORTH IT. I visited Banteay Srei after going to Kbal Spean (the riverbed carvings). The journey was quite long (well over an hour on a moto & would be longer in a tuk tuk). Maybe a car might be a better bet for this day? By being so far away from the rest of the main temples, it meant that it was much quieter so I was able to enjoy it more. The carvings were very intricate & beautiful.On the whole, the site seemed to be in fairly good condition (some temple sites had areas awaiting renovation which just looked like piles of rubble!).

Its a long way to go for what it is. Its about an hr and a half ( the ride is lovely) by tuk tuk. The temple is really small and underconstruction. It doesnt help that there are tour buses everywhere so your basically shoulder to shoulder when your inside. it took all of 10 minutes to see the whole thing and was no where near as cool as the closer temples. There is some stuff past it like a waterfall that would make it worthwhile for a quick stop off but not worth the time b y itself

A bit far.... A little out of the way, particularly if you are travelling with a young adult/older teen who isn't terribly interested in the archeology/art. It wasn't our favorite and we would have been just as happy had it not been visited.

Spectacular on a small scale.. Unlike the massive Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, Banteay Srei is on small scale and has been lovingly restored, especially thedetailed work above the doors and the beautiful statues of the monkeys. Many consider this temple the crowning achievementof Angkor artistry. It's about 45 minutes out of Siem Reap on agood road. Rumor has it that it was designed by a woman and that accounts for its beauty.
Beautiful. this is a small temple, but the color and carving make it very unique.
one of my favorites. Loved the detailed intricate carvings. The color of the red stone helped too.
Great. the temple truly reminds me of Indiana Jones the movie, what can i say truly a beauty :)

Worth the Drive. Beautiful, ornately carved pink stone and few tourists compared to Angkor Wat and "Tomb Raider" temple. A drive, but interesting to see villages along the way. You can stop and see women making palm sugar and try a bit of palm sugar candy, very much like US Southern praline.

less travelled, but not to be missed. The details visible there were more complete than many of the larger wats and the crowds were a lot less dense. It was actually the first of the temples we visited and are glad that it was since it doesn't blow you away in terms of scale as Bayon or Angkor Wat will, but don't skip it...consider starting with it!

Beautiful temple. One of the prettiest temples in the Angkor area. Small but very well preserved. Well worth the hour by tuk-tuk to get there. I visited the Butteryfly center and the Land mine museum in the same trip, which makes it a nice half day tour. Try to get to the temple early before all the buses arrive. It was crowded when I left, but almost no people there when I arrived at 8.30 AM.
amazing. long way to go in a tuktuk but worth it. we really wish we had spent longer in Siem Reap, a week would have been good to have one day on, one day off

A little away from the City but extremely rewarding. These temples are slightly different from the main temples with a style that is very distinctive but it is highly recommended. The remains are sparse but very well put together. The clour of the stone is different from the other Angkor temples and again makes for great photographs. You will have wonderful photographic memories of your Siem Reap vacation so make sure you have a good camera.
Citadel of Women. The temple is really amazing! And I like the info board outside the temple where they mentioned the period and what buildings build at that period. Very educational.
Loved it. So peaceful if you get there early, otherwise there can be bus loads of people wandering in and out of your photographs..Take a picnic! It is quite far out.

Pink not grey. Quite small compared to the big temples of Angkor and is constructed with a pinkish sandstone instead of the gray stone used for the big temples. The stone is finely carved to a highly intricate level of detail. The name, which translates "citadel of the women", is assumed to mean the carvings were produced by women rather than men

Delicate and beautiful. Love the intricate stone carvings and the music produced by the land mine victims in the background. It is very small, so take your time, do not rush. We found that people were very patient giving each other the opportunity to take undisturbed photos

The best of all the temples!. In our two day tour within the Angkor ruins, this is by far my favourite temple. It is unlike any of the others and the fact that is pretty far from the rest of the temple area means there are less tourists here, and that means peace and quiet for enjoying the magnificent carvings of Banteay Srei! :)

You must see this, allow some time. A great temple a bit further out than the rest so allow some time but the carvings are insanely detailed and skilled. The best example of relief carvings in Cambodia

worth your 1hr travel time, especially combined with other stops. Beautiful, well-preserved temple. Some intricate carvings that you can get up close and personal with and some great views of the temple's major structures as you're leaving the temple itself, and preparing to walk back to the parking lot/food/souvenir area. I went fairly early (mid-morning), and it was only a little bit crowded, not bad at all. Also, as you leave, the food price is negotiable; as I was leaving I said no thank you to a girl showing me a menu for her family's food area, and the price of the pancakes immediately dropped from $4 to $2, which I couldn't say no to. Also, in the souvenir stores, even after negotiating the price of my handful of scarves down, I was sad to learn that the scarves could be bought for less money at the Landmine Museum (which is on the way back to Siem Reap)...and though I like to shop a little bit from many different people when I travel, I would have much rather the money have gone to the Museum, which not only helps with demining Cambodia, it also takes in orphans. On my way back from Banteay Srei, I stopped first at the Landmine Museum and then the Butterfly Museum, both are quite small (could run through them in 15minutes, could spend an hour at each), but I feel a great use of time, and it breaks up some of the monotony of the somewhat long (though beautiful) trip.

Go early to avoid the crowds. We thought we had cracked it by arriving at 10.00 but wrong! the world had obviously decided to visit that morning so go even earlier if you can, though bear in mind its an hour's car drive (even longer in a tuk tuk) from the centre of Siem Reap. Still a lovely temple though - called the women's temple as the carving is so delicate and so intricate that it is difficult to believe a man could have fashioned it. It is beautiful in the sunlight - made of pink standstone. The crowds make it difficult to walk directly to the entrace but there are places to view and take photos to the right of the main temple which are not so crowded. Fortunately, the heart of the temple is roped off so it is possible to stand and take photos without interruption. well worth the trip out of Siew Reap.

The Ladies Temple. Widely recognised as the model for the much larger Angkor Wat this temple is in magnificent repair. Its reliefs and general condition is exceptional. A beautiful place to visit and highly recommended Evn if you do feel "templed out" tis on is certainly worth the effort, it will be well rewarded.

The pink wonder. This is a distance away from everywhere else but well worth the visit, it is often the guides favourite place, quieter and wonderful carvings, there is a serenity about the place, very special and not to be missed.

Small but beautiful. We combined our visit to Banteay Srei with a trek up to Kbal Spean. We travelled via tuk tuk which was just fascinating, observing the village life and seeing the little children on their way to or from school was lovely. They all smiled and waved, very heartwarming. Back to Banteay Srei, you cannot enter the temple but you can go around the outside and as it is small it is definitely worthwhile. The carvings are very ornate and quite beautiful. Make sure when you leave don't go the way you came exit to the right and you get nice views of the temple with a reflection in the water (obviously if the weather permits). It had signs up saying your shoulders should be covered but people had singlets and sleeveless tops and it didn't seem a problem. Out of respect I think it is good to dress appropriately though it was incredibly hot they day we were there. It is definitely worth visiting this one.

Banteay Srei. Pink sandstone ruins. Pretty and pleasant to look at. Very popular, so get there early if you don't want other tourists in your pictures. There's also very little shade, so an early start will keep you from touring while the sun is high in the sky. It's far from town, but that's a good thing actually. You get to see the Cambodian countryside.

Really enjoyed this temple. Bantay Srei is a bit of a drive but well worth the extra effort. The attention to detail and pristine state of this temple are impressive. Highly recommend making this part of your itinerary.
Worth the trip out. Well worth the early rise and longer trip out to see it

Worth the trip. And I say it's worth the trip because the trip out and back is a trip in itself. Situated about 38 km from Siem Reap it takes about an hour by tuk tuk. Wouldn't do it any other way. Go in a tuk tuk to get up close and personal with the villagers along the way. Banteay Srei has changed significantly over the past three years in that that have a very modern visitor center now with walking paths throughout to add to the experience. The temple itself is not very imposing but the carvings are indescribable. Can get a bit crowded and difficult to move around at times but nothing serious.
Must see. As I have stated in my previous reviews all the temples should be visited.
One of the best places in the complex. Although not near Siem Reap this is a place you have to visit. It has one of the best red stone carvings in the world! Amazing!

Far, far away... Well, it is ok, I guess... the thing is: although it is a beautiful temple, very well preserved and all, it is close to wonders such as Bayon, Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm... so having to travel, yes travel, for almost one hour to see it, makes it a bit of a disappointment...
A bijou. An absolute jewel of a temple, small but perfect. Welll worth a visit

lovely and different. the best part of this was seeing all the intricate details and there were a lot of stories played out in the art that our guide - Mr. Thy, from Cambodian Trails, was able to talk us through. He's great!
Great intricate carvings. The best carvings in Angkor by far - very intricate, well preserved and the stone colors were amazing. Well worth the longer trip out of town.

Exquisite carvings. A little further away from Siem Reap and requiring a car or taxi (although some people do struggle out there in tuk tuks), Banteay Srei has exquisite carvings in a rose tinted stone. The site is compact and well organised, and there is a small market adjacent to it for those wanting to buy souvenirs.
Red sandstone Temple. Beautiful carvings here and the red sandstone makes it look quite beautiful in the late sun.

Prettiest of the all!. A smaller temple a bit outside the smaller circuit, but definatly worth it! Intricate cravings with a lot of detailes, really preserved area and not as many tourists as on the other temples.
Surprisingly different. We had visited most of the temples during two visits to Siem Reap. This one proved to be refreshingly different - a temple in miniature. Highly recommended.

Interesting break from the main temples. We went here on a day trip along with Kbal Spean. It was an enjoyable break from the main Angkor temples. The temple and the carvings were better preserved and it was nice. I wouldn't go out of my way if I only had a day or two, though.

Compact artistry. What a great temple to visit. Small and easy to do in a few minutes or an hour if you want to sit and check out the craftsmanship. The cobble stones are a bit difficult to navigate for senior citizens, so take it slow.

Don't miss Banteay Srei while in Siem Reap!!. This was built nearly 200 years before Angkor Wat and is completely awe-inspiring. An art class could spend days studying here because the carvings in the wall are more like 3-dimensional carvings than just drawing. The talent that existed in that culture over 1,000 years ago is incomprehensible...like an entire city of Michelangelo's all working together on this amazing creation. I suggest doing as much reading and research as possible before you go on the "Banteay Srei" era of art, if you have time. Give yourself enough time to take it in and get there early enough to avoid the crowds.
Most beautiful. This is the best of the sites , most intimate and most beautiful carvings. Lovely sandstone, well preserved

An excursion into the country. This temple is included in your Angkor Park ticket and only costs an extra $5 to pay to the driver even though it is 37 km out in the country. It provides an opportunity to see something of the countryside and you can stop at the landmines museum to get an insight into Cambodia's experiences. The development at the shrine is quite new and the facilities are good. The temple is small and intimate and if you have the time (it's a half-day excursion) then I would recommend it.
Detailed Carvings. This Temple had the most detailed carvings out of all the temples we saw. It is a small temple but it is well worth the time to see it and appreciate the intricate carvings.
See this one first.. After visiting the Ankgor National Museum, see this temple next. It is the best preserved temple that is smaller than the rest and a good visit to set the stage for the big ones.

Miniature Temple. If you want to have pictures of you looking bigger than the temples, this is the temple for you. The temples are reddish to pink in color and even the soil are different. Travelling from the gate to this temple though would be a challenge because it takes 45 minutes at least to reach it depending on your mode of transportation.
a little out of the way but worth it!. this temple is about an hour drive by tuk tuk from the city but it is worth it.
Good temple. have excellent artworks but is somewhat out of the way, popular temple

Great but too crowd at time... Been there numerous times. Each time, less accessible. First time we went, numerous years back, we were able to touch and be closer to the artworks on the wall. Agree it's for the better to protect it against the ignorant tourists. Now there are roping areas with directions to walk with the massive crowd. Too many tour groups all at once..

Detailed and refine carvings. Next to Angkor Wat and Preah Vihear temple, Banteay Srei is another favorite for me. Although the temple is very small, the carvings are exquiste and refine. The worksmanship of the temple was amazing and it surpasses other temples in the area. The figures depicted on the wall are vivid and one could see the emotions on these figures. A must visit if you are in Siem Reap (a 40-mins ride from Angkor Wat).

The temple which has the nicest details and a really nice color !. It worths to be seen. If you do it by yourself you need to rent a car with a driver. It is really too far to take a tuk tuk... you will be more on the road that to enjoy your day. This temple is the nicest one and the only one wich wasn't built by a King. Really well preserved. It was the 1st temple to be renovated in 1930's. Thanks to this success, they decided to renovated the others temples as Bayon, Ta Prohm... Its color is really nice, not "grey" like the others but "orange-pink". If you like take pictures, you will like to go there. Be aware that it is a small temple. Don't expect a big one like Angkor Wat or you will be disappointed. You also need to know that you can not enter inside, you will walk along it.

Pink. This place is a truly a ladies delight. Truly the person who thought of making it appealing for the women folk did a very good job. The design set in Hard red stone (which looks more Pink) is a pleasure sight to the eyes.

Highly decorative but the most 'touristy' of the sites. These were compact, beautiful temples and carvings. It is a little unfortunate that they are more of a 'touristy' feel given the gates and gits shop feel of them but they are well preserved and looked after so sometimes this is the balance in order to ensure that. Not touristy but out in the same direction is the River of 1000 lingas which provides a great opportunity to travel out into the countryside by tuk-tuk (dont do it by car, this way you feel much more in touch with your surroundings). Then you get to walk up the trail a couple of km's through the forest and to the river. On sundays locals hike up with picnics and enjoy splashing around in the river. A lovely, worthwhile trip.

Beautiful and on a more appreciable scale. I heard again and again that this is a beautiful temple, and it is. Even after seeing Angkor Wat, Bayon, Baphon and others, this temple stands out. Well worth the trip out.

Intricate and beautiful. I loved the intricate carvings and the stories behind them. Make sure you have a Temple guide book. Skip the guide for this trip. It is a bit out of the way, and therefore quieter.
Be spiritual...take it in.. Go early before the crowds and don't miss the visitors center, it's fantastic if you want to know more. Also visit the rice paddies behind the temple...
Beautiful temple. Amazing stone carvings. Try to get there around lunchtime after the touristbuses have left for the day. Combine with a trip to Kabal spean.

Beautiful. The carvings at Banteay Srei are unbelievable; carved so deeply with the most incredible detail, they really stand out on a sunny day! It is quite a distance from the main temples at Angkor but well worth the journey. It was unfortunate that the central cluster of temples were closed off to the public when we visited so we couldn't get up close to get detaled photographs.

Temple carvings done by ladies artisan > more intricate details & TLC. We visited this temple on the last day of our 3 days temple. While we were somewhat "exhausted" from visiting all the previous awesome temples like Bayon, Ta Prohm, Banteay Kdei,...somehow, every new temple revitalised us and was not boring at all. As such, Bantaey Srei did not disappoint us at all. Other than the unique pinkish-red sandstone material used in the constructuon of this fabulous temple, the intricate nature of the carving by the tender loving care (TLC) of female artisans certainly differentiated itself from the rest. The relatively "opened feel" of the venue and well-kept modern (recently built?) reception area are great. The rest areas have clean toilets to freshen up (those with temple pass need not pay for entry. The toilet entry charges are for locals who don't need temple pass). There also drinks and refreshment kiosks for thirsty visitors. Worth a visit, definitely ^__^

Small but beutiful and neatly kept.. Smaller but well kept, with more professional/museum like entrance than the other temples, Banteay Srei has some of the finest and best preserved detail in its temple reliefs and carvings. Combining a visit here with a visit to the Land Mine Museum is a good plan to avoid separate trips due to their distance from Siem Reap.
Visit early. Get up and out on the temple run early and you will enjoy the temples much better especially this one

I didn't believe my guide when he told me it was the best carving - he was sooo right!. This was the last temple we went to on our 3rd day of visiting Angkorian temples. I wasn't sure I was going to be impressed. The temple did not let me down - carving was so detailed & because it was a single story structure you can actually see it all. Tons of Hindu stories carved into this temple - make sure you go with a legitimate certified Cambodian tour guide so they can explain all the carvings, so worth the extra $. Also going in a tuk-tuk would be a very dusty experience :( guide w car is awesome!

Small gem. Compared to Angkor and the rest Banteay Srei is small, small temple...as everything small comes with exquisite packaging. From perspective of ornamentation and beauty if hadcraft it is simply the best - you can literally spend hours looking and every detail and aWays find something new and different. Definitelly worth the visit though off the major course and not included in the small track.
Fabulous carvings. One of the best examples here of Angkorian carvings, all so intricately done into pink sandstone.

Excellent temples. It's worth driving out there. The sandstone used to build the temple complex were a different type and color from the ones in Angkor Wat, Bayon, etc. The carvings were very well preserved and details were great.

Beautiful color & well preserved details. The most beautiful colors of all the temples are in this one. This also has some of the best preserved carvings and statues. It takes a while to get here (but great scenery on the way), and most of it is roped off (which is probably best since people can't keep their hands off things). Not very big and can get very crowded - go early.

a delightful temple. i went here 7 years ago and this trip i was stunned at the changes made. a visitor centre and proper shopping area and car park (that locals don't want to use) for big tourist buses. the temple itself is still the prettiest one and exceedingly popular. be prepared for waits. go very early morning or late afternoon is my advice. it's small and the carvings are intricate and the colours of the walls are lovely. don't miss it.

Far away but the first temple. This is the oldest temple in the area built around 9th century.They have done a fantastic job excavating this site. If you go there by sunset you will be all alone (we where) and a couple of dollars to the police who sleep in the temple and they might let you in behind the no entry-zone... But don't touch!

The amazing cravings of the ancient. Worth the 45 minutes tuk tuk ride from Siem Reap. This should be coupled together with Kbal Spean (lingas craving on the riverbed). The cravings are really very detailed and will leave you wondering how on earth did they manage to carve up a whole temple.

Small temple with intricate carvings. The temple’s intricate carvings more than compensate for its small size. Take the time to slowly appreciate the elaborate details of the gopura, sanctuary, walls, enclosures and libraries.

Well worth the extra journey. A much quieter place when we visited with an excellent information gallery. The monument was typically amazing but an added bonus had to be the opportunity for bird watching, especially from the designated areas overlooking the nearby lake.
Beautiful!. I loved this temple !, the intricate work is amazing.. It was not as busy as some of the other , larger temples which made it even more pleasurable to visit it...
Quiet prayers. My daughters and I enjoyed this lovely temple where we got to do a prayer
Banteay Srei - A Beautiful Woman Indeed. This temple was gorgeous. We arrived at a time of day where we saw this temple to all of it's color and splendor. There was nothing to dislike.

Beutiful yes - but the most beautiful parts are not accessable !!. Surely it is the most beautiful temple in Cambodia viewed up close. But the parts one sees in pictures, were not open for viewing. That sucked. We were told by our guide that if we gave the policeman a dollar, he would take our camera into that area and take some pictures. This was disappointing. I wish our hotel had mentioned this to us. But the drive to and fro was quite interesting with rice paddy field views and cambodian villages
10th century Masterpiece. This is also my favorite temple in Siem Reap, a sophisticated masterpiece from the 10th century. Do pay attention to the detailed carvings of the temple

Exquisite !. This is one of the most beautiful temples from the Angkor era. Its the only temple designed and built by women and it shows in the exquisite carvings and reliefs all over.This is a MUST VISIT - even though it takes over 2 hours to get there from Siem Reap
Is well worth the visit. This site is so beautiful. the extra time taken to go there is more than worth it

Beauty of its own. Small, delicate, with own characteristics. Thou the ride was long, you get to see the little villages in action. Because it is small, we cld spend more time appreciating its beauty, unlike other bigge temples.

Nice ride from town and worth the wait. I enjoyed taking my time to walk around and examine the temple and surrounding grounds. I was impressed with the site, not so crazy about some of the new restoration work, looks out of place. On this visit I decided to check out the new market and it was okay; I am glad to see that they built it away from the temple. Worth reading up on the history of this temple devoted to women. I had fun here walking around and viewing the water buffalos in the adjoining fields and also watching fire ants making their busy way ofer some of the temple blocks.

Temple surrounded by lakes. This temple is in need of repair but is still magnificent. It is long with many rooms and has several walls supported by timbers. Again the four faces carved into the gateway are something to see.

Worth the visit. A bit far than the rest of the temples but comfortable in tuktuk at this time of the year at least, it has some of the most beautiful carvings and amazing statues of monkeys, lions, apsaras etcs. The interpretation center is very new and explains everything about the temple (that I miss in the other ones).After visiting it, you can have a relaxing walk around enjoying big trees, birds and breath taking landscapes.
quite far, but worth seeing. it's in the price of the ticket for Angkor, and it's definately a nice diversification from other same-like Angkor Temples
A miniature beauty. The most delicate of the angkor temples..beautiful surroundings
Well preserved/restored site. Very detailed carvings, relatively small area to cover. Best to visit in the early morning or late afternoon to avoid the hot sun as the place has very little shade.

Beautiful, intricate and detailed.. It's a bit of a trek from the main temple site, but it's a lovely tuk-tuk ride through the Cambodian countryside. Banteay Srei is a gorgeous temple with the best stone masonry carving to be found at the Angkor site.
Adventure in Cambodia. David, our personal guide, suggested that we visit Banteay Srei. It was well worth the trip! Enjoy!

Beautiful temple. Banteay Srei was one of my favourite temples, it was a very warm red stone that had been used and the intricately carved detail was astounding. Preferred this to the other bigger temples.

A bit of a drive but worth it for the amazing detail in the carvings.. This was one of the most intricately carved temples we visited. Was much. Smaller than most other temples in the Ankgor area. It's a bit of a drive, which we did in a van with a guide. I really don't believe this would be much fun to ride to in a tuk-tuk. Excellent entrance almost made it feel like entering a Disneyland ride. Be sure to look at the photo display after viewing the temple. They offer a fascinating look at the rediscovery and restoration of the Temple and the audacious story of fake archeologists plundering the site.

Some of the finest craftsmenship of all of the temples. Worth the extra drive to get to Banteay Srei. Our tuk-tuk driver charged us 35US for a round trip where we went as far as Kbal Spean. Probably could've got it for 30US but what the hell. Was a beautiful little temple. Slightly different to angkor wat, the bayon, etc so was a welcome change, although it was still in the same vein.

Great Carvings. This temple is well worth the vist for the great carvings. If you don't vist that early you miss the coach loads of tourists. Still busy but not manic. A good temple to mix with a big circuit tour.

Intriguing and very worthwhile. Not a huge temple but small and surrounded by a moat. Some really gorgeous reliefs and carvings and the jungle setting is quite lovely. Loved the monkey/men statues but wondered why so many right arms were missing from them. It was really quite curious.Really glad I saw this one and in perfect weather as well. Highly recommended for an hour or so. What have you got to lose ?
My prefered place. Authentic but the Tour bus are coming . Good luck to take a picture !!!!

Beautiful little temple. This is a beauty of a small temple. The carvings are so intricate and detailed be sure to take wide angle and close ups. It can get crowded, rather than push through with the people we worked our way around the outside by the wall first. Remember, tour groups come and go on a pretty quick schedule so we waited a bit and by the time we went into the temple most had worked their way though and departed. It is a small temple but the carvings and detail will hold your attention, exquisite. Nice photo op from the wall looking back across the pond at the temple before you leave the complex.

Very nice. I think this was a bit off the track for us but it was worth going. You're not coming back to Cambodia anytime, so go to Bantaey Srei to complete your whole Cambodia temple/archeology tour.
Another world class site in Cambodia. We love the historicity of this site! Make sure you add this to your list of temples to visit.

Hot Lady In Pink. No disrespect by using the word hot as a description, but it was a very, very hot day!!! My trip started with a visit to Kulen Mountain and the River of a Thousand Lingas with a stop at Banteay Srei on the way back to Siem Riep city. Bantey Srei is known by different names such as, the Lady Temple, and the Citadel of Women. The temple is dedicated to the god Shiva and is located about 20 to 25 km from Angkor Wat area. Roads to the temple are in great condition. The temple complex itself is small in comparison to others but the intricate carvings in pink sandstone are absolutely exquisite!!! Don't rush through this temple, take the time to enjoy the beautiful carvings. The oxidation of the sandstone from the rain and mildew gives the temple an amazing color variation. Remember these artisans must have put in many, many hours into this lost art. When taking pictures take some wide angle pics as well as close ups of the carvings you may notice many details you didn't pay attention to before. Best wishes to all on your journeys wherever they may be. As always, I recommend my guide Narin ( angkornarin@yahoo.com ).
go there for the drive. one of the most beautiful drives..stop at Banteay Samre on way back..really worth it
Not worth the long drive. There is a lot more decoration on this temple but the drive to it is vy long, and I didn't really think it was worth the long drive.

THE finest carvings of all temples.. This small temple complex is fabulous and when you are a bit lucky, not very busy as it's about 15km from the major ones. The settings is beautiful too, with rice fields and other greenery surrounding this most precious temple. A very picturesque temple, with human dimensions and carvings like jewelry. Take a side-approach, it will avoid having to wait for people all taking pictures from within the middle corridor of the temple.
Fabulous. This carved temple is the most beautiful of the temples we visited. Another "Must See".

A bijou temple away from the main site. Banteay Srei is a different experience and definitely worth the visit: it is a much smaller (in a way more intimate) temple than the mighty Angkor Wat, but much more delicate and beautiful, almost "bijou": pink sandstone and fine carvings on the walls and lintels make this temple very recognisable. Combine the visit with a trip to Kbal Spean (requires a 1h30 hike in the jungle, so not for everyone) and you will have a great "day out".
the finest of all the temples. but really crowded, roped off , exposed to the sun , worth it all the same

Very special because of the fine art handcraft. We went there with a guided bike tour. Very special along small roads. A long trip (about 30 km) but the visit of Bantea Srei was worth the trip. Nice statues and well kept carvings.

So tangible and beautiful. A beautiful temple on it's own about 16km out of Siem Reap. Such beautiful red coloured stone and I loved the monkey guards - all missing their right arms. A great, tangible, easy to see temple.
same same as Wat angkor. Wonderful to se, take on Camera... but tooooo crowdy. Must see anyway, so...just go for it.
carvings. Full of incredible carvings and inscriptions, this temple is a long way out of town and really needs to be part of a full day itinerary to get good value

Well preserved temple but noisy crowd. Again, the beauty and preservation of carvings in Banteay Srei did not disappoint me once again. Unfortunately in Angkor Wat complex, all temples are filled with throngs of tour groups with guides speaking very loud. It really spoils all serenity of temple visits.

Bantey Srei marvellous. It was my favorite temple, dedicated for the women. the carving is different from other temples. Just be aware that it is a small temple and can be overcrowded with tours very often.I suggest to go there early morning as I did and to leave it when the buses are coming
Beautiful beyond words.. Small temple in the middle of nowhere with the most amazing bas reliefs you would ever find.

Most Beautiful Intricate Carvings. A much smaller temple to the others surounding Angkor Wat, but the carvings are definately ones to see - veryu different to the others. This temple is about 1 hour drive from Siem Reap
Beautiful Carvings. Of all the sites we saw, Banteay Srei contained the most beautiful and intricate carved stone and engravings.
Pink temple. Carvings are all done with women which explains the details. a little far out but worth the ride.

Beautiful, but choked with tourists. Banteay Srei must be seen, unfortunately, it must be seen in short glimpses between busloads of tourists from all corners of the earth. The miniature scale does not permit you to escape tourist congestion, but if you at all have the time go to Banteay Srei.

Beautiful carvings!. One of the best preserved temples in the whole Angkor area and in the pink/red stone looks even more stunning.
A little further away than the main temples,but worth the visit!
a different ruin. Wonderful site and worth visiting. A very large structure and we saw some musicians that were victims of the landmines. Sad to see but at least they are making decent money.

Absolutely worth the rider. Take the time to go to Banteay Srei - this temple is so remarkably preserved, the rose sandstone is so beautiful, and there are fewer tourists than at Angkor Wat! Also, the interpretation center is the best in Angkor.
Off the beaten track. Another temple but in a different style and enjoyed the small museum of the unearthing of the temple
Amazing. Never seen such good carving details before. Not even China. Can't imagine how the people do these so many years ago with great limitation on tools.

very distinct carvings. Banteay Srei is about 30km away from the main complex of Angkor Wat, but the drive is worth it. It's nice to get out of the congestion of big tour buses and crowds and just enjoy a tuk tuk ride thru the beautiful countryside. The temple itself is quite small, but the carvings are very well preserved and the pink sandstone is really pretty.

One of the best preserved.. I think one of the best preserved ones with the best detailed decoratives.The reddish colour of the stone gives it another dimension when you go like we did when the sun is low.The monkey faced sculptures gathered around on the central sanctuary are amazing.But so much more to see that you easliy get lost in time if you want to look at everything for more than just a few seconds......I need to go back there.All is on eye level so even people having difficulty to walk don't need to climb.

Lovin' the Girlie Temple..... This temple is about 45 mins from the Angkor Wat complex but is indeed well worth the trip. Your tuk-tuk driver might ask for a little extra but when you haggle/bargain, make sure that you'd want to go to this place and settle for a fixed price.Banteay Srei is a temple in Cambodia built in honor of female deities, representing strength, unity, and safety. Bantaey Srei happens to the one of the smallest of all the temples but it is indeed the most beautiful, technically and easily my favorite of all the temples that I have visited. The intricate carvings and the story that surrounds the place is just overwhelmingly beautiful. It's the only temple that is happens to be colored in comparison with all the other temples as the structure itself was made from red sandstone which enabled its builders a great medium for the elaborate and decorative wall carvings that will just leave you in awe of the place!

A different scale.... Before going to Banteay Srei, I didn't fully read about the scale of this temple and was very surprised: the doors are about 1m tall and everything is very small. No real explanation (that we found anyway...) but real great fun.

beautiful but crowded. The temple and the carvings are amazing, some of the best preserved in the park. Unfortunately this temple is very much on the tour bus trail and the temple is quite small with just one route you can take around it. This leads to having to complete with huge groups of tour groups to view things and to take pictures at every turn because there is always a new tour group coming through. This was by far the most frustrating experience due to crowds that we had at Angkor. Definitely still worth visiting though, just enter with a lot of patience.
Beautiful. It is a n amazing temple and a little different from the others, which is what makes it unique and worth the trip.
A long trip. A long trip for a temple that is not as impressive as Siem Reap
Shiva meets Buddha. the ancients of the ancients in Siem Riep! Great place to visit on your way to the Bang Melay and the lost temple
beautiful carvings. definitely worth the visit. next time will want to bike all the way up there.

Privately built, if only modern Goverments could build to this standard. The most beautiful temple of any that I have seen so far. Red stone, deep relief carvings and in the most incredibly high state of repair. You would not believe it dates back about 1,000 years. Watch out for the moat, we had to wade across the causeway due to the recent floods and only the week before helicopters had to rescus tourists trapped here by rising flood waters. Again, if there's been heavy rain check with the locals before visiting.
Charming. Simply charming. It is unlike all the magnificent, huge temples but it is pretty and really charming.
Lady Temple - in pink!. This is a little off the beaten track, but worth the travel - some fabulous carvings, incredibly intricate, and in an unusual pinky stone. Beautiful
Must see -take the time!. This Temple is a must see - take the time to make the short trip and enjoy one of the best Temples of Cambodia! Great for photography.

Loved it! Pink and Intricate. This was very different from the other temples and we liked it just as much. The rock has a pink tint and most of the external walls have fallen down so it's wide open and you can see the intricate carvings everywhere. And I mean everywhere! I have never seen anything like this! The only negative thing was the security staff who told us we were VIP and should feel free to scamper over the temple (behind the ropes!!). We didn't think this was right so did not take them up on their offer, and we were disappointed to see other tourists walking over the closed sections. This temple is farther away than the others but well worth the trip. Visit the land mine museum on your way there or back.

charming and worthwhile. The "pink temple" and the "women's temple" should not be overlooked. It was the least damaged of the temples we saw, and the pinkish-colored stone was striking in photos. There were also golden dragonflies buzzing around everywhere, stone monkey guards at the entrances, and local kids swimming in the moat -- all adding further to the charm. Several Cambodians I met said this was their favorite temple.
beautiful temple. We were only in Angkor for one day and had this one on our list - it was beautiful and we were glad we made it! Definitely one of the top in all of Angkor!!
Where all the ladies stay at!. The experience was OK. This was the place where all females back in the old day stay at. Not much beside stone.

Not so impressed with the place. Perhaps I'm just not as attracted to the finer things as the others, but I didn't feel the Banteay Srei compares to its better known cousins, Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, Bayon etc. The place itself is very small, and the motifs carved on the walls are quite similar to those in the other temples. The difference was that you have to travel 37km to see the carvings here, which made it a little off-putting for me. I think though that if you can tell the difference between the carvings and shapes and stuff, and if you want to see one of the oldest temples in Angkor, this is a good place to visit.
Well worth the trip!. Its takes a wee bit of time to get to Banteay Srei from town but it is well worth it. And you get to take in the beautiful countryside.

Beautiful, Intricate Details. Banteay Srei is located out of the Grand+Small Circuit, about 40km away from town. Took a 45-minute tuk tuk ride from Siem Reap town to Banteay Srei. A very relaxing ride, with the pleasant morning breeze; passing through paddy fields and wooden houses villages. Along the way, many buses and private cars with tourists passed by us.Reached Banteay Srei just after 9, and there were already quite a number of tourists. This temple is interestingly on a smaller scale, relative to the other temples in Siem Reap. And upon entering the main temple, the whole area is like glowing in red under the morning sun!The walls are covered with reliefs in fine details which make Banteay Srei one of the most beautiful temples. Add in the many monkey-like and dragon-like sculptures, this temple has somewhat a mystical feeling to it. Very interesting, and well-preserved too.

A real Jewel. It takes more than an hour's drive to go through the 30 kms to banteay Srei. The temple is not a large one, in fact its a tiny set of temples. What is astonishing is the quality of workmanship and delicate nature of the architecture. Banteay Srei means the Citadel of Women, the temple feels as beautiful and delicate as a woman. we did not have this in our plan initially but we got it included. No regrets whatsoever at all. If you can spare some time, please do go and visit.

the best temple. although small, the carvings in this temple is so beautiful,making it the nicest temple we have went so far. Though far from the city, the long travel is worth it once you see those detailed carvings!

Must to VISIT!. Best to go in the morning when its quiet and serene. The colours on the temples are just AMAZING!!!! a MUST to visit! and along the way back, ask your driver/guide to take you to Banteay Samre, it's a smaller version of Angkor Wat, lesser visitors so you'll have the whole place to yourself to breath in the fresh air and it makes for great photography!

Best for Stone Carvings. Although much smaller than the Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom areas, Banteay Srei has better and more detailed stone carvings. The colours are more intense (mainly reds). Part of the fun is the ride out to Banteay Srei where you will pass through several villages, giving a glimpse into real Cambodian life. Stop and sample some of the sugar palm making along the way, there is also some lovely wood carving shops.

Evening Magic. This temple is a standout. Exquisite detail in an exquisite locale.Not to be missed...One of the things i had not expected in my visit to Siem Reap was the gracious parklands which surround all of the temples.If you can find time to allow yourself the luxury of getting off the beaten tourist tramps to just find a corner and sit for a while in nature and history you will be privileged indeed :)

Best of the bunch, don't miss it. The little temple of Banteay Srei should be the highlight of any trip to Siem Reap but it's a bit far and many visitors miss it. Don't be one of them. This Hindu temple, often called the "women's citadel," is memorable because of its small scale, intricate carvings, intact statues and lovely setting off the beaten track. A real gem. To get there, be prepared to pay more; my driver and I agreed on $15 above the standard day rate of $30. Believe me, it was worth it. By the way, I do recommend my driver, Sak, to anyone visiting Siem Reap. His email: asakhappybeer@hotmail.com. His English is very good and he can brief you on the temples, although he can't tour them with you because he's not a licensed guide.
The citadel of women. Such fine carvings are unbelievable, for the age of this 10th. century temple, a must see.
art gallery of Angkor. Hindu temple cut from stone includes some of the finest stone carving seen anywhere on earth. Many carvings three dimentional.

So awesome. Visit Early. Hey if you are going to watch the sunrise over Angkor Wat or Angkor Tom then your next stop should be the banteay Srei. You will have the whole place to yourself or with just 2-4 others. I was able to spend a whole hour wandering the grounds with out a tour group in sight. The security guards let me wander thru the whole complex on a VIP tour. They only asked for a couple bucks. The areas are roped off as the temple is so small too many people will crowd around. As soon as we were driving out around 8 am we passed 3 tour buses. This is the smallest of the major temple complexes. So you will miss the beauty if you go too late! Also early in the morning the touts are not working yet. Also a major bonus as it can get a bit tiresome.

Banteay magic. Of the temples we saw I regard Banteay Srei as my pick, we arrived at 7.30 in the morning and there was very few tourists about its only a small temple compared to others, but its colours and carvings are quite breath taking. Its a nice drive to get there and on the way back we stop at a butterfly farm and also a museum, a fellow has devoted his life to retriving land mines quite an amazing person.

The most beautiful and well-preserved temple! A must see!. Banteay Srei is one of the most beautiful temples I have ever seen. This temple is dubbed the "Ladies Temple", and rightfully so. Built sometime around the second half of the 10th century. You will need at least one hour here, we wish we had spent longer here, as photo opportunities abound. This is one of the best protected temples in the Angkor region. It is about 20km from Siem Reap. This temple is quite small with almost no stairs to climb.This temple is pink, orange and brown. And it is unbelievablly in terrific shape, with the carvings still almost untouched over all these years. The scriptures can still be read, so don't touch them so they are preserved longer.I rate this temple in the top five that we saw in Angkor. I truly love this temple, it is beautiful, unique, well preserved and very cool to see. You will regret if you do not visit here. On the way out you can also stop at the landmine museum, highly recommended to see this also!If I ever get back to Angkor I will surely visit this temple again and spend more time there.

Intricate carvings. The carvings are probably the most impressive of all of the temples and worth the short trip out from the central temple area. That said, the temple is comparatively small, gets quite crowded, and there's not a lot of exploring opportunities that I prefer but I'm glad we went.

The so called "women" temple. This temple is one of the most beautiful temples in Siem Reap. It is well conserved and because of the pink sandstone it is known as the "women temple". It is very small but enormous in beauty of the work in the sandstone.

Best of the temples at Cambodia. This is the best temple site at Cambodia. Its made of pink sandstone and around 40 kms away from Angkor. Take a hotel cab and come all the way to this place. If you want to see the local villages, take the tuk tuk at a bargain. Do not forget to carry your water... there is a lot of walking in Cambodia.This place is much more beautiful than other temples. Look at the intricate carvings. If you are not from India, then take a guide who will explain all the carvings, their meanings and messages. Guides are very helpful here and they are certified to talk to various languages. Each temple entrance here has a uniquie carving related to the Hindu religion. They have a relevance of that place. Broker structures are kept nearby and also replicated. Overall a good experience! Very well maintained...You can also do some shopping outside this site. Remember to bargain. Have coconut water if you are thirsty.... infact, its s must! As long as you buy the USD40 ticket to all temples, you need not buy other entrance tickets for this one.Carry your hat, sunglasses, sunblock, etc.

Ruins in Pink. Amongst all the Temples of Siem Reap, this one boasts Angkor intricacy at its bestThe carvings are out of this world and amazingDown to the detail, the tiny etches, scratches and chips, the details stand outIt's also worth noting that the ruins are pink and sits atop clay groundsThough a little more than half an hour car ride from the other Angkor temples, it's a must-see stopVery nice

Must See. While the trip takes a good 40 minutes, this temple is a must-see. Compared to the temples in the main center, this is small. But it more than makes up for it with the intricate details of its design. This, undoubtedly, is the prettiest of temples in Siem Reap.

Lovely intricate temple but watch out for the crowds!. It is a lovely temple BUT it's not near the Angkor temple complex, it's not near any other attractions - well you can stop by the Land Mine Museum on route but it still is a decent travel. So imagine your irritation when you arrive and there are hordes of people and there's this one little temple and no shade ... The authorities have build quite an impressive facility (by Cambodian standards) next to it - washrooms, huts for souvenirs, food stalls, information boards .... But I think we are there for the temple. So we trudge behind a group, with a group behind us and enter slowly ... Trying not to trod on others and trying to take an unobstructed picture. Meanwhile the sun beat down mercilessly. Do this if you have done the angkor complex. A friend who visited during a lull period really loved it so if younger lucky .....

Don't miss this temple. I can't add much to the other reviews, other than to say it's well with the trip. It can be easily combined with a trip to Kbal Spean, which is only 15 km away. If you had the option of a car over a tuk tuk, definitely take the car. I think the well-preserved nature of the carvings (the pink sandstone is meant to be much harder than other stone used in the Angkor complex), as well as the unique style and detailing, warrant the visit. Don't miss the great interpretation centre here (sign-posted simply as 'Exhibition' before the main path to the temple). It's got excellent information about the design, restoration and statuary of Banteay Srei, as well as information about where some of the key works are. It also has general information about Angkor. (There are some info boards up at the very entrance - this is not the interpretation centre). I thought the centre, apart from really enhancing my visit to the temple, was easily the best of it's kind I'd seen anywhere in Angkor. Hence my rave.

It is far away but don't miss it. Banteay Srei is approximately one hour from Siem Reap by Tuk Tuk but iscertainly worth a day visit. It is like a miniature of the larger temples inAngkor Wat and is full carvings at eye level.....really spectacular! My friendsand I spent the morning there just walking around, relaxing under the trees andreading our guide books to go back now and then to admire the details of everycarving.

A gem among temples. It may be a bit further out compared to the other temples, but it's worth the visit. The complex is among the most well-restored ones among all the temples, and you walk past a beautifully landscaped area on the way to the temple. The actual temple is small, but the detail of the carvings are amazing - the actual stone has a pinkish hue, which adds to the beauty of the delicate carvings on most areas of the temple - the doors, the columns, the roofs. The doors actually get progressively smaller as you walk through the temple!You can even walk around the temple complex to a nearby village and there's a lookout spot to the paddy fields as well.Go that extra mile!

Nice temple, most beautiful carvings. This temple is a little further from Angkor Wat but well worth a visit. The colour of the temple is different from the others, it is more red that the rest of the temples. It has maybe the most beautiful carvings than any of the others in Angkor area.

Great guide for Angkor temples. We just spent 3 days in Angkor area and thoroughly recommend it. Get a guide - they are cheap and they make sure you see everything you can within your time constraints. I can recommend Chhin as a guide well worth taking. His email is chhinangkor@yahoo.com

Temple with the pink stone left me a bit underwhelmed. A day spent exploring and learning about (preferably with a guide for only USD20) Angkor Thom, Angkor Wat, Ta Phrom and Bayon Temple is clearly the number one reason to visit Siem Reap. However, I don't think Banteay Srey compares to any of those temples, and if it weren't for the Cambodian Landmine Museum on the way to Banteay Srey, not to mention seeing the landscape and Cambodian people and how they live during the ride, I'm not sure going to see Banteay Srey by itself was all that spectacular. It was cool to learn about and interesting to see, but my senses had already been overwhelmed with all the other temples the day beforel. Then again, the Landmine Museum shouldn't be missed, and if you're going to ride 30 minutes each way for that, then you might as well go another 15 minutes each way to see Banteay Srey.

Worth the trip. We visited Banteay Srei on the same day as Kbal Spean. It was my favorite temple of all the many we visited in three days around Siem Reap. The red sandstone and moss combine to make the miniaturized temple a pink and green beauty begging for photographs. The detail is well preserved and closer to you (as opposed to tipping your head way back looking up at some of Angkor Wat).It was well worth the trip, even for our temple-fatigued eyes!

Great tour organiser, wonderful guide, what a destination!. We recently had a fabulous holiday in Cambodia, with 3 days in and around Siem Reap. The gorgeous temples of Banteay Srei were easily the highlight of our visit to the region. The beauty and delicacy of the carvings is breathtaking! And the effort it must have taken to create this finely detailed work, which is over 1000 years old, is simply mind-boggling. Our trip was superbly organised by Wide Eyed Tours (www.wideeyedtours.com) who put us in the hands of a friendly guide named Keo Somchhin, with an airconditioned car and driver at our disposal. Usually known as Chhin, our guide proved to be wonderfully well-informed, fluent in English, and arranged a flexible itinerary for us. He can also be contacted directly at chhinangkor@yahoo.com and we would recommend him without hesitation.
Simply Superb. If you had only 1 day in Siem Reap, I'd tell you to visit Banteay Srei and Angkor WatVery well preserved, superb and intricate carvings and probably the jewel of the Angkor temples

A Haunting Beauty All Of Its' Own. Located 37km from Siem Reap & nestled amidst lush green jungle, sits the hauntingly beautiful ruins of Banteay Srey. From the moment you step foot in this temple, you cannot help but be overwhelmed by the extraordinary atmosphere of peace & tranquility which envelops you. Fortunately Banteay Srey remains relatively unspoilt by hoards of tourists, possibly due to its' more remote location. Unpretentious guides offer their services for a personalised tour of the ruins; you find yourself following in anticipation, climbing over sandstone blocks covered with moss, ducking through crumbling doorways to enter shadowed hallways, peering through foliage to find beautiful bas relief images - and the greatest reward of all, seeing the look of sheer happiness on the face of the guide, who has been able to share his culture & history with you.Banteay Srei is spell binding & mystic; transport yourself back in time to imagine how this temple was constructed, envisage temple dancers & an ancient cilvilisation going about their daily chores. Truly an awe inspiring experience not to be missed.

Worth the ride. This temple is about 25 kilometers from Pre Rup and is worth the ride. It's another of the temples at the angkor ruins and one might as well see all that he can see while there. It's the fartherest one out that we visited.

well preserved. Most of the decorative structures were original and very little eroded by the elements. Our guide told us this temple was remarkably preserved as the whole complex was covered by an ant hill when discovered.It's a small by comparison but the quality of the carvings preserved the epic tales very well and allows for as much time if not more time as you would at Bayon or Angkor Wat to figure out all the tales on each wall.Try to go earlier before the day gets hot and when the sunlight is more forgiving for pictures. Try to make this almost your last temple to visit, so that you've heard all the Ramayana mythological tales from the other temples and try to spot them on your own...where's wally (or Sita or Kama or Kala or Siva)?

Ornate Temple in Minature. The best thing about visiting this temple complex is the intricate and ornate carvings. The temple also seems to be in minature it is about 38km from Siem Reap. But the journey by Tuk-Tuk although dusty was an excellent way to see all sorts of Cambodian life close up and we enjoyed the trip immensley.We visited several other temples on the way back

Citadel of Beauty!!. Almost the temples in this country were buit by the king but this temple wes buit by king's counsellors. Routinely described in gushing terms as the "Jewel of Khmer Art", Banteay Srei is nevertheless a temple of great beauty, and compres with little else in Angkor. Is miniature scale almost always surprise visitors, and the near-total decoration of its surfaces is exceptional. So visit Siem Reap visit Banteay Srei.

a little out of the way but worth the effort..... This is another beautifully preserved temple dating to around 967AD The Citadel of Women has intricate carvings that will take your breath away. The ruins are minature compared to Angkor Wat, but this little gem hidden in the jungle about 20 miles from Angkor, is worth the visit.Go first thing in the morning before it is too hot and over run with other tourists. Take some water too. Good footware is helpful but there is minimal climbing here...so mobility constrained individuals will have an easier time of it.And, make a donation to the musicians who play on the edge of the ruins -- they are mine victims who survived the Killing Fields

My favorite temple in Siem Reap. Benteay Srei, Citadel of Women, will remain my favorite in Siem Reap. A temple dedicated to Shiva. It is totally managable as an afternoon excursion because of its intimate size. It has tons of delicate cravings of women sitting on lotus and stories from Ramayana, The lavishly decorated libraries are must-sees. I went in the late afternoon and stayed till about sunset. The sun gave all the cravings a very pleasing glow for picture-taking. Definitely worth the one- hour trip from Siem Reap.
